Source: Recommendation ITU-T V.254 is applicable to the interconnection of multi-functional communication devices (such as mobile phones) with devices intended to provide assistive capabilities for those communication devices. It defines a range of serial binary commands that comply to the format and general rules of Recommendation ITU-T V.250 via a range of suitable interfaces.
Standard: V.254
output: The asynchronous serial command interface defined in ITU-T V.254 is designed for the interconnection of multi-functional communication devices, such as mobile phones, with devices that provide assistive capabilities. It specifies a series of serial binary commands that adhere to the format and general rules of ITU-T V.250, facilitating communication via various suitable interfaces.

instruction: What are the main categories of assistive device commands specified for mobile devices?
output: The main categories of assistive device commands for mobile devices include Calendar, Modify display parameters, Cursor control, Menu, Screen, Speech-to-text, Text telephony, Text-to-speech, Time-out, and Volume control. These categories cover a wide range of functionalities designed to enhance accessibility and usability for users with disabilities.

instruction: What is the purpose of an asynchronous serial command interface in assistive and multi-functional communication devices?
input:
Source: This Recommendation builds upon the current asynchronous DCE control in [ITU-T V.250] to include command protocols that support the interfacing of assistive controlling devices with communication devices over a range of suitable serial binary data interfaces.
Standard: V.254
output: The asynchronous serial command interface is designed to support the interfacing of assistive controlling devices with communication devices across a range of suitable serial binary data interfaces. It extends the capabilities of asynchronous DCE control to include command protocols that facilitate this interaction.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +CCALR command in assistive device communication?
input:
Source: Execute syntax: +CCALR=<begin date>, <end date>  Description: This command causes the read ing of vCalendar information within the parameters specified. The results are the vCale ndar objects between the <begin date> , and <end date> . There can be any number of calendar objects. Defined values: None. Result codes: <vCalendar>,<vCalendar>,<vCalendar>,..,<vCalendar> OK +CCALR ERROR: <error code> Read syntax: Same as the Execute syntax. Test syntax: +CCALR=? If the functionality is supported, the response is <begin date>, <end date>  Implementation: Calendar information is transferred using the vCalendar format.
Standard: V.254
output: The +CCALR command is used to read vCalendar information from a multi-functional communication device within specified date parameters. It retrieves vCalendar objects between a given begin date and end date, with the results returned as a series of vCalendar objects. The command supports execution, reading, and testing syntaxes, with responses indicating success or an error code if the operation fails.

instruction: What is the command syntax for writing vCalendar objects in a communication device?
input:
Source: Execute syntax: +CCALW=<vCalendar> 
Description: The +CCALW  command writes vCalendar objects.  
Defined values: <vCalendar> : vCalendar exchange format. 
Result codes: +CCALW: OK 
+CCALW: ERROR: <error code>
Standard: V.254
output: The command syntax for writing vCalendar objects is +CCALW=<vCalendar>, where <vCalendar> represents the vCalendar exchange format. The command returns result codes such as +CCALW: OK for success or +CCALW: ERROR: <error code> for failure.

instruction: What is the range of values for the red, green, and blue components when setting the background color of a communication device's display?
input:
Source: Defined values: <R>: The value of the colour red, in the range 0..255 <G> : The value of the colour green, in the range 0..255 <B>: The value of the colour blue, in the range 0..255
Standard: V.254
output: The red, green, and blue components each have a range of 0 to 255 when setting the background color of a communication device's display.

instruction: What are the defined values and their meanings for the status parameter in the +CDRG command for pointing device drag operations?
input:
Source: <status>  is an integer value that represents  the status of the drag operation: 0 Start Drag 1 Move Drag 2 Release Drag 9 No Drag (Cancelling of the drag  operation, e.g., by pressing ESC)
Standard: V.254
output: The status parameter in the +CDRG command for pointing device drag operations is an integer value that represents the status of the drag operation. The defined values are: 0 for Start Drag, 1 for Move Drag, 2 for Release Drag, and 9 for No Drag, which cancels the drag operation, for example, by pressing ESC.

instruction: What are the components of an item in a menu notification command for mobile devices?
input:
Source: <item> = <menu item name> ,<me nu item type>,<menu item value> <menu item name> : text string <menu item type> :  0 normal item (in plain text)  1 radio button  2 checkbox  <menu item value> : 0 not ticked  1 ticked NOTE 1 – The <menu item value>  is only relevant when the <menu item type>  is a radio button or checkbox.
Standard: V.254
output: An item in a menu notification command consists of three components: <menu item name>, which is a text string; <menu item type>, which can be 0 for normal item (in plain text), 1 for radio button, or 2 for checkbox; and <menu item value>, which is 0 for not ticked or 1 for ticked. The <menu item value> is only relevant when the <menu item type> is a radio button or checkbox.

instruction: What are the defined values for the <operation> parameter in the +CNMEN command for menu navigation on an external device?
input:
Source: <operation> : 0 back to previous menu (if any) 1 highlight next menu item 2 highlight previous menu item 3 Select/change status of current menu item (e.g., select current menu item or tick checkbox or radio button if not ticked)
Standard: V.254
output: The <operation> parameter in the +CNMEN command has four defined values: 0 for going back to the previous menu (if any), 1 for highlighting the next menu item, 2 for highlighting the previous menu item, and 3 for selecting or changing the status of the current menu item, such as selecting the current menu item or toggling a checkbox or radio button.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +CDMP command in mobile communication devices?
input:
Source: The 'send screen dump' functionality sends the screen dump from the communication device to the external device, which can then be presented in a bigger size. This functionality shall send still pictures, but these could be updated according to the needs of each situation. The external device may chose to update the screen (using +CDMP=) in intervals or according to the user's interactions. The assistive device needs to get information on how many octets it will receive from the mobile device so that it knows when to stop receiving input. The mobile device provides information on the number of octets it will send and sends it in <Number of octets>. The file received shall be in a standardized picture format, such as JPEG, GIF, BMP, PNG.
Standard: V.254
output: The +CDMP command is used to send a screen dump from the communication device to an external device. This functionality allows the external device to display the screen contents in a larger size, which is particularly useful for persons with vision impairments. The command sends still pictures that can be updated as needed, with the mobile device specifying the number of octets to be sent in the <Number of octets> parameter. The received file is in a standardized picture format such as JPEG, GIF, BMP, or PNG.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +CSTXT command in text telephony systems?
input:
Source: Execute syntax: +CSTXT=<destination>, <string>
Description: An application will simulate th e text telephony service from an assistive 
device. It will receiv e text character by character or , alternatively, a string of 
characters using the command +CRTXT . The user can communicate with one 
or more other parties. 
Defined values: <destination> : Contact identifier of  the receiving party. 
<string> : The hexadecimal string represen tation of UTF-8. An example is 
seen in Table 2, where the word 'He llo' is represented with the UTF-8 
hexadecimal string '48656C6C6F'.
Standard: V.254
output: The +CSTXT command in text telephony systems is used to simulate the text telephony service from an assistive device. It allows an application to send text character by character or a complete string of characters to one or more receiving parties. The command requires a destination contact identifier and a hexadecimal string representation of UTF-8 encoded text. For example, the word 'Hello' is represented as '48656C6C6F' in UTF-8 hexadecimal format.

instruction: What are the parameters and their ranges for configuring text-to-speech service using the +CTTS command?
input:
Source: Execute syntax: +CTTS=<state> <speech rate> <spelling speed> <number option> <language> Description: The +CTTS command indicates to the network if the text-to-speech service shall be set up or not (if it is available). Defined values: <state> : 0 Text-to-speech off 1 Text-to-speech on <speech rate> : 0 to N, where N is the number of words per minute. Larger N values indicate increasing speed. Speech rate specifies the speed at which a synthetic voice reads selected text; see [ISO/IEC 24751-2], reading rate . <spelling speed> : 0 to N, where N is the number of characters per minute. A larger N value indicates higher speed.
Standard: V.254
output: The +CTTS command parameters include: <state> with values 0 (off) or 1 (on); <speech rate> ranging from 0 to N words per minute, where higher N indicates faster speed; <spelling speed> ranging from 0 to N characters per minute, with higher N indicating faster speed; <number option> for specifying how numbers larger than four digits are read; and <language> specified using ISO 639-1 and ISO 639-2 codes, indicating the language and country variant (e.g., 'fr-FR' for French in France).

instruction: What are the options for reading numbers longer than four digits in text-to-speech functionality?
input:
Source: <number option> : 0 Single digits. Numbers longer than four digits can be read as single digits. 1 Double digits. Numbers longer than four digits can be read as double digits. 2 Whole numbers. Numbers longer than four digits can be read as whole numbers.
Standard: V.254
output: Numbers longer than four digits can be read in three ways: as single digits (option 0), as double digits (option 1), or as whole numbers (option 2).

instruction: What AT commands are used for managing network configuration in mobile devices?
input:
Source: Network Configuration Manage the selection of, and connection to a mobile network, including identification, closed user groups and multiparty calls. Includes Wireless LAN connection as well as GSM, GPRS, etc. '+WS46', '+CREG', '+COPS', '+CLCK', '+CPWD', '+CLIR', '+COLP', '+CDIP', '+CCUG', '+CCFC', '+CCWA', '+CHLD', '+CTFR', '+CTFR', '+CSSN', '+CLCC', '+CPOL', '+CPLS', '+COPN', '+CAEMLPP', '+CPPS', '+CFCS', '+CAAP', '+CUUS1', '+CSQ', '+CIND', '+CGDCONT', '+CGDSCONT', '+CGTFT', '+CGQREQ', '+CGQMIN', '+CGEQREQ', '+CGEQMIN', '+CGEQNEG', '+CGATT', '+CGACT', '+CGCMOD', '+CGDATA', '+CGCLOSP' (Obsolete), '+CGPADDR', '+CGAUTO', '+CGANS', '+CGCLASS' (GPRS only), '+CGCLPAD' (GPRS only), '+CGEREP', '+CGREG', '+CGSMS'
Standard: V.254
output: The AT commands for managing network configuration in mobile devices include '+WS46', '+CREG', '+COPS', '+CLCK', '+CPWD', '+CLIR', '+COLP', '+CDIP', '+CCUG', '+CCFC', '+CCWA', '+CHLD', '+CTFR', '+CSSN', '+CLCC', '+CPOL', '+CPLS', '+COPN', '+CAEMLPP', '+CPPS', '+CFCS', '+CAAP', '+CUUS1', '+CSQ', '+CIND', '+CGDCONT', '+CGDSCONT', '+CGTFT', '+CGQREQ', '+CGQMIN', '+CGEQREQ', '+CGEQMIN', '+CGEQNEG', '+CGATT', '+CGACT', '+CGCMOD', '+CGDATA', '+CGPADDR', '+CGAUTO', '+CGANS', '+CGCLASS' (GPRS only), '+CGCLPAD' (GPRS only), '+CGEREP', '+CGREG', '+CGSMS'. These commands cover selection and connection to a mobile network, including identification, closed user groups, multiparty calls, and Wireless LAN connections.

instruction: What is the purpose of procedures defined for equipment interconnecting GSTN networks with IP networks?
input:
Source: Recommendation ITU-T V .152 defines procedures for equi pment that interconnect GSTN networks with IP networks to provide satisfact ory, transparent delivery of modulated voice-band data (VBD) as encoded audio content over IP (data modems, facsimile terminals and text telephones).
Standard: V.152
output: The purpose is to ensure satisfactory, transparent delivery of modulated voice-band data (VBD) as encoded audio content over IP networks. This includes support for data modems, facsimile terminals, and text telephones, maintaining high quality of service for voice and voice-band data services carried over IP.

instruction: What are the minimum requirements for the Voice Band Data (VBD) mode of operation?
input:
Source: 6.1 Minimum requirements for VBD mode of operation
Standard: V.152
output: The minimum requirements for the Voice Band Data (VBD) mode of operation include the ability to support the transport of voice band data signals over IP networks without significant degradation. This involves ensuring compatibility with existing voice band data equipment, maintaining signal integrity, and supporting the necessary bandwidth for data transmission. Additionally, the system must handle the transition between voice and data modes seamlessly, including the negotiation of codecs and other enhanced functionalities specific to VBD operations.

instruction: What is the purpose of using ITU-T preamble in an ITU-T gateway?
input:
Source: Annex C – Use of ITU-T V.21 preamble for echo canceller control in an ITU-T V.152 gateway
Standard: V.152
output: The ITU-T V.21 preamble is used in an ITU-T V.152 gateway for echo canceller control. This allows the gateway to manage echo cancellation effectively during the transmission of signals, ensuring clear communication by reducing echo interference.

instruction: What is the purpose of voice-band data (VBD) operation in VoIP gateways?
input:
Source: This Recommendation describes the voice-band data (VBD) operation of Voice-over-Internet Protocol (VoIP) gateways and media gateways. The term 'VBD' refers only to the use of suitable voice-band codecs for the transport of data payloads via RTP.
Standard: V.152
output: The purpose of voice-band data (VBD) operation in VoIP gateways is to transport data payloads over IP networks using suitable voice-band codecs via RTP. This allows for the transmission of data in a format that is compatible with voice-band frequencies, enabling the integration of data services within VoIP sessions without excluding other capabilities such as audio signal transport, facsimile relay, modem relay, and text relay.

instruction: What is the function of a media gateway in network communications?
input:
Source: The media gateway converts media provided in one type of network to the format required in anothe r type of network. For example,  a MG could terminate bearer channels from a switched circui t network (e.g., DS0s) and media streams from a packet network (e.g., RTP streams in an IP network). This gatewa y may be capable of processing audio, video and ITU-T T.120 multimedia signals alone or in any co mbination, and will be capable of full duplex media translations. The MG may also play audi o/video messages and performs other interactive voice response (IVR) functions, or may perform media conferencing. For the purpose of this Recommendation, the term media gate way refers to a voice gateway.
Standard: V.152
output: A media gateway converts media from one type of network to the format required by another type of network. For example, it can terminate bearer channels from a switched circuit network (e.g., DS0s) and media streams from a packet network (e.g., RTP streams in an IP network). It is capable of processing audio, video, and ITU-T T.120 multimedia signals, either alone or in any combination, and performs full duplex media translations. Additionally, it may play audio/video messages, perform interactive voice response (IVR) functions, or handle media conferencing.

instruction: What is transcoding in the context of media formats?
input:
Source: Translation from one type of encoded media format to another different media format (examples: ITU-T G.711 A-law to μ-law or vice versa, ITU-T G.711 codec to ITU-T G.726-40K, ITU-T G.711 to a broadband codec that operates at 256 kbit/s, etc.).
Standard: V.152
output: Transcoding refers to the process of converting media from one encoded format to another. Examples include converting between ITU-T G.711 A-law and μ-law, from ITU-T G.711 codec to ITU-T G.726-40K, or from ITU-T G.711 to a broadband codec operating at 256 kbit/s.

instruction: What are the two models for the session description protocol concerning the indication and negotiation of media and transport capabilities?
input:
Source: This Recommendation provides example signalling syntax. There are two models for the session description protocol (SDP) concerning the indication and negotiation of media and transport capabilities:
Standard: V.152
output: The two models for the session description protocol (SDP) concerning the indication and negotiation of media and transport capabilities are the SDP Offer/Answer protocol variants. These models facilitate the negotiation of media and transport capabilities between communicating parties.

instruction: What are the key requirements for a system operating in Voice-band Data (VBD) mode?
input:
Source: For voice-band data (VBD) mode of operation, a ll voice-band modulated si gnal samples shall be transported across an IP network using the RTP protocol defined in [IETF RFC 3550]. When in VBD mode, an ITU-T V.152 compliant implementation shall: – use a codec that passes voice- band modulated signals with mi nimal distortion. This codec shall be assigned as the VBD codec with a specific RTP payload type which shall be negotiated with the remote ITU-T V.152 impl ementations as descri bed in clause 7; – have end-to-end constant latency; – disable voice activity detection and comfort noi se generation during the data transfer phase; – disable any DC removal filters that may be integral with the speech encoder used; and should consider the a ppropriate application of: – forward error correction (FEC) (e.g., [I ETF RFC 5109]) or other forms of redundancy (e.g., [IETF RFC 2198]) only if support has been successfully negotiate d with the remote ITU-T V.152 implementation; – voice packet loss concealment techniques and algorithms that are suitable for modem and facsimile modulations.
Standard: V.152
output: In Voice-band Data (VBD) mode, a system must transport voice-band modulated signal samples across an IP network using the RTP protocol. It must use a codec that minimally distorts voice-band modulated signals, assigned with a specific RTP payload type negotiated with remote implementations. The system must ensure end-to-end constant latency, disable voice activity detection and comfort noise generation during data transfer, and disable any DC removal filters integral to the speech encoder. Additionally, it should consider applying forward error correction (FEC) or redundancy if negotiated, and use suitable voice packet loss concealment techniques for modem and facsimile modulations.

instruction: What are the characteristics of non-assured VBD transport service?
input:
Source: The non-assured VBD transport service is defined by the mandatory capabilities of ITU-T V.152, i.e., according to clause 6.1, – without RTP transport redundancy ( according to [IETF RFC 2198]); and – without forward error correction of RTP packets (accordi ng to [IETF RFC 5109]). The non-assured VBD mode should be sufficient in case of 'good' IP network conditions. The non-assured VBD mode may be operated in two sub-modes with re spect to the transfer of inband signals, see the following subclauses.
Standard: V.152
output: The non-assured VBD transport service is characterized by mandatory capabilities that exclude RTP transport redundancy and forward error correction of RTP packets. It operates without RTP payload format for telephony events and is considered sufficient under 'good' IP network conditions. This service can operate in two sub-modes regarding the transfer of inband signals.

instruction: What is the purpose of the 'gpmd' attribute in SDP when negotiating VBD mode?
input:
Source: The general form of this attribute line is: 

a=gpmd:<format> <parameter list>
In the context of VBD declaration, the <format> must be an RTP/AVP payload type. The <parameter list> is a semicolon-separated list of 'parameter=value' pairs. For RTP/AVP formats, these pairs address parameters that are not part of their standard MIME definition. For sessions supporting this Recommendation, the parameter of interest is the Boolean 'vbd' that may have the value of 'yes' or 'no'. When set to 'yes', the attribute indicates that the implementation supports VBD mode as described in this Recommendation.
Standard: V.152
output: The 'gpmd' (general-purpose media descriptor) attribute in SDP is used to associate payload types in a media information ('m') line with VBD (Voice-Band Data) mode. It indicates whether an implementation supports VBD mode by including a Boolean 'vbd' parameter that can be set to 'yes' or 'no'. Setting 'vbd=yes' explicitly supports VBD mode, while 'vbd=no' indicates the payload type will not be used for VBD. Omission of the 'gpmd' attribute with 'vbd=yes' is interpreted as non-support of VBD mode.

instruction: What does the 'maxmptime' attribute indicate in an SDP session description?
input:
Source: When receiving an SDP session description, the maxm ptime attribute conveys the list of maximum packetization periods that the remote endpoint is capable of using for this connection; one for each media format in the 'm=' line. For media formats whose packetization period is specified as a hyphen ('-'), the VBD gateway shall use one of the maximum packetization periods that was actually specified in the list.
Standard: V.152
output: The 'maxmptime' attribute in an SDP session description conveys a list of maximum packetization periods that the remote endpoint is capable of using for the connection, with one period specified for each media format in the 'm=' line. For media formats where a single maximum packetization rate does not apply, such as non-voice codecs, a hyphen ('-') is included in the list at the corresponding location.

instruction: What are the session configurations for combining audio and VBD modes in SDP offers?
input:
Source: Offered (4) session configurations: • Preference 1: Audio (ITU-T G.729), VBD (ITU-T V.152 PCMU) & NTE ([IETF RFC 4733]) • Preference 2: Audio (ITU-T G.729), VBD (ITU-T V.152 G.726-32) & NTE ([IETF RFC 4733]) • Preference 3: Audio (PCMU including silence suppression), VBD (ITU-T V.152 PCMU) & NTE ([IETF RFC 4733]) • Preference 4: Audio (PCMU including silence suppression), VBD (ITU-T V.152 G.726-32) & NTE ([IETF RFC 4733])
Standard: V.152
output: The session configurations for combining audio and VBD (Voice Band Data) modes in SDP offers include four preferences: 1) Audio using G.729 codec with VBD using V.152 PCMU and NTE, 2) Audio using G.729 codec with VBD using V.152 G.726-32 and NTE, 3) Audio using PCMU including silence suppression with VBD using V.152 PCMU and NTE, and 4) Audio using PCMU including silence suppression with VBD using V.152 G.726-32 and NTE. These configurations allow for individual packetization times, avoiding the need for the 'a=maxmptime' parameter.

instruction: What are the main advantages of Revised SDP Offer/Answer syntax over Legacy SDP Offer/Answer?
input:
Source: The following main advantages may be noted concerning Revised versus Legacy SDP Offer/Answer: – the ITU-T V.152 introduced SDP attribute ' a=maxmptime: ' may be replaced by IETF SDP elements; – there is an explicit indicated, preferred order with regard to the offered media configurations (this is missing in Legacy SD P Offer/Answer: it is unclear, e.g., whether configuration 2 is pref erred over configuration 3 or vice versa); and – the answerer in Legacy SDP Offer/Answer c ould select both audio c odecs and/or both VBD codecs (which may require subs equent Offer/Answer cycles).
Standard: V.152
output: The main advantages include: the replacement of the ITU-T V.152 introduced SDP attribute 'a=maxmptime:' by IETF SDP elements, explicit indication of a preferred order for offered media configurations which is missing in Legacy SDP Offer/Answer, and the prevention of the answerer selecting both audio codecs and/or both VBD codecs in Legacy SDP Offer/Answer which may require subsequent Offer/Answer cycles.

instruction: What are the potential issues with using static payload types for Voice Band Data (VBD) in SDP Offer/Answer protocol?
input:
Source: The use of static payload types for VBD is strongly discouraged because there is a danger that a non-ITU-T V.152 system would see a proposal with, say, [ITU-T G.711] VBD and [ITU-T G.729]. However, not understanding the VBD attributes, it may consider ITU-T G.711 as a valid audio codec. However, network operators may prefer that [ITU-T G.711] not be utilized, except in the case where VBD is necessary, and that all voice shall be [ITU-T G.729]. To illustrate this point, consider this offer: m=audio 15400 RTP/AVP 0 18 a=gpmd:0 vbd=yes and consider this answer: m=audio 15400 RTP/AVP 0 18 The systems would then, most likely, communicate using [ITU-T G.711], rather than the intended [ITU-T G.729], for voice. This is a possible issue and inherent to Legacy SDP Offer/Answer protocol. This problem may be avoided by explicit potential configuration in Revised SDP Offer/Answer, see Table 4.
Standard: V.152
output: Using static payload types for Voice Band Data (VBD) in SDP Offer/Answer protocol can lead to misinterpretation by non-ITU-T V.152 systems. Such systems might incorrectly interpret a proposal combining ITU-T G.711 for VBD and ITU-T G.729 for voice, considering ITU-T G.711 as a valid audio codec for voice instead of ITU-T G.729. This misinterpretation can result in the systems communicating using ITU-T G.711 for voice, contrary to the intended ITU-T G.729, due to the inherent limitations of the Legacy SDP Offer/Answer protocol.

instruction: What are the audio and VBD codec types listed in the example SDP encoding for potential configurations?
input:
Source: a=mcap:1 G729/8000      ; audio codec  a=mcap:2 PCMU/8000      ; VBD codec 1 a=mcap:3 G726-32/8000   ; VBD codec 2
Standard: V.152
output: The audio codec type listed is G.729/8000. The VBD codec types listed are PCMU/8000 (VBD codec 1) and G726-32/8000 (VBD codec 2).

instruction: What are the parameters included in the LocalControl and Local sections of an ITU-T H.248 encoding for audio and VBD?
input:
Source: Mode = RecOnly, ReserveGroup = ON, ReserveValue = ON }, Local { v=0 c=IN IP4 $ m=audio $ RTP/AVP 18 0 98 99 a=rtpmap:98 PCMU/8000 a=gpmd:98 vbd=yes a=rtpmap:99 G726-32/8000 a=gpmd:99 vbd=yes }; IP termination for audio and VBD } } } }
Standard: V.152
output: The LocalControl section includes Mode set to RecOnly, ReserveGroup set to ON, and ReserveValue set to ON. The Local section includes the SDP parameters: v=0, c=IN IP4 with an IP address placeholder, m=audio with a port placeholder and RTP/AVP payload types 18, 0, 98, 99, a=rtpmap for payload types 98 (PCMU/8000) and 99 (G726-32/8000), and a=gpmd for both payload types indicating vbd=yes.

instruction: What is the purpose of the wildcard CHOOSE ('$') in H.248 text encoding?
input:
Source: The MGC applies the wildcard CHOOSE ('$') in the media description: • the wildcard is in the format list (see also clause 6.11 of [ITU-T H.248.39]); • such an underspecification implies 'a priori knowledge' at the MG side, in order to choose an 'appropriate' media format; • e.g., it is expected that the MG selects a VBDoIP format, but not anything else (like, e.g., another audio codec type); • such kind of behaviour is either under the responsibility of the network management or could be defined in an ITU-T H.248 profile specification.
Standard: V.152
output: The wildcard CHOOSE ('$') in H.248 text encoding is used to allow the Media Gateway (MG) to select an appropriate media format based on its 'a priori knowledge'. This underspecification implies that the MG has the responsibility to choose a suitable format, such as a VBDoIP format, without the Media Gateway Controller (MGC) explicitly specifying it. This behavior is typically under the network management's responsibility or defined in an H.248 profile specification.

instruction: What is the purpose of the 'pmft' attribute in SDP session descriptions?
input:
Source: The 'pmft' attribute and its formatting in the SDP session description is described by the following ABNF syntax: pmft-attribute = "a=pmft:" *(SPACE modem-fax-transport) modem-fax-transport = 1* ("V1501" / "T38" / "V151") This attribute allows an ITU-T V.152 implementation to indicate whether it prefers any of the listed relay transport mechanism above the VBD mode. Omission of this attribute in an SDP session description means that VBD mode is the preferred transport mechanism of voice-band data.
Standard: V.152
output: The 'pmft' attribute in SDP session descriptions is used to indicate a preference list of modem and facsimile transport methods over VBD (Voice Band Data) mode. It allows an implementation to specify preferred relay transport mechanisms such as T.38 for facsimile relay, V.150.1 for modem relay, or text relay, instead of defaulting to VBD. The attribute is formatted as 'a=pmft:' followed by the preferred transport methods, and it must be placed at the session level in the SDP description.

instruction: What are the key components of an SDP offer/answer exchange for VoIP and FoIP configurations?
input:
Source: v=0 o=Offerer  0 0 IN IPV4 <IPAddressA> s=- t=0 0 p=+1 965 1109-1965 c=IN IP4  <IPAddressA> a=group:FID 1 2 m=audio <udpPort x> RTP/AVP 18 0 13 96 a=mid:1 a=ptime:10 a=rtpmap:96 PCMU/8000 a=gpmd: 96 vbd=yes m=image <udpPort y> udptl t38 a=mid:2 a=T38version:0 a=T38FaxRateManagement:transferredTCF  a=T38FaxUdpEC:t38UDPRedundancy
Standard: V.152
output: The key components of an SDP offer/answer exchange for VoIP and FoIP configurations include the session description protocol (SDP) version (v=0), origin (o=), session name (s=-), timing (t=0 0), connection information (c=), and media descriptions (m=). For VoIP, the media description specifies the audio codecs (e.g., RTP/AVP 18 0 13 96) and attributes like payload type (a=rtpmap), packet time (a=ptime), and generic parameters (a=gpmd). For FoIP, the media description specifies the image transmission protocol (udptl t38) and T.38-specific attributes like version (a=T38version), fax rate management (a=T38FaxRateManagement), and error correction (a=T38FaxUdpEC). The exchange also includes grouping attributes (a=group:FID) to associate media streams and optional attributes like preferred media for fax transmission (a=pmft).

instruction: What are the four possible media configurations for transporting G3FE data and other modems in a VoIP application?
input:
Source: Figure 3 illustrates the four possible media configurations, offered in this example, and positively acknowledged by the answerer. The offerer gateway, on receipt of such an answer, shall transport G3FE data using ITU-T T.38, i.e., potential configuration 3 or 4) and all other modems, or non- G3FE must be transported via ITU-T V.152 (i.e., potential configuration 1 or 2).
Standard: V.152
output: The four possible media configurations are: 1) VoIP using G.729 codec with VBDoIP via V.152 (G.711), 2) VoIP using G.711 codec with VBDoIP via V.152 (G.711), 3) VoIP using G.729 codec with FoIP via T.38 UDPTL/UDP, and 4) VoIP using G.711 codec with FoIP via T.38 UDPTL/UDP. G3FE data is transported using ITU-T T.38 (configurations 3 or 4), while all other modems or non-G3FE must be transported via ITU-T V.152 (configurations 1 or 2).

instruction: What are the audio codecs and VBD codec used in the SDP session description for ITU-T support?
input:
Source: a=mcap:1 G729/8000    ; audio codec 1 
a=mcap:2,4 PCMU/8000  ; audio codec 2 and 
VBD codec 
a=mcap:3 CN/8000      ; comfort noise for 
audio c. 2 
a=mscap:4 gpmd vbd=yes  ; for V.152 PCMU
Standard: V.152
output: The SDP session description for ITU-T V.152 support includes audio codecs G.729/8000 and PCMU/8000, and a VBD codec using PCMU/8000 with dynamic payload type 96. Comfort noise for audio is provided by CN/8000.

instruction: What does the SDP payload type 96 indicate in the context of ITU-T implementations?
input:
Source: An ITU-T V.152 implementation that receives an SDP session description, as in the above example, shall interpret it as the remote gateway's capability to support ITU-T V.152 and that the payload type that shall be used for VBD packets is 96.
Standard: V.152
output: In the context of ITU-T V.152 implementations, the SDP payload type 96 indicates that the remote gateway has the capability to support ITU-T V.152 and specifies that payload type 96 shall be used for Voice Band Data (VBD) packets. This is typically associated with the encoding 'PCMU/8000' for audio data.

instruction: What are the audio and VBD codecs listed in the SDP encoding example for VoIP and VBDoIP configurations?
input:
Source: m=audio <udpPort A> RTP/AVP 18 0 13 96 a=ptime:10 a=rtpmap:96 PCMU/8000 a=gpmd: 96 vbd=yes ; ; POTENTIAL CONFIGURATIONs a=tcap:1 RTP/AVP ; transport for VoIP and VBDoIP a=acap:1 ptime:10 ; common packetization time a=mcap:1 G729/8000 ; audio codec 1 a=mcap:2,4 PCMU/8000 ; audio codec 2 and VBD codec 1 a=mcap:3 CN/8000 ; comfort noise for audio c. 2 a=mscap:4 gpmd vbd=yes ; for V.152 PCMU a=pcfg:1 t=1 a=-ms:1 m=1,4 pt=1:18,4:96 a=pcfg:2 t=1 a=-ms:1 m=2,3,4 pt=1:0,3:13,4:96
Standard: V.152
output: The SDP encoding example lists the following codecs for VoIP and VBDoIP configurations: For audio, G.729/8000 and PCMU/8000 are specified, with PCMU/8000 also serving as a VBD codec when accompanied by the gpmd attribute indicating vbd=yes. Additionally, CN/8000 is listed for comfort noise generation. The configurations show preference for G.729 with V.152 PCMU as the primary setup, and PCMU with silence suppression and V.152 PCMU as an alternative.

instruction: What are the key components of an SDP offer for establishing a communication session between two gateways?
input:
Source: v=0 o=GatewayA  0 0 IN IPV4 <IPAddressA> 
s=- 
t=0 0 p=+1 c=IN IP4  <IPAddressA> a=group:FID 1 2 m=audio <udpPort x> RTP/AVP 18 0 13 96 a=mid:1 a=ptime:10 
a=rtpmap:96 PCMU/8000 
a=gpmd: 96 vbd=yes m=image <udpPort y> udptl t38 a=mid:2 a=T38version:0 a=T38FaxRateManagement:transferredTCF  a=T38FaxUdpEC:t38UDPRedundancy
Standard: V.152
output: The key components of an SDP offer include the version (v=0), origin (o=), session name (s=), timing (t=), connection information (c=), and media descriptions (m=). For audio, it specifies the UDP port, RTP profile (RTP/AVP), payload types (e.g., 18, 0, 13, 96), and attributes like mid (media identification), ptime (packet time), rtpmap (RTP payload mapping), and gpmd (generic parameter media description). For image (fax), it includes the UDP port, protocol (udptl), and T.38 fax attributes like T38version, T38FaxRateManagement, and T38FaxUdpEC.

instruction: What are the four potential session configurations offered in the example SDP encoding for VoIP and FoIP?
input:
Source: 1) OFFER: ; SESSION CONFIGURATIONs  a=sescap:1 1    ; VoIP = G.729, VBDoIP = V.152 (G.711) a=sescap:2 2    ; VoIP = G.711, VBDoIP = V.152 (G.711) a=sescap:3 3,5  ; VoIP = G.729, FoIP = T.38 UDPTL/UDP a=sescap:4 4,5  ; VoIP = G.711, FoIP = T.38 UDPTL/UDP
Standard: V.152
output: The four potential session configurations offered are: 1) VoIP using G.729 codec and VBDoIP using V.152 (G.711), 2) VoIP using G.711 codec and VBDoIP using V.152 (G.711), 3) VoIP using G.729 codec and FoIP using T.38 UDPTL/UDP, and 4) VoIP using G.711 codec and FoIP using T.38 UDPTL/UDP.

instruction: What are the audio codecs listed in the SDP encoding example for VoIP and VBDoIP?
input:
Source: a=mcap:1 G729/8000    ; audio codec 1 
a=mcap:2,4 PCMU/8000  ; audio codec 2 and 
VBD codec 
a=mcap:3 CN/8000      ; comfort noise for 
audio c. 2
Standard: V.152
output: The audio codecs listed are G729/8000 as audio codec 1, PCMU/8000 as audio codec 2 and VBD codec, and CN/8000 as comfort noise for audio codec 2.

instruction: What are the key components of an SDP offer and answer in a VoIP gateway communication?
input:
Source: SDP encoding (shortened SD P description) Comments 
1) OFFER: 
SDP from Gateway A: v=0 
o=Gateway A 25678 753849 IN IP4 128.96.41.1 
s= c=IN IP4 128.96.41.1 t=0 0 m=audio 49230 RTP/AVP 0 8 18 97 98  a=gpmd:0 vbd=yes a=gpmd:8 vbd=yes a=rtpmap:97 telephone-event/8000 
a=fmtp:97 0-15,32,33,34,35,66,70 
a=rtpmap:98 v150fw/8000 m=audio 49232 udpsprt 100 a=sprtmap:100 v150mr/8000  
a=fmtp:100 mr=0; 
mg=1;DSCselect=3;mrmods=1,2;jmdelay=no;versn
=1.1  
2) ANSWER: 
v=0 
o=GatewayB 25678 753849 IN IP4 128.96.41.1 s= c=IN IP4 128.96.41.1 t=0 0 m=audio 49230 RTP/AVP 0 8 18 97 98  
a=gpmd:0 vbd=yes 
a=gpmd:8 vbd=yes a=rtpmap:97 telephone-event/8000 a=fmtp:97 0-15,32,33,34,35,66,70 a=rtpmap:98 v150fw/8000 m=audio 49232 udpsprt 100 a=sprtmap:100 v150mr/8000  
a=fmtp:100 mr=0; 
mg=1;DSCselect=3;mrmods=1,2;jmdelay=no;versn
=1.1
Standard: V.152
output: The key components of an SDP offer and answer in a VoIP gateway communication include the version (v=0), origin (o=), session name (s=), connection information (c=), timing (t=0 0), and media descriptions (m=). Media descriptions specify the media type (e.g., audio), port number, transport protocol (e.g., RTP/AVP), and payload types. Attributes (a=) provide additional details such as generic packetized media descriptions (gpmd), real-time transport protocol maps (rtpmap), and format parameters (fmtp). These components are used to negotiate capabilities and parameters between gateways.

instruction: What are the audio and VBD codecs used in Preference 1 session configuration?
input:
Source: Preference 1: Audio (ITU-T G.729), VBD (ITU-T V.152 PCMU)
Standard: V.152
output: The audio codec used is G.729, and the VBD codec is V.152 PCMU.

instruction: What is the purpose of the 'a=mscap:2,3 gpmd vbd=yes' line in SDP encoding?
input:
Source: a=mscap:2,3 gpmd vbd=yes  ; for V.152 PCMU & PCMA
Standard: V.152
output: The 'a=mscap:2,3 gpmd vbd=yes' line in SDP encoding indicates the support for V.152 PCMU and PCMA codecs in Voice Band Data (VBD) mode. The 'mscap' attribute specifies media stream capabilities, with '2,3' representing the payload types for PCMU and PCMA respectively, and 'vbd=yes' signaling that VBD mode is enabled for these codecs.

instruction: What are the components of a potential media configuration in SDP for VoIP and VBDoIP?
input:
Source: a=tcap:1 RTP/AVP  ; transport for VoIP & VBDoIP a=mcap:1 G728/8000    ; audio codec a=mcap:2 PCMU/8000    ; VBD codec a=mcap:3 RED/8000     ; RTP RFC 2198 redundancy a=mfcap:3 %2%/%2%/%2%/%2% ; RFC 2198 redundancy format a=mscap:2 gpmd vbd=yes  ; for V.152 PCMU a=pcfg:1 t=1 a=-ms m=2,1,3 pt=2:0,1:15,3:102
Standard: V.152
output: A potential media configuration in SDP for VoIP and VBDoIP includes transport capabilities, media codecs, and redundancy formats. Specifically, it comprises transport capability for VoIP and VBDoIP (RTP/AVP), audio codecs such as G728/8000, VBD codecs like PCMU/8000 with packet redundancy, and RTP RFC 2198 redundancy formats. Additionally, it may include media format capabilities for V.152 PCMU with specific attributes like 'gpmd vbd=yes' and configuration preferences for audio and VBD with packet redundancy.

instruction: What are the components of an SDP offer for audio media configuration using RTP/AVP with payload types 0, 15, and 78?
input:
Source: c=IN IP4 224.2.17.12 t=0 0 m=audio 49170 RTP/AVP 0 15 78 a=gpmd:0 vbd=yes a=rtpmap:78 parityfec/8000 a=fmtp:78 49170 IN IP4 224.2.17.12
Standard: V.152
output: The SDP offer for audio media configuration using RTP/AVP includes the following components: the connection line 'c=IN IP4 224.2.17.12' specifies the IP address for the session; the timing line 't=0 0' indicates the session is not bounded by time; the media line 'm=audio 49170 RTP/AVP 0 15 78' defines the media type as audio, the port number as 49170, the protocol as RTP/AVP, and the payload types as 0 (PCMU), 15 (G728), and 78 (parityfec). Attributes include 'a=gpmd:0 vbd=yes' indicating voice band data support for payload type 0, 'a=rtpmap:78 parityfec/8000' mapping payload type 78 to parity forward error correction at 8000 Hz, and 'a=fmtp:78 49170 IN IP4 224.2.17.12' providing format parameters for payload type 78.

instruction: What are the defined values for the <vendorIDformat> in the 'vndpar' attribute line format?
input:
Source: Integer representation Vendor ID format 
1 [ITU-T T.35] 
2 IANA Private enterprise number
Standard: V.152
output: The <vendorIDformat> in the 'vndpar' attribute line format has two defined values: 1 for ITU-T T.35 format and 2 for IANA Private enterprise number.

instruction: What is the purpose of the VBDCapability in ITU-T H.323 systems?
input:
Source: ITU-T H.323 systems support ITU-T V.152 through the use of the VBDCapability capability defined in [ITU-T H.245]. This capability, which is a type of AudioCapability, is used during capability exchange and in the open logical channel (OLC) signalling to indicate support for VBD channels and to signal the opening of those channels.
Standard: V.152
output: The VBDCapability in ITU-T H.323 systems is used during capability exchange and in the open logical channel (OLC) signalling to indicate support for Voice-Band Data (VBD) channels and to signal the opening of those channels. It is a type of AudioCapability that allows devices to specify their support for VBD by including these capabilities in the TerminalCapabilitySet message. This facilitates the switching of VBD media flows within a single RTP session alongside normal voice audio and other audio-related media.

instruction: What happens when two ITU-T H.323 devices propose incompatible sets of capabilities during logical channel signalling?
input:
Source: Since ITU-T H.323 devices operate asynchronously, it is possible that one device may transmit an OLC message offering one set of capabilities, while the peer device transmits an OLC with an incompatible set of capabilities. For example, one device may propose an OLC that suggests the use of {G.729, VBD/G.711, T.38} while the peer device sends an OLC which suggests the use of {G.723.1, VBD/G.726}. Of course, both messages should be independently legal based on the exchanged capabilities. While [ITU-T H.323] permits devices to use different audio codecs in each direction, it may not be preferred. In this case, the fact that one side proposes to use T.38 over RTP and the other side does not is a problem. In all such cases, [ITU-T H.323] specifies that the master shall resolve such conflicts by rejecting the OLC with a reason of masterSlaveConflict or other appropriate reason. Devices should not fail as a result, but should converge to a common mode. Devices should utilize the request mode message in [ITU-T H.245] in order to suggest a compatible mode of operation. Either the master or the slave device may transmit a request mode message. Note, however, that the request may be rejected. Ultimately, the slave device may have no choice, except to use the preferred mode of the master. Even so, the master should honour requests from the slave device when possible.
Standard: V.152
output: When two ITU-T H.323 devices propose incompatible sets of capabilities during logical channel signalling, the master device resolves the conflict by rejecting the Open Logical Channel (OLC) message with a reason of masterSlaveConflict or another appropriate reason. Devices should not fail as a result but should converge to a common mode of operation. They may use the request mode message from ITU-T H.245 to suggest a compatible mode. However, the request may be rejected, and ultimately, the slave device may have to use the master's preferred mode. The master should honor requests from the slave device when possible.

instruction: What triggers a capability renegotiation in VoIP gateways during a call?
input:
Source: There might be the need for mid-call ITU-T V.152 negotiations, if ITU-T V.152 was not negotiated during the call establishment phase and if VBD stimuli were detected in a "mid-call phase". The VBD stimuli detection logic in VoIP gateways may be always enabled, independent of the call-individual negotiation; Any mid-call VBD stimuli detection shall trigger a capability renegotiation (e.g., via SIP re-INVITE);
Standard: V.152
output: A capability renegotiation in VoIP gateways during a call is triggered by the detection of Voice Band Data (VBD) stimuli in a mid-call phase. This detection logic may be always enabled in VoIP gateways, independent of the call-individual negotiation. Upon detection, the gateway initiates a capability renegotiation, which can be performed using protocols such as SIP re-INVITE.

instruction: What is the alternative method for transporting ANS, /ANS, ANSam, and /ANSam signals in audio or VBD packets if supported by media gateways?
input:
Source: IETF RFC 4733 telephone-events ANS (32), /ANS (33), ANSam (34) and /ANSam (35) can optionally be used as an alternative method for the transport of these signals in audio or VBD packets. If these events are declared by a media gateway, the remote media gateway may use [IETF RFC 4733] to transmit these signals. If both media gateways indicate the support of IETF RFC 4733 telephone-events ANS (32), /ANS (33), ANSam (34) and /ANSam (35), the gateway generating the events shall use [IETF RFC 4733] to transmit these signals. In either case, when [IETF RFC 4733] is used for transporting these signals, the gateways shall suppress the transport of these signals in audio or VBD packets. The amount of in-band signal leakage into the IP network using audio encoding for ANS, ANSam, /ANS, and /ANSam signals shall be less than 50 ms.
Standard: V.152
output: The alternative method for transporting ANS (32), /ANS (33), ANSam (34), and /ANSam (35) signals in audio or VBD packets, if supported by media gateways, is the use of IETF RFC 4733 modem/facsimile/text telephone events. When these events are declared by a media gateway, the remote media gateway may use IETF RFC 4733 to transmit these signals. If both media gateways indicate support for these events, the gateway generating the events shall use IETF RFC 4733 for transmission, and the transport of these signals in audio or VBD packets shall be suppressed. The in-band signal leakage into the IP network using audio encoding for these signals must be less than 50 ms.

instruction: What stimuli can initiate a transition to VBD mode for facsimile applications?
output: For facsimile applications, the stimuli that can initiate a transition to VBD mode include CED (Calling Tone), ANSam (Answer Tone with phase modulation), Preamble signals, and CNG (Calling Tone). These signals are specific to facsimile communication protocols.

instruction: What triggers the transition from audio mode to VBD mode in a implementation?
input:
Source: The transition from audio mode to VBD mode is performed when the VBD detectors classify an input signal as VBD. Detection of the stimuli described in clause 9 shall be carried out at least in the direction from the GSTN to the IP network; however, detection in the direction from the IP network to the GSTN network is not precluded. The bi directional VBD stimuli detecti on capability of a VBD gateway improves the probability of correct and timely gate way local state transition, which offers a more robust VBD service a nd state transition.
Standard: V.152
output: The transition from audio mode to VBD mode is triggered when VBD detectors classify an input signal as VBD. This detection must occur at least in the direction from the GSTN to the IP network, though detection in the opposite direction is also possible. The detection of specific stimuli, as outlined, initiates this transition, enhancing the robustness of VBD service and state transition by ensuring correct and timely gateway local state transition.

instruction: What conditions must be met for a VBD gateway to transition from VBD to audio mode?
input:
Source: Transition from VBD to voice may be carried out by detection: 
• In the direction from the GSTN to IP network of any of the following stimuli:  
– end of modem or facsimile signals; – voice signals; 
– detection in both directions, GSTN to IP  and IP to GSTN, of silence. With the 
following caveats:  
• For text telephones, the appropriate dete ction of silence must be considered 
because text telephone conversations may have long periods of silence. 
• For the case of facsimile calls, the sile nce period should be gr eater than the T2 
timer defined in [ITU-T T.30]. 
– MGC signalling or other out -of-band signalling methods. 
• In the direction from IP to GSTN network due to receipt of RTP packets that have non-
VBD payload types, only after the first VBD RT P packet has been received. This will avoid 
the situation of an incorrect transition into audio mode when it has transitioned to VBD mode on detection of VBD signa ls on its TDM side and is s till receiving voice RTP packets 
(because the remote end has not yet transitioned, based on reception of the VBD RTP packets).
Standard: V.152
output: A VBD gateway transitions from VBD to audio mode upon detection of specific stimuli in the direction from the GSTN to IP network. These stimuli include the end of modem or facsimile signals, voice signals, or detection of silence in both directions (GSTN to IP and IP to GSTN), with considerations for text telephones and facsimile calls. For text telephones, appropriate detection of silence is necessary due to potential long silence periods. For facsimile calls, the silence period must exceed the T2 timer defined in ITU-T T.30. Additionally, transition can occur due to MGC signaling or other out-of-band signaling methods, or upon receipt of RTP packets with non-VBD payload types in the direction from IP to GSTN network, but only after the first VBD RTP packet has been received to prevent incorrect transitions.

instruction: What are the minimum set of state signalling events required for VBD operation in ITU-T implementations?
input:
Source: The minimum set of state signalling events that shall be supported for VBD operation are events 0 through 3 which are basic to the SSE protocol. The null SSE event (0) shall never be sent and should be ignored if received.
Standard: V.152
output: The minimum set of state signalling events required for VBD operation in ITU-T V.152 implementations are events 0 through 3, which are basic to the SSE protocol. Event 0, the null SSE event, should never be sent and must be ignored if received.

instruction: What triggers a media gateway to transition to VBD mode in non-cases?
input:
Source: When one or both of the two gateways does not support ITU-T V.150.1 operation, then transitions to and from the VBD mode shall be governed by the procedures in this clause. An attempt shall be made to make these procedures isomorphic to ITU-T V.150.1 procedures so that media gateways do not incur the burden of supporting and testing multiple VBD switching mechanisms.
Standard: V.152
output: A media gateway transitions to VBD mode upon detecting a voice-band data stimulus, such as an answer tone variant, and if it has the necessary resources available. It then immediately changes the connection to the VBD media state and issues an SSE indicating this state.

instruction: What are the criteria for transitioning from VBD media mode to audio mode in media gateways?
input:
Source: On detecting a termination of data transmission, media gateways shall locally transition the connection to the audio mode and issue an SSE:audio (Initial audio SSE, event code 1) to the remote gateway. If it receives an SSE:audio, it shall change the media state to initial audio and respond back with an SSE:audio. The criteria for determining the termination of data transmission are application-specific and are not defined here. Examples of such criteria are the detection of voice or of pre-determined intervals of silence.
Standard: V.152
output: The transition from VBD media mode to audio mode occurs when a termination of data transmission is detected. The specific criteria for determining this termination are application-specific and not universally defined. Examples include the detection of voice or predetermined intervals of silence. Upon detection, the gateway transitions locally to audio mode and sends an SSE:audio (Initial audio SSE, event code 1) to the remote gateway. If the remote gateway responds with an SSE:audio, both gateways change the media state to initial audio.

instruction: What is the role of SRTP in VBD mode for data payload transport?
input:
Source: When the VBD mode is used to transport data payloads, it lends itself easily to secure, encrypted operation based on SRTP (Secure RTP). Support of security features is not required by ITU-T V.152 compliant implementations and is negotiated at call establishment. Based on declarations at the time of session establishment, it is possible to encrypt some RTP payload types (e.g., voice, VBD and IETF RFC 4733 events), while passing other RTP payload types (e.g., SSEs) unencrypted. Such selective encryption will allow fast response times to SSEs, without compromising the security of media sourced by the end-user.
Standard: V.152
output: SRTP (Secure RTP) is used in VBD mode to provide secure, encrypted operation for transporting data payloads. It allows for the encryption of certain RTP payload types, such as voice, VBD, and IETF RFC 4733 events, while other payload types like SSEs can be passed unencrypted. This selective encryption enables fast response times to SSEs without compromising the security of end-user sourced media. Support for security features is optional and negotiated during call establishment.

instruction: What is the structure of a vendor-ID when it follows the ITU-T T.35 format?
input:
Source: When the vendor-ID format is ITU-T T.35, the vendo r-ID consists of a country code followed by a vendor code. The country code consists of four oc tets and the vendor-ID cons ists of two octets. If the representation of the vendor-I D is hexadecimal, leading zeros  in the country code may be omitted, while leading zeros in the vendor code may not be omitted.
Standard: V.152
output: When the vendor-ID format is ITU-T T.35, the vendor-ID consists of a country code followed by a vendor code. The country code is four octets long, and the vendor code is two octets long. In hexadecimal representation, leading zeros in the country code may be omitted, but leading zeros in the vendor code must not be omitted.

instruction: What is the purpose of data signal detection and silence insertion in voiceband data transmission over IP networks?
input:
Source: Data signal detector (DSD) and silence insertion in VBD mode is a technique that reduces the transmission bandwidth over IP networks by inserting silence indicator descriptors during the silence periods of a voiceband data modem connection. This is especially efficient for half-duplex data transmissions.
Standard: V.152
output: Data signal detection (DSD) and silence insertion in voiceband data (VBD) mode are techniques used to reduce transmission bandwidth over IP networks by inserting silence indicator descriptors during silence periods of a voiceband data modem connection. This is particularly efficient for half-duplex data transmissions, as it minimizes the amount of data transmitted during silent intervals.

instruction: What does the SDP attribute 'a=gpmd:99 dsd=yes' indicate about a device's capabilities?
input:
Source: "a=gpmd:99 dsd=yes" indicates that the devi ce supports the DSD capability; "a=rtpmap:99 CN/8000" shows that the device sends SID frame w ith payload type 99. If mutually negotiated, both gateways can use the DSD procedures described in this annex.
Standard: V.152
output: The SDP attribute 'a=gpmd:99 dsd=yes' indicates that the device supports the Discontinuous Transmission (DSD) capability. This means the device can handle the procedures for DSD as described in the relevant technical specifications.

instruction: What are the two possible configurations for echo cancellers in relation to media gateways?
input:
Source: This procedure is only valid for media gateways compliant to this Recommendation. Note that in this application, echo cancellers may be embedded within the media gateway or be external to it. The signalling of the gateway to the echo canceller can be via proprietary means if it is an embedded type in the gateway, or by some standardized means if connected to an external echo canceller. The means definition of external echo canceller control is for further study.
Standard: V.152
output: Echo cancellers can be either embedded within the media gateway or external to it. Embedded echo cancellers typically use proprietary signalling methods, while external echo cancellers may use standardized signalling means, although the specific definition for external echo canceller control is still under study.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Secure Real-time Transport Protocol (SRTP)?
input:
Source: [b-IETF RFC 3711] IETF RFC 3711 (2004), The Secure Real-time Transport Protocol (SRTP) .
Standard: V.152
output: The Secure Real-time Transport Protocol (SRTP) is designed to provide encryption, message authentication, integrity, and replay protection for Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) traffic. It is used to secure the transmission of multimedia communications over IP networks, ensuring confidentiality and protection against attacks.

instruction: What is the definition of effective data transfer rate in data communication?
input:
Source: The average number of bits, characters, or blocks per unit time transferred from a data source to a data sink and accepted as valid. It is expressed in bits, characters, or blocks per second, minute, or hour.
Standard: V.7
output: The effective data transfer rate is defined as the average number of bits, characters, or blocks per unit time transferred from a data source to a data sink and accepted as valid. It is typically expressed in bits, characters, or blocks per second, minute, or hour.

instruction: What is out-of-band signalling in the context of DCE communication?
input:
Source: The exchange of control signals between interconnected DCEs using signals other than those for the transmission of data in the forward channel. The transmission of DTE data is not disrupted.
Standard: V.7
output: Out-of-band signalling refers to the exchange of control signals between interconnected Data Circuit-terminating Equipment (DCEs) using signals that are separate from those used for the transmission of data in the forward channel. This method does not disrupt the transmission of Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) data.

instruction: What is the carrier frequency specified for line signals at 2400 and 1200 bit/s?
input:
Source: 2.1 The carrier frequency is to be 1800 ± 1 Hz. No separate pilot frequencies are provided. The power levels used will conform to Recommendation V.2.
Standard: V.26
output: The carrier frequency specified for line signals at 2400 and 1200 bit/s is 1800 ± 1 Hz.

instruction: What are the phase changes associated with each dibit in differential phase modulation?
input:
Source: Dibit Phase change (see Note)
00
011110+ 45°
+ 135°+ 225°+ 315°
Note - The phase change is the actual on-line phase shift in the
transition region from the centre of one signalling element to the
centre of the following signalling element.
Standard: V.26
output: In differential phase modulation, the phase changes associated with each dibit are as follows: dibit '00' corresponds to a phase change of +45°, dibit '01' corresponds to +135°, dibit '11' corresponds to +225°, and dibit '10' corresponds to +315°. These phase changes represent the actual on-line phase shift during the transition from the center of one signaling element to the center of the following signaling element.

instruction: What is the required received signal frequency tolerance for a modem receiver considering transmitter and connection drift?
input:
Source: Noting that the carrier frequency tolerance allowance at the transmitter is ± 1 Hz and assuming a maximum frequency drift of ± 6 Hz in the connection between the modems, then the receiver must be able to accept errors of at least ± 7 Hz in the received frequencies.
Standard: V.26
output: The modem receiver must be able to accept frequency errors of at least ± 7 Hz. This accounts for the ± 1 Hz carrier frequency tolerance at the transmitter and a maximum frequency drift of ± 6 Hz in the connection between the modems.

instruction: What are the response times for circuit 106 from the connection to an ON or OFF condition?
input:
Source: Fascicle VIII.1 - Rec. V.26 bis 55.2.2 Circuit 106 response times are from the connection to an ON or OFF condition on: - circuit 105 to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106; or - circuit 107 (where circuit 105 is not required to initiate the synchronizing signal) to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106.
Standard: V.26
output: The response times for circuit 106 are measured from the connection to an ON or OFF condition on circuit 105 to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106. Alternatively, if circuit 105 is not required to initiate the synchronizing signal, the response times are measured from the connection to an ON or OFF condition on circuit 107 to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106.

instruction: What are the response time specifications for Circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON state?
input:
Source: OFF to ON 750 ms to 1400 ms (see Note 1) a) 65 ms to 100 ms (see Note 2) b) 200 ms to 275 ms (see Note 2)
Standard: V.26
output: The response time for Circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON state is specified as 750 ms to 1400 ms for automatic calling and answering during call establishment. For system applications, the response times can be either 65 ms to 100 ms for limited protection against line echoes or 200 ms to 275 ms for protection against line echoes.

instruction: What are the threshold levels for the received line signal detectors in modems, and how do they affect circuits 109 and 122?
input:
Source: Level of received line signal at receive line terminals of modem for all types of connections, i.e. general switched telephone network or non-switched leased telephone circuits: - greater than -43 dBm: circuits 109/122 ON - less than -48 dBm: circuits 109/122 OFF The condition of circuits 109 and 122 for levels between -43 dBm and -48 dBm is not specified except that the signal detectors shall exhibit a hysteresis action such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs is at least2 dB greater than that for the ON to OFF transition. Where transmission conditions are known and allowed, it may be desirable at the time of modem installation to change these response levels of the received line signal detector to less sensitive values (e.g. -33 dBm and -38 dBmrespectively).
Standard: V.26
output: The threshold levels for received line signal detectors in modems are set such that circuits 109 and 122 turn ON when the received line signal level is greater than -43 dBm and turn OFF when the level is less than -48 dBm. For levels between -43 dBm and -48 dBm, the condition of circuits 109 and 122 is not specified, except that the signal detectors must exhibit a hysteresis action where the OFF to ON transition occurs at a level at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition. Under known and allowed transmission conditions, these response levels can be adjusted to less sensitive values, such as -33 dBm for ON and -38 dBm for OFF, during modem installation.

instruction: What is the purpose of DTE-controlled call negotiation in data communication?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines means for use in DTE control of V.8 and V.8 bis call negotiation.
Standard: V.251
output: DTE-controlled call negotiation in data communication is designed to allow Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) to control the process of call setup and negotiation using protocols such as V.8 and V.8 bis. This enables the DTE to manage the establishment of communication parameters and modes between devices, ensuring compatibility and optimal performance during data transmission over telephone networks.

instruction: What are the key functions of signal indications in modem communication?
output: V.8 signal indications in modem communication serve several key functions: CI signal indication (+A8I) for call initiation, calling tone indication (+A8C) for detecting the calling tone, answer signal indication (+A8A) for detecting the answer signal, V.8 negotiation complete (+A8J) indicating the completion of negotiation, V.8 menu report (+A8M) for reporting menu selections, and V.8 bis signal and message reporting for handling additional signals and messages.

instruction: What are the key components of a origination session for data transmission?
input:
Source: 10.1 V.8 origination, connect as V.34 transmit and receive data
Standard: V.251
output: A V.8 origination session for V.34 data transmission involves establishing a connection where the modem originates the call and is configured to transmit and receive data using the V.34 protocol. This includes the negotiation of modulation parameters, error correction, and data compression techniques specific to V.34 to ensure optimal data transmission rates and reliability.

instruction: What are the functions a DCE must provide when compliant with specific annex requirements?
input:
Source: A DCE compliant with this annex shall provide the following functions: a) accept DTE preconfiguration command before call establishment; b) provide necessary V.8 physical layer functions, including ANSam and V.21 modem; c) provide indications to the DTE for detection of remote V.8 signals (ANSam, CI, CM, JM, CJ), V.25 signals (CT, T.30 CNG) and relevant sigA and sigC signals (e.g. T.30 Ch2 flags); d) accept V.8 signals from the remote station, and convert them to hexadecimal octet coding for presentation to the DTE; e) accept V.8 signal octets in hexadecimal octet coding from the DTE and convert them to V.8 format for transmission; f) return to Command State after CJ transmission, detection or failure detection, so that DTE can take timely action; g) accept V.8 bis signal codes and V.8 bis message octets in hexadecimal octet coding from the DTE and convert them to V.8 bis format for transmission; h) detect V.8 bis signals and messages from the remote station, and convert them to the appropriate signal codes and hexadecimal octet coding for presentation to the DTE.
Standard: V.251
output: A DCE compliant with specific annex requirements must provide several functions including: accepting DTE preconfiguration commands before call establishment; providing necessary V.8 physical layer functions such as ANSam and V.21 modem; offering indications to the DTE for detecting remote V.8 signals (ANSam, CI, CM, JM, CJ), V.25 signals (CT, T.30 CNG), and relevant sigA and sigC signals; accepting and converting V.8 signals from the remote station to hexadecimal octet coding for DTE presentation; converting V.8 signal octets from hexadecimal octet coding from the DTE to V.8 format for transmission; returning to Command State after CJ transmission, detection, or failure detection; accepting and converting V.8 bis signal codes and message octets from hexadecimal octet coding from the DTE to V.8 bis format for transmission; and detecting and converting V.8 bis signals and messages from the remote station to appropriate signal codes and hexadecimal octet coding for DTE presentation.

instruction: What are the valid values and their descriptions for the operation control subparameters in modem communication?
input:
Source: Table 1/V.251 – V.8 operation control subparameters 
Values Description 
<v8o>=0 Disable V.8 origination negotiation 
<v8o>=1 Enable DCE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation 
<v8o>=2 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, send V.8 CI only 
<v8o>=3 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, send 1100 Hz CNG only 
<v8o>=4 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, send 1300 Hz CT only 
<v8o>=5 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, send no tones 
<v8o>=6 Enable DCE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, issue +A8x indications 
<v8a>=0 Disable V.8 answer negotiation 
<v8a>=1 Enable DCE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation 
<v8a>=2 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, send ANSam 
<v8a>=3 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, send no signal 
<v8a>=4 Disable DTE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, send ANS 
<v8a>=5 Enable DCE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, issue +A8x indications 
<v8cf>=X..Y Set the V.8 CI signal call function to the hexadecimal octet value X..Y 
<v8b>=0 Disable V.8 bis negotiation <v8b>=1 enable DCE-controlled V8 bis negotiation 
<v8b>=2 Enable DTE-controlled V.8 bis negotiation 
<cfrange>= 
"<string of values >" Set to alternative list of call function "option bit" values that the answering DCE 
shall accept from the caller 
<protrange >= 
"<string of values >" Set to alternative list of protocol "option bit" values that the answering DCE 
shall accept from the caller
Standard: V.251
output: The valid values for V.8 operation control subparameters include: <v8o>=0 disables V.8 origination negotiation; <v8o>=1 enables DCE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation; <v8o>=2 enables DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, sending V.8 CI only; <v8o>=3 enables DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, sending 1100 Hz CNG only; <v8o>=4 enables DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, sending 1300 Hz CT only; <v8o>=5 enables DTE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, sending no tones; <v8o>=6 enables DCE-controlled V.8 origination negotiation, issuing +A8x indications. For <v8a>: 0 disables V.8 answer negotiation; 1 enables DCE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation; 2 enables DTE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, sending ANSam; 3 enables DTE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, sending no signal; 4 disables DTE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, sending ANS; 5 enables DCE-controlled V.8 answer negotiation, issuing +A8x indications. <v8cf> sets the V.8 CI signal call function to a hexadecimal octet value X..Y. <v8b>=0 disables V.8 bis negotiation; 1 enables DCE-controlled V.8 bis negotiation; 2 enables DTE-controlled V.8 bis negotiation. <cfrange> and <protrange> set alternative lists of call function and protocol 'option bit' values, respectively, that the answering DCE shall accept from the caller.

instruction: What happens when subparameters <v8o>, <v8a>, and <v8b> are set to 0?
input:
Source: For subparameters <v8o>, <v8a> and <v8b>, values of 0 disable the corresponding feature. Values of 1 enable the feature, with operation controlled by the DCE, based implicitly on manufacturer-determined procedures and on previous configuration commands.
Standard: V.251
output: When subparameters <v8o>, <v8a>, and <v8b> are set to 0, the corresponding features are disabled. This means the features controlled by these subparameters are not active, and their operation is not influenced by the DCE's manufacturer-determined procedures or previous configuration commands.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +A8M command in V-Series DCEs?
input:
Source: This command directs the DCE to send a V.8 CM or JM signal using the specified hexadecimal coded string. If the DCE can decode the menu octet string, and if it cannot implement a specified feature, the DCE shall report an ERROR final result code, but stay in V.8 operation awaiting another command.
Standard: V.251
output: The +A8M command directs the DCE to send a V.8 CM or JM signal using a specified hexadecimal coded string. If the DCE can decode the menu octet string but cannot implement a specified feature, it reports an ERROR final result code while remaining in V.8 operation to await another command.

instruction: What are the functions of the subparameters <sig_en>, <msg_en>, and <supp_delay> in bis signal detection?
input:
Source: Subparameter <sig_en> directs the DCE to search for specified V.8 bis signals. A value of zero enables detection of initiating signals; a value of one enables detection of responding signals; a value of two enables detection of both signals. Subparameter <msg_en>, if set to 1, directs the DCE to search for V.8 bis messages. A value of zero disables detection of the messages. Note that detection of an ES signal automatically conditions the DCE to look for an immediately subsequent V.8 bis message regardless of the setting of <msg_en>; see 9.2 Subparameter <supp_delay >, if set to 1, directs the DCE to insert a 1.5 second delay between the transmitted V.8 bis signal and the subsequent V.8 bis message, if any.
Standard: V.251
output: The subparameter <sig_en> controls the detection of V.8 bis signals: a value of zero enables detection of initiating signals, one enables detection of responding signals, and two enables detection of both. The subparameter <msg_en>, when set to 1, enables the DCE to search for V.8 bis messages, with zero disabling this detection. Note that detection of an ES signal automatically conditions the DCE to look for a subsequent V.8 bis message regardless of <msg_en> setting. The subparameter <supp_delay>, when set to 1, instructs the DCE to insert a 1.5-second delay between the transmitted V.8 bis signal and any subsequent message.

instruction: What are the signal values and their descriptions for calling tone indication in V-Series DCEs?
input:
Source: Signal value Description 
0 Indicates that the DCE concluded answer tone transmission without 
reporting detection of any calling tone 
1 Indicates a CNG tone (1100 Hz) 
2 Indicates 1300 Hz V.25 data modem calling tone 
3 Indicates sigC signal: V.32/V.32  bis AA tone 
Implementation 
Implementation of this indication is mandatory for V-Series DCEs supporting DTE control of V.8, 
or for DCEs supporting the <v8a>=5 subparameter value in the +A8E command. Individual values 1, 
2 and 3 shall be implemented if the DCE supports detection of the relevant signal.
Standard: V.251
output: The signal values for calling tone indication in V-Series DCEs are: 0, which indicates that the DCE concluded answer tone transmission without reporting detection of any calling tone; 1, which indicates a CNG tone (1100 Hz); 2, which indicates a 1300 Hz V.25 data modem calling tone; and 3, which indicates a sigC signal: V.32/V.32 bis AA tone. Implementation of these values is mandatory for DCEs supporting DTE control of V.8 or those supporting the <v8a>=5 subparameter value in the +A8E command, with individual values 1, 2, and 3 implemented if the DCE supports detection of the relevant signal.

instruction: What does the +A8J indication signify in negotiation?
input:
Source: This indication is issued by either DCE, if DTE control of V.8 negotiation is enabled, when the negotiation is complete and CJ is sent or detected. An answering DCE will issue this on detection of CJ from the remote terminal. A calling DCE will send a CJ signal to the remote terminal at the same time as a +A8J indication. +A8J:1 indicates CJ; +A8J:0 indicates that the DCE timed out waiting for a CJ signal.
Standard: V.251
output: The +A8J indication is issued by either DCE when V.8 negotiation is complete and CJ is sent or detected. +A8J:1 indicates CJ, while +A8J:0 indicates that the DCE timed out waiting for a CJ signal. An answering DCE issues this on detection of CJ from the remote terminal, and a calling DCE sends a CJ signal to the remote terminal simultaneously with a +A8J indication.

instruction: What are the requirements for DCE configuration before the Dial command in origination procedures?
input:
Source: Before the Dial command, the DCE must be enabled by setting the +A8E <v8o> to a value other than 0 or 1, and setting <v8cf> to a valid Call Function value (see Table 3/V.8). If <v8cf> is not valid, the DCE may still use it to generate a V.8 CI signal, but the remote terminal is unlikely to recognize it.
Standard: V.251
output: Before the Dial command, the DCE must be enabled by setting the +A8E <v8o> to a value other than 0 or 1, and setting <v8cf> to a valid Call Function value. If <v8cf> is not valid, the DCE may still use it to generate a V.8 CI signal, but the remote terminal is unlikely to recognize it.

instruction: What is the sequence of operations for DTE-controlled operation when ANSam is detected?
input:
Source: For DTE-controlled V.8 operation, if ANSam is detected, the +A8A:1 indication followed by the final result code prompts the DTE to send the V.8 CM signal octets, as a hexadecimal octet sequence preceded by the +A8M= command. The DCE shall send the resulting CM signal to the remote terminal and condition its receiver to detect JM and proceed to  7.6.
Standard: V.251
output: When ANSam is detected in DTE-controlled V.8 operation, the DCE sends a +A8A:1 indication followed by the final result code. This prompts the DTE to send the V.8 CM signal octets as a hexadecimal octet sequence preceded by the +A8M= command. The DCE then transmits the CM signal to the remote terminal and prepares its receiver to detect JM, proceeding to the next phase of operation.

instruction: What action should a DCE take upon detecting a CI signal?
input:
Source: If V.8 CI is detected, the DCE shall report this to the DTE using the +A8I: <v8cf> indication with call function (see 6.1). If <v8a>=2, the DCE shall commence the transmission of ANSam.
Standard: V.251
output: Upon detecting a V.8 CI signal, the DCE shall report this to the DTE using the +A8I: <v8cf> indication with call function. If <v8a>=2, the DCE shall commence the transmission of ANSam.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +A8E command with a <v8b> value of 2 in bis procedures?
input:
Source: The +A8E=,,,<v8b> command with <v8b> value of 2 commences V.8 bis operation under DTE control, directing the DCE to begin listening for incoming initiating V.8 bis signals. Note that capable DCE may accept this command on-hook or off-hook, in any relevant +FCLASS setting.
Standard: V.251
output: The +A8E command with a <v8b> value of 2 initiates V.8 bis operation under DTE control, directing the DCE to begin listening for incoming initiating V.8 bis signals. This command can be accepted by the DCE whether it is on-hook or off-hook, in any relevant +FCLASS setting.

input:
Source: 10.1 V.8 origination, connect as V.34 transmit and receive data

Standard: V.251
