1 Asynchronous ERM Buffered V.14 2 Asynchronous ERM w. V.42 bis V.42/LAPM 
3 Asynchronous UNERM HDLC Frame Tunneling 4 Reserved Transparent 
<nlpidData> Network Layer Protocol Identifier data; hexadecimal coded octet string <t84prof> A 32-bit integer in hexadecimal format defining a bit-mapped value with T.84 
capabilities. Bit assignments are as follows: 
 00001 Unrestricted 
00002 QCIF
Standard: V.252
output: The +SDC command parameters include: <dcode> for duplex data channel identifier (data channel 0 is always connected to DTE), <appl> for data application mode (e.g., 0 for Non-standard application, 1 for T.120, etc.), <prtcls> for data protocol mode (with Class 17 and Class 18 definitions), <nlpidData> for Network Layer Protocol Identifier data in hexadecimal, <t84prof> for a 32-bit integer in hexadecimal defining T.84 capabilities, and optional parameters like <uih>, <winsize>, <recovery>, <crc>, <n401>, <V42bislen>, <V42bissiz> for additional configurations. This command configures DCE capabilities exchanges and can be issued before or during a connection to change the DCE's default configuration.

instruction: What are the possible values for error recovery in a channel and what do they signify?
input:
Source: <recovery> V.76 error recovery for this channel: 0 None 1 Non-selective reject 2 Selective reject 3 Multiple selective reject
Standard: V.252
output: The possible values for V.76 error recovery in a channel are: 0 for None, 1 for Non-selective reject, 2 for Selective reject, and 3 for Multiple selective reject. These values signify the method of error recovery employed by the channel, with 'None' indicating no error recovery, 'Non-selective reject' indicating that all frames starting from the erroneous one are retransmitted, 'Selective reject' indicating only the erroneous frame is retransmitted, and 'Multiple selective reject' allowing for the retransmission of multiple specified erroneous frames.

instruction: What are the possible values for the CRC type used by multiplex for a channel?
input:
Source: <crc>  CRC type used by V.76 multiplex for this channel: 
 0 8-bit 
1 16-bit 2 32-bit
Standard: V.252
output: The CRC type used by V.76 multiplex for a channel can be 0 for 8-bit, 1 for 16-bit, or 2 for 32-bit.

instruction: What are the parameters and their functions in the video transmit configuration command for a DCE?
input:
Source: 3.6 Video transmit configuration +SVC (Class 18 only) 
Parameter 
+SVC=<vcode>,<std>[,< qcifMPI >[,< cifMPI>[,< maxBitRate >[,< tstrade>[,< stillImage > 
[,<sqcifMPI >[,< cif4MPI >[,< cif16MPI >[,< urv>[,< arith>[,< advpred >[,< pbframes >]]]] 
]]]]]]]] 
Description 
This parameter sets the preferred operating mode for an outgoing video channel from video device 
<vcode>. If the remote terminal is incapable of operating at the preferred mode, video channel operation may take place in another mode within the DCE's capability. 
This command serves to configure the DCE transmit capabilities, and may be issued prior to a 
connection to change the DCE from the default configuration, or during a connection prior to a +STC 
command. The subsequent +STC  may then trigger a capabilities exchange. 
Defined values 
<vcode> This is a supported video device code as defined in 2.1. 
<std> This selects or describes the video encoding standard for the outgoing channel: 
 1 H.261 
2 H.263 
<qcifMPI> This integer selects the Minimum Picture Interval for QCIF encoding, with values 
in the range 0..4 for H.261 and 0..32 for H.263. For example, a value of 1 indicates 30 frames per second, a value of 2 indicates 15 fps, etc. A value of 0 indicates QCIF is not supported for the specified encoder.  
<cifMPI> This integer selects the Minimum Picture Interval for CIF encoding, with values in 
the range 0..4 for H.261 and 0..32 for H.263. A value of 0 indicates CIF is not supported for the specified encoder. 
<maxBitRate> This subparameter sets the maximum rate, in units of 100 bit/s, at which the 
encoder may transmit video. 
<tstrade> When set to 1, this boolean subparameter enables the encoder to implement 
time/space tradeoffs, as requested by the receiving terminal. When set to zero, time/space tradeoffs are disabled. 
<stillImage> When set to 1, this boolean subparameter enables the ability for still images as 
specified in Annex D/H.261. It is not applicable to H.263 encoders and may be 
ignored when <std> =2. 
 Subsequent subparameters are applicable to H.263 encoders only, and are ignored 
when <std> =1. 
<sqcifMPI> This integer selects the Minimum Picture Interval for SQCIF encoding, with values 
in the range 1..32. A value of 0 indicates SQCIF is not supported. 
<cif4MPI> This integer selects the Minimum Picture Interval for QCIF4 encoding, with values 
in the range 1..32. A value of 0 indicates QCIF4 is not supported.
Standard: V.252
output: The video transmit configuration command for a DCE includes several parameters to set the preferred operating mode for an outgoing video channel. The parameters are: <vcode>, which specifies the video device code; <std>, which selects the video encoding standard (1 for H.261, 2 for H.263); <qcifMPI>, which selects the Minimum Picture Interval for QCIF encoding; <cifMPI>, for CIF encoding; <maxBitRate>, which sets the maximum transmission rate in units of 100 bit/s; <tstrade>, a boolean to enable or disable time/space tradeoffs; <stillImage>, a boolean to enable still image capability for H.261; <sqcifMPI>, for SQCIF encoding; <cif4MPI>, for QCIF4 encoding; and additional parameters specific to H.263 encoders for further configuration options.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Minimum Picture Interval parameter in QCIF16 encoding?
input:
Source: This integer selects the Minimum Picture Interval for QCIF16 encoding, with values in the range 1..32. A value of 0 indicates QCIF16 is not supported.
Standard: V.252
output: The Minimum Picture Interval parameter in QCIF16 encoding selects the interval between pictures, with values ranging from 1 to 32. A value of 0 indicates that QCIF16 encoding is not supported.

instruction: What are the possible values and their meanings for the audio indication reporting parameter in a DCE?
input:
Source: <value> 0 DCE shall not generate +SAR:  and +SAT:  indications. 
 1 DCE shall generate +SAR:  and +SAT:  indications. 
Default values 
Recommended default value is zero.
Standard: V.252
output: The audio indication reporting parameter in a DCE can have two values: 0 and 1. A value of 0 means the DCE shall not generate +SAR: and +SAT: indications when audio channels are established or closed. A value of 1 means the DCE shall generate these indications. The recommended default value is zero.

instruction: What does the +VAC command do in audio device configuration?
input:
Source: This parameter sets the audio device that is affected by subsequent +Vxxx commands in this clause (i.e., +VRL, +VSP, +VTA, +VTH, +VDX, +VHC). These commands will be directed to the specified audio device until modified by a subsequent +VAC command.
Standard: V.252
output: The +VAC command sets the audio device that will be affected by subsequent +Vxxx commands, such as +VRL, +VSP, +VTA, +VTH, +VDX, and +VHC. These commands will be directed to the specified audio device until modified by another +VAC command. The command takes a supported audio device code as its parameter, with the default value being manufacturer-specific.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +VGT command in DCE operations?
input:
Source: This command causes the DCE to set the gain for a transmit audio channel. The transmit gain is an unsigned octet where values larger than 128 indicate a larger gain than nominal, and values smaller than 128 indicate a gain smaller than nominal. The nominal value is 128. The largest range of numbers is 0 to 255. The DCE may limit the gain to a more narrow range, such as 120 to 136 or 120 to 128. The value of zero is reserved for DCE Automatic Gain Control (AGC). This command may be issued prior to the opening of a transmit audio channel and its assignment to an audio input device. In this case, the gain setting for the device is stored, and becomes effective when the channel is opened.
Standard: V.252
output: The +VGT command is used to set the gain for a transmit audio channel in a DCE. The gain is represented as an unsigned octet where values larger than 128 indicate a gain higher than nominal, and values smaller than 128 indicate a gain lower than nominal, with 128 being the nominal value. The range can be from 0 to 255, though the DCE may restrict this range. A value of 0 is reserved for DCE Automatic Gain Control (AGC). This command can be issued before opening a transmit audio channel, with the setting becoming effective once the channel is opened.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +VTD command in a DCE?
input:
Source: This command sets the default DTMF/tone generation duration used by the DCE in conjunction with the +VTS command. This command does not affect the settings for the ATD command. Defined values <dur> 0 Specifies a manufacturer-specific duration. 1..255 Specifies the duration in units of 0.01 second.
Standard: V.252
output: The +VTD command sets the default duration for DTMF or tone generation used by the DCE in conjunction with the +VTS command. The duration is specified in units of 0.01 second for values ranging from 1 to 255, with 0 indicating a manufacturer-specific duration. This command does not affect the settings for the ATD command.

instruction: How are tones delivered to a remote device when the input device is associated with a transmit audio channel and DCE-DCE messaging is enabled?
input:
Source: If this is an input device, and the device is associated with a transmit audio channel, the tones are delivered to the remote device. This accomplished by instructing the remote DCE to generate the tones via a DCE-DCE message, if enabled.
Standard: V.252
output: The tones are delivered to the remote device by instructing the remote DCE to generate the tones via a DCE-DCE message.

instruction: What are the parameters and their ranges for the +VRL command used to produce ringing voltage on a local phone?
input:
Source: Parameter +VRL=<ring_duration>[,<silence_duration>[,<ring_duration>]...] Parameter description This command causes the DCE to produce ringing voltage to the specified local phone. The command returns the OK result code immediately if all subparameters are found to be properly formatted; the actual production of ringing occurs 'asynchronously'. No separate indication is given to the DTE when the specified ring pattern has been completed. If the local phone is off-hook, then the ringing is not performed (although an OK result code is still produced); if the local phone goes off-hook during the ringing, then ring voltage is terminated and the remainder of the ringing is not performed. Defined values <ring_duration>,<silence_duration> The +VRL command can accept a variable number of subparameters. All < x_duration> subparameters are decimal values in the range 0 to 255, each in increments of 100 milliseconds. The first such subparameter indicates the duration of the first ringing segment of the ring pattern; the second subparameter, if present, indicates the duration of the silent period before the next segment of the ring pattern; the third subparameter indicates the duration of the second ringing segment; and so forth, alternatively specifying the duration of the ring and silence segment. Note that it is not necessary to indicate the amount of silence that follows the pattern separating it from the next pattern; it is the responsibility of the DTE to repeat the command (at, typically, 6-second intervals) if additional ring patterns are desired. Default values The DCE shall support subparameter strings specifying a minimum of three <ring_duration> subparameters; more may be supported.
Standard: V.252
output: The +VRL command accepts variable numbers of subparameters, specifically <ring_duration> and <silence_duration>, which are decimal values ranging from 0 to 255, each in increments of 100 milliseconds. The first subparameter specifies the duration of the first ringing segment, the second (if present) specifies the silent period before the next segment, and subsequent subparameters alternate between specifying ring and silence durations. The DCE must support a minimum of three <ring_duration> subparameters, with the possibility of supporting more.

instruction: What does the information text response (0-255),(0-255),3 indicate in the context of DCE capabilities?
input:
Source: (0-255),(0-255),3
indicates that the DCE supports the full range of values for both <ring_duration> and 
<silence_duration> subparameters, and the minimum three <ring_duration> subparameters per string.
Standard: V.252
output: The information text response (0-255),(0-255),3 indicates that the DCE supports the full range of values (0 to 255) for both the <ring_duration> and <silence_duration> subparameters, and requires a minimum of three <ring_duration> subparameters per string.

instruction: What are the possible configurations for speakerphone operation in a DCE?
input:
Source: Parameter +VDX=<spconfig > Parameter description This command configures the speakerphone function’s mode of operation to half-duplex or duplex. Defined values <spconfig> 0 Configure speakerphone in the DCE for half-duplex operation. 1 Configure speakerphone in the DCE for duplex operation.
Standard: V.252
output: The speakerphone in a DCE can be configured for either half-duplex or duplex operation. Half-duplex operation is set with <spconfig> value 0, allowing communication in one direction at a time. Duplex operation, set with <spconfig> value 1, enables simultaneous two-way communication. The actual availability of duplex operation depends on the DCE channel configuration.

instruction: What is the purpose of the +VPH command in telecommunication devices?
input:
Source: This is a read-only parameter, that reports the on-hook/off-hook status of local phone devices connected to the DCE (i.e., it reports whether the devices are drawing loop current from the DCE). Read syntax +VPH? The DCE shall transmit the current status for each local phone, e.g.: +VPH: L0,1 +VPH: L1,0 Reports that the phone on L0 is drawing loop current, while the phone at L1 is not.
Standard: V.252
output: The +VPH command is used to report the on-hook/off-hook status of local phone devices connected to the DCE. It indicates whether the devices are drawing loop current from the DCE, with examples of responses being +VPH: L0,1 for a phone on L0 drawing loop current and +VPH: L1,0 for a phone on L1 not drawing loop current.

instruction: What does the hook status value '0' indicate for a telephone port configured for single-line telephone simulation?
input:
Source: Default value for <hookstat> shall be 0 for all applicable <acode>'s. Read syntax +VHC? The DCE shall transmit the hook status for each local phone port configured for single-line telephone simulation, e.g.: +VHC: L0,1 +VHC: L1,0 reports that port L0 is off hook, while the port L1 is on hook.
Standard: V.252
output: The hook status value '0' indicates that the telephone port is on hook, meaning the phone is not in use or the handset is placed on the cradle.

instruction: What are the subparameters and their meanings in the +SRCV remote terminal capability indication?
input:
Source: +SRCV: < CapTblEntNum >,<CapDir>,<std>,<qcifMPI >,<cifMPI>,<maxBitRate >, <tstrade>[,< stillImage >[,< sqcifMPI >[,< cif4MPI >[,< cif16MPI >[,< urv>[,< arith>[, <advpred >[,< pbframes >]]]]]]]
Standard: V.252
output: The +SRCV remote terminal capability indication includes several subparameters: <CapTblEntNum> specifies the capability table entry number (1..65535), serving as an index without indicating preference. <CapDir> indicates direction: 0 for receive, 1 for transmit, and 2 for receiveAndTransmit. Other subparameters define video capabilities, including <std> for standard, <qcifMPI> and <cifMPI> for video resolutions, <maxBitRate> for maximum bit rate, <tstrade> for trade-off between temporal and spatial resolution, and optional parameters like <stillImage>, <sqcifMPI>, <cif4MPI>, <cif16MPI>, <urv>, <arith>, <advpred>, and <pbframes> for additional video features and capabilities.

instruction: What does the +SAR indication report in audio channel communications?
input:
Source: This indication reports the establishment or closing of an incoming audio channel to audio device <acode>, with port number <portnum>. Values are as defined in the +SAM command. An indication which just supplies the <acode> value indicated that the corresponding audio channel has been closed.
Standard: V.252
output: The +SAR indication reports the establishment or closing of an incoming audio channel to a specified audio device, identified by <acode>, with a specific port number <portnum>. It includes parameters such as <std> for standard, <arate> for audio rate, and <silsup> for silence suppression, among others. If only the <acode> value is provided, it indicates that the corresponding audio channel has been closed.

instruction: What does the +VACR indication report in video communication systems?
input:
Source: This indication proceeds the +VCIDR , +VDIDR , and +VTER  indications defined in this clause. It indicates to which audio devices these subsequent indications apply. If consecutive indications in this clause are output by the DCE, the DCE may omit the intervening +VACR  report.
Standard: V.252
output: The +VACR indication reports the audio code to which subsequent indications like +VCIDR, +VDIDR, and +VTER apply in video communication systems. It precedes these indications and specifies the audio devices they are related to. If multiple indications are output consecutively by the DCE, the intervening +VACR report may be omitted.

instruction: What are the defined values and descriptions for the event code <tcode> in telephony devices?
input:
Source: Reports that event <tcode> was detected at the telephony device L n indicated by <acode>. Defined values of <tcode> are: Code Description 0-9 DTMF 0-9 A-D DTMF A-D E DTMF * F DTMF # h Line current break (local phone goes on hook). (Note 1) H Line current detected (local phone goes off hook). (Note 1) ! Hook-Flash (Line current interruption). (Note 1) L Loop current polarity reversal. This may indicate a hang-up or a receive depending on the implementation of the central office. (Note 2) r Ringback (cadence). (Note 2) b BUSY (cadence). If the DCE continues to detect BUSY, the DCE may repeatedly report this event. The time interval between reports shall be no less than 4.0 seconds. The detection criterion is implementation specific. (Note 2) d DIALTONE. If the DCE continues to detect DIALTONE, the DCE may repeatedly report this event. The time interval between reports shall be no less than 3.0 seconds. The detection criterion is implementation specific. (Note 2) K Reorder/fast busy (cadence). (Note 2) p Line voltage increase (extension phone goes on hook). (Note 2) P Line voltage decrease (extension phone goes off hook). (Note 2) R (n) Ringing detected. The value of (n), if included, specifies distinctive ringing cadence detected. If n is omitted, standard ringing cadence (1) shall be assumed. Valid values for (n) are 1-4. (Note 2) i Stuttered dialtone. (Note 2) NOTE 1 – Applicable when port is configured for central office simulation. NOTE 2 – Applicable when port is configured for single-line telephone simulation.
Standard: V.252
output: The defined values for the event code <tcode> in telephony devices include: 0-9 for DTMF digits 0-9, A-D for DTMF letters A-D, E for DTMF *, F for DTMF #, h for line current break (local phone goes on hook), H for line current detected (local phone goes off hook), ! for Hook-Flash (line current interruption), L for loop current polarity reversal, r for ringback (cadence), b for BUSY (cadence) with reports no less than 4.0 seconds apart, d for DIALTONE with reports no less than 3.0 seconds apart, K for reorder/fast busy (cadence), p for line voltage increase (extension phone goes on hook), P for line voltage decrease (extension phone goes off hook), R(n) for ringing detected with n specifying distinctive ringing cadence (1-4, standard is 1 if omitted), and i for stuttered dialtone.

instruction: What are the in-band commands used by DTE to change the configuration of an existing channel?
input:
Source: The DTE may use in-band +SDC , +SAC, +SAM, +SVC (Class 18 only), and +SVM (Class 18 only) commands to change the configuration of an existing channel.
Standard: V.252
output: The DTE may use in-band commands such as +SDC, +SAC, +SAM, +SVC (Class 18 only), and +SVM (Class 18 only) to change the configuration of an existing channel.

instruction: What are the key components of a protocol reference model for terminal adaptors?
input:
Source: 5 Reference models... 5.1 Functional reference model... 5.2 Protocol reference model... 5.3 Interworking model... 5.4 Call mapping model
Standard: V.130
output: The key components of a protocol reference model for terminal adaptors include the functional reference model, protocol reference model, interworking model, and call mapping model. These components define the structure, protocols, interaction between different systems, and call handling mechanisms respectively.

instruction: What is the function of a Terminal Adaptor in ISDN systems?
input:
Source: The expression 'Terminal Adaptor' is commonly used to refer to a stand-alone item of equipment (or alternatively a printed circuit card plugged into a terminal) that allows a non-ISDN terminal to be connected to an ISDN user-network interface. Formally though, Terminal Adaptor (TA) is the name of one of the (conceptual) Functional Groups defined in Recommendation I.411. The TA Functional Group contains functions that allow a TE2 (non-ISDN) terminal to use the services provided by an ISDN.
Standard: V.130
output: A Terminal Adaptor (TA) functions to enable non-ISDN terminals (TE2) to connect to and utilize the services provided by an ISDN user-network interface. It acts either as a stand-alone equipment or as a printed circuit card within a terminal, bridging the compatibility gap between non-ISDN terminals and ISDN services.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics specified for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s?
input:
Source: ITU-T Recommendation V.10 (1993), Electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s .
Standard: V.130
output: The electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s include specifications for voltage levels, signal timing, and interface compatibility to ensure reliable data transmission over such circuits.

instruction: What is a modec in telecommunications?
input:
Source: 3.1 modec : The term modec is used to refer to a functional block (sometimes called a digital modem) whose overall functionality is equivalent to that of a modem connected to a codec. A modec has no internal analoguecomponents and only digital interfaces.
Standard: V.130
output: A modec is a functional block, sometimes referred to as a digital modem, that replicates the functionality of a modem connected to a codec. It is characterized by having no internal analogue components and only digital interfaces.

instruction: What are the additional U plane functions in terminal adaptation?
input:
Source: Additional U plane functions include: – end-to-end mapping of the states of R interface control signals;– in-band notification/checking/negotiation of adaptation protocol (for multi-protocol TAs);– in-band notification/checking/negotiation of adaptation protocol parameters;– handling error conditions detected at the R interface;– recovery of timing information (network independent clock);– end-to-end flow control between TAs (methods are described in both Recommendations V.110 and V.120); – multiplexing of several user connections into one ISDN call;– aggregation of several ISDN calls to provide one user connection. Protocols for this purpose are described in Recommendation H.244 and the complementary International Standard, ISO/IEC 13871; – detection and optional correction of errors that occur between the TAs;– compression of the user information stream to increase the effective throughput;– encryption of the user information stream for security purposes;– modec function (see 10.3).
Standard: V.130
output: Additional U plane functions in terminal adaptation include end-to-end mapping of R interface control signals states, in-band notification/checking/negotiation of adaptation protocol and its parameters, handling R interface error conditions, recovery of timing information (network independent clock), end-to-end flow control between TAs, multiplexing of several user connections into one ISDN call, aggregation of several ISDN calls for one user connection, detection and optional correction of inter-TA errors, compression and encryption of the user information stream, and the modec function.

instruction: What functions does the management and maintenance control block provide in a terminal adaptor?
input:
Source: This block provides overall control of the TA and may in addition provide maintenance functions. Examples are: – storage of ISDN numbers for Calling Line Identification (CLI) checking of incoming calls;– control of maintenance loops.
Standard: V.130
output: The management and maintenance control block in a terminal adaptor provides overall control of the terminal adaptor and may include maintenance functions. Examples include the storage of ISDN numbers for Calling Line Identification (CLI) checking of incoming calls and the control of maintenance loops.

instruction: What are the key components of the Terminal Adaptor Protocol Reference Model in the Control (C) plane?
input:
Source: R-physicalR-signalling (Note) Rec. I.430 or I.431 (D-channel) FIGURE  2A/V.130 Terminal adaptor protocol reference model – Control (C) planeNOTE – The structure of the R-signalling layer varies from one R interface to another.
Standard: V.130
output: The key components of the Terminal Adaptor Protocol Reference Model in the Control (C) plane include the R-physical layer, R-signalling layer, and the D-channel. The R-physical layer is based on Rec. I.430 or I.431, and the structure of the R-signalling layer varies depending on the R interface.

instruction: What are the general requirements for successful interworking between TE2 + TA combinations?
input:
Source: The two TE2 + TA combinations must have a minimum common functionality for communication to be successful, for example both TAs must support the same rate adaptation protocol operating at the same bit rate.
Standard: V.130
output: The two TE2 + TA combinations must have a minimum common functionality for communication to be successful. This includes both TAs supporting the same rate adaptation protocol operating at the same bit rate.

instruction: What are the three call mapping cases shown in the TA diagrams where call durations on both sides are the same?
input:
Source: In Figure 4 three cases are shown where the durations of the calls on both sides of the TA are the same. The first is for a simple TA where there is a 1:1 mapping between the calls at the TE2 and ISDN sides. An example is the V.110 TA described in Appendix I. The second is for a TA which multiplexes several (in this case three) TE2 calls into one ISDN call. An example would be a TA using the statistical multiplexing feature of Recommendation V.120. The third case is for a TA using channel aggregation to synthesize a 128 kbit/s channel out of two ISDN 64 kbit/s circuit mode calls.
Standard: V.130
output: The three cases are: 1) A simple TA with a 1:1 mapping between TE2 and ISDN calls, exemplified by a V.110 TA. 2) A TA that multiplexes several TE2 calls into one ISDN call, such as using the statistical multiplexing feature of V.120. 3) A TA using channel aggregation to combine two ISDN 64 kbit/s circuit mode calls into a 128 kbit/s channel.

instruction: What are the possible bearer capabilities (BC) that can be specified in a SETUP message for a terminal adaptor (TA)?
input:
Source: The TA operates in the 3.1 kHz audio mode. Optionally, the MODEC can then commence (in-band) modem identification procedures. 6.2.2 Incoming calls For an incoming call the MTA's response depends on the BC(s) contained in the SETUP message: 6.2.2.1 BC = both UDI-TA and 3.1 kHz Providing the TA is otherwise compatible (e.g. the rate adaptation specified in the LLC information element is acceptable) then it responds with a CONNECT message containing the UDI-TA BC and operates in 64 kbit/sunrestricted mode. Otherwise it responds with the 3.1 kHz BC and operates in the 3.1 kHz audio (modec) mode. Thisallows 3.1 kHz (modec) interworking with other terminal adaptors which support the Multi-Use bearer service but useincompatible rate adaptation protocols in 64 kbit/s unrestricted mode. 6.2.2.2 BC = UDI-TA or 64 kbit/s unrestricted digital The TA responds with a CONNECT message containing the BC copied from the SETUP message and operates in the 64 kbit/s unrestricted mode. 6.2.2.3 BC = 3.1 kHz only (possibly with GSTN interworking indicated) The TA responds with a CONNECT message containing the BC copied from the SETUP message and operates in the 3.1 kHz audio (modec) mode.
Standard: V.130
output: The possible bearer capabilities (BC) that can be specified in a SETUP message for a terminal adaptor (TA) include: 3.1 kHz audio, both UDI-TA and 3.1 kHz audio, UDI-TA or 64 kbit/s unrestricted digital, and 3.1 kHz only (possibly with GSTN interworking indicated). The TA's response and operation mode depend on the BC specified in the SETUP message.

instruction: What are the three information elements provided by Q.931 for call negotiation?
input:
Source: Recommendation Q.931 provides three information elements for call negotiation: i) Bearer Capability (BC);ii) Low Layer Compatibility (LLC);iii) High Layer Compatibility (HLC).
Standard: V.130
output: The three information elements provided by Q.931 for call negotiation are Bearer Capability (BC), Low Layer Compatibility (LLC), and High Layer Compatibility (HLC). These elements are used to select alternative features at the destination, though some networks may not allow their transparent passage, limiting the features that can be specified.

instruction: What are the possible interface types at the R reference point between the TA and TE2 functional blocks?
input:
Source: The interface at the R reference point between the TA and the TE2 functional blocks may be a physical interface or may be embedded within a piece of equipment.
Standard: V.130
output: The interface at the R reference point between the TA and TE2 functional blocks may be a physical interface or may be embedded within a piece of equipment.

instruction: What are the functions of a Multi-Protocol Terminal Adaptor (MTA)?
input:
Source: A Multi-Protocol Terminal Adaptor (MTA) supports more than one adaptation protocol in the user plane. The actual protocol used is chosen on a per call basis. Figure 7 shows such a TA which supports three different adaptation functions(shown as U plane functions 1, 2 and 3). These could be, for example, rate adaptation conforming to Recommenda-tions V.110 and V.120 using the 64 kbit/s unrestricted BC, adn a modec function (clause 10) using the 3.1 kHzaudio BC.
Standard: V.130
output: A Multi-Protocol Terminal Adaptor (MTA) supports multiple adaptation protocols in the user plane, allowing the selection of the appropriate protocol on a per call basis. It can include functions such as rate adaptation conforming to specific standards using the 64 kbit/s unrestricted bearer capability, and a modem function using the 3.1 kHz audio bearer capability. The selection of the appropriate user plane function can be made either by the user or automatically during or immediately after call set-up.

instruction: What are the two alternative methods for providing data communications between ISDN and GSTN subscribers?
input:
Source: Recommendation I.530 identifies two alternative ways of providing data communications between ISDN and GSTN subscribers. i) The DTE (TE2) of the ISDN subscriber is connected to a TA which rate adapts the information flow to 64 kbit/s according to, for example, Recommendation I.463 (V.110). At a suitable interworking pointwithin the network, the original information flow is extracted and converted to an "analogue" form by amodem for transfer over the GSTN to the remote terminal (i.e. the usage of modem pools). Thismechanism is described in Recommendation I.515. ii) The DTE (TE2) of the ISDN subscriber is connected to a modem which in turn is connected to a TA incorporating a codec. Interworking between the ISDN and GSTN is handled as for telephony. Thissecond case, "Terminal Adaptor with CODEC", is shown in Figure 8.
Standard: V.130
output: The two alternative methods are: 1) Connecting the DTE (TE2) of the ISDN subscriber to a TA which rate adapts the information flow to 64 kbit/s, then converting the original information flow to an analogue form by a modem for transfer over the GSTN. 2) Connecting the DTE (TE2) of the ISDN subscriber to a modem which is then connected to a TA incorporating a codec, with interworking between the ISDN and GSTN handled as for telephony.

instruction: What is a modec in the context of telecommunications equipment?
input:
Source: Figure 10 shows how the process of integrating a modem into a terminal adaptor can be taken a stage further by defining a new functional block, a modec (sometimes called a digital modem), which has no internal analogue functions and only digital interfaces. Interface (a) is the DTE’s bit or character stream. Interface (b) is an octet stream which is the same as the PCM coding (according to Recommendation G.711) of the voiceband signal at the analogue (GSTN) interface of an equivalent modem. This TA uses the 3.1 kHz audio bearer service.
Standard: V.130
output: A modec, or digital modem, is a functional block that combines the functions of a modem and a terminal adaptor without any internal analogue functions. It features only digital interfaces, where interface (a) connects to the DTE’s bit or character stream, and interface (b) connects to an octet stream equivalent to the PCM coding of a voiceband signal at the analogue interface of an equivalent modem. This design utilizes the 3.1 kHz audio bearer service and eliminates the analogue components typically found in separate modem and terminal adaptor units.

instruction: What are the functions of the RA0, RA1, and RA2 stages in the protocol stack?
input:
Source: In the user plane (Figure I.2), on the terminal side, the user’s information is carried in the start-stop character format. This character stream is then subjected to the three stages of rate adaptation in the V.110 protocol stack. The RA0 function uses the method described in Recommendation V.14 to generate a synchronous bit stream. This is then subjected to first and second stage rate adaptation by the RA1 and RA2 functions to produce a 64 kbit/s stream that is carried over the ISDN B-channel. The process is reversed for the information stream received from the network.
Standard: V.130
output: The RA0, RA1, and RA2 stages in the V.110 protocol stack perform rate adaptation functions. RA0 converts an asynchronous start-stop character stream into a synchronous bit stream using the method described in V.14. RA1 and RA2 then perform first and second stage rate adaptation, respectively, to transform this synchronous bit stream into a 64 kbit/s stream suitable for transmission over an ISDN B-channel. The process is reversed for incoming data from the network.

instruction: What are the key components of a V-Series Call Control Managed Object?
output: A V-Series Call Control Managed Object consists of four key components: a Managed Object Template, Attributes, Actions, and Notifications. The Managed Object Template defines the structure and behavior of the managed object. Attributes represent the properties or characteristics of the managed object. Actions are operations that can be performed on the managed object. Notifications are events or alerts generated by the managed object.

instruction: What are the main components of a V-Series Line Interface Managed Object?
output: The main components of a V-Series Line Interface Managed Object include a Managed Object Template, Attributes, Actions, and Notifications. The Managed Object Template defines the structure and behavior of the managed object. Attributes represent the properties or characteristics of the managed object. Actions are operations that can be performed on the managed object. Notifications are alerts or messages generated by the managed object in response to certain conditions or events.

instruction: What is the purpose of object classes and attribute types in network management?
input:
Source: Object classes and attribute types are defined only for the purpose of communicating network management messages between systems, and need not be related to the structure of data within those systems.
Standard: V.58
output: Object classes and attribute types are defined for the purpose of communicating network management messages between systems. They facilitate the structured exchange of management information, enabling systems to understand and process management data consistently. These definitions are not necessarily related to the internal data structure of the systems involved.

instruction: What are the possible values for the monitorEnable attribute in audio monitor control?
input:
Source: monitorEnable ENUMERATED { off (0),alwaysOn (1),monitorDial (2),monitorCallSetup (3)}
Standard: V.58
output: The monitorEnable attribute in audio monitor control can take the following enumerated values: off (0), alwaysOn (1), monitorDial (2), monitorCallSetup (3). These values control the operation of the audio monitor, such as a loudspeaker, for audible indication of modem dialling operations.

instruction: What are the possible automatic call modes that can be implemented in a DCE?
input:
Source: autoCallModesSupported ::= BIT STRING { none (0), v-25 (1),v-25bis (2),v-at (3),cct108-1 (4)} Description: Indicates which automatic call modes are implemented in the DCE.
Standard: V.58
output: The possible automatic call modes that can be implemented in a DCE include none, v-25, v-25bis, v-at, and cct108-1. These modes are indicated by a BIT STRING where each mode corresponds to a specific bit position: none (0), v-25 (1), v-25bis (2), v-at (3), cct108-1 (4).

instruction: What are the possible modes of operation specified by the dceModeSelect parameter?
input:
Source: dceModeSelect ::= BIT STRING  {
leasedPointToPoint (0),
leasedMultipointControl (1),leasedMultipointTributary (2),dialAutocall (3),dialAutoanswer (4),dialBackupCall (5),dialBackupAnsw (6)}
Description: If DCE is capable of operating in leased line or GSTN mode, this parameter specifies the selected
mode(s) of operation.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: More than one mode can be selected, if dialBackupEnable or autoRestoralEnable is TRUE.
Standard: V.58
output: The dceModeSelect parameter specifies the following possible modes of operation: leasedPointToPoint (0), leasedMultipointControl (1), leasedMultipointTributary (2), dialAutocall (3), dialAutoanswer (4), dialBackupCall (5), and dialBackupAnsw (6). More than one mode can be selected if dialBackupEnable or autoRestoralEnable is TRUE.

instruction: What is the purpose of the pauseDuringDialTime parameter in DCE configuration?
input:
Source: pauseDuringDialTime ::= INTEGER (1..8)
Description: Sets the amount of time, in seconds the DCE pauses upon encountering the "pause during dialling”
character (e.g. comma).
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: Specification not required
Applications: Configuration Management
Registered as: {vSeriesCallControl pauseDuringDialTime (16)}
Standard: V.58
output: The pauseDuringDialTime parameter sets the amount of time, in seconds, that the DCE pauses upon encountering the 'pause during dialling' character, such as a comma. The valid range for this parameter is 1 to 8 seconds.

instruction: What is the purpose of the dialDisconnectReq action in a DCE?
input:
Source: dialDisconnectReq  ::= NULL
dialDisconnectConf ::= CallProgress
Description: This action is used to disconnect the DCE when in dial up or dial backup mode.
Operations: ACTION
Behaviour: If the DCE is in dial up mode, this action disconnects any calls in progress and returns the DCE to
the enabled unlocked state.
If the DCE is in dial backup, i.e. leased line mode, this action disconnects the DCE and attempts to
re-establish communications over the leased line.
Standard: V.58
output: The dialDisconnectReq action is used to disconnect the DCE when it is in dial up or dial backup mode. In dial up mode, it disconnects any calls in progress and returns the DCE to the enabled unlocked state. In dial backup (leased line mode), it disconnects the DCE and attempts to re-establish communications over the leased line.

instruction: What are the attributes and operations associated with the v42bis compression package in data communication equipment?
input:
Source: v42bisPkg PACKAGE ATTRIBUTESv42bisCompressionActive GET,v42bisCompressionSelect GET-REPLACE,v42bisDictionarySizeActive GET,v42bisDictionarySizeSelect GET-REPLACE,v42bisDictionarySizeSupported GET,v42bisMaximumStringLengthActive GET,v42bisMaximumStringLengthSelect GET-REPLACE,v42bisMaximumStringLengthSupported GET;NOTIFICATIONSlossOfSynchronization;PRESENT IF 'compressionEnable is v42bisonly'; REGISTERED AS {ccitt(0), recommendation(0), v(22), v58(58), vSeriesDataCompression(1)};
Standard: V.58
output: The v42bis compression package in data communication equipment includes several attributes and operations. The attributes are v42bisCompressionActive (GET), v42bisCompressionSelect (GET-REPLACE), v42bisDictionarySizeActive (GET), v42bisDictionarySizeSelect (GET-REPLACE), v42bisDictionarySizeSupported (GET), v42bisMaximumStringLengthActive (GET), v42bisMaximumStringLengthSelect (GET-REPLACE), and v42bisMaximumStringLengthSupported (GET). These attributes allow for the management and configuration of the v42bis compression functionality, including checking the active state, selecting compression options, and determining supported dictionary sizes and maximum string lengths.

instruction: What are the possible values for bis data compression modes?
input:
Source: v42bisCompressionActive ::= ENUMERATED { none (0), txOnly (1),rxOnly (2),both (3)}
Standard: V.58
output: The possible values for V.42 bis data compression modes are none (0), txOnly (1), rxOnly (2), and both (3). These values represent no compression, transmission-only compression, reception-only compression, and both transmission and reception compression, respectively.

instruction: What is the range of maximum string length supported by the DCE in v42bis data compression?
input:
Source: v42bisMaximumStringLengthSupported ::= INTEGER (6..250)
Standard: V.58
output: The maximum string length supported by the DCE in v42bis data compression ranges from 6 to 250 characters.

instruction: What does the backedUpStatus attribute indicate in a V-Series DCE?
input:
Source: backedUpStatus ::= BOOLEAN
Description: This attribute indicates if the V-Series DCE has been backed up after failure.
Operations: GET
Behaviour: Set to TRUE if DCE has failed and been backed up by a standby unit. Set to FALSE in all other
cases.
Standard: V.58
output: The backedUpStatus attribute indicates whether the V-Series DCE has been backed up after a failure. It is a BOOLEAN value set to TRUE if the DCE has failed and been backed up by a standby unit, and FALSE in all other cases.

instruction: What are the possible types of V-Series DCE equipment as defined by their equipmentType?
output: The V-Series DCE equipment types are defined by a BIT STRING with two options: dialModem (0) and leasedLineModem (1). Additionally, the lineInterface can be either analogue (0) or digital (1), and the dceImplementation can be rackMount (0), standAlone (1), internal (2), or builtIn (3).

instruction: What is the purpose of the presetConfigurationRange attribute in a DCE?
input:
Source: presetConfigurationRange ::= INTEGER (0..255)
Description: Allows the Network Management System to determine the number of factory preset configuration
profiles supported by the DCE.
Standard: V.58
output: The presetConfigurationRange attribute allows the Network Management System to determine the number of factory preset configuration profiles supported by the DCE. It is an INTEGER type with a range of 0 to 255.

instruction: What are the two types of self-tests that can be invoked on a DCE, and how do they differ in operation?
input:
Source: selfTestReq ::= ENUMERATED { intrusiveFullTest (0), safePartialTest (1)} [...] The Intrusive Full Test terminates calls in progress and disables the DCE. The Safe Partial Test provides a limited test of the DCE and does not terminate calls in progress.
Standard: V.58
output: The two types of self-tests that can be invoked on a DCE are the Intrusive Full Test and the Safe Partial Test. The Intrusive Full Test terminates calls in progress and disables the DCE, providing a comprehensive check on the operation of hardware components and memory. The Safe Partial Test offers a limited test of the DCE without terminating calls in progress, serving as a non-intrusive 'health' check. The Intrusive Full Test is more thorough but disruptive, while the Safe Partial Test is less comprehensive but does not interfere with normal operation.

instruction: What are the components of an equipmentFailure notification in a DCE?
output: An equipmentFailure notification in a DCE consists of a SEQUENCE that includes a priority of type EventPriority and a faultType which is an ENUMERATED type with possible values memoryFault (0) and deviceFault (1). This notification is used to indicate to the management entity that the DCE has detected an equipment fault condition.

instruction: What is the purpose of the antiStreamingTimer attribute in a DTE interface?
input:
Source: antiStreamingTimer ::= INTEGER  (0..255)
Description: Maximum continuous duration in seconds that a multipoint DCE is allowed to transmit.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: The timer is initiated at the OFF/ON transition of circuit 105. If circuit 105 remains on for more
than the duration of the timer, then the DCE’s line signal will be turned off. When circuit 105 isturned off normal operation resumes – i.e. line signal follows an OFF/ON transition of circuit 105.A value of 0 indicates that the timer is inhibited. When the timer expires, a streamingDetectednotification is transmitted.
Applications: Fault Management
Registered as: {vSeriesDteInterface antiStreamingTimer (0)}
Standard: V.58
output: The antiStreamingTimer attribute in a DTE interface is an integer value ranging from 0 to 255 seconds. It defines the maximum continuous duration that a multipoint DCE is allowed to transmit. The timer starts at the OFF/ON transition of circuit 105. If circuit 105 remains on longer than the timer's duration, the DCE's line signal is turned off. Normal operation resumes when circuit 105 is turned off. A value of 0 disables the timer. When the timer expires, a streamingDetected notification is sent. This attribute is primarily used for fault management.

instruction: What are the possible values for the parityBitValue in autoDetectCharacterFormat?
input:
Source: parityBitValue ENUMERATED { odd (0),even (1),mark (2),space (3) }
Standard: V.58
output: The parityBitValue in autoDetectCharacterFormat can be one of the following: odd (0), even (1), mark (2), or space (3).

instruction: What is the range of additional delay in milliseconds that can be set for circuit 105 to circuit 106 in switched carrier operation?
input:
Source: cct105to106Delay ::= INTEGER (0..1023)
Standard: V.58
output: The additional delay that can be set for circuit 105 to circuit 106 in switched carrier operation ranges from 0 to 1023 milliseconds.

instruction: What is the range and increment for modifying the circuit 109 turn off delay?
input:
Source: cct109TurnOffDelay ::= INTEGER  (0..255)
Description: Provides the capability to modify the circuit 109 turn off delay in increments of 10 milliseconds.
Standard: V.58
output: The circuit 109 turn off delay can be modified in the range of 0 to 255, with increments of 10 milliseconds.

instruction: What are the possible character formats supported in DCE implementations for start/stop configurations?
input:
Source: characterFormatSupported ::= BIT STRING {automatic (0), cf8Data2Stop (1),cf8Data1Parity1Stop (2),cf8Data1Stop (3),cf7Data2Stop (4),cf7Data1Parity1Stop (5),cf7Data1Stop (6),cf6Data2Stop (7),cf6Data1Parity1Stop (8),cf6Data1Stop (9),cf5Data2Stop (10),cf5Data1Parity1Stop (11)}
Standard: V.58
output: The DCE implementations support various character formats for start/stop configurations, including automatic, cf8Data2Stop, cf8Data1Parity1Stop, cf8Data1Stop, cf7Data2Stop, cf7Data1Parity1Stop, cf7Data1Stop, cf6Data2Stop, cf6Data1Parity1Stop, cf6Data1Stop, cf5Data2Stop, and cf5Data1Parity1Stop. The supported range may depend on the value of dteModeActive.

instruction: What are the possible operating modes for DTE in start-stop operation?
input:
Source: startStopV14 (0), startStopErrorControl (1),startStopBuffered (2),synchronous (3),syncAfterDial (4)} Description: Type of DTE (sync or start stop async) mode for which the DCE has been configured. For start stop operation, there are three possible operating modes.
Standard: V.58
output: The possible operating modes for DTE in start-stop operation are startStopV14, startStopErrorControl, and startStopBuffered.

instruction: What flow control methods are supported for a secondary channel when it shares the same physical interface as the primary channel?
input:
Source: Only dteByDce flow control is supported for a V.34 secondary channel. In the case of a V.34 secondary channel that shares the same physical interface as the primary channel, this attribute may also be used to control the operation of circuit 121.
Standard: V.58
output: For a V.34 secondary channel sharing the same physical interface as the primary channel, only dteByDce flow control is supported. The supported methods include none (0), xonXoff (1), and cct106 (2) for dteByDce flow control.

instruction: What are the supported modes of long space disconnect in a DCE?
output: The supported modes of long space disconnect in a DCE are disabled, disconnectWhenReceived, and sendToDisconnect. These modes allow the Network Management System to determine how the DCE handles long space disconnections.

instruction: What are the possible methods for DTE interface speed adaptation in start-stop mode?
input:
Source: startStopDteInterfaceSpeedAdaptation ::= ENUMERATED { disabled (0), autoDetectDteSpeed (1),sameAsLineRate (2)} Description: Sets the method by which DTE interface speed adaptation is accomplished.
Standard: V.58
output: The possible methods for DTE interface speed adaptation in start-stop mode are disabled, autoDetectDteSpeed, and sameAsLineRate. Disabled means no adaptation is performed. AutoDetectDteSpeed allows the system to automatically detect the DTE speed. SameAsLineRate sets the DTE interface speed to match the line rate.

instruction: What are the possible values for the errorControlActive attribute in error control management?
output: The errorControlActive attribute can take the following enumerated values: disable (0), lapm (1), and altProtocol (2). These values indicate the error control method used during the current or previous call.

instruction: What are the possible states of the link layer as defined in the enumeration?
input:
Source: linkState ::= ENUMERATED { linkDisconnected (0), linkConnecting (1),linkIdle (2),linkActive (3),linkDisconnecting (4)}
Standard: V.58
output: The possible states of the link layer are: linkDisconnected (0), linkConnecting (1), linkIdle (2), linkActive (3), and linkDisconnecting (4). These states indicate the current condition of the link layer, ranging from being disconnected to actively transmitting data.

instruction: What are the enumerated options for break options in error control protocols?
input:
Source: Recommendation V.58     (09/94) 27v42BreakOptions ::= ENUMERATED { nonDesNonExp (0), nonDesExp (1),desExp (2),desNonExp (3),doNotSendBreak (4)} Description: Indicates which V.42 break option is to be used.
Standard: V.58
output: The enumerated options for V.42 break options are nonDesNonExp (0), nonDesExp (1), desExp (2), desNonExp (3), and doNotSendBreak (4). These options indicate which V.42 break option is to be used in error control protocols.

instruction: What actions can a DCE take if it exhausts all attempts to establish enabled error control protocols?
input:
Source: Behaviour: If the DCE exhausts all of the attempts specified to establish the enabled error control protocol(s), it takes the action specified by this parameter: disconnect the call, enter buffered mode (with flowcontrol), or enter unbuffered V.14 operation without flow control (adjusting the DTE interfacespeed to match the line speed). The selected method must be one of v42FallbackSupported.
Standard: V.58
output: The DCE can disconnect the call, enter buffered mode with flow control, or enter unbuffered V.14 operation without flow control, adjusting the DTE interface speed to match the line speed. The selected method must be one of the supported fallback modes.

instruction: What is the purpose of the framesReceivedAcknowledged counter in a DCE?
input:
Source: framesReceivedAcknowledged is the number of frames containing user data received by the DCE for which acknowledgement has been sent.
Standard: V.58
output: The framesReceivedAcknowledged counter tracks the number of frames containing user data that have been received by the DCE and for which an acknowledgement has been sent. This counter does not reset to zero upon reaching its maximum count but is reset to zero at reconnection.

instruction: What are the attributes of the vSeriesLineInterface managed object class?
input:
Source: vSeriesLineInterface MANAGED OBJECT CLASS
-- Source ITU T SG14 Q4
-- Status final draft 6 June 1994
DERIVED FROM "Recommendation M.3100: 1992":managedElement
CHARACTERIZED BY
vSeriesLineInterfacePkg PACKAGE
ATTRIBUTESlineTypeActive GET,lineTypeSelect GET-REPLACE,lineTypeSupported GET,transmitLevelActive GET,transmitLevelAdjustable GET,transmitLevelSelect GET-REPLACE;
CONDITIONAL PACKAGES
gstnPkg PACKAGE
ATTRIBUTESlineSignalFailDisconnectTimer GET-REPLACE WITH DEFAULT;NOTIFICATIONScallClearedcallEstablishedringIndication;PRESENT IF "the lineTypeSelect is GSTN 2 or 4 wire",
lineAutocallPkg PACKAGE
ATTRIBUTESanswerToneSelect GET-REPLACE,answerToneSupported GET,busyDetection GET-REPLACE,callingToneSelect GET-REPLACE,callingToneSupported GET,callSetupFailTimer GET-REPLACE,dialSignalling GET-REPLACE,dialToneDetection GET-REPLACE,dtmfToneDuration GET-REPLACE,pulseDialModeSelect GET-REPLACE,pulseDialModeSupported GET;PRESENT IF "the V-Series DCE has an autocall capability";
REGISTERED AS
{ccitt(0), recommendation(0), v(22), v58(58), vSeriesLineInterface(5)};
Standard: V.58
output: The vSeriesLineInterface managed object class includes several attributes grouped into packages. The main package, vSeriesLineInterfacePkg, contains attributes such as lineTypeActive (GET), lineTypeSelect (GET-REPLACE), lineTypeSupported (GET), transmitLevelActive (GET), transmitLevelAdjustable (GET), and transmitLevelSelect (GET-REPLACE). Conditional packages include gstnPkg, which is present if the lineTypeSelect is GSTN 2 or 4 wire, and lineAutocallPkg, present if the V-Series DCE has an autocall capability. The gstnPkg includes attributes like lineSignalFailDisconnectTimer (GET-REPLACE WITH DEFAULT) and notifications such as callCleared, callEstablished, and ringIndication. The lineAutocallPkg includes attributes like answerToneSelect (GET-REPLACE), answerToneSupported (GET), busyDetection (GET-REPLACE), callingToneSelect (GET-REPLACE), callingToneSupported (GET), callSetupFailTimer (GET-REPLACE), dialSignalling (GET-REPLACE), dialToneDetection (GET-REPLACE), dtmfToneDuration (GET-REPLACE), pulseDialModeSelect (GET-REPLACE), and pulseDialModeSupported (GET).

instruction: What are the possible values for the answerToneSupported BIT STRING in a DCE?
output: The answerToneSupported BIT STRING in a DCE can have the following values: none (0), v25 (1), and v8 (2). These values allow the Network Management System to determine which Answer Tone modes are supported by the DCE.

instruction: What are the parameters and their functions in the dialToneDetection sequence?
input:
Source: dialToneDetection ::= SEQUENCE {
dialToneRequired BOOLEAN,
pause INTEGER (0..16),giveUpTimer INTEGER (0..255)}
Description: Specifies whether the DCE should listen for dial tone before dialling, or the amount of time, in
seconds, to delay before “blind dialling” (whether or not a dial tone is present).
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: If dialToneRequired is TRUE, the DCE must detect dial tone before it begins dialling a call; if no
dial tone is detected, the call attempt is abandoned. If dialToneRequired is FALSE, the DCE doesnot detect dial tone, but instead simply pauses the specified number of seconds after going off hookbefore beginning dialling if so instructed.
Standard: V.58
output: The dialToneDetection sequence includes three parameters: dialToneRequired (BOOLEAN), pause (INTEGER from 0 to 16), and giveUpTimer (INTEGER from 0 to 255). dialToneRequired specifies whether the DCE should detect dial tone before dialing; if TRUE, it must detect dial tone, otherwise, it abandons the call. If FALSE, the DCE pauses for the specified seconds (pause) before dialing without detecting dial tone. giveUpTimer defines the time in seconds the DCE waits for dial tone before abandoning the call.

instruction: What are the possible line types that a DCE can be configured to operate with?
output: A DCE can be configured to operate with several line types including leased point-to-point 4-wire, leased multipoint 4-wire, leased point-to-point 2-wire, leased multipoint 2-wire, GSTN 4-wire, and GSTN 2-wire. Additionally, it can be configured to indicate the use of a cellular link.

instruction: What does the transmitLevelAdjustable attribute indicate about a device's transmit level?
input:
Source: transmitLevelAdjustable ::= SEQUENCE {
externallyAdjustable BOOLEAN,
internallyAdjustable BOOLEAN}
Description: This attribute indicates whether the transmit level is adjustable.
Operations: GET
Behaviour: The FALSE condition of these parameters indicates that the Transmit Level are not programmable.
Standard: V.58
output: The transmitLevelAdjustable attribute indicates whether the transmit level of a device can be adjusted, either externally or internally. It is defined as a SEQUENCE with two BOOLEAN fields: externallyAdjustable and internallyAdjustable. A FALSE value for either field means that the transmit level cannot be programmed in that manner.

instruction: What does the event 'callCleared' indicate in a DCE?
input:
Source: Description: Indicates that the DCE has gone on hook and that the previously existing network connection has been cleared.
Operations: NOTIFICATION
Behaviour: Specification not required
Applications: Configuration Management
Registered as: {vSeriesLineInterface callCleared (18)}
Standard: V.58
output: The event 'callCleared' indicates that the DCE has gone on hook and that the previously existing network connection has been cleared. This event is used in Configuration Management and is registered under the vSeriesLineInterface as callCleared (18).

instruction: What is the purpose of the equalizationSelect attribute in signal conversion systems?
input:
Source: equalizationSelect ::= INTEGER (0..255)
Description: Selects a stored equalizer compromise configuration.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: A value of 0 indicates that no compromise equalizer is enabled. A value in excess of
equalizationSupported shall be considered invalid.
Applications: Configuration Management
Registered as: {vSeriesSignalConvertor equalizationSelect (0)}
Standard: V.58
output: The equalizationSelect attribute is used to select a stored equalizer compromise configuration in signal conversion systems. It accepts integer values from 0 to 255, where 0 indicates that no compromise equalizer is enabled. Values exceeding the equalizationSupported attribute's value are considered invalid. This attribute is primarily used for configuration management.

instruction: What are the possible values for the fallBackSignalQualityThreshold in a DCE and what do they indicate?
input:
Source: fallBackSignalQualityThreshold ::= ENUMERATED {
disabled (0),
high (1),normal (2),low (3)}
Description: Determines the quality threshold that causes the DCE to fall back.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: “High” threshold indicates that the signal quality must be worse than the “normal” or “low”
threshold setting to cause fall back.
Standard: V.58
output: The fallBackSignalQualityThreshold in a DCE can have the following values: disabled (0), high (1), normal (2), and low (3). 'Disabled' means the feature is turned off. 'High' indicates that the signal quality must be worse than the 'normal' or 'low' threshold settings to cause fall back. 'Normal' and 'low' represent intermediate and least stringent thresholds, respectively, for signal quality degradation that triggers fall back.

instruction: What are the modulation schemes that can be selected in a DCE for GSTN applications?
input:
Source: gstnModulationSchemesSelect ::= BIT STRING { v17 (0), v21 (1),v22 (2),v22bis (3),v23CC (4),v23SC (5),v26bis (6),v26ter (7),v27ter (8),v29HD (9),v32 (10),v32bis (11),v34 (12),v34HD (13),reserved (14)}
Standard: V.58
output: The modulation schemes that can be selected in a DCE for GSTN applications include v17, v21, v22, v22bis, v23CC, v23SC, v26bis, v26ter, v27ter, v29HD, v32, v32bis, v34, and v34HD. These schemes are represented as a BIT STRING where each bit position corresponds to a specific modulation scheme, enabling the selection of one or more schemes for 'Auto-moding' capabilities.

instruction: What are the modulation schemes available for leased line applications in signal converters?
input:
Source: leasedModulationSchemesSupported ::= BIT STRING { v21 (0), v22 (1),v22bis (2),v23 (3),v26CC (4),v26SC (5),v26ter (6),v27CC (7),v27SC (8),v27bisCC (9),v27bisSC (10),v29 (11),v32 (12),v32bis (13),v33 (14),v34 (15),v34HD (16),reserved (17),vendorSpecific (18)}
Standard: V.58
output: The modulation schemes available for leased line applications in signal converters include v21, v22, v22bis, v23, v26CC, v26SC, v26ter, v27CC, v27SC, v27bisCC, v27bisSC, v29, v32, v32bis, v33, v34, v34HD, reserved, and vendorSpecific. These schemes are defined for different operational modes such as Continuous Carrier (CC), Switched Carrier (SC), and Half Duplex (HD).

instruction: What are the possible values for the redialSignalQualityThreshold parameter and what do they indicate?
input:
Source: redialSignalQualityThreshold ::= ENUMERATED {
disabled (0),
high (1),normal (2),low (3)}
Description: Determines the quality threshold that causes the DCE to re-establish the connection.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: “High” threshold indicates that the signal quality must be worse than the “normal” or “low”
threshold setting to cause re-establishment.
Standard: V.58
output: The redialSignalQualityThreshold parameter can take the following values: disabled (0), high (1), normal (2), low (3). 'Disabled' means the feature is turned off. 'High' indicates that the signal quality must be worse than both 'normal' and 'low' thresholds to cause the DCE to re-establish the connection. 'Normal' and 'low' represent progressively less stringent quality thresholds for re-establishment.

instruction: What is the purpose of the transmissionSignallingRatesSelect attribute in DCE configuration?
input:
Source: transmissionSignallingRatesSelect ::= SEQUENCE {
transmit DceBitrateRange,
receive DceBitrateRange}
Description: Indicates the range of bitrates enabled.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: More than one signalling rate can be enabled. The enabled signalling rates must be contained in
transmissionSignallingRatesSupported. The actual selected signalling rate is contained intransmissionSignallingRateActive. Some DCE specifi cations may not allow “Transmit” and
“Receive” to be different.
Standard: V.58
output: The transmissionSignallingRatesSelect attribute is used to indicate the range of bitrates enabled for both transmit and receive operations in a DCE. It allows for the configuration of multiple signalling rates, provided they are within the supported ranges specified by transmissionSignallingRatesSupported. The actual selected signalling rate is reflected in transmissionSignallingRateActive. Some DCE specifications may restrict the transmit and receive rates to be the same.

instruction: What are the possible features that can be active in a signal converter?
input:
Source: v34FeaturesActive ::= BIT STRING {adaptivePreemphasis (0), auxiliaryChannel (1), constellationShaping (2), nonlinearEncoding (3), powerControl (4), precoding (5), secondaryChannel (6), trellisEncoding-16state (7), trellisEncoding-32state (8), trellisEncoding-64state (9)}
Standard: V.58
output: The possible V.34 features that can be active in a signal converter include adaptive preemphasis, auxiliary channel, constellation shaping, nonlinear encoding, power control, precoding, secondary channel, trellis encoding with 16 states, trellis encoding with 32 states, and trellis encoding with 64 states. These features are represented as a BIT STRING where each bit corresponds to a specific feature being active.

instruction: What are the possible symbol rate and carrier frequency combinations for a v34 signal convertor?
input:
Source: symbol2400-Carrier1600 (0),symbol2400-Carrier1800 (1),symbol2743-Carrier1646 (2),symbol2743-Carrier1829 (3),symbol2800-Carrier1680 (4),symbol2800-Carrier1867 (5),symbol3000-Carrier1800 (6),symbol3000-Carrier2000 (7),symbol3200-Carrier1829 (8),symbol3200-Carrier1920 (9),symbol3429-Carrier1959 (10)}
Standard: V.58
output: The possible symbol rate and carrier frequency combinations for a v34 signal convertor include: symbol2400-Carrier1600, symbol2400-Carrier1800, symbol2743-Carrier1646, symbol2743-Carrier1829, symbol2800-Carrier1680, symbol2800-Carrier1867, symbol3000-Carrier1800, symbol3000-Carrier2000, symbol3200-Carrier1829, symbol3200-Carrier1920, and symbol3429-Carrier1959. These combinations are specified for both transmitter and receiver configurations.

instruction: What does a value of 0 for symbolRateDifference indicate in operations?
input:
Source: A value of 0 for symbolRateDifference means that asymmetric symbol rate operation is not supported.
Standard: V.58
output: A value of 0 for symbolRateDifference indicates that asymmetric symbol rate operation is not supported in V.34 operations.

instruction: What are the components of a fallBackNotification in data communication equipment?
output: A fallBackNotification in data communication equipment consists of three main components: priority, direction, and initiator. The priority is defined by EventPriority. The direction is an ENUMERATED type with possible values: transmit (0), receive (1), or both (2). The initiator is also an ENUMERATED type with values: local (0) or remote (1). This notification indicates that the DCE has fallen back to a lower signalling rate and is only issued after automatic fall back or fall back initiated from the remote DCE, and only if the signalling rate is actually changed.

instruction: What are the attributes of the vSeriesTestFunction managed object class?
input:
Source: vSeriesTestFunction MANAGED OBJECT CLASS
-- Source ITU T SG14 Q4
-- Status final draft 6 June 1994
DERIVED FROM "Recommendation M.3100: 1992":managedElement
CHARACTERIZED BY
testFunctionPkg PACKAGE
ATTRIBUTEScct140Enable GET-REPLACE,cct141Enable GET-REPLACE,erroredBitsReceived GET,erroredBlocksReceived GET,loop2Local GET,loop2LocalEnable GET-REPLACE,loop2Remote GET,loop2RemoteEnable GET-REPLACE,loop3 GET,loop3Enable GET-REPLACE,v54Address GET REPLACE,v54Mode GET REPLACE;ACTIONSinvokeErrorRateTest,invokeLoop2Local,invokeLoop2Remote,invokeLoop3,stopErrorRateTest;NOTIFICATIONSloop2InvokedByRemoteDce;
REGISTERED AS
{ccitt(0), recommendation(0), v(22), v58(58), vSeriesTestFunction(7)};
Standard: V.58
output: The vSeriesTestFunction managed object class includes several attributes: cct140Enable (BOOLEAN, GET-REPLACE), cct141Enable (BOOLEAN, GET-REPLACE), erroredBitsReceived (INTEGER 0..65535, GET), erroredBlocksReceived (GET), loop2Local (GET), loop2LocalEnable (GET-REPLACE), loop2Remote (GET), loop2RemoteEnable (GET-REPLACE), loop3 (GET), loop3Enable (GET-REPLACE), v54Address (GET REPLACE), and v54Mode (GET REPLACE). These attributes support operations like enabling/disabling circuits, retrieving error counts, and managing loopback tests.

instruction: What is the purpose of the loop3Enable parameter in analog loop control?
input:
Source: loop3Enable ::= BOOLEAN
Description: If TRUE, the local analog loop (V.54 loop 3) can be controlled via the front panel.
Operations: GET-REPLACE
Behaviour: Specification not required
Applications: Configuration Management
Registered as: {vSeriesTestFunction loop3Enable (9)}
Standard: V.58
output: The loop3Enable parameter is a BOOLEAN value that, when set to TRUE, allows the local analog loop (V.54 loop 3) to be controlled via the front panel. It supports GET-REPLACE operations and is primarily used in Configuration Management.

instruction: What are the possible states of the digital loop (loop 2) when invoked or revoked in the addressed DCE?
input:
Source: invokeLoop2LocalConf ::= ENUMERATED { loopNowActive (0), loopNowInactice (1)} Description: Invokes/revokes the digital loop (V.54 loop 2) in the addressed DCE.
Standard: V.58
output: The digital loop (V.54 loop 2) in the addressed DCE can be in one of two states when invoked or revoked: 'loopNowActive' (0) indicating the loop is currently active, or 'loopNowInactive' (1) indicating the loop is currently inactive.

instruction: What are the possible states identified by CallProgress in a DCE line interface?
input:
Source: CallProgress ::= ENUMERATED { onHook (0), waitingForDialTone (1),dialling (2),waitingForRinging (3),ringing (4),answerTone (5),connected (6),failed (7)}
Standard: V.58
output: The CallProgress enumeration identifies several states for a DCE line interface, including onHook (0), waitingForDialTone (1), dialling (2), waitingForRinging (3), ringing (4), answerTone (5), connected (6), and failed (7).

instruction: What are the building block objects defined for V-Series DCEs?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines  a set of “building block” objects which  permit a range of V-Series DCEs to be defined. These “building block” objects are: •V-Series DCE; •V-Series Line Interface; •V-Series DTE Interface; •V-Series Signal Converter; •V-Series Call Control; •V-Series Error Control; •V-Series Data Compression; •V-Series Test Function. These require the use of the objects Equipment and managed Element, which are defined in Recommendation M.3100.
Standard: V.58
output: The building block objects defined for V-Series DCEs include V-Series DCE, V-Series Line Interface, V-Series DTE Interface, V-Series Signal Converter, V-Series Call Control, V-Series Error Control, V-Series Data Compression, and V-Series Test Function. These objects are used to define a range of V-Series DCEs and require the use of Equipment and Managed Element objects defined in Recommendation M.3100.

instruction: What is the purpose of the antiStreamingTimer attribute in communication systems?
input:
Source: antiStreamingTimer, 16
Standard: V.58
output: The antiStreamingTimer attribute is used to prevent streaming, which is the continuous transmission of data without proper control or acknowledgment, in communication systems. It sets a timer that limits the duration of data transmission to ensure proper flow control and prevent network congestion or data loss.

instruction: What is the purpose of the inactivity timer in communication systems?
input:
Source: inactivityTimerSelect, 22inactivityTimerSupported, 22
Standard: V.58
output: The inactivity timer in communication systems is used to monitor the duration of inactivity on a communication link. If no data transmission or reception occurs within the specified timer period, the system may take predefined actions such as disconnecting the link to conserve resources or initiating a reconnection process to ensure continuous communication availability.

instruction: What is the purpose of the v42bis compression in data transmission?
input:
Source: v42bisCompressionActive, 9v42bisCompressionSelect, 9v42bisDictionarySizeActive, 9v42bisDictionarySizeSelect, 9v42bisDictionarySizeSupported, 9v42bisMaximumStringLengthActive, 9v42bisMaximumStringLengthSelect, 9v42bisMaximumStringLengthSupported, 10
Standard: V.58
output: The v42bis compression is used in data transmission to reduce the amount of data sent over the communication channel, thereby increasing the effective data throughput. It employs the Lempel-Ziv-Welch (LZW) algorithm to compress data dynamically during transmission. The compression parameters, such as dictionary size and maximum string length, can be adjusted to optimize performance based on the data characteristics and transmission conditions.

instruction: What are the key components of a -type interface?
output: The key components of a V.24-type interface include a list of interchange circuits, electrical characteristics, and operational requirements. The interchange circuits define the physical connections and their functions. The electrical characteristics specify the voltage levels, impedance, and other electrical parameters required for proper operation. Operational requirements detail the conditions under which the interface must function correctly, including timing and signal integrity specifications.

instruction: What are the key functions of the TU functional block in a DCE?
output: The TU functional block in a DCE performs several key functions including data channels handling, DCE management channel operations, bit timing, octet timing, frame alignment, activation, deactivation, power feeding, and maintenance. These functions ensure proper data transmission and management within the communication system.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s?
input:
Source: ITU-T Recommendation V.10 (1993), Electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s.
Standard: V.300
output: The electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s include specifications for voltage levels, signal timing, and interface requirements to ensure compatibility and reliable communication between data terminal equipment (DTE) and data circuit-terminating equipment (DCE). These characteristics are designed to support data transmission over short distances with minimal signal degradation.

instruction: What are the recommended data signalling rates for synchronous communication?
input:
Source: The recommended data signalling rate (user rate) is synchronous at 128 kbit/s (144 kbit/s may also be supported).
Standard: V.300
output: The recommended data signalling rate for synchronous communication is 128 kbit/s, with 144 kbit/s also being a supported option.

instruction: What is the generating polynomial used in the self-synchronizing descrambler for the DCE receiver?
input:
Source: a self-synchronizing descrambler having the polynomial 1 + x–18 + x–23 shall be provided in the receiver of the DCE. The message data sequence output by the receiver of the transmission unit (see Figure I.1) shall be effectively multiplied by the generating polynomial 1 + x–18 + x–23 to form the descrambled message. The coefficients of the recovered message sequence taken in descending order form the output data sequence D o, which is given by: D o = Ds (1 ¯ x–18 ¯ x–23)
Standard: V.300
output: The self-synchronizing descrambler in the DCE receiver uses the generating polynomial 1 + x⁻¹⁸ + x⁻²³. This polynomial is applied to the message data sequence output by the receiver to form the descrambled message. The output data sequence Dₒ is derived by effectively multiplying the input sequence Dₛ by this polynomial, represented as Dₒ = Dₛ (1 ⊕ x⁻¹⁸ ⊕ x⁻²³), where ⊕ denotes modulo-2 addition.

instruction: What is the response time for circuit 106 to follow transitions on circuit 105 in a DCE?
input:
Source: Circuit 106 will follow OFF to ON or ON to OFF transitions on circuit 105 within 0.5 to 3.5 ms (this value is for further study). This time is from the application of an ON or OFF condition on circuit 105.
Standard: V.300
output: Circuit 106 will follow OFF to ON or ON to OFF transitions on circuit 105 within 0.5 to 3.5 ms. This response time is measured from the application of an ON or OFF condition on circuit 105.

instruction: What is the procedure for monitoring the output of a descrambler to ensure correct delay equalization?
input:
Source: Then the output of the descrambler shall be monitored for the reception of eleven binary 1 bits (five bits are necessary to synchronize the descrambler), indicating the correct delay equalization.
Standard: V.300
output: The output of the descrambler is monitored for the reception of eleven consecutive binary 1 bits. This sequence indicates correct delay equalization, with the first five bits being necessary to synchronize the descrambler.

instruction: What is the purpose of the self-test function in a DCE?
input:
Source: The provision of the self-test function specified herein is optional. The tests described hereafter (in 8.2.1 and 8.2.2) employ an internally generated data pattern that is typically controlled by a switch on the DCE. It shall be possible to perform these tests with or without the DCE being connected to a DTE. Upon activation of the self-test function, an internally generated data pattern at the selected user signalling rate shall be transmitted as though it was introduced to the DCE via circuit 103 or circuit T, respectively (see Figure I.1). An error detector, capable of identifying errors in the test pattern, shall be connected to the received data path. How the presence of errors is indicated is beyond the scope of this Recommendation. NOTE – The test pattern has no end-to-end bearing. Its specification is therefore not part of this Recommendation. Examples for test patterns may be alternative binary ONEs and ZEROs (reversals) or the 511-bit test pattern in accordance with Recommendation O.153 [12].
Standard: V.300
output: The self-test function in a DCE is designed to verify the operational integrity of the device by using an internally generated data pattern.
