This pattern is transmitted as if it were introduced via specific circuits (103 or T), and an error detector checks for any discrepancies in the received data. The function can be performed with or without the DCE being connected to a DTE, and it does not require end-to-end communication as the test pattern has no bearing beyond the test itself.

instruction: What are the key components of a DCE functional block diagram when implementing a -type DTE-DCE interface?
input:
Source: Figure I.1 gives an example of a simplified functional block diagram of a DCE in accordance with this Recommendation, that contains all functional blocks specified in the main part of this Recommendation when a V.24-type DTE-DCE interface is implemented. The transmission unit contains all functions of a (typically baseband) transmitter and a receiver, which are necessary to interface the DCE to the cable plant of the individual national network. Details are a national matter. For this example it is assumed that the transmission unit is inside the DCE, and interworks with a transmission unit which is installed at the other end of the local loop (see also Appendix II).
Standard: V.300
output: The key components include a transmission unit with baseband transmitter and receiver functions for interfacing with the cable plant, a test pattern receiver and generator for V.54 recognition, loop 2 circuitry, scrambler and descrambler for data processing at 128 kbit/s (or 144 kbit/s), data carrier detect, 1024 bits '1' recognition, message communication function, and equipment management function for interfacing with all managed elements. An optional control interface is also part of the diagram.

instruction: What is the purpose of a transmission unit in a 2-wire metallic line system?
input:
Source: The objectives of this transmission unit are to operate on 2-wire metallic lines that meet minimum ISDN requirements and to use existing components designed for ISDN basic access line transmission system.
Standard: V.300
output: The transmission unit in a 2-wire metallic line system is designed to operate on lines that meet minimum ISDN requirements, utilizing existing components from ISDN basic access line transmission systems. Its primary objectives include facilitating communication over 2-wire metallic lines and ensuring compatibility with ISDN infrastructure.

instruction: What are the functions of the transmission unit in a DCE when operating in master and slave modes?
input:
Source: The transmission unit incorporated within the DCE (see Figure III.1) interworks with a remote transmission unit at the other end of the local loop that is part of the baseband line termination integrated within the DCE (see Figure III.1). Operation of both units is not symmetrical. One is configured to operate in the master mode and the other is configured to operate in the slave mode. The decision as to which TU is to be operating in the master mode may be taken at the time of installation of the line transmission system (configurable parameter). The TU working in slave mode provides the different NT1 functions. TU working in the master mode provides LT functions. NT1 and LT functions are specified in Recommendation G.961. Refer also to Figure III.3
Standard: V.300
output: The transmission unit (TU) in a DCE has distinct functions when operating in master and slave modes. In slave mode, the TU provides NT1 functions, which typically include line termination and signal conversion for the user side. In master mode, the TU provides LT (Line Termination) functions, which involve interfacing with the network side and managing the line transmission system. The mode of operation (master or slave) is determined during the installation of the line transmission system and is a configurable parameter.

instruction: What are the functions provided by the TU functional blocks in a data communication system?
input:
Source: This function may provide two bidirectional and independent 64 kbit/s data channels. These correspond to the two B-channels in ISDN basic access signals. For the purpose of this Recommendation, the two 64 kbit/s channels may be used aggregated (optionally individually). Where only one 64 kbit/s channel is used (e.g. interworking with a V.38-type DCE) it should correspond to the first B-channel in the ISDN application. This function provides a 16 kbit/s bidirectional channel for the remote management of the DCE. This corresponds to the D-channel in ISDN basic access signals. When this channel is not used for management purposes, it can provide an additional 16 kbit/s transfer capacity for data application allowing an overall bit rate of 144 kbit/s. While the 16 kbit/s channel may not be allocated to the transmission of management information, the use of the eoc (defined in III.5.7.1) remains an alternative way of performing the remote management of the DCE. This function provides bit timing to enable the TU to retrieve information from the aggregate stream. Bit timing for direction slave TU to master TU shall be derived from clock received by slave TU from the master TU.
Standard: V.300
output: The TU functional blocks in a data communication system provide several key functions including two bidirectional and independent 64 kbit/s data channels, a 16 kbit/s bidirectional channel for DCE management or additional data transfer, bit timing for information retrieval from the aggregate stream, octet timing, frame alignment, activation, deactivation, operations and maintenance, and power feeding. The 64 kbit/s channels can be used aggregated or individually, similar to the B-channels in ISDN basic access signals. The 16 kbit/s channel corresponds to the D-channel in ISDN and can be used for remote management or as an additional data channel, allowing an overall bit rate of 144 kbit/s. Bit timing for the direction from slave TU to master TU is derived from the clock received by the slave TU from the master TU.

instruction: What is the purpose of the octet timing function in a 64 kbit/s data channel?
input:
Source: This function provides an 8 kHz octet timing for the 64 kbit/s data channels. It shall be derived from the frame alignment.
Standard: V.300
output: The octet timing function provides an 8 kHz timing signal for the 64 kbit/s data channels, which is derived from the frame alignment to ensure synchronized data transmission.

instruction: What is the line symbol rate for a system with a gross bit rate of 160 kbit/s using 2B1Q encoding?
input:
Source: The gross bit rate is 160 kbit/s; 144 kbit/s are occupied by the data channels and the 16 kbit/s management channel (or data extension channel) and the CL channel presents a bit rate of 4 kbit/s. The remaining 12 kbit/s are used for the frame alignment word. The line symbol rate (modulation rate) is 80 kbauds.
Standard: V.300
output: The line symbol rate for a system with a gross bit rate of 160 kbit/s using 2B1Q encoding is 80 kbauds. This is because 2B1Q encoding represents 2 bits per symbol, effectively halving the required symbol rate compared to the bit rate.

instruction: What is the frame offset between slave TU and master TU during synchronization?
input:
Source: The slave TU synchronizes transmitted frames with received frames from the master TU. Transmitted frames are offset with respect to received frames by 60 ± 2 quaternary symbols (i.e. about 0.75 ms).
Standard: V.300
output: The frame offset between slave TU and master TU during synchronization is 60 ± 2 quaternary symbols, which is approximately 0.75 ms.

instruction: What is the purpose of the activation bit in the 2B1Q multiframe technique?
input:
Source: act Activation bit (set to ONE during activation to indicate readiness for layer 2 communication progress)
Standard: V.300
output: The activation bit is set to ONE during activation to indicate readiness for layer 2 communication progress.

instruction: What are the functions of the CL channel in a transmission unit?
input:
Source: Functions of the CL channel listed below are based on bit allocation for the multiframe defined in Figure III.5: – Error monitoring function (crc bits). – Far-end block error (febe bit). – Activation (act). – Deactivation (dea). – Power status of slave TU (ps1, ps2). – Slave TU test mode indicator (ntm); its use is optional. It may be used by the slave TU to indicate that a maintenance action has been locally initiated by the corresponding DTE. – Alarm indicator bit (aib); its use is optional. It can be used by the master TU to indicate a failure of intermediate transmission system. – Embedded operation channel functions (eoc). Functions provided are essentially 144 kbit/s signal (2B+D) loopbacks, 64 kbit/s signals (B1 and B2) loopbacks in the slave TU (type-2 loopback) or in regenerator (loopback 1A) if required. Only the master TU is permitted to control loopbacks this way. 64 eoc message codes have been reserved for standard applications or for internal network use. Other codes may be used for non-standard applications such as supporting DCE management functions. At least 120 codes are available for this purpose. Any use of such messages shall not interfere with the 16 kbit/s management channel when provided.
Standard: V.300
output: The CL channel in a transmission unit performs several functions including error monitoring through CRC bits, far-end block error indication via the febe bit, activation (act) and deactivation (dea) commands, power status indication of the slave TU (ps1, ps2), and an optional slave TU test mode indicator (ntm). Additionally, it can optionally include an alarm indicator bit (aib) to signal intermediate transmission system failures. The channel also supports embedded operation channel (eoc) functions, enabling loopbacks of 144 kbit/s signals (2B+D) and 64 kbit/s signals (B1 and B2) in the slave TU or regenerator, with control exclusively by the master TU. It reserves 64 eoc message codes for standard applications and allows at least 120 codes for non-standard applications, ensuring they do not interfere with the 16 kbit/s management channel when present.

instruction: What are the specific functions of the equipment management function when a TU is working in slave mode?
input:
Source: Equipment management function: 
– manages the procedure of activation for the line transmission system initiated by the master 
TU; 
– generates loopback confirmation. 
Optionally, where the equipment management function of a slave TU detects a loop command 
coming from the control interface or from the interchange circuits of the user interface or from the DCE management channel, it communicates this test mode status to the master TU by setting the ntm bit to binary ZERO.
Standard: V.300
output: The specific functions include managing the activation procedure for the line transmission system initiated by the master TU and generating loopback confirmation. Optionally, it can detect a loop command from various interfaces and communicate this test mode status to the master TU by setting the ntm bit to binary ZERO.

instruction: What is the carrier frequency and its tolerance for a 4800 bits per second modem with manual equalizer?
input:
Source: 2.1 The carrier frequency is to be 1800 ± 1 Hz. No separate pilot frequencies are provided. The power levels used will conform to Recommendation V.2.
Standard: V.27
output: The carrier frequency is 1800 Hz with a tolerance of ±1 Hz.

instruction: What are the characteristic frequencies and modulation rate for a backward channel as specified in ?
input:
Source: The modulation rate, characteristic frequencies, tolerances, etc. to be as recommended for backward channel in Recommendation V.23. This does not preclude the use of a higher speed backward channel with operational capability of 75 bauds or higher, bearing the same characteristic frequencies as the V.23 backward channel.
Standard: V.27
output: The characteristic frequencies and modulation rate for a backward channel are as recommended for the backward channel in V.23, with the possibility of using a higher speed backward channel operating at 75 bauds or higher, maintaining the same characteristic frequencies as the V.23 backward channel.

instruction: What are the threshold levels and response times for circuit 109 in data communication equipment?
input:
Source: A fall in level of the incoming line signal to -31 dBm or lower for more than 10 ± 5 ms will cause circuit 109 to be turned OFF. An increase in level to -26 ± 1 dBm or higher will turn this circuit ON after a delay of: a) 13 ± 3 ms for fast operations, b) 100 ms to 1200 ms for slow operation, where the choice of the delay for slow operation depends upon the application. Delays within the range of b) may be provided for 4-wire full-duplex continuous carrier operation.
Standard: V.27
output: Circuit 109 is turned OFF when the incoming line signal level falls to -31 dBm or lower for more than 10 ± 5 ms. It is turned ON when the signal level increases to -26 ± 1 dBm or higher, with a delay of 13 ± 3 ms for fast operation or 100 ms to 1200 ms for slow operation. The choice of delay for slow operation depends on the application.

instruction: What are the optional response times between the OFF to ON transition of circuit 105 and the OFF to ON transition of circuit 106?
input:
Source: The time between the OFF to ON transition of circuit 105 and the OFF to ON transition of circuit 106 shall be optionally 20 ± 3 ms or 50 ± 20 ms.
Standard: V.27
output: The optional response times are 20 ± 3 ms or 50 ± 20 ms.

instruction: What is the generating polynomial used in the self-synchronizing scrambler/descrambler for the specified modem?
input:
Source: A self-synchronizing scrambler/descrambler having the generating polynomial: 1 + x-6 + x-7 with additional guards against repeating patterns of 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9 and 12 bits, shall be included in the modem.
Standard: V.27
output: The generating polynomial used is 1 + x^-6 + x^-7, which includes additional guards against repeating patterns of 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, and 12 bits.

instruction: What is the generating polynomial used in the scrambling process described?
input:
Source: The message polynomial is divided by the generating polynomial 1 + x-6 + x-7.
Standard: V.27
output: The generating polynomial used in the scrambling process is 1 + x^-6 + x^-7. This polynomial is applied to divide the message polynomial, and the coefficients of the quotient from this division are taken in descending order to form the transmitted data sequence.

instruction: What are the key characteristics of a generator in an interchange circuit?
output: The key characteristics of a generator in an interchange circuit include resistance and d.c. offset voltage, static reference measurements, and dynamic voltage balance and rise time measurements. These parameters ensure the generator meets the required specifications for proper circuit operation.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics of a balanced differential signalling interchange circuit operating at data signalling rates up to 10 Mbit/s?
input:
Source: This Recommendation deals with the electrical characteristics of the generator, receiver and interconnecting leads of a differential signalling (balanced) interchange circuit with an optional d.c. offset voltage. The balanced generator and load components are designed to cause minimum mutual interference with adjacent balanced or unbalanced interchange circuits (see Recommendation V.10) provided that waveshaping is employed on theunbalanced circuits. In the context of this Recommendation, a balanced interchange circuit is defined as consisting of a balanced generator connected by a balanced interconnecting pair to a balanced receiver. For a balanced generator, the algebraic sum of both the outlet potentials, with respect to earth, shall be constant for all signals transmitted; the impedances of the outlets with respect to earth shall be equal. The degree of balance and other essential parameters of the interconnecting pair is a matter for further study. The electrical characteristics specified in this Recommendation apply to interchange circuits operating with data signalling rates up to 10 Mbit/s.
Standard: V.11
output: The electrical characteristics include a balanced generator and load components designed to minimize mutual interference with adjacent circuits, whether balanced or unbalanced, especially when waveshaping is used on unbalanced circuits. The circuit consists of a balanced generator connected by a balanced interconnecting pair to a balanced receiver. For the generator, the algebraic sum of both outlet potentials with respect to earth must remain constant for all transmitted signals, and the impedances of the outlets with respect to earth must be equal. The interconnecting pair's degree of balance and other essential parameters are subjects for further study. These characteristics are suitable for data signalling rates up to 10 Mbit/s.

instruction: What are the signal conditions for the generator in terms of voltage between output points A and B?
input:
Source: When the signal condition 0 (space) for data circuits or ON for control and timing circuits is transmitted, the output point A is positive with respect to point B. When the signal condition 1 (mark) for data circuits or OFF for control and timing circuits is transmitted, the output point A is negative with respect to point B.
Standard: V.11
output: When the signal condition 0 (space) for data circuits or ON for control and timing circuits is transmitted, the output point A is positive with respect to point B. When the signal condition 1 (mark) for data circuits or OFF for control and timing circuits is transmitted, the output point A is negative with respect to point B.

instruction: What are the recommended solutions to alleviate reflections experienced on balanced interchange circuits?
input:
Source: In the event that reflections are experienced on V.11 circuits, either the use of a terminating network at the receiver (in the range of 120 to 126 ohms) or the use of series resistors (approximately 33 ohms) added to the generator output leads, should alleviate this problem. This latter solution has the additional benefit of providing protection from over-voltages but creates a problem with meeting the Test-termination measurement specified in 5.2.2.
Standard: V.11
output: To alleviate reflections on balanced interchange circuits, either a terminating network at the receiver with an impedance in the range of 120 to 126 ohms can be used, or series resistors of approximately 33 ohms can be added to the generator output leads. The latter solution also provides protection from over-voltages but may create issues with meeting specific test-termination measurements.

instruction: What are the differential significant levels for a receiver in a data communication interface?
input:
Source: VA′ – VB′ ≤ –0.3 V VA′ – VB′ ≥ +0.3 V
Data circuits 1 0
Control and timing circuits OFF ON
Standard: V.11
output: The differential significant levels for a receiver are defined such that for data circuits, a binary '1' is represented when VA′ – VB′ ≤ –0.3 V, and a binary '0' is represented when VA′ – VB′ ≥ +0.3 V. For control and timing circuits, 'OFF' corresponds to VA′ – VB′ ≤ –0.3 V, and 'ON' corresponds to VA′ – VB′ ≥ +0.3 V.

instruction: What is the maximum allowable current through output points A or B when short-circuited to point C in both binary states?
input:
Source: With the output points A and B short-circuited to point C, the current flowing through each of the output points A or B in both binary states shall not exceed 150 milliamperes.
Standard: V.11
output: The current flowing through each of the output points A or B when short-circuited to point C in both binary states shall not exceed 150 milliamperes.

instruction: What are the requirements for the output signal transition characteristics when testing with a nominal signal element duration tb?
input:
Source: The change in amplitude of the output signal during transitions from one binary state to the other shall be monotonic between 0.1 and 0.9 Vss within 0.1 of tb or 20 nanoseconds, whichever is greater. Thereafter the signal voltage shall not vary more than 10% of Vss from the steady state value.
Standard: V.11
output: The output signal transition must be monotonic between 0.1 and 0.9 Vss within 0.1 of tb or 20 nanoseconds, whichever is greater. After this transition, the signal voltage must not vary more than 10% of Vss from the steady state value.

instruction: What are the voltage and current requirements for receiver input measurements when one input is held at 0 volt and the other ranges between -10 volts and +10 volts?
input:
Source: With the voltage Via (or Vib) ranging between –10 volts and +10 volts, while Vib (or Via) is held at 0 volt, the resultant input current Iia (or Iib) shall remain within the shaded range shown in Figure 6. These measurements apply with the power supply of the receiver in both the power-on and power-off conditions.
Standard: V.11
output: When one receiver input (Via or Vib) is held at 0 volt and the other input ranges between -10 volts and +10 volts, the resultant input current (Iia or Iib) must remain within the range of -3.25 mA to +3.25 mA. These measurements are applicable with the receiver's power supply in both power-on and power-off conditions.

instruction: What are the requirements for a receiver's differential input voltage and common mode voltage range in a balanced transmission system?
input:
Source: Over the entire common mode voltage ( Vcm) range of +7 volts to –7 volts, the receiver shall not require a differential input voltage ( Vi) of more than 300 millivolts to assume correctly the intended binary state. Reversing the polarity of Vi shall cause the receiver to assume the opposite binary state. The maximum voltage (signal plus common mode) present between either receiver input and receiver ground shall not exceed 10 volts nor cause the receiver to malfunction. The receiver shall tolerate a maximum differential voltage of12 volts applied across its input terminals without being damaged.
Standard: V.11
output: In a balanced transmission system, the receiver must not require a differential input voltage (Vi) of more than 300 millivolts to correctly assume the intended binary state over a common mode voltage (Vcm) range of +7 volts to -7 volts. Reversing the polarity of Vi should cause the receiver to assume the opposite binary state. The maximum voltage (signal plus common mode) between either receiver input and receiver ground must not exceed 10 volts or cause malfunction. Additionally, the receiver must tolerate a maximum differential voltage of 12 volts across its input terminals without damage.

instruction: What are the environmental constraints for operating a balanced interchange circuit at data signalling rates between 0 and 10 Mbit/s?
input:
Source: In order to operate a balanced interchange circuit at data signalling rates ranging between 0 and 10 Mbit/s, the following conditions apply: 1) For each interchange circuit a balanced interconnecting pair is required.2) Each interchange circuit must be appropriately terminated (see Appendix I).3) The total common-mode voltage at the receiver must be less than 7 volts peak. The common mode voltage at the receiver is the worst case combination of: a) generator-receiver ground-potential difference ( V g, Figure 2); b) longitudinally induced random noise voltage measured between the receiver points A ′ or B′ and C′ with the generator ends of the cable A, B and C joined together; and c) generator d.c. offset voltage, if any. Unless the generator is of a type which generates no d.c. offset voltage, the sum of a) and b) above, which is the element of the common mode voltage due to the environment of the interchange circuit, must be less than 4 volts peak.
Standard: V.11
output: For operating a balanced interchange circuit at data signalling rates between 0 and 10 Mbit/s, the following conditions must be met: 1) Each interchange circuit requires a balanced interconnecting pair. 2) Each interchange circuit must be appropriately terminated. 3) The total common-mode voltage at the receiver must be less than 7 volts peak. The common mode voltage is the worst case combination of generator-receiver ground-potential difference, longitudinally induced random noise voltage, and generator d.c. offset voltage, if any. If the generator produces a d.c. offset voltage, the sum of the ground-potential difference and the induced noise voltage must be less than 4 volts peak.

instruction: What are the different types of fault condition interpretations by a receiver or load in data communication interfaces?
input:
Source: 10 Recommendation V.11     (10/96)The interpretation of a fault condition by a receiver (or load) is application dependent. Each application may use a combination of the following classification: •Type 0 – No interpretation. A receiver or load does not have fault detection capability. •Type 1 – Data circuits assume a binary 1 state. Control and timing circuits assume an OFF condition. •Type 2 – Data circuits assume binary 0 state. Control and timing circuits assume an ON condition. •Type 3 – Special interpretation. The receiver or load provides a special indication for interpreting a fault condition. This special indication requires further study.
Standard: V.11
output: In data communication interfaces, fault condition interpretations by a receiver or load are classified into four types: Type 0 – No interpretation, where the receiver or load lacks fault detection capability; Type 1 – Data circuits assume a binary 1 state, and control and timing circuits assume an OFF condition; Type 2 – Data circuits assume a binary 0 state, and control and timing circuits assume an ON condition; Type 3 – Special interpretation, where the receiver or load provides a unique indication for fault conditions, requiring further study.

instruction: What are the key electrical characteristics that should be matched between the two conductors of an interconnecting cable for optimal performance?
input:
Source: Over the length of the cable, the two conductors should have essentially the same values of: 1) capacitance to ground;2) longitudinal resistance and inductance;3) coupling to adjacent cables and circuits.
Standard: V.11
output: The two conductors of an interconnecting cable should have essentially the same values of capacitance to ground, longitudinal resistance and inductance, and coupling to adjacent cables and circuits to ensure optimal performance.

instruction: What are the key factors that determine cable length limitations in balanced interchange circuits?
input:
Source: These curves are based upon empirical data using twisted pair telephone cable (0.51-mm wire diameter) both unterminated and terminated in a 100-ohm resistive load. The cable length restrictions shown by the curves are based upon the following assumed signal quality requirements at the load: 1) signal rise and fall time equal to, or less than, one-half the duration of the signal element; 2) a maximum voltage loss between generator and load of 6 dB. At the higher data signalling rates (see Figure I.1), the sloping portion of the curves shows the cable length limitation established by the assumed signal rise and fall time requirements. The cable length has been arbitrarily limited to 1000 metres by the assumed maximum allowable loss of 6 dB.
Standard: V.11
output: The cable length limitations in balanced interchange circuits are primarily determined by signal quality requirements, including signal rise and fall times, and maximum voltage loss. Specifically, the signal rise and fall times must be equal to or less than one-half the duration of the signal element, and the maximum voltage loss between the generator and load should not exceed 6 dB. These requirements lead to different cable length restrictions for terminated (Curve 1) and unterminated (Curve 2) interchange circuits, especially at higher data signalling rates where cable imperfections and common-mode noise become significant. Additionally, the cable length is arbitrarily limited to 1000 meters to adhere to the 6 dB loss limit.

instruction: Under what conditions should a cable termination resistance be used in data signaling?
input:
Source: The use of a cable termination resistance ( Zt) is optional and dependent on the specific application. At the higher data signalling rates (above 200 kbit/s) or at any data signalling rate where the cable propagation delay is of the order of halfthe signal element duration, a termination should be used to preserve the signal rise time and minimize reflections. Theterminating impedance should match as closely as possible the cable characteristic impedance in the signal spectrum. Generally, a resistance in the range of 100 to 150 ohms will be satisfactory, the higher values leading to lower power dissipation. At the lower data signalling rates, where distortion and rise-time are not critical, it may be desirable to omit the termination in order to minimize power dissipation in the generator.
Standard: V.11
output: A cable termination resistance should be used at higher data signaling rates (above 200 kbit/s) or at any data signaling rate where the cable propagation delay is approximately half the signal element duration. This helps preserve the signal rise time and minimize reflections. The terminating impedance should closely match the cable characteristic impedance in the signal spectrum, typically within the range of 100 to 150 ohms, with higher values reducing power dissipation. At lower data signaling rates where distortion and rise-time are less critical, termination may be omitted to minimize power dissipation in the generator.

instruction: What are the provisional maximum degrees of individual distortion for channels using and modems?
input:
Source: Channel with modem V.21:20-25% Channels with modem V.23: 600 bauds - leased circuits: 20-30% 1200 bauds - leased circuits: 25-35%600 bauds - switched circuit: 25-30%1200 bauds - switched circuit: 30-35%
Standard: V.50
output: For channels with modem V.21, the provisional maximum degree of individual distortion is 20-25%. For channels with modem V.23, the distortion limits vary by baud rate and circuit type: 600 bauds on leased circuits have a limit of 20-30%, 1200 bauds on leased circuits 25-35%, 600 bauds on switched circuits 25-30%, and 1200 bauds on switched circuits 30-35%.

instruction: What is the duration of the continuous answering tone sent by an answering modem after connection to the line?
input:
Source: 1.8 to 2.5 s after the answering modem is connected to the line (i.e. circuits 125 and 108 are ON), it sends a continuous answering tone for a duration of not more than 4.0 s.
Standard: V.25
output: The answering modem sends a continuous answering tone for a duration of not more than 4.0 seconds after being connected to the line, which occurs 1.8 to 2.5 seconds after circuits 125 and 108 are ON.

instruction: What are the modulation rates and characteristic frequencies for the forward data-transmission channel in a 600/1200-baud modem?
input:
Source: Modulation rates and characteristic frequencies for the forward data-transmission channel F 0 FZ FA (symbol 1, symbol 0, mark) space) Mode 1: up to 600 bauds 1500 Hz 1300 Hz 1700 HzMode 2: up to 1200 bauds 1700 Hz 1300 Hz 2100 Hz
Standard: V.23
output: For a 600/1200-baud modem, the modulation rates and characteristic frequencies for the forward data-transmission channel are as follows: In Mode 1 (up to 600 bauds), the frequencies are 1500 Hz for symbol 1 (mark), 1300 Hz for symbol 0 (space), and 1700 Hz for the alternate frequency. In Mode 2 (up to 1200 bauds), the frequencies are 1700 Hz for symbol 1 (mark), 1300 Hz for symbol 0 (space), and 2100 Hz for the alternate frequency.

instruction: What are the modulation rate and characteristic frequencies for the backward channel in a VF telegraph-type channel?
input:
Source: The modulation rate and characteristic frequencies for the backward channel are as follows: FZ FA (symbol 1, (symbol 0, mark) space) Modulation rate up to 75 bauds 390 Hz 450 Hz In the absence of any signal on the backward channel interface, the condition Z signal is to be transmitted.
Standard: V.23
output: The modulation rate for the backward channel is up to 75 bauds. The characteristic frequencies are 390 Hz for symbol 1 (mark) and 450 Hz for symbol 0 (space). In the absence of any signal on the backward channel interface, the condition Z signal is to be transmitted.

instruction: What are the response times for circuits 109 and 122 in modem operations?
input:
Source: 8.3.1.1 Circuits 109 and 122 response times are the times that elapse between the connection or removal of a tone to or from the modem receive line terminals and the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuits 109and 122. The test tone should have a frequency corresponding to the characteristic frequency of binary 1 and be derived from a source with an impedance equal to the nominal input impedance of the modem. The level of the test tone should fall within the level range between 3 dB above the actual threshold of the received line signal detector and the maximum admissible level of the received signal. At all levels within this range the measured response times shall be within the specified limits.
Standard: V.23
output: The response times for circuits 109 and 122 are defined as the durations between the application or removal of a tone to the modem's receive line terminals and the corresponding ON or OFF condition appearing on these circuits. The test tone used must match the frequency characteristic of binary 1 and originate from a source with an impedance equal to the modem's nominal input impedance. The tone's level should be within 3 dB above the actual threshold of the received line signal detector up to the maximum admissible received signal level. Across this level range, the measured response times must adhere to specified limits.

instruction: What are the functions of interchange circuits 102 and 103 in a data communication system?
input:
Source: 102 Signal ground or common return, 103 Transmitted data
Standard: V.23
output: Interchange circuit 102 is designated as 'Signal ground or common return', which provides a common reference point for electrical signals to ensure proper voltage levels and signal integrity. Interchange circuit 103 is designated as 'Transmitted data', which carries data signals from the data terminal equipment (DTE) to the data circuit-terminating equipment (DCE) for transmission over the communication channel.

instruction: What are the response time dependencies for circuit 106 in a data communication system?
input:
Source: Circuit 106 response times are from the connection of an ON or OFF condition on: - circuit 105 (where it is provided) to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106; - circuit 122 (where circuit 105 is not provided) to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106 in a configuration having a single data channel together with a single backward channel only; - circuit 107 (where circuits 105 and 122 are not provided) to the appearance of the corresponding ON or OFF condition on circuit 106;
Standard: V.23
output: The response times for circuit 106 depend on the connection of an ON or OFF condition on: circuit 105 (if provided) leading to the corresponding condition on circuit 106; circuit 122 (in absence of circuit 105) leading to the corresponding condition on circuit 106 in systems with a single data channel and a single backward channel; or circuit 107 (when neither circuit 105 nor 122 is provided) leading to the corresponding condition on circuit 106.

instruction: What are the response time ranges for the transition from OFF to ON and ON to OFF for circuit 106?
input:
Source: TABLE 3/V.23 Circuit 106 OFF to ON ON to OFF750 ms to 1400 ms (see Note 1) a) 20 ms to 40 ms (see Note 2) b) 200 ms to 275 ms (see Note 2)
Standard: V.23
output: The response time for circuit 106 transitioning from OFF to ON is between 750 ms to 1400 ms, and from ON to OFF, it is between 20 ms to 40 ms when no protection is given against line echoes, and between 200 ms to 275 ms when protection is given against line echoes.

instruction: What are the conditions for clamping circuits in half-duplex mode on a 2-wire line?
input:
Source: The DCE, when operating in half-duplex mode on a 2-wire line, shall hold, where implemented: i) circuit 104 in the binary 1 condition and circuit 109 in the OFF condition when circuit 105 is in the ON condition and, where required to protect circuit 104 from false signals, for a period of 150 ± 25milliseconds following the ON to OFF transition on circuit 105. The use of this additional delay isoptional, based on system considerations; ii) circuit 119 in the binary 1 condition and circuit 122 in the OFF condition when circuit 120 is in the ON condition and, where required to protect circuit 119 from false signals, for a time interval following theON to OFF transition on circuit 120. The specific duration of this time interval is left for further study.The additional delay is optional, based on system considerations.
Standard: V.23
output: In half-duplex mode on a 2-wire line, the DCE shall hold circuit 104 in the binary 1 condition and circuit 109 in the OFF condition when circuit 105 is in the ON condition. Additionally, to protect circuit 104 from false signals, it may hold these conditions for a period of 150 ± 25 milliseconds following the ON to OFF transition on circuit 105, though this delay is optional based on system considerations. Similarly, circuit 119 should be held in the binary 1 condition and circuit 122 in the OFF condition when circuit 120 is in the ON condition. An optional delay may also be applied following the ON to OFF transition on circuit 120 to protect circuit 119 from false signals, with the specific duration of this delay left for further study.

instruction: What is the purpose of transmitting a synchronizing pattern consisting of alternate binary 0 and binary 1 at clock rate in a modem?
input:
Source: If such a clock is included in the modem, a synchronizing pattern consisting of alternate binary 0 and binary 1 at clock rate should be transmitted for the whole interval between the OFF to ON transitions of interchange circuits 105and 106. Users should note that part of this synchronizing pattern may appear at the distant receiver on circuit 104 afterthe OFF to ON transition of circuit 109. The data terminal equipment should make provision to differentiate betweenthese false signals and true data.
Standard: V.23
output: The purpose of transmitting a synchronizing pattern consisting of alternate binary 0 and binary 1 at clock rate in a modem is to ensure synchronization between the transmitting and receiving ends during the interval between the OFF to ON transitions of interchange circuits 105 and 106. This pattern helps the distant receiver on circuit 104 to differentiate between false signals and true data after the OFF to ON transition of circuit 109.

instruction: What is the recommended data signalling rate for international use in synchronous data transmission between customers on leased circuits?
input:
Source: The recommended data signalling rate (equals the customer signalling rate) for international use is synchronous at 48 kbit/s.
Standard: V.36
output: The recommended data signalling rate for international use in synchronous data transmission between customers on leased circuits is 48 kbit/s.

instruction: What are the recommended data signalling rates for international use and certain national applications?
input:
Source: The recommended data signalling rate (equals the customer signalling rate) for international use is synchronous at 48 kbit/s. For certain national applications or with bilateral agreement between Administrations the data signalling rate of 56 kbit/s is applicable. The recommended data signalling rate is synchronous at 64 kbit/s.
Standard: V.36
output: The recommended data signalling rate for international use is synchronous at 48 kbit/s. For certain national applications or with bilateral agreement between Administrations, the data signalling rate of 56 kbit/s is applicable. Additionally, another recommended data signalling rate is synchronous at 64 kbit/s.

instruction: What is the relationship between binary signals and transmitted line signal states in amplitude modulation?
input:
Source: The relationship between the binary signals at the real or hypothetical output of the scrambler and the transmitted line signal states shall be in accordance with the amplitude modulation case of Recommendation V.1, i.e.,tone ON for binary 1 and tone OFF for binary 0. In a practical case this means that the voltage or no voltage conditions which will result from the full wave rectification of the demodulated line signal will correspond with the binary 1 and binary 0 signals respectively at theoutput of the scrambler.
Standard: V.36
output: In amplitude modulation, the binary signals at the output of the scrambler correspond to the transmitted line signal states such that a tone ON represents binary 1 and tone OFF represents binary 0. This results in voltage or no voltage conditions after full wave rectification of the demodulated line signal, matching the binary 1 and 0 signals respectively at the scrambler's output.

instruction: What are the level limitations for frequencies applied to the transmit input terminals at -15 dBm0 in different bands?
input:
Source: The transmit filter shall be such that any frequency applied to the transmit input terminals at a level of -15 dBm0 will not cause a level exceeding: a) -73 dBm0p in the adjacent group,b)-61 dBm0 in the vicinity (± 25 Hz) of the pilot 104.08 kHz, c) -55 dBm0 in the data band between 64 and 101 kHz,d) the values specified in Recommendation Q.414 [7] to protect the nearest low level signalling path.
Standard: V.36
output: For frequencies applied to the transmit input terminals at a level of -15 dBm0, the level must not exceed: a) -73 dBm0p in the adjacent group, b) -61 dBm0 in the vicinity (± 25 Hz) of the pilot 104.08 kHz, c) -55 dBm0 in the data band between 64 and 101 kHz. Additionally, the values specified to protect the nearest low level signalling path must not be exceeded.

instruction: What are the threshold levels for circuit 109 to turn ON and OFF?
input:
Source: For a data line signal level greater than -13 dBm0, circuit 109 is ON. For data line signal level less than -18 dBm0, circuit 109 is OFF. Note - The corresponding levels for the pilot carrier are -22 dBm0 and -27 dBm0 respectively. The condition of circuit 109 for levels between the above levels is not specified, except that the signal detector shall exhibit a hysteresis action such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs is at least 2 dB greaterthan that for the ON to OFF transition.
Standard: V.36
output: Circuit 109 turns ON when the data line signal level is greater than -13 dBm0 and turns OFF when the level is less than -18 dBm0. For the pilot carrier, these thresholds are -22 dBm0 and -27 dBm0 respectively. The detector must exhibit hysteresis, with the OFF to ON transition occurring at least 2 dB higher than the ON to OFF transition.

instruction: What is an applied data bit in the context of a scrambler process?
input:
Source: The data bit which has been applied to the scrambler but has not affected the transmission at the time of consideration.
Standard: V.36
output: An applied data bit refers to the data bit that has been input into the scrambler but has not yet influenced the transmission at the moment of consideration. It is part of the scrambling process where data bits are transformed before transmission to ensure signal integrity and reduce the likelihood of repetitive patterns that could interfere with transmission quality.

instruction: What is the condition for an adverse state to be apparent in the scrambling process?
input:
Source: An adverse state shall be apparent only if the binary values of the p-th and (p+8)th earlier transmitted bits have not differed from one another when p represents all the integers from 1 to q inclusive. The value of q shall be such that, for p = (q+1), the p-th and (p+8)-th earlier transmitted bits had opposite binary values and q = (31 + 32 r), r being 0 or any positive integer.
Standard: V.36
output: An adverse state is apparent if the binary values of the p-th and (p+8)-th earlier transmitted bits have not differed from one another for all integers p from 1 to q inclusive, where q is such that for p = (q+1), the p-th and (p+8)-th earlier transmitted bits had opposite binary values, and q = (31 + 32 r), with r being 0 or any positive integer.

instruction: What are the key components required for the transmission of wide-spectrum signals on wideband group links?
input:
Source: CCITT Recommendation Transmission of wide-spectrum signals (data, facsimile, etc.) on wideband group links, Vol. III, Rec. H.52.
Standard: V.36
output: The transmission of wide-spectrum signals on wideband group links requires several key components, including signal receivers for manual working, multifrequency signal senders, and multifrequency signal receiving equipment. Additionally, the sending and receiving parts of the multifrequency signalling equipment are essential for proper signal transmission and reception.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of a modem designed for 4800 bits per second transmission over the general switched telephone network?
input:
Source: a) Use of data signalling rate of 4800 bits per second with 8-phase differentially encoded modulation as described in Recommendation V.27. b) Reduced rate capability at 2400 bits per second with 4-phase differentially encoded modulation as described in Recommendation V.26, Alternative A. c) Provision for a backward channel at modulation rates up to 75 bauds, use of this channel being optional.d) Inclusion of an automatic adaptive equalizer.
Standard: V.27
output: The principal characteristics include: a) Use of a data signalling rate of 4800 bits per second with 8-phase differentially encoded modulation. b) Reduced rate capability at 2400 bits per second with 4-phase differentially encoded modulation. c) Optional provision for a backward channel at modulation rates up to 75 bauds. d) Inclusion of an automatic adaptive equalizer.

instruction: What is the required attenuation for the energy density at 1200 Hz and 2400 Hz in a system operating at 2400 bits per second with raised cosine energy spectrum shaping?
input:
Source: The energy density at 1200 Hz and 2400 Hz shall be attenuated 3.0 dB ± 2.0 dB with respect to the maximum energy density between 1200 Hz and 2400 Hz.
Standard: V.27
output: The energy density at 1200 Hz and 2400 Hz must be attenuated 3.0 dB ± 2.0 dB with respect to the maximum energy density between 1200 Hz and 2400 Hz.

instruction: What are the phase changes corresponding to dibit values 00 and 01 in a modem's signaling system?
input:
Source: Dibit values Phase change (see Note)
00
011110    0°
  90°180°270°
Note - The phase change is the actual on-line phase shift in
the transition region from the centre of one signalling element
to the centre of the following signalling element.
Standard: V.27
output: For dibit value 00, the phase change is 0°. For dibit value 01, the phase change is 90°. These phase changes represent the actual on-line phase shift during the transition from the center of one signaling element to the center of the following signaling element.

instruction: What are the phase changes and corresponding PRS bits for 4800 bit/s data speed in Segment 4?
output: For 4800 bit/s data speed in Segment 4, the phase changes are 0°, 180°, 180°, 180°, 180°, 180°, 0°, and so on, ending with 180°, 180°, 0°, 0°. The corresponding PRS bits are 011, 101, 101, 100, 100, 101, 001, and so on, ending with 110, 100, 010, 001.

instruction: What are the time segments and their durations in a Turn-OFF sequence for a modem?
input:
Source: Segment A Segment B Total
Turn-OFF time
Type of line signals Remaining data followed by
continous scrambled ONEsNo transmitted energy Total of Segments A and B
With or without
protection against talkerecho5 ms to 10 ms 20 ms 25 ms to 30 ms
Standard: V.27
output: The Turn-OFF sequence consists of two segments: Segment A and Segment B. Segment A has a duration of 5 ms to 10 ms, during which remaining data followed by continuous scrambled ONEs is transmitted with or without protection against talker echo. Segment B lasts for 20 ms, during which no energy is transmitted. The total duration of the Turn-OFF sequence, combining both segments, ranges from 25 ms to 30 ms.

instruction: What are the response times for circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON state with protection against talker echo at 4800 bits per second?
input:
Source: OFF to ON a) 215 ± 10 ms +   50 ms
b) 215 ± 10ms + 708 msa)   50 ms
b) 708 ms
Standard: V.27
output: The response times for circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON state with protection against talker echo at 4800 bits per second are 215 ± 10 ms plus an additional 50 ms or 708 ms, depending on the specific condition.

instruction: What are the response times for Circuit 106 when transitioning from OFF to ON with and without protection against talker echo?
input:
Source: OFF to ON a) 215 ± 10 ms +   67 ms b) 215 ± 10 ms + 944 msa)   67 ms b) 944 ms
Standard: V.27
output: For Circuit 106 transitioning from OFF to ON with protection against talker echo, the response times are 215 ± 10 ms plus 67 ms for sequence a) and 215 ± 10 ms plus 944 ms for sequence b). Without protection against talker echo, the response times are 67 ms for sequence a) and 944 ms for sequence b).

instruction: What is the purpose of the additional delay period of 150 ± 25 ms following the ON to OFF transition on circuit 105?
input:
Source: condition and, where required to protect circuit 104 from false signals, for a period of 150 ± 25 ms following the ON to OFF transition on circuit 105; the use of this additional delay is optional, based on system considerations;
Standard: V.27
output: The additional delay period of 150 ± 25 ms following the ON to OFF transition on circuit 105 is implemented to protect circuit 104 from false signals. This delay is optional and its use depends on specific system considerations.

instruction: What is the purpose of the scrambler in a data modem transmitter and receiver?
input:
Source: At the transmitter the scrambler shall effectively divide the message polynomial, of which the input data sequence represents the coefficients in descending order, by the scrambler generating polynomial to generate the transmitted sequence, and at the receiver the received polynomial, of which the received data sequence represents the coefficients in descending order, shall be multiplied by the scrambler generating polynomial to recover the message sequence.
Standard: V.27
output: The scrambler in a data modem transmitter divides the message polynomial, represented by the input data sequence coefficients in descending order, by the scrambler generating polynomial to generate the transmitted sequence. At the receiver, the received polynomial, represented by the received data sequence coefficients in descending order, is multiplied by the scrambler generating polynomial to recover the original message sequence.

instruction: What are the clock frequencies for segments 4 and 5 in a scrambler?
input:
Source: Clock H 3600 Hz 2400 Hz
Clock M 1200 Hz 1200 Hz
Note 3 - H is 3 times baud rate clock.
Note 4 - M is baud rate clock (1600 Hz).
Standard: V.27
output: In a V.27 scrambler, the clock frequency for segment 4 is 3600 Hz (H) and 1200 Hz (M), and for segment 5, it is 2400 Hz (H) and 1200 Hz (M). The H clock is 3 times the baud rate clock, and the M clock is equal to the baud rate clock, which is 1600 Hz.

instruction: What are the handshaking procedures proposed for interconnection between public data networks and public switched telephone networks?
input:
Source: According to the type of modem (see Table 1/V.100), a half-duplex or a duplex procedure is used. 1.1 Half-duplex procedure See Figure 1/V.100. 1.1.1 Answer mode modem a) Following the transmission of the answer sequence in accordance with Recommendation V.25, the modem shall apply an ON condition to circuit 107, and then transmit a segment S1 in accordance withTable 1/V.100 for 294 ms. Interchange circuits 106 and 109 are in the OFF condition during theprocedure. b) The modem remains silent until it detects S2 (defined in Table 1/V.100) or the synchronizing signals of a V.27 ter modem in the fallback mode. c) Then the modem conditions itself to the selected mode or disconnects. If no response is detected within 2 seconds following the end of the S1 transmission, the modem resumes transmitting S1.
Standard: V.100
output: The handshaking procedures proposed include both half-duplex and full-duplex procedures, depending on the type of modem used. For half-duplex modems, the procedure involves the transmission of a segment S1 for 294 ms following the answer sequence, with interchange circuits 106 and 109 in the OFF condition. The modem then remains silent until it detects segment S2 or synchronizing signals from a V.27 ter modem in fallback mode. If no response is detected within 2 seconds after S1 transmission ends, the modem resumes transmitting S1. For full-duplex modems, the procedure varies based on the data rate and the specific recommendation (e.g., V.21, V.22, V.22 bis, V.26 ter, V.32), with different S2 and S1 signals defined for each category and data rate.

instruction: What frequency tone does a duplex modem transmit to disable echo suppressors, and for how long?
input:
Source: the modem transmits a 2100 ± 15 Hz tone for 500 ± 50 ms to disable echosuppressors, then remains silent for 75 ± 20 ms.
Standard: V.100
output: A duplex modem transmits a 2100 ± 15 Hz tone for 500 ± 50 ms to disable echo suppressors.

instruction: What is the sequence of operations performed by a modem in answer mode following the transmission of the answer sequence?
input:
Source: a) Following the transmission of the answer sequence in accordance with Recommendation V.25, the modem shall apply an ON condition to circuit 107 (interchange circuits 106 and 109 are in the OFF condition during the procedure. b)Then, the modem transmits a segment S1 in accordance with Table 1/V.100 at least 40 ± 10 ms and until it has detected the end of transmission of S2. Note - During this period, some exchanges may occur between the two modems according to the Series V Recommendation concerned (see Recommendation V.32). If no response is detected within a time period (under study), the modem shall disconnect from line. If S2 indicates a capability not available, the modem shall disconnect from the line.If S2 indicates a capability available, the modem conditions itself to this mode.
Standard: V.100
output: After transmitting the answer sequence, the modem applies an ON condition to circuit 107 while keeping interchange circuits 106 and 109 in the OFF condition. It then transmits a segment S1 for at least 40 ± 10 ms and until it detects the end of transmission of S2. If no response is detected within a specified time period, the modem disconnects from the line. If S2 indicates a capability not available, the modem disconnects; if the capability is available, the modem conditions itself to this mode.

instruction: What are the characteristics of the S1 signal transmitted by a modem after the sequence?
input:
Source: a) After the V.25 sequence, the modem will transmit S1 which is composed of two segments S11 and S12 (as described in Appendix I to Recommendation V.32). S11 is a modulated signal transmitted during 294 ms in a 600-3000 Hz bandwidth, S12 is a tone out of the 600-3000 Hz band.
Standard: V.100
output: The S1 signal is composed of two segments: S11 and S12. S11 is a modulated signal transmitted for 294 ms within a 600-3000 Hz bandwidth. S12 is a tone that falls outside the 600-3000 Hz band.

instruction: What is the general approach for bit rate adaption of synchronous data signalling rates up to 38.4 kbit/s?
input:
Source: 5.1.1 General approach........................................................................................... 4 5.1.2 Adaption of V-series data signalling rates to the intermediate rates ............. 5
Standard: V.110
output: The general approach for bit rate adaption of synchronous data signalling rates up to 38.4 kbit/s involves converting the user data rate to one of several intermediate rates before further adapting it to the 64 kbit/s network rate. This process includes frame synchronization and may incorporate additional signalling capacity as needed.

instruction: What are the key states in the operating sequence of a TA duplex operation?
output: The key states in the operating sequence of a TA duplex operation include: 1) Idle (or ready) state, where the TA is prepared for operation but not actively connected; 2) Connect TA to line state, establishing the connection to the line; 3) Data transfer state, where actual data transmission occurs; 4) Disconnect mode, terminating the connection; and 5) Loss of frame synchronization, indicating a disruption in communication frames.

instruction: What are the typical timer values used in parameter exchange and maintenance processes?
output: Timer values for parameter exchange and maintenance processes are typically specified to ensure proper synchronization and error handling. For parameter exchange, timer values are set to manage the time allowed for exchanging parameters between devices. For maintenance, timer values are used to monitor and maintain the connection, ensuring that any issues are promptly addressed. These values are critical for the stability and reliability of the communication system.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics specified for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s?
input:
Source: ITU-T Recommendation V.10 (X.26) (1993), Electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s
Standard: V.110
output: The electrical characteristics for unbalanced double-current interchange circuits operating at data signalling rates nominally up to 100 kbit/s include specifications for voltage levels, signal timing, and circuit impedance to ensure reliable data transmission. These characteristics are designed to support interoperability between data terminal equipment (DTE) and data circuit-terminating equipment (DCE) in various communication environments.

instruction: What are the functions of RA1 and RA2 in bit rate adaptation for synchronous data signalling rates up to 38.4 kbit/s?
input:
Source: The bit rate adaption functions within the TA are shown in Figure 1. The function RA1 converts the user data signalling rate to an appropriate intermediate rate expressed by 2^k × 8 kbit/s (where k = 0, 1, 2 or 3). RA2 performs the second conversion from the intermediate rates to 64 kbit/s. The data signalling rates of 48 and 56 kbit/s are converted directly into the 64-kbit/s B-channel rate. The intermediate rate of 64 kbit/s is directly mapped into the 64-kbit/s B-channel rate.
Standard: V.110
output: RA1 converts the user data signalling rate to an appropriate intermediate rate expressed by 2^k × 8 kbit/s, where k can be 0, 1, 2, or 3. RA2 then performs the second conversion from these intermediate rates to 64 kbit/s. For data signalling rates of 48 and 56 kbit/s, they are converted directly into the 64-kbit/s B-channel rate without needing an intermediate step. The intermediate rate of 64 kbit/s is directly mapped into the 64-kbit/s B-channel rate.

instruction: What is the structure of an 80-bit frame used in the conversion of V-series data signalling rates to intermediate rates?
input:
Source: As shown in Table 2, the conversion of the V-series rates to the intermediate rates uses an 80-bit frame. The octet zero contains all binary 0, whilst octet 5 consists of a binary 1 followed by seven E bits (see 5.1.2.4). Octets 1-4 and 6-9 contain a binary 1 in bit number 1, a status bit (S- or X-bit) in bit number 8 and six data bits (D-bits) in bit positions 2-7. The order of bit transmission is from left to right and top to bottom.
Standard: V.110
output: The 80-bit frame consists of 10 octets. Octet zero contains all binary 0s, and octet 5 consists of a binary 1 followed by seven E bits (E1-E7). Octets 1-4 and 6-9 each start with a binary 1 in bit position 1, followed by six data bits (D-bits) in bit positions 2-7, and a status bit (S- or X-bit) in bit position 8. The order of bit transmission is from left to right and top to bottom.

instruction: What are the data bit assignments for adapting 7200, 14400, and 28800 bit/s rates to 16, 32, and 64 kbit/s intermediate rates respectively?
input:
Source: The adaption of 7200, 14 400 and 28 800 bit/s rates to the 16, 32 and 64 kbit/s intermediate rate, respectively, use the data bit assignments shown in Table 6d.
Standard: V.110
output: The data bit assignments for adapting 7200, 14400, and 28800 bit/s rates to 16, 32, and 64 kbit/s intermediate rates respectively are shown in Table 6d. The table includes specific bit patterns for data (D1-D36), fill bits (F), and synchronization bits (S1, S3, S4, S6, S8, S9), along with control bits (E4-E7).

instruction: What is the 17-bit alignment pattern used for frame synchronization in data communication?
input:
Source: The following 17-bit alignment pattern is used to achieve frame synchronization: 00000000 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY The bits marked 'Y' are not part of the frame alignment pattern. They carry the user data (D bits) and S and X status bits as shown in Table 2. To ensure a reliable synchronization, it is recommended that at least two 17-bit alignment patterns in consecutive frames be detected.
Standard: V.110
output: The 17-bit alignment pattern used for frame synchronization is '00000000 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY 1YYYYYYY'. The bits marked 'Y' carry user data (D bits) and S and X status bits, and are not part of the frame alignment pattern. For reliable synchronization, it is recommended that at least two 17-bit alignment patterns in consecutive frames be detected.

instruction: What are the typical states of signals S, X, and D during different phases of a B-channel connection in data transfer?
input:
Source: (S = X = OFF) (S = X = OFF) (S = X = OFF) (S = X = ON) (S = X = ON) (S = X = ON)(D = 0) (S = OFF, X = ON) (D = 0) (S = OFF, X = ON)(D = 0) (S = OFF, X = ON)
Standard: V.110
output: During different phases of a B-channel connection in data transfer, the states of signals S, X, and D vary as follows: During frame search and B-channel connection establishment, S and X are typically OFF. Upon entry to the data phase, S and X turn ON. During the data phase, S remains OFF while X is ON, and D is set to 0. For B-channel disconnection and exit from the data phase, S and X are ON. The specific states are crucial for synchronization and proper operation during data transfer phases.

instruction: What are the criteria for assuming loss of frame synchronization in a continuous monitoring process?
input:
Source: Loss of frame synchronization shall not be assumed unless at least three consecutive frames, each with at least one framing bit error, are detected.
Standard: V.110
output: Loss of frame synchronization is assumed when at least three consecutive frames, each with at least one framing bit error, are detected.

instruction: What is the frame alignment pattern for user data signalling at 48 kbit/s?
input:
Source: At the user data signalling rate of 48 kbit/s, the frame alignment pattern consists of 1011 in bit 1 of consecutive octets of one frame. To ensure reliable synchronization, it is suggested that at least five 4-bit alignment patterns in consecutive frames be detected.
Standard: V.110
output: The frame alignment pattern for user data signalling at 48 kbit/s consists of 1011 in bit 1 of consecutive octets of one frame. Reliable synchronization is suggested by detecting at least five 4-bit alignment patterns in consecutive frames.

instruction: What are the three functional blocks involved in the bit rate adaptation process for asynchronous rates up to 38,400 bit/s?
input:
Source: The bit rate adaption functions within the TA are shown in Figure 4. A three-step method is employed with the functional blocks RA0, RA1, and RA2. The RA0 function is an asynchronous-to-synchronous conversion step, for support of the rates specified in Table 8, using the same technique as defined in Recommendation V.14. It produces a synchronous bit stream defined by 2n × 600 bit/s (where n = 0 to 6). The functions RA1 and RA2 are the same as specified in 5.1. Function RA1 adapts the user rate to the next higher rate expressed by 2k × 8 kbit/s (where k = 0, 1, 2 or 3). RA2 performs the second conversion to 64 kbit/s.
Standard: V.110
output: The three functional blocks involved in the bit rate adaptation process are RA0, RA1, and RA2. RA0 performs an asynchronous-to-synchronous conversion, supporting rates specified in a table, and produces a synchronous bit stream defined by 2n × 600 bit/s (where n = 0 to 6). RA1 adapts the user rate to the next higher rate expressed by 2k × 8 kbit/s (where k = 0, 1, 2, or 3). RA2 performs the second conversion to 64 kbit/s.

instruction: What are the data rates and their corresponding tolerances for asynchronous user rates as specified in the table?
input:
Source: Data rate (bit/s) Rate tolerance (%) Number of data units Number of stop elements RA0/RA1 rate (bit/s) RA1 rate (kbit/s) 24 000 +1 – 2.5 7 or 8 1 or 2 38 400 64 28 800 +1 – 2.5 7 or 8 1 or 2 38 400 64 38 400 +1 – 2.5 7 or 8 1 or 2 38 400 64
Standard: V.110
output: The data rates for asynchronous user rates are 24,000 bit/s, 28,800 bit/s, and 38,400 bit/s, each with a rate tolerance of +1% to -2.5%. These rates can use 7 or 8 data units and 1 or 2 stop elements. The RA0/RA1 rate is 38,400 bit/s, and the RA1 rate is 64 kbit/s for all specified data rates.

instruction: What is the minimum number of stop polarity bits a DTE must transmit on circuit 103 after a start polarity break signal before sending further data characters?
input:
Source: the DTE must transmit on circuit 103 at least 2M bits of stop polarity after the start polarity break signal before sending further data characters. The converter shall then regain character synchronism from the following stop to start transition.
Standard: V.110
output: The DTE must transmit at least 2 million bits of stop polarity on circuit 103 after the start polarity break signal before sending further data characters. The converter then regains character synchronism from the following stop to start transition.

instruction: What characters are typically used for XON and XOFF in asynchronous flow control?
input:
Source: The characters typically used for XON and XOFF are device control one (DC1) and device control three (DC3) (bit combinations 1/1 and 1/3 in Recommendation T.50) respectively, although alternative bit combinations can be used.
Standard: V.110
output: The characters typically used for XON and XOFF are device control one (DC1) and device control three (DC3), which correspond to bit combinations 1/1 and 1/3 in the International Alphabet No. 5 (IA5) set, respectively. Alternative bit combinations can also be used.

instruction: What are the general requirements for a TA supporting flow control?
input:
Source: The following are general requirements for a TA supporting flow control: i) A TA supporting flow control shall be capable of operating with an intermediate rate and bit repetition factor that is independent of the asynchronous speed used at its DTE interface. ii) A TA supporting flow control shall, if possible, adapt to the intermediate rate and bit repetition factor required for an incoming call. User rate information will be obtained from signalling. iii) A TA supporting flow control shall be capable of executing a local flow control protocol to reduce the character rate to that of the far-end DTE. iv) A TA supporting flow control will support the use of end-to-end (TA-to-TA) flow control using the X-bit, and will contain a character buffer.
Standard: V.110
output: The general requirements for a TA supporting flow control include: i) Capability to operate with an intermediate rate and bit repetition factor independent of the asynchronous speed at its DTE interface. ii) Ability to adapt to the intermediate rate and bit repetition factor required for an incoming call, using user rate information obtained from signalling. iii) Execution of a local flow control protocol to reduce the character rate to match the far-end DTE. iv) Support for end-to-end flow control using the X-bit and inclusion of a character buffer.

instruction: What is the purpose of interchange circuits 102a and 102b in data terminal equipment?
input:
Source: NOTE 2 – Interchange circuits 102a and 102b are required where the electrical characteristics defined in Recommendation V.10 are used at data signalling rates above 20 kbit/s.
Standard: V.110
output: Interchange circuits 102a and 102b are required when the electrical characteristics defined for data terminal equipment are used at data signalling rates above 20 kbit/s. These circuits ensure proper functionality and operational requirements are met under these conditions.

instruction: What electrical characteristics are recommended for rates greater than 19.2 kbit/s in TE2/TA interfaces?
input:
Source: Use of electrical characteristics conforming to Recommendations V.10 and/or V.11 is recommended together with the use of the connector and pin assignment plan specified by ISO 4902. i) Concerning circuits 103, 104, 113, 114 and 115, both the generators and the receivers shall be in accordance with Recommendation V.11. ii) In the case of circuits 105, 106, 107 and 109, generators shall comply with Recommendation V.10 or alternatively Recommendation V.11. The receivers shall comply with Recommendation V.10, category 1, or Recommendation V.11 without termination. iii) In the case of all other circuits, Recommendation V.10 applies, with receivers configured as specified by Recommendation V.10 for category 2.
Standard: V.110
output: For rates greater than 19.2 kbit/s, the use of electrical characteristics conforming to Recommendations V.10 and/or V.11 is recommended, along with the connector and pin assignment plan specified by ISO 4902. Specifically, circuits 103, 104, 113, 114, and 115 require both generators and receivers to be in accordance with Recommendation V.11. For circuits 105, 106, 107, and 109, generators should comply with Recommendation V.10 or V.11, with receivers complying with Recommendation V.10, category 1, or V.11 without termination. All other circuits should follow Recommendation V.10, with receivers configured as specified by Recommendation V.10 for category 2.

instruction: What are the conditions of circuits 103, 105, 108/1, and 108/2 during the idle state of a TA?
input:
Source: – Circuit 103 = Continuous binary 1. – Circuit 105 = See Note. – Circuit 108/1 = OFF; circuit 108/2 = ON. NOTE – In many duplex DTEs circuit 105 is either permanently in the ON condition or it is not present. If not present, the function must be set in an ON condition in the TA. See 7.1.2.4 for the case where a duplex DTE can operate circuit 105.
Standard: V.110
output: During the idle (or ready) state, the TA (DCE) receives from the DTE: Circuit 103 as continuous binary 1, Circuit 105's condition depends on the DTE (either permanently ON or not present, requiring the TA to set it ON if not present), Circuit 108/1 as OFF, and Circuit 108/2 as ON.

instruction: What actions does a receiver perform when it recognizes that the status of bits S and X are in the ON condition?
input:
Source: When the receiver recognizes that the status of bits S and X are in the ON condition, it will perform the following functions: a) Turn ON circuit 107 toward the DTE and stop timer T1. NOTE 1 – A duplex DTE that implements and is able to operate circuit 105 may be expected to turn this circuit ON at any time. However, if not previously turned ON, it must be turned ON in response to the ON condition on circuit 107. b) Then, circuit 103 may be connected to the data bits in the frame; however, the DTE must maintain a binary 1 condition on circuit 103 until circuit 106 is turned ON in the next portion of the sequence. c) Turn ON circuit 109 and connect the data bits to circuit 104. NOTE 2 – Binary 1 is being received on circuit 104 at this time. d) After an interval of N bits (see 6.3), it will turn ON circuit 106. e) Circuit 106 transitioning from OFF to ON will cause the transmitted data to transition from binary 1 to the data mode. If circuit 107 has not been turned ON, after expiring of timer T1 the TA shall be disconnected according to the procedures specified in 7.1.4.
Standard: V.110
output: When the receiver recognizes that the status of bits S and X are in the ON condition, it performs the following functions: a) Turns ON circuit 107 toward the DTE and stops timer T1. b) Connects circuit 103 to the data bits in the frame, maintaining a binary 1 condition on circuit 103 until circuit 106 is turned ON. c) Turns ON circuit 109 and connects the data bits to circuit 104. d) After an interval of N bits, turns ON circuit 106. e) Causes the transmitted data to transition from binary 1 to the data mode when circuit 106 transitions from OFF to ON. If circuit 107 has not been turned ON, after timer T1 expires, the TA shall be disconnected.

instruction: What is the suggested timer value for the local TA to guard against the failure of the remote TA to respond to a disconnect request?
input:
Source: To guard against the failure of the remote TA to respond to the disconnect request, the local TA may start a timer T2 (suggested value 5 s) which is stopped by the reception or transmission of any D-channel clearing message (DISCONNECT, RELEASE, RELEASE COMPLETE). If the timer expires, the local TA should clear the call via the ISDN D-channel signalling protocol.
Standard: V.110
output: The suggested timer value for the local TA to guard against the failure of the remote TA to respond to a disconnect request is 5 seconds. This timer, referred to as T2, is stopped upon the reception or transmission of any D-channel clearing message such as DISCONNECT, RELEASE, or RELEASE COMPLETE. If the timer expires without such a message, the local TA should clear the call via the ISDN D-channel signalling protocol.

instruction: What is the frequency tolerance of modems synchronized to their own clock in the context of transferring data signals via the 80-bit frame to the receiving TA?
input:
Source: The frequency tolerance of such modems is 100 ppm. The following method shall be used to enable transfer of those data signals and the corresponding bit timing information via the 80-bit frame to the receiving TA.
Standard: V.110
output: The frequency tolerance of modems synchronized to their own clock is 100 ppm (parts per million). This applies when synchronous data signals at user rates up to and including 19.2 kbit/s are received from outside the ISDN, such as through an interworking unit from a DTE/modem on the PSTN, where the data may not be synchronized to the ISDN.

instruction: What is the formula for calculating phase difference in network-independent clocking systems?
input:
Source: NOTE 1 – Phase measurements are given relative to R1 by the formula: Phase = phase (R2) – phase (R1).
Standard: V.110
output: The phase difference is calculated using the formula: Phase = phase (R2) - phase (R1), where R2 and R1 are the clock signals being compared.

instruction: What is the purpose of transmitting an extra user D-bit in the 80-bit frame during transition from the +40% state to the −40% state?
input:
Source: On transition from the +40% state to the −40% state, an extra user D-bit has to be transmitted in the 80-bit frame, using bit E6 (positive compensation). At the receiving TA, this extra bit will be inserted between D24 and D25 as shown in Table 2, immediately following the E-bits.
Standard: V.110
output: The extra user D-bit, transmitted using bit E6 (positive compensation), is inserted between D24 and D25 at the receiving terminal adaptor (TA). This mechanism ensures proper data alignment and compensation during state transitions in the communication frame.

instruction: What are the four functional elements required of a terminal adaptor as depicted in the reference model?
input:
Source: The elements (1), (2), (3) and (4) shown in Figure A.1 represent the functionality required of a terminal adaptor. The elements are not intended to correspond to separate physical units. However, a terminal adaptor need not necessarily constitute a single physical unit. The functions of these elements are: 1) Provision of layer 1, in accordance with Recommendations V.24 and V.28 or other applicable Recommendations and ISO/IEC 2110 or other applicable standards, of the interface at reference point R. 2) Specific TA functions, including the adaption of the TE2 data (rate and format) for transmission over an ISDN B-channel and provision of R-interface lead control information. This Recommendation covers primarily these functions. 3) Network control signalling functions, including the mapping of call control signals (in accordance with Recommendation V.25 bis or other applicable standard) at the R-interface into signals (according to Recommendation Q.931) for transmission on the D-channel across the S/T interface. 4) Provision of layer 1, in accordance with Recommendation I.430 of the interface at reference points S or T.
Standard: V.110
output: The four functional elements required of a terminal adaptor are: 1) Provision of layer 1 in accordance with V.24 and V.28 or other applicable standards at reference point R, including electrical, mechanical, functional, and procedural characteristics. 2) Specific TA functions, which include adapting TE2 data (rate and format) for transmission over an ISDN B-channel and providing R-interface lead control information. 3) Network control signalling functions, involving the mapping of call control signals at the R-interface into signals for transmission on the D-channel across the S/T interface. 4) Provision of layer 1 in accordance with I.430 at reference points S or T, ensuring compatibility with ISDN requirements.

instruction: What are the additional functions provided by a Terminal Adaptor Type B (TA-B) compared to a Terminal Adaptor Type A (TA-A)?
input:
Source: The TA-B includes, in addition to those functions provided by a TA-A, the mapping functions necessary to convert the automatic calling and/or automatic answering procedures of Recommendation V.25 bis to the ISDN D-channel signalling protocol. This additional functionality is in functional unit (3) in Figure A.1. Terminal adaptor type B is to be used with the 64-kbit/s unrestricted bearer service.
Standard: V.110
