output: A Terminal Adaptor Type B (TA-B) includes all the functions of a TA-A and additionally provides mapping functions necessary to convert the automatic calling and/or automatic answering procedures of V.25 bis to the ISDN D-channel signalling protocol. This functionality is specifically designed for use with the 64-kbit/s unrestricted bearer service.

instruction: What are the primary functions of an interworking function (IWF) in ISDN networks?
input:
Source: Interworking function
Terminal adaptor function – (DTEs with V-series interfaces)Terminal adaptor function – (DTEs with X.21 or X.21 bis interfaces). See Recommendation X.30.ISDN
International
transit
NOTE 1 – The location of this interworking function is discussed in Recommendation I.510 and general
requirements are given in Recommendations I.515 and I.530. The need for a Recommendation covering detailed
requirements for such an IWF is for further study.
Standard: V.110
output: The primary functions of an interworking function (IWF) in ISDN networks include facilitating circuit-mode bearer services between ISDN and non-ISDN networks, supporting terminal adaptor functions for DTEs with V-series or X.21/X.21 bis interfaces, and enabling international transit connections. It also plays a crucial role in parameter exchange for compatibility checking of data calls, terminal adaptor parameter information exchange, and maintenance operations information exchange.

instruction: What is the definition of a Terminal Adaptor (TA) in the context of in-band parameter exchange?
input:
Source: I.2.1 TA : A terminal adaptor.
Standard: V.110
output: A Terminal Adaptor (TA) is a device that facilitates the connection between different types of communication terminals, enabling them to communicate over a network. In the context of in-band parameter exchange, it plays a crucial role in establishing and managing connections, including initiating and accepting connections, and exchanging parameter information.

instruction: What are the four user data rates at which IPE can be initiated after a call is established?
input:
Source: Once the call has been established, the IPE is initiated at one of four user data rates as per Table I.1. It is recommended that, where possible, the IPE is performed using the unrestricted/restricted 64 kbit/s rate. If the TA is not capable of starting at this rate, then the appropriate default
Standard: V.110
output: IPE can be initiated at one of four user data rates, with the recommended rate being the unrestricted/restricted 64 kbit/s. If the TA is not capable of starting at this rate, then the appropriate default rate is used. The specific rates are detailed in Table I.1, which includes the unrestricted/restricted 64 kbit/s rate and three other rates not specified in the provided text.

instruction: What are the frame synchronization procedures for user rates of 4.8, 9.6, or 19.2 kbit/s in a TA?
input:
Source: In the case of user rates of 4.8, 9.6 or 19.2 kbit/s, the TA first completes the frame synchronization procedure described in this Recommendation, with the changes detailed below: a) The transmitter sends frames towards its peer with status information S = OFF and X = OFF and enters the awaiting synchronization-parameter exchange state (state 6). b) When the TA recognizes the frame synchronization pattern in the awaiting synchronization- parameter exchange state (state 6), it verifies the status information received and then enters the appropriate state, in a coordinated manner, as follows: – Data transfer (state 4), upon receipt of S = ON and X = ON (see I.5.6); – IPE default exchange (state 5), upon receipt of S = OFF and X = OFF; – Parameter exchange (state 7), upon receipt of S = OFF and X = ON (see I.5.3). c) When the TA is in the IPE default exchange state (state 5), it shall transmit frames with status information S = OFF and X = ON and verify the status information received and then enter the appropriate state, in a coordinated manner, as follows: – Data transfer (state 4), upon receipt of S = ON and X = ON (see I.5.6); – Parameter exchange (state 7), upon receipt of S = OFF and X = ON (see I.5.3).
Standard: V.110
output: For user rates of 4.8, 9.6, or 19.2 kbit/s, the TA first completes the frame synchronization procedure by sending frames with status information S = OFF and X = OFF, entering the awaiting synchronization-parameter exchange state (state 6). Upon recognizing the frame synchronization pattern in this state, it verifies the received status information and transitions to the appropriate state: Data transfer (state 4) upon receiving S = ON and X = ON, IPE default exchange (state 5) upon receiving S = OFF and X = OFF, or Parameter exchange (state 7) upon receiving S = OFF and X = ON. In the IPE default exchange state (state 5), the TA transmits frames with S = OFF and X = ON, then verifies the received status to transition to either Data transfer (state 4) or Parameter exchange (state 7) based on the received status.

instruction: What is the sequence of events during a parameter exchange in a telecommunication system?
input:
Source: Recommendation V.110    (02/2000)  35T1701720-92XSTARTCalling TA Originating TACalled TA Answering TA (RA VERSION) RA VERSION (1)Repeat for each parameter etc.RA VERSION (1) etc.IDLE XSTART XSTART FILLPARAM-X ( ≥32) LOW HIGH LOW HIGH LOW HIGH FILL FILL Repeat for each parameter(Pair 1) (Pair 2) (Pair 3)RA VERSION ( ≥32) LOW HIGH LOW HIGH LOW HIGH PARAM-X(1)IDLE (X START) RA VERSION (n) RA VERSION ( ≥32) LOW HIGH LOW HIGH LOW HIGH PARAM-X(1)(Pair 1)  (Pair 3)(Pair 2){ { {(Pair 1) (Pair 2) (Pair 3) PARAM-X ( ≥32) LOW HIGH LOW HIGH LOW HIGH FILL(Pair 1)  (Pair 3)(Pair 2){ { {
Standard: V.110
output: The sequence of events during a parameter exchange in a telecommunication system involves several steps. Initially, the calling TA (Terminal Adapter) originates the call to the called TA. The answering TA responds, and the RA VERSION is exchanged, which is repeated for each parameter. The process includes sending XSTART signals, filling parameters with values (≥32), and alternating between LOW and HIGH signals for each parameter pair. This sequence is repeated for each parameter pair (Pair 1, Pair 2, Pair 3) until all parameters are exchanged. The IDLE state is used to indicate the start of the parameter exchange with X START, and the process concludes with the final parameter exchange.

instruction: What is the sequence of operations during the parameter transfer in a TA communication?
input:
Source: The parameter transfer commences with the transmission of a sequence of RA VERSION command octets followed by a series of LOW-HIGH data octet pairs containing the rate adaption identifier (see I.6.2). Directly following the transmission of the rate adaption identifier, the transfer continues with the parameters themselves in five groups: PARAM-0 to PARAM-4 (see I.6.4), transmitted in ascending order. Each group begins with the transmission of a sequence of the appropriate PARAM command octet followed by a series of LOW-HIGH data octet pairs which carry the parameters. At the completion of the parameter information transfer, both TAs send repeated FILL status octets until the next stage of the parameter exchange. Transmission of the complete parameter block shall be made within the period T2.
Standard: V.110
output: The parameter transfer begins with the transmission of RA VERSION command octets, followed by LOW-HIGH data octet pairs containing the rate adaption identifier. Subsequently, parameters are transmitted in five groups (PARAM-0 to PARAM-4) in ascending order, each starting with the appropriate PARAM command octet and followed by LOW-HIGH data octet pairs carrying the parameters. After completing the parameter transfer, both TAs send repeated FILL status octets until the next stage. The entire parameter block must be transmitted within period T2.

instruction: What are the conditions for a TA to enter the data transfer state from the no exchange state?
input:
Source: When the TA is in the no exchange state (state 9), it shall transmit frames with status information S = ON and X = ON and enter the data transfer state (state 4) upon receipt of S = ON and X = ON.
Standard: V.110
output: A TA enters the data transfer state (state 4) from the no exchange state (state 9) upon receiving status information S = ON and X = ON. While in the no exchange state, the TA transmits frames with S = ON and X = ON and transitions to the data transfer state when it receives the same status information.

instruction: What conditions prevent the use of the mechanism for re-entering IPE from the data transfer state?
input:
Source: This mechanism is not applicable to unrestricted 64-kbit/s or restricted 64-kbit/s connection types, or when the rate during data transfer is 64 kbit/s, 56 kbit/s or 48 kbit/s.
Standard: V.110
output: The mechanism for re-entering IPE from the data transfer state is not applicable under the following conditions: when the connection types are unrestricted 64-kbit/s or restricted 64-kbit/s, or when the data transfer rate is 64 kbit/s, 56 kbit/s, or 48 kbit/s.

instruction: How is data transmitted for a user rate of 56 kbit/s in terms of bit sequence and alignment?
input:
Source: In the case of a user rate of 56 kbit/s, the data is transmitted to line in bit sequence from bit 1 to bit 7 followed by an 8th bit set to ONE – according to this Recommendation, rate adaption (in total this is the equivalent data stream to 64 kbit/s). Network-provided octet alignment shall be used.
Standard: V.110
output: For a user rate of 56 kbit/s, data is transmitted to the line in bit sequence from bit 1 to bit 7, followed by an 8th bit set to ONE. This creates an equivalent data stream to 64 kbit/s when rate adaptation is used. Network-provided octet alignment is employed in this process.

instruction: What are the bit patterns for the RA VERSION command and LOW-HIGH data octet pairs in rate adaptation?
input:
Source: RA VERSION 0 1 0 1 0 1 1 1

 HIGH d4 d5 d6 d7 1 1 0 1 
  Rate adaption version identifier encoding

  I3

I3-I0: Identifier V.110

Standard: V.110
output: The RA VERSION command octet is encoded as 01010111 (b1-b8). The LOW data octet pattern is d0 d1 d2 d3 0101, and the HIGH data octet pattern is d4 d5 d6 d7 1101, where d0-d7 represent data bits. These patterns are used in sequence for rate adaptation version identification, with the LOW octet transmitted before the HIGH octet in each pair.

instruction: What is the binary coding for the XSTART command octet in TA parameter information transfer?
input:
Source: XSTART 0 1 1 0 0 1 1 1
Standard: V.110
output: The XSTART command octet is coded as 01100111, where bits b1 to b8 represent 0, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1 respectively.

instruction: What are the possible configurations for stop bits in serial communication as defined by parameter 2 encoding?
input:
Source: S1-S0 Stop bits S1 S0       Not used 1 1.5 2 0  0 1 1 0 1 0 1
Standard: V.110
output: The possible configurations for stop bits in serial communication, as defined by parameter 2 encoding, are: Not used (S1=0, S0=0), 1 stop bit (S1=0, S0=1), 1.5 stop bits (S1=1, S0=0), and 2 stop bits (S1=1, S0=1).

instruction: What are the binary codings for the READY, IDLE, FILL, and INACTIVE status octets in a TA communication?
input:
Source: b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8 
READY 0 1 0 1 1 1 1 1 
Figure I.14/V.110 – READY octet coding

Figure I.15/V.110 – IDLE octet coding 
 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8 FILL 1 1 0 1 1 1 1 1 
Figure I.16/V.110 – FILL octet coding 
 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8 
INACTIVE 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 
Figure I.17/V.110 – INACTIVE octet coding
Standard: V.110
output: The binary codings for the status octets are as follows: READY is coded as 01011111, IDLE is coded as 01111111, FILL is coded as 11011111, and INACTIVE is coded as 11111111. Each status octet is 8 bits long, with each bit position (b1 to b8) representing a specific part of the octet.

Standard: V.110
output: The possible states in a Terminal Adapter (TA) state diagram when it does not support Interworking Parameter Exchange (IPE) include: Null (undefined state), Inactive (ONEs inactive), Awaiting sync transfer (S = OFF, X = OFF, d = ONEs), Default exchange (Rx S = ON, Rx X = ON), and Data transfer (S = ON, X = ON, d = DATA). These states represent the transitions and conditions under which a TA operates without IPE support.

output: The possible states in the maintenance loop 4 state diagram for data transfer initiation include 'Inactive', 'Initiate data transfer', 'Awaiting sync transfer', 'Default exchange', 'IPE default exchange', 'Parameter exchange', 'Await resync', 'No exchange', 'Data transfer', 'Await re-enter IPE', and 'Maintenance loop 4'. Each state transitions based on specific conditions such as timer expirations, signal states (Rx S, Rx X), and re-entry flags.

instruction: What are the key signalling messages defined in Q.931 for bis based terminals?
input:
Source: The D-channel signalling capabilities provided to V.25 bis based terminals shall comprise the signalling messages as defined in Recommendation Q.931. Recall of the circuit list involved in the V.25 bis call set-up – Ready for sending (106). – Data set ready (107). – Data terminal ready (108/2). – Transmit data (103). – Receive data (104). – Calling indicator (125).
Standard: V.110
output: The key signalling messages defined in Q.931 for V.25 bis based terminals include Ready for sending (106), Data set ready (107), Data terminal ready (108/2), Transmit data (103), Receive data (104), and Calling indicator (125). These messages are part of the D-channel signalling capabilities provided to V.25 bis based terminals.

instruction: What signals does a TA use to indicate an incoming call via the bis interface?
input:
Source: The TA indicates an incoming call via the V.25 bis interface by setting 125 = ON, 104 = '1' and 107 = OFF; thereby entering state 8 Incoming Call.
Standard: V.110
output: The TA indicates an incoming call by setting circuit 125 to ON, circuit 104 to '1', and circuit 107 to OFF, thereby entering the Incoming Call state.

instruction: What are the key steps in a direct call DTE call set-up and clearing process?
input:
Source: The process is best described in Figure II.5. T1701410-91TA (D) (B)(D) (D)(D) (B) (D) (D)Ready (108/1 = OFF) Call request (108/1 = ON) Ready for data (107 = ON) Data transfer Clearing by DTE (108/1 = OFF) DCE ready (107 = OFF)SETUP CALL PROCEED CONNECT End-to-end synchronization DTR = OFF, TD = 1 DISCONNECT RELEASE RELEASE COMPLETEDTE
Standard: V.110
output: The key steps in a direct call DTE call set-up and clearing process include: 1. Ready state with 108/1 signal OFF, 2. Call request initiated by setting 108/1 signal ON, 3. Ready for data indicated by 107 signal ON, 4. Data transfer phase, 5. Clearing initiated by DTE setting 108/1 signal OFF, and 6. DCE ready indicated by 107 signal OFF. The sequence involves signals SETUP, CALL PROCEED, CONNECT for establishing the call, and DISCONNECT, RELEASE, RELEASE COMPLETE for clearing the call, with end-to-end synchronization maintained throughout the data transfer phase.

instruction: What are the different types of Call Failure Indications (CFI) in bis and their interpretations by the DTE?
input:
Source: Handling of the Call Failure Indication (CFI) by the DTE may be a national matter. CFI (AB) is to be taken by the DTE as no use for the DTE to call again, some changes need to be done within the DTE before the call can be successful; CFI (ET) is to be taken by the DTE as a transient condition, the DTE may retry the call without changes; CFI (NT) indicates a serious failure of the call and the DTE should wait before retrying the call. CFI (INV) is reserved for local invalid commands and is not a mapping of an ISDN cause code.
Standard: V.110
output: The V.25 bis standard defines several Call Failure Indications (CFI) with specific interpretations for the DTE: CFI (AB) indicates that the DTE should not call again without making changes, suggesting a need for internal adjustments before a successful call can be made. CFI (ET) signifies a transient condition, allowing the DTE to retry the call immediately without any changes. CFI (NT) denotes a serious failure, advising the DTE to wait before attempting another call. CFI (INV) is reserved for local invalid commands and does not map to any ISDN cause code.

instruction: What are the Q.931 cause codes for 'Requested circuit/channel not available' and their corresponding bis call response codes?
input:
Source: 23 Requested circuit/channel not available 44 No connection ET
Standard: V.110
output: The Q.931 cause code for 'Requested circuit/channel not available' is 44, and its corresponding V.25 bis call response code is 'No connection ET'.

instruction: What is the procedure for handling call collision at the bis interface?
input:
Source: The TA shall accept an incoming SETUP message. When at the V.25 bis interface a call collision is detected (TA presents incoming call indication, V.25 bis DTE presents call request), the TA will delay the outgoing call to monitor for incoming calls and will accept the incoming call and not process the outgoing call.
Standard: V.110
output: When a call collision is detected at the V.25 bis interface, where the TA presents an incoming call indication and the V.25 bis DTE presents a call request, the TA will delay the outgoing call to monitor for incoming calls. It will accept the incoming call and not process the outgoing call.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of a 14,400 bits per second modem designed for point-to-point 4-wire leased telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of this modem are as follows: a) fallback rate of 12 000 bits per second;b) capable of operating in a duplex mode with continuous carrier;c) combined amplitude and phase modulation with synchronous mode of operation;d) inclusion of an eight state trellis coded modulation;e) optional inclusion of a multiplexer for combining data rates of 12 000, 9600, 7200, 4800 and 2400 bits per second (see Note 3).
Standard: V.33
output: The principal characteristics include: a fallback rate of 12,000 bits per second; capability to operate in a duplex mode with continuous carrier; use of combined amplitude and phase modulation with synchronous operation; inclusion of an eight-state trellis coded modulation; and an optional multiplexer for combining data rates of 12,000, 9,600, 7,200, 4,800, and 2,400 bits per second.

instruction: What are the data signalling rates and modulation rate specified for trellis-coded modulation?
input:
Source: The data signalling rates shall be 14 400 and 12 000 bit/s ± 0.01%. The modulation rate is 2400 bauds ± 0.01%.
Standard: V.33
output: The data signalling rates are 14,400 and 12,000 bit/s with a tolerance of ±0.01%. The modulation rate is 2,400 bauds with the same tolerance of ±0.01%.

instruction: What are the threshold levels for circuit 109 to switch ON and OFF?
input:
Source: - greater than -26 dBm: circuit 109 ON - less than - 33 dBm: circuit 109 OFF The condition of circuit 109 for levels between -26 dBm and -33 dBm is not specified except that the signal detector shall exhibit a hysteresis action, such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs is at least 2 dBgreater than that for the ON to OFF transition.
Standard: V.33
output: Circuit 109 switches ON when the signal level is greater than -26 dBm and switches OFF when the signal level is less than -33 dBm. For levels between -26 dBm and -33 dBm, the condition of circuit 109 is not specified, but the signal detector must exhibit a hysteresis action where the OFF to ON transition occurs at a level at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition.

instruction: What are the response time requirements for circuit 109 after a line signal interruption when no new equalization is needed?
input:
Source: after a line signal interruption that lasts more than the ON to OFF response time: a)when no new equalization is needed, 25 ± 10 ms;
Standard: V.33
output: The response time for circuit 109 after a line signal interruption when no new equalization is needed is 25 ± 10 ms.

instruction: What are the four segments of synchronizing signals in data transmission and their respective durations in symbol intervals?
input:
Source: Segment 1Segment 2 TRNSegment 3 Segment 4 Total Type of line signal Alternations ABABEqualizer condition patternRate sequence Scrambled all binary ONEsTotal synchronizing signal time Number of symbolintervals256 2976 64 48 3344 Approximate time in ms106 1240 27 20 1393
Standard: V.33
output: The four segments of synchronizing signals in data transmission are: Segment 1, consisting of alternations between states A and B for 256 symbol intervals; Segment 2, the equalizer conditioning pattern lasting 2976 symbol intervals; Segment 3, the rate signal comprising 64 symbol intervals; and Segment 4, the scrambled all binary ONEs segment lasting 48 symbol intervals. The total synchronizing signal time is 3344 symbol intervals.

instruction: What do bits B8 and B9 indicate in a modem's rate signal transmission?
input:
Source: B8 1 Denotes ability to transmit and receive data at 12 000 bit/s (Note) B9 1 Denotes ability to transmit and receive data at 14 000 bit/s (Note) Note - When transmitting a rate signal, the modern will transmit bits B8 B9 equal to 11 or 01 when the data signalling rate of segment 4 equals 14.4 kbit/s and B8 B9 = 10 when the data signalling rate of segment 4 equals 12 kbit/s.
Standard: V.33
output: Bits B8 and B9 in a modem's rate signal transmission indicate the modem's ability to transmit and receive data at specific rates. Specifically, B8 set to 1 denotes the ability to handle 12,000 bit/s, and B9 set to 1 denotes the ability to handle 14,000 bit/s. When transmitting a rate signal, the combination B8 B9 equal to 11 or 01 indicates a data signalling rate of 14.4 kbit/s for segment 4, while B8 B9 equal to 10 indicates a data signalling rate of 12 kbit/s for segment 4.

instruction: What are the possible multiplex configurations for an aggregate data rate of 14,400 bit/s?
input:
Source: TABLE 5A/V.33 Aggregate data rate (bit/s) Multiplex configuration Sub-channel data rate (bit/s) Multiplex channel Modulator bits Q1 Q2 Q3 Q4 Q5 Q6 14 400 1 14 400 A X X X X X X 14 400 2 12 000 2 400 A B X X X X X X 14 400 3 9 600 4 800 A B X X X X X X 14 400 4 9 600 2 400 2 400 A B C X X X X X X 14 400 5 7 200 7 200 A B X X X X X X 14 400 6 7 200 4 800 2 400 A B C X X X X X X 14 400 7 7 200 2 400 2 400 2 400 A B C D X X X X X X 14 400 8 4 800 4 800 4 800 A B C X X X X X X 14 400 9 4 800 4 800 2 400 2 400 A B C D X X X X X X 14 400 10 4 800 2 400 2 400 2 400 2 400 A B C D E X X X X X X 14 400 11 2 400 2 400 2 400 2 400 2 400 A B C D E F X X X X X X
Standard: V.33
output: For an aggregate data rate of 14,400 bit/s, there are 11 possible multiplex configurations. These configurations vary by the number of sub-channels and their respective data rates. The configurations include: 1 sub-channel at 14,400 bit/s; 2 sub-channels at 12,000 and 2,400 bit/s; 3 sub-channels at 9,600, 4,800, and 2,400 bit/s; 4 sub-channels at 9,600, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; 5 sub-channels at 7,200, 7,200, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; 6 sub-channels at 7,200, 4,800, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; 7 sub-channels at 7,200, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; 8 sub-channels at 4,800, 4,800, 4,800, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; 9 sub-channels at 4,800, 4,800, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; 10 sub-channels at 4,800, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, 2,400, and 2,400 bit/s; and 11 sub-channels at 2,400 bit/s each.

instruction: What is the purpose of circuit 105 in a multiplexer port?
input:
Source: Note 2 - Circuit 105 is not necessary for continuous carrier transmission. The transmitted line signal will not be controlled by this interchange circuit. If needed, circuit 105 (when the multiplexer is present) is used to control circuit 109 at the remote DCE.  See § 10.4 below.
Standard: V.33
output: Circuit 105, known as 'Request to send', is used to control circuit 109 at the remote Data Circuit-terminating Equipment (DCE) when the multiplexer is present. It is not necessary for continuous carrier transmission as the transmitted line signal will not be controlled by this interchange circuit. The buffer in the transmitter of each multiplexer port is initialized when the OFF to ON transition of circuit 105 occurs.

instruction: What are the possible sources of port transmitter signal element timing in a DCE?
input:
Source: Source of port : transmitter signal element timing (used to clock in circuit 103)Source of DCE : internal transmitter element timing (internal transit clock)Port transmit buffer Internal (Independent timing)Not required 114 (DCE source) External a) (circuit 113 of selected port)Not required Receiver timing (loopback timing)Not required Internal (Independent timing)Required 113 (DTE a) source)External a) (Circuit 113 of selected port)Required for all ports except port supplying circuit 113 to DTE Receiver timing(loopback timing)Required a) In these applications a source could also be another DCE.
Standard: V.33
output: The possible sources of port transmitter signal element timing in a DCE include internal (independent timing), external from circuit 113 of a selected port, and receiver timing (loopback timing).

instruction: What is the length of the pseudo-random sequence generated by the polynomial 1 + x^-18 + x^-23?
input:
Source: The polynomial 1 + x-18 + x-23 generates a pseudo-random sequence of length 223 - 1 = 8,388,607.
Standard: V.33
output: The polynomial 1 + x^-18 + x^-23 generates a pseudo-random sequence of length 8,388,607, which is calculated as 2^23 - 1.

instruction: What are the key corrections and clarifications addressed in the corrigendum for DSVD terminal control procedures?
input:
Source: This corrigendum addresse s corrections and clarif ications in ITU-T Rec. V.75 (1996) concerning errors and omissions in Tables 3 and 6, positioning of segmentati on/reassembly header, negotiation of suspend/resume option, usage of H.245 'portN umber', normative references, and update of the ASN.1 regarding N401 Value Range, H.245 codepoints for V.42 bis on an ERM channel, and codepoint for G.729 Annex B.
Standard: V.75
output: The corrigendum addresses corrections and clarifications in Tables 3 and 6, the positioning of segmentation/reassembly headers, negotiation of suspend/resume options, usage of H.245 'portNumber', normative references, and updates to the ASN.1 regarding N401 Value Range, H.245 codepoints for V.42 bis on an ERM channel, and codepoint for G.729 Annex B.

instruction: What is the purpose of the H.245 'portNumber' specification in communication protocols?
input:
Source: Clarification on usage of H.245 'portNumber'
Standard: V.75
output: The H.245 'portNumber' specification is used to designate the communication port for H.245 control channel messages in multimedia communication protocols. This allows for the proper routing and management of control signals between endpoints during a communication session.

instruction: What are the required parameters for L-ESTABLISH user-data in DSVD terminal control procedures?
input:
Source: Table 3/V.75 – L-ESTABLISH user-data parameters L-ESTABLISH MF primitives Applicable H.245 parameters CE reference Comments – request – OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannel Number.LogicalChannelNumber 1a.1 – indication – OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannel Parameters.portNumber 1a.9 – required to be present for DSVD and shall identify a logical channel user. – OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannel Parameters.multiplexParameters.v76 Logical ChannelParameters 1a.4 – 1a.8 – shall be present for DSVD – OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannel Parameters.multiplexParameters.v76 Logical ChannelParameters 1a.4 – 1a.8 – shall be present for DSVD – OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannel Parameters.v76Parameters. v75Parameters 1a.3 – shall be present for DSVD – OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannel Parameters.dataType.AudioData 1a.10 – OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannel Parameters.dataType.dataDataApplication Capability 1a.10 – OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannel Parameters 1a.11 – shall be present for DSVD – OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannel Parameters.v76Parameters .v75Parameters 1a.3 – shall be present for DSVD – OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannel Parameters.dataType 1a.11 – identical to forward datatype parameters with the exception of the AudioCapability INTEGER – response – confirm – OpenLogicalChannelAck.forwardLogical ChannelNumber – OpenLogicalChannelAck.portNumber 1a.12 – shall be present for DSVD
Standard: V.75
output: The required parameters for L-ESTABLISH user-data in DSVD terminal control procedures include OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannelNumber.LogicalChannelNumber, OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannelParameters.portNumber, OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannelParameters.multiplexParameters.v76LogicalChannelParameters, OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannelParameters.multiplexParameters.v76LogicalChannelParameters, OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannelParameters.v76Parameters.v75Parameters, OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannelParameters.dataType.AudioData, OpenLogicalChannel.forwardLogicalChannelParameters.dataType.dataDataApplicationCapability, OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannelParameters, OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannelParameters.v76Parameters.v75Parameters, and OpenLogicalChannel.reverseLogicalChannelParameters.dataType. Additionally, OpenLogicalChannelAck.forwardLogicalChannelNumber and OpenLogicalChannelAck.portNumber are required in the response.

instruction: What are the two changes required to be implemented in Table 6 for L-DATA user-data parameters?
input:
Source: Implement the following two changes: • Add '– TerminalCapabilitySe t.sequenceNumber' as firs t entry in 2nd column of Table 6/V.75 . • Add '– RequestMode.ModeDescription.M odeElement.V76ModeParameters' below ' – Endsession' entry in 2nd column of Table 6/V.75 .
Standard: V.75
output: The two changes required are: 1) Add 'TerminalCapabilitySet.sequenceNumber' as the first entry in the second column of Table 6. 2) Add 'RequestMode.ModeDescription.ModeElement.V76ModeParameters' below the 'Endsession' entry in the second column of Table 6.

instruction: What is the default value of the portNumber parameter in H.245 and what does it signify?
input:
Source: "NOTE – The portNumber parameter shall have a defau lt value of "0", which indicates an "unspecified" input or output association. Use of other values of this parameter is for further study."
Standard: V.75
output: The default value of the portNumber parameter in H.245 is '0', which signifies an 'unspecified' input or output association. Other values for this parameter are reserved for further study.

instruction: What is the purpose of the H-header octet in the frame structure for transmission on the DLC?
input:
Source: "An H-header octet shall be is added as the first octet in the information before the address field of every the frame to be transmitted on the DLC. The format of the H octet is shown in Figure 2."
Standard: V.75
output: The H-header octet is added as the first octet in the information before the address field of every frame to be transmitted on the DLC. It serves to facilitate segmentation and reassembly processes in the communication protocol, ensuring proper frame delineation and processing.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of gateways facilitating end-to-end connection of V-series DCEs over an IP network?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines the inter-operation of two PSTN to IP network gateways that facilitate the end-to-end connection of V-series DCEs over an IP network. The principal characteristics of these gateways are: a mechanism to allow the transparent transport of modem signals end-to-end, a mechanism to allow the termination of modem signals at the gateways and the transport of the data between gateways, the definition of a transport protocol, which is suitable to relay data between gateways, and procedures to allow gateways to transition between Voice-over-Internet Protocol and Modem-over-Internet Protocol operation.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The principal characteristics include a mechanism for transparent transport of modem signals end-to-end, a mechanism for terminating modem signals at the gateways and transporting data between them, the definition of a suitable transport protocol for relaying data between gateways, and procedures for transitioning between Voice-over-Internet Protocol and Modem-over-Internet Protocol operation.

instruction: What are the operational modes of MoIP?
input:
Source: Clause 10 Operational modes of MoIP
Standard: V.150.1
output: The operational modes of MoIP include various states and processes that facilitate the transmission of modem signals over IP networks. These modes encompass initialization, connection establishment, data transfer, and termination phases, each involving specific messages and protocols to ensure reliable communication.

instruction: What are the optional modes of operation that may be provided by MoIP gateways?
input:
Source: Other modes of operation that may be optionally provided by MoIP gateways are Fax over IP (FoIP) and Text over IP (ToIP). The procedures for FoIP are defined in ITU-T Rec. T.38. Procedures for ToIP are defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The optional modes of operation that may be provided by MoIP gateways include Fax over IP (FoIP) and Text over IP (ToIP). FoIP procedures are defined for real-time Group 3 facsimile communication over IP networks, while ToIP procedures are defined for the end-to-end connection of analogue PSTN text telephones over an IP network utilizing text relay.

instruction: What are the event codes and their corresponding functional descriptions for call discrimination messages in fax and text relay systems?
input:
Source: Fax Relay SSE (Note) 4 Switch to FoIP  Procedures for this media switch are for further study Text Relay SSE (Note) 5 Switch to ToIP Text Relay  Procedures used for this media switch are defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151 are for further study Text Probe SSE (Note) 6 Switch to Text Probe state Procedures used for this media switch are defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151
Standard: V.150.1
output: In fax relay systems, the event code is SSE (Note) 4, which corresponds to switching to FoIP (Fax over IP), with procedures for this media switch marked for further study. In text relay systems, the event code is SSE (Note) 5, which corresponds to switching to ToIP (Text over IP) Text Relay, with procedures for this media switch defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151 and also marked for further study. Additionally, the event code SSE (Note) 6 is used for switching to the Text Probe state, with procedures for this media switch defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151.

instruction: What do the INIT bits 4:15 indicate in a gateway's receiver?
input:
Source: INIT bits MSB:LSB Definition … 4:15 Optional MoIP Data types . This field indicates the optional data types that are supported by the gateway's receiver. Support is indicated by a value of binary ONE in the appropriate bit position. A bi nary ZERO indicates no support. b4: I_RAW-BIT support b5: I_FRAME support b6: I_CHAR-STAT support b7: I_CHAR-DYN support b8: I_OCTET-CS support b9: I_CHAR-STAT-CS support b10: I_CHAR-DYN-CS support b118…b15: Reserved for ITU-T; these bits are set to zero by the transmitter and not interpreted by the receiver.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The INIT bits 4:15 indicate the optional MoIP (Media over IP) data types supported by the gateway's receiver. Each bit position corresponds to a specific data type, where a binary ONE signifies support and a binary ZERO indicates no support. The specific data types are: b4 for I_RAW-BIT support, b5 for I_FRAME support, b6 for I_CHAR-STAT support, b7 for I_CHAR-DYN support, b8 for I_OCTET-CS support, b9 for I_CHAR-STAT-CS support, and b10 for I_CHAR-DYN-CS support. Bits b11 to b15 are reserved for ITU-T and are set to zero by the transmitter without interpretation by the receiver.

instruction: What is the purpose of the CS field in the Octet with sequence number (I_OCTET-CS) data type message?
input:
Source: CS Character sequence number. This two- byte field is initialized to zero upon establishment of SPRT connect ion. CS is incremented by one after each character is transmitted into the IP network (modulo 65536). The sequence number in the SPRT packet represents the sequence number for the first character in the SPRT packet payload.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The CS (Character Sequence Number) field in the I_OCTET-CS data type message is a two-byte field initialized to zero upon establishment of SPRT connection. It is incremented by one after each character is transmitted into the IP network (modulo 65536). This sequence number represents the sequence number for the first character in the SPRT packet payload and is used by the MoIP application to generate the correct number of fill characters when packet loss is detected in the IP network.

instruction: What are the possible values and meanings of the 3-bit P field indicating parity type in character format specifications?
input:
Source: 0 – unknown; 1 – none; 2 – even parity; 3 – odd parity; 4 – space parity; 5 – mark parity; 6 – reserved; 7 – reserved.
Standard: V.150.1
output: The 3-bit P field can have the following values and meanings: 0 indicates unknown parity; 1 indicates no parity; 2 indicates even parity; 3 indicates odd parity; 4 indicates space parity; 5 indicates mark parity; values 6 and 7 are reserved.

instruction: What are the requirements for gateways implementing both ToIP and MoIP interworking with text telephony?
input:
Source: The support and interworking of ToIP gateways with MoIP gateways is for further study. Methods and procedures for the support of PSTN text telephones is defined in ITU-T Rec. V.151 for Text Relay and ITU-T Rec. V.152 for VBD. For gateways that implement both this Recommendation and ITU-T Rec. V.151, the following needs to be considered. Firstly, since the default media switching methods for this Recommendation and ITU-T Rec. V.151 are different, it is required that Gateways that support both mechanisms shall consider the use of the SSE protocol in the V.151 procedures to be required in order to allow for correct interoperation. In general, and with the exception of three cases, the application of the V.151 discrimination procedures for the detection text telephones during the (a, a) state can be added to the (a, a) of this Recommendation. On detection and validation of a text telephone signal, V.151 procedures will apply. Two of the exceptions are the handling of the Answer Tone signals. This includes V.25 ANS and V.8 ANSam. For consistency with V.151, the VBD method of handling these signals should be used as described in 20.4.7. The third exception is that the gateway is receiving a V.8 signal (i.e., indicated by detecting ANSam), then the gateway shall follow the procedures of this Recommendation unless it discovers that the V.8 CM signal contains a call function indicating that it is a text device. At this point, the V.151 procedures are followed.
Standard: V.150.1
output: Gateways implementing both ToIP and MoIP interworking with text telephony must consider the use of the SSE protocol in V.151 procedures to ensure correct interoperation, due to differing default media switching methods. They should apply V.151 discrimination procedures for detecting text telephones during the (a, a) state, with exceptions for handling Answer Tone signals (V.25 ANS and V.8 ANSam) where the VBD method should be used. If receiving a V.8 signal indicating a text device, the gateway switches to V.151 procedures.

instruction: What are the indicated media states for event encodings 1 through 6 in media state coding?
input:
Source: Table C.1/V.150.1 – Coding of the media states
Event encoding
(Decimal) Indicated media state
0 Reserved for future use by ITU-T
1 Initial Audio
2 Voice Band Data (VBD)
3 Modem Relay
4 Fax Relay
5 Text Relay
6 Text Probe
67-31 Reserved for future use by ITU-T
32-63 Vendor-defined
Standard: V.150.1
output: The indicated media states for event encodings 1 through 6 are: 1 for Initial Audio, 2 for Voice Band Data (VBD), 3 for Modem Relay, 4 for Fax Relay, 5 for Text Relay, and 6 for Text Probe.

instruction: What are the different types of signal links described in the figures for non-to non-communication?
input:
Source: Figure IV.3/V.150.1 – Non -V.18 to non -V.18 (T2 first) into text relay  
Figure IV.4/V.150.1  – Non -V.18 to non -V.18 (T2 first) into VBD  
Figure IV.5/V.150.1 – Non -V.18 to non -V.18 (T1 first) into text relay  
Figure IV.6/V.150.1 – Non -V.18 to non -V.18 (T1 first) into VBD
Figure IV.7/V.150.1 – TDD fallback with incompatible gateway types
Standard: V.150.1
output: The figures describe several types of signal links for non-V.18 to non-V.18 communication, including text relay (ToIP) links and Voice Band Data (VBD) links. Specifically, there are configurations for T2 first into text relay, T2 first into VBD, T1 first into text relay, and T1 first into VBD. Additionally, there is a scenario described for TDD fallback with incompatible gateway types involving both VBD and text relay components.

instruction: What are the typical data signalling rates for modems?
input:
Source: 5.1 Data signalling rates
Standard: V.34
output: V.34 modems support data signalling rates ranging from 2,400 bits per second (bps) up to 33,600 bps. These rates are achieved through advanced modulation techniques and adaptive line probing to determine the optimal transmission speed based on line conditions.

instruction: What are the phases involved in half-duplex operating procedures for modems?
output: The half-duplex operating procedures for V.34 modems involve several phases: Phase 1 – Network interaction, Phase 2 – Probing, Phase 3 – Primary channel equalizer training, Control channel start-up, Primary channel resynchronization procedure, Control channel resynchronization procedure, Primary channel retrains, and Control channel retrains.

instruction: What are the mandatory symbol rates for a modem using Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) on each channel with synchronous line transmission?
input:
Source: c) Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) for each channel with synchronous line transmission at selectable symbol rates including the mandatory rates of 2400, 3000, and 3200 symbols/s and the optional rates of 2743, 2800 and3429 symbols/s;
Standard: V.34
output: The mandatory symbol rates for a modem using Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) on each channel with synchronous line transmission are 2400, 3000, and 3200 symbols/s.

instruction: What is the purpose of an auxiliary channel in modem communications?
input:
Source: 3.1 auxiliary channel : A 200 bit/s data channel which, along with the primary channel, is multiplexed into the bit stream transmitted by the modem. Data conveyed in the auxiliary channel is independent from the primary channel and may consist of secondary channel data and modem control data. Modem control channel procedures that may be used between consenting modems are detailed in Annex A.
Standard: V.34
output: An auxiliary channel in modem communications is a 200 bit/s data channel that is multiplexed with the primary channel into the transmitted bit stream. It carries data independent of the primary channel, which can include secondary channel data and modem control data. This allows for additional communication and control functions to occur simultaneously with the main data transmission.

instruction: What are the supported synchronous data signalling rates for the primary channel in modems?
input:
Source: The primary channel shall support synchronous data signalling rates of 2400 bit/s to 33 600 bit/s in multiples of 2400 bit/s. An auxiliary channel with a synchronous data signalling rate of 200 bit/s may also be optionally supported.
Standard: V.34
output: The primary channel supports synchronous data signalling rates ranging from 2400 bit/s to 33,600 bit/s, in multiples of 2400 bit/s. Additionally, an optional auxiliary channel may support a synchronous data signalling rate of 200 bit/s.

instruction: What is the definition of normalized frequency in the context of transmit spectrum specifications?
input:
Source: The transmit spectrum specifications use a normalized frequency, which is defined as the ratio f/S, where f is the frequency in Hz and S is the symbol rate.
Standard: V.34
output: Normalized frequency is defined as the ratio f/S, where f is the frequency in Hz and S is the symbol rate. This ratio is used to specify the magnitude of the transmitted spectrum, which must conform to given templates for normalized frequencies within a specific range.

instruction: What is the purpose of the numerical index in specifying the transmitted spectrum for a modem?
input:
Source: The transmitted spectrum shall be specified by a numerical index. The index shall be provided by the remote modem during Phase 2 of start-up by the procedures defined in 11.2. or 12.2.
Standard: V.34
output: The numerical index specifies the transmitted spectrum characteristics of a modem, allowing for the selection of appropriate spectral parameters during the modem's start-up phase. This index is provided by the remote modem during Phase 2 of the start-up process, facilitating the establishment of communication parameters between modems.

instruction: What are the functions of Circuit 114 and Circuit 115 in synchronous interfacing for modems?
input:
Source: The modem shall provide to the DTE a clock on Circuit 114 for transmit-data timing, and a clock on Circuit 115 for receive-data timing. The transmit-data timing may, however, originate in the DTE and be transferred to the modem via Circuit 113.
Standard: V.34
output: In synchronous interfacing for modems, Circuit 114 provides the DTE with a clock for transmit-data timing, and Circuit 115 provides the DTE with a clock for receive-data timing. The transmit-data timing may alternatively originate in the DTE and be transferred to the modem via Circuit 113.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics required for the primary channel when an external physical interface is provided?
input:
Source: Where an external physical interface is provided, electrical characteristics conforming to Recommendations V.10 and V.11 shall be used. The connector and pole assignments specified by ISO 2110 or ISO/IEC 11569, column 'V-Series > 20 000 bit/s', shall be used. Alternatively, when the DTE-DCE interface speed is not designed to exceed 116 kbit/s, these same connectors may be used with characteristics conforming to Recommendation V.10 only (see Note).
Standard: V.34
output: The electrical characteristics for the primary channel must conform to V.10 and V.11 recommendations when an external physical interface is provided. The connector and pole assignments should follow ISO 2110 or ISO/IEC 11569, specifically under the 'V-Series > 20,000 bit/s' column. For interfaces not designed to exceed 116 kbit/s, V.10 characteristics alone may be used with the same connector assignments.

instruction: What is the purpose of hysteresis in a signal detector for Circuit 109?
input:
Source: The condition of Circuit 109 between the ON and OFF levels is not specified except that the signal detector shall provide hysteresis, such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs shall be at least 2 dB greater than that for the ONto OFF transition.
Standard: V.34
output: Hysteresis in a signal detector for Circuit 109 ensures that the OFF to ON transition level is at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition level, providing noise immunity and preventing rapid toggling between states due to signal fluctuations near the threshold.

instruction: How are mapping frames and symbol intervals indexed in a communication system?
input:
Source: Mapping frames are indicated by the time index i, where i = 0 for the first mapping frame of signal B1 defined in 10.1.3.1, and is incremented by 1 for each mapping frame thereafter. 4D symbol intervals are indicated by the time index m = 4i + j, where j ( = 0, 1, 2, 3) is a cyclic time index that indicates the position of the 4D symbol interval in a mapping frame. 2D symbol intervals are indicated by the time index n = 2m + k, where k ( = 0, 1) is a cyclic time index that indicates the position of the 2D symbol interval in a 4D symbol interval.
Standard: V.34
output: Mapping frames are indexed by the time index i, starting with i = 0 for the first mapping frame and incrementing by 1 for each subsequent frame. 4D symbol intervals within these frames are indexed by m = 4i + j, where j (0, 1, 2, 3) indicates the position of the 4D symbol interval in a mapping frame. Further, 2D symbol intervals are indexed by n = 2m + k, where k (0, 1) indicates the position of the 2D symbol interval within a 4D symbol interval.

instruction: How is the auxiliary channel multiplexing pattern determined in data transmission systems?
input:
Source: The auxiliary channel multiplexing pattern may be derived using an algorithm similar to the algorithm for SWP, the frame switching pattern. Prior to each data frame, a counter is set to zero. The counter is incremented by W at the beginning of each mapping frame. If the counter is less than P, a primary channel bit is sent; otherwise, an auxiliary channel bit is sent, and the counter is decremented by P.
Standard: V.34
output: The auxiliary channel multiplexing pattern is determined using an algorithm similar to the frame switching pattern algorithm. Prior to each data frame, a counter is initialized to zero. This counter is incremented by a value W at the start of each mapping frame. If the counter's value is less than a parameter P, a primary channel bit is transmitted. If the counter's value is equal to or exceeds P, an auxiliary channel bit is transmitted instead, and the counter is decremented by P.

instruction: What is the structure of signal constellations in a 1664-point superconstellation system?
input:
Source: Signal constellations consist of complex-valued signal points which lie on a two-dimensional rectangular grid. All signal constellations used in this Recommendation are subsets of a 1664-point superconstellation. Figure 5 shows one-quarter of the points in the superconstellation. These points are labelled with decimal integers between 0 and 415.The point with the smallest magnitude is labelled as 0, the point with the next larger magnitude is labelled as 1, and so on.When two or more points have the same magnitude, the point with the greatest imaginary component is taken first. Thefull superconstellation is the union of the four quarter-constellations obtained by rotating the constellation in Figure 5 by0, 90, 180 and 270 degrees. A signal constellation with L points consists of the L/4 points from the quarter-constellation in Figure 5 with labels 0 through L/4  – 1, and the 3L/4 points which are obtained by 90, 180 and 270 degree rotations of these signal points.
Standard: V.34
output: Signal constellations in a 1664-point superconstellation system consist of complex-valued signal points arranged on a two-dimensional rectangular grid. The superconstellation is divided into four quarter-constellations, each containing points labeled from 0 to 415, where the point with the smallest magnitude is labeled 0, and points with increasing magnitudes are labeled sequentially. Points with the same magnitude are ordered by their imaginary components. The full superconstellation is formed by rotating one quarter-constellation by 0, 90, 180, and 270 degrees. A signal constellation with L points includes L/4 points from the original quarter-constellation (labels 0 through L/4 - 1) and their rotations by 90, 180, and 270 degrees.

instruction: What is the relationship between the number of bits K and the parameter b in shell mapping for modems?
input:
Source: K=  0 if b  ≤  12; =  b  –  12  –  8q if b  >  12; (9-1) where q is the smallest non-negative integer such that K < 32 (q = 0 when K = 0).
Standard: V.34
output: In shell mapping for V.34 modems, the number of bits K put into the shell mapper per mapping frame is determined by the parameter b. If b is 12 or less, K is 0. For b greater than 12, K is calculated as b minus 12 minus 8 times q, where q is the smallest non-negative integer ensuring K remains less than 32. When K equals 0, q is also 0.

instruction: How is the number of signal points L in a 2D signal constellation calculated for modems?
input:
Source: L can also be calculated according to: L = 4M · 2q(9-2) Table 10/V.34 – Mapping parameters K, M and L at different data rates and symbol rates
Standard: V.34
output: The number of signal points L in a 2D signal constellation for V.34 modems is calculated using the formula L = 4M · 2q, where M and q are parameters that vary with the data rate and symbol rate. The values of M and q, along with the resulting L, are provided in a mapping table that correlates these parameters with different data and symbol rates.

instruction: What are the mapping parameters K, M, and L for a symbol rate of 2400 and a data rate of 19200?
input:
Source: 19 200 27 11 13 176 208
Standard: V.34
output: For a symbol rate of 2400 and a data rate of 19200, the mapping parameters are K=27, M=11, L=13 for the minimum values, and K=27, M=11, L=13 for the expanded values.

instruction: What are the values of K, M, and L for a symbol rate of 19,200 and data rate of 28?
input:
Source: 19 200 28 12 14 96 112
Standard: V.34
output: For a symbol rate of 19,200 and data rate of 28, the values are K=28, M=12, and L=14. The minimum expanded values are 96 for M and 112 for L.

instruction: How are the remaining bits divided in a mapping frame when the auxiliary channel is present?
input:
Source: In each mapping frame the remaining b  – K bits are divided into four groups of equal size, corresponding to four 4D symbols. The first three bits in each group are denoted by (I1 i,j, I2i,j, I3i,j), 0 ≤ j ≤ 3. (When the auxiliary channel is present, the bit I1 i,0 in the first group is either a primary channel bit or an auxiliary channel bit depending on AMP, the Auxiliary Channel Multiplexing Pattern, as explained in 8.3.) The remaining 2q = (b – K)/4 – 3 bits are divided into two subgroups of size q denoted by (Q i,j,k,1, Qi,j,k,2, ..., Qi,j,k,q), 0 ≤ k ≤ 1, corresponding to two 2D symbols.
Standard: V.34
output: In a mapping frame with an auxiliary channel present, the remaining bits after subtracting K bits are divided into four groups of equal size, corresponding to four 4D symbols. The first three bits in each group are denoted by (I1i,j, I2i,j, I3i,j), where 0 ≤ j ≤ 3. The bit I1i,0 in the first group can be either a primary channel bit or an auxiliary channel bit, depending on the Auxiliary Channel Multiplexing Pattern (AMP). The remaining bits, calculated as 2q = (b – K)/4 – 3, are further divided into two subgroups of size q, denoted by (Qi,j,k,1, Qi,j,k,2, ..., Qi,j,k,q), where 0 ≤ k ≤ 1, corresponding to two 2D symbols.

instruction: How is the integer I(m) calculated in a differential encoder for each 4D symbol interval?
input:
Source: In each 4D symbol interval m = 4i + j, the two bits (I2 i,j, I3i,j) shall be converted into an integer: I(m) = I2i,j + 2 · I3 i,j (9-25)
Standard: V.34
output: In each 4D symbol interval m = 4i + j, the integer I(m) is calculated from two bits (I2i,j, I3i,j) using the formula I(m) = I2i,j + 2 · I3i,j. This integer is then used in the differential encoding process.

instruction: How are the output 2D signal points u(2m) and u(2m + 1) obtained in a 4D symbol interval?
input:
Source: For each 4D symbol interval m = 4i + j, the mapping indices Q(2m) and Q(2m + 1) label two signal points v(2m) and v(2m + 1), respectively, from the quarter superconstellation of Figure 5. The output 2D signal points u(2m) and u(2m + 1) are obtained by rotating v(2m) by Z(m) · 90 degrees clockwise and v(2m + 1) by [Z(m) + 2 · I1i,j + U0(m)] · 90 degrees clockwise, respectively. The bit U 0(m) is the output of the trellis encoder, and is obtained according to the method described in 9.6.3.
Standard: V.34
output: The output 2D signal points u(2m) and u(2m + 1) are obtained by rotating the signal points v(2m) and v(2m + 1) from the quarter superconstellation. Specifically, v(2m) is rotated by Z(m) · 90 degrees clockwise, and v(2m + 1) is rotated by [Z(m) + 2 · I1i,j + U0(m)] · 90 degrees clockwise. The bit U0(m) is the output of the trellis encoder.

instruction: How are the four bits [Y4(m), Y3(m), Y2(m), Y1(m)] generated in a symbol-to-bit converter?
input:
Source: The symbol-to-bit converter generates four bits [Y 4(m), Y3(m), Y2(m), Y1(m)] as follows: The complex 2D channel output symbols y(2m) and y(2m + 1) lie on a 2D rectangular grid with odd-integer coordinates. The signal points on the grid are represented by a 3-bit subset label in an 8-way set partition. This labelling of points isshown in Figure 9 for a small subset of the points near the origin. Two-channel output symbols y(2m) and y(2m + 1) are used to generate two subset labels s(2m) and s(2m + 1), respectively, which are converted into four input bits [Y 4(m), Y3(m), Y2(m), Y1(m)] for the convolutional encoder according to Table 13.
Standard: V.34
output: The four bits [Y4(m), Y3(m), Y2(m), Y1(m)] are generated by converting two subset labels s(2m) and s(2m + 1) derived from two-channel output symbols y(2m) and y(2m + 1). These symbols lie on a 2D rectangular grid with odd-integer coordinates and are represented by a 3-bit subset label in an 8-way set partition. The conversion from subset labels to the four bits is performed according to a specific table that maps each combination of s(2m) and s(2m + 1) to the corresponding [Y4(m), Y3(m), Y2(m), Y1(m)] values.

instruction: What are the available encoders in a modem's start-up procedure and their respective states and rates?
input:
Source: The following encoders are available: – 16-state rate-2/3 (Figure 10);– 32-state rate-3/4 (Figure 11);– 64-state rate-4/5 (Figure 12). For the 32-state encoder, the input bit Y 3(m) is not used. For the 16-state encoder, the input bits Y 4(m) and Y 3(m) are not used.
Standard: V.34
output: The available encoders during a modem's start-up procedure include a 16-state rate-2/3 encoder, a 32-state rate-3/4 encoder, and a 64-state rate-4/5 encoder. For the 32-state encoder, the input bit Y3(m) is not used, and for the 16-state encoder, the input bits Y4(m) and Y3(m) are not used.

instruction: What is the frequency and transmission power level of Tone A in modem communication?
input:
Source: Tone A is a 2400 Hz tone transmitted by the answer modem. Transitions between A and A, and similarly between A and A, are 180 degree phase reversals in the 2400 Hz tone. During the transmission of A and A, the answer modem sends a 1800 Hz guard tone without any phase reversals. Tone A is transmitted at 1 dB below the nominal transmit power while the guard tone is transmitted at the nominal transmit power.
Standard: V.34
output: Tone A is a 2400 Hz tone transmitted by the answer modem, with transitions between A and A marked by 180 degree phase reversals. It is transmitted at 1 dB below the nominal transmit power level. During its transmission, the answer modem also sends a 1800 Hz guard tone without any phase reversals at the nominal transmit power.

instruction: What is the polynomial used for CRC generation in certain modulation systems?
input:
Source: The CRC is calculated by dividing a binary sequence by the specified polynomial. The polynomial used to compute the CRC is: x16 + x12 + x5 + 1. The CRC is calculated as follows: 1) load the shift register in the CRC generator with all ones;2) shift in the binary sequence; 3) output the contents of the shift register, starting with bit 0 in Figure 14. Bit 0 of the CRC is the LSB.
Standard: V.34
output: The polynomial used for CRC generation is x^16 + x^12 + x^5 + 1. The CRC is calculated by dividing a binary sequence by this polynomial, starting with the shift register loaded with all ones, shifting in the binary sequence, and then outputting the contents of the shift register starting with bit 0.

instruction: What is the purpose of bits 12 through 14 in the INFO 0 sequences of a modem?
input:
Source: 12 Set to 1 indicates symbol rate 2743 is supported. 13 Set to 1 indicates symbol rate 2800 is supported. 14 Set to 1 indicates symbol rate 3429 is supported.
Standard: V.34
output: Bits 12 through 14 in the INFO 0 sequences of a V.34 modem are used to indicate the modem's capabilities regarding supported symbol rates. Specifically, bit 12 set to 1 indicates support for a symbol rate of 2743, bit 13 set to 1 indicates support for a symbol rate of 2800, and bit 14 set to 1 indicates support for a symbol rate of 3429.

instruction: What is the purpose of bits 12-14 in the INFO 1c sequence of a modem communication?
input:
Source: 12:14 Minimum power reduction to be implemented by the answer modem transmitter. An integer between 0 and 7 gives the recommended power reduction in dB. These bits shall indicate 0 if INFO 0a indicated that the answer modem transmitter cannot reduce its power.
Standard: V.34
output: Bits 12-14 in the INFO 1c sequence specify the minimum power reduction to be implemented by the answer modem transmitter. This is represented as an integer between 0 and 7, indicating the recommended power reduction in dB. If the answer modem transmitter cannot reduce its power, as indicated by INFO 0a, these bits shall be set to 0.

instruction: What is the purpose of the INFO 1a sequence bits 12:14 in modem communication?
input:
Source: 12:14 Minimum power reduction to be im plemented b y the call modem transmitter. An inte ger between 0 and 7 gives the recommended power reduction in dB. These bits shall indicate 0 if INFO 0c indicated that the call mode m transmitter cannot reduce its power.
Standard: V.34
output: The INFO 1a sequence bits 12:14 specify the minimum power reduction to be implemented by the call modem transmitter. This is represented as an integer between 0 and 7, indicating the recommended power reduction in dB. If INFO 0c indicates that the call modem transmitter cannot reduce its power, these bits shall be set to 0.

instruction: How are INFOMARKS c and a transmitted in a modem communication system?
input:
Source: INFOMARKS c is transmitted by the call modem by applying binary ones to the DPSK modulator described in 10.1.2.3.1. INFOMARKS a is transmitted by the answer modem by applying binary ones to the DPSK modulator described in 10.1.2.3.1.
Standard: V.34
output: INFOMARKS c is transmitted by the call modem by applying binary ones to the DPSK modulator. Similarly, INFOMARKS a is transmitted by the answer modem also by applying binary ones to the DPSK modulator.

instruction: What is the purpose of sequence B1 in modem communication?
input:
Source: Sequence B1 consists of one data frame of scrambled ones transmitted at the end of start-up using the selected data mode modulation parameters. Bit inversions for superframe synchronization are inserted as if the data frame were the last dataframe in a superframe. Prior to transmission of B1, the scrambler, trellis encoder, differential encoder, and the precodingfilter tap delay line are initialized to zeroes.
Standard: V.34
output: Sequence B1 consists of one data frame of scrambled ones transmitted at the end of start-up using the selected data mode modulation parameters. It includes bit inversions for superframe synchronization as if the data frame were the last dataframe in a superframe. Before transmission, the scrambler, trellis encoder, differential encoder, and the precoding filter tap delay line are initialized to zeroes.

instruction: What is the structure and purpose of signal PP in modem communication?
input:
Source: Signal PP consists of  six periods of a 48-symbol sequence and is used by the remote modem for training its equalizer. PP(i), i = 0, 1, ..., 287 is defined as follows: Set i  =  4k  +  I where: k  =  0, 1, 2, ..., 71; and I  =  0, 1, 2, 3 for each k then: PP(i)  = ejπ(kI+4)/6if k modulo 3  =  1 =ejπkI/6otherwise (10-1) PP(0) is transmitted first.
Standard: V.34
output: Signal PP consists of six periods of a 48-symbol sequence, totaling 288 symbols (i = 0 to 287). It is used by the remote modem for training its equalizer. The sequence is defined by the formula PP(i) = ejπ(kI+4)/6 if k modulo 3 = 1, otherwise PP(i) = ejπkI/6, where i = 4k + I, k ranges from 0 to 71, and I ranges from 0 to 3 for each k. The transmission starts with PP(0).

instruction: How is the 16-point MP sequence generated in modem communication?
input:
Source: The 16-point MP sequence is generated by using four scrambled bits I1 n, I2n, Q1n and Q2 n which are transmitted every 2D symbol interval where I1 n is the first bit in time. Integer 2 * Q2n + Q1n selects the point from the quarter-superconstellation of Figure 5. Integers I n = 2 * I2n + I1n are differentially encoded to generate integer Z n as the modulo 4 sum of I n and Zn−1. Finally, the transmitted point is obtained by clockwise rotation of the selected point by Zn * 90 degrees. The differential encoder shall be initialized using the final symbol of the transmitted TRN sequence.
Standard: V.34
output: The 16-point MP sequence is generated using four scrambled bits I1n, I2n, Q1n, and Q2n, transmitted every 2D symbol interval, with I1n being the first bit in time. The integer 2 * Q2n + Q1n selects the point from the quarter-superconstellation. Integers In = 2 * I2n + I1n are differentially encoded to generate integer Zn as the modulo 4 sum of In and Zn−1. The transmitted point is obtained by clockwise rotation of the selected point by Zn * 90 degrees. The differential encoder is initialized using the final symbol of the transmitted TRN sequence.

instruction: What is the purpose of the frame sync bits in the MP sequence Type 1 for modems?
input:
Source: 0:16 Frame sync: 11111111111111111.
Standard: V.34
output: The frame sync bits in the MP sequence Type 1 for V.34 modems serve as a synchronization pattern. Specifically, bits 0 to 16 (LSB:MSB) are set to '11111111111111111' to help the receiving modem identify the start of the MP sequence and synchronize its decoding process with the transmitting modem's data stream.

instruction: What are the characteristics of the INFO h sequence bits in half-duplex operation Phase 2?
input:
Source: Table 22/V.34 – Definition of bits in INFO h sequence
Standard: V.34
output: The INFO h sequence bits in half-duplex operation Phase 2 are defined with specific roles across bits 0 to 50. Bits 0:3 are fill bits set to 1111. Bits 4:11 represent frame sync with the pattern 01110010, where the left-most bit is first in time. Bits 12:14 indicate the power reduction requested by the recipient modem receiver, ranging from 0 to 7 dB, with 0 indicating no power reduction capability. Bits 15:21 specify the length of TRN sequence in 35 ms increments, ranging from 0 to 127. Bit 22, when set to 1, indicates the use of high carrier frequency in data mode. Bits 23:26 determine the pre-emphasis filter index, ranging from 0 to 10. Bits 27:29 define the symbol rate for data transmission, with 0 representing 2400 and 5 representing 3429. Bit 30 indicates whether TRN uses a 16-point (1) or 4-point (0) constellation. Bits 31:46 are for CRC code, and bits 47:50 are fill bits set to 1111.

instruction: How is signal Sh transmitted in the described modulation scheme?
input:
Source: Signal Sh is transmitted by alternating between point 0 of the quarter-superconstellation of Figure 5 and the same point rotated counterclockwise by 90 degrees. Signal Sh is transmitted by alternating between point 0 rotated by 180 degrees and point 0 rotated counterclockwise by 270 degrees. Signal Sh shall end with the transmission of point 0 rotatedcounterclockwise by 90 degrees. Signal Sh shall begin with the transmission of point 0 rotated by 180 degrees.
Standard: V.34
output: Signal Sh is transmitted by alternating between point 0 of the quarter-superconstellation and the same point rotated counterclockwise by 90 degrees. It begins with the transmission of point 0 rotated by 180 degrees and ends with the transmission of point 0 rotated counterclockwise by 90 degrees.

instruction: What are the key differences between Type 0 and Type 1 MPh sequences in half-duplex mode?
input:
Source: Type 1 is the same as Type 0 with the addition of fields for precoding coefficients. The bit fields for the two types ofMPh sequences used in half-duplex mode are defined in Tables 23 and 24. Either type (Type 0 or Type 1) of MPh sequence may be sent. Prior to receiving the first MPh sequence during control channel start-up, the precoding coefficients are initialized to 0. If a Type 0 sequence is received, the precodingcoefficients are unaffected.
Standard: V.34
output: Type 0 MPh sequences include fields for frame sync, start bit, type indication, maximum data signalling rate, control channel data signalling rate, trellis encoder selection, non-linear encoder parameter selection, constellation shaping, data signalling rate capability mask, and asymmetric control channel data rate enable. Type 1 sequences contain all these fields plus additional fields for precoding coefficients. Prior to receiving the first MPh sequence, precoding coefficients are initialized to 0 and remain unaffected if a Type 0 sequence is received.

instruction: What is the definition and purpose of the Frame sync in the MPh sequence Type 1?
input:
Source: 0:16 Frame sync: 11111111111111111.
Standard: V.34
output: The Frame sync in the MPh sequence Type 1 is defined as a sequence of 17 consecutive '1's (LSB:MSB 0:16). Its purpose is to provide a synchronization signal that helps the receiving modem identify the start of a frame and align its decoding process accordingly.

instruction: What is the purpose of the PPh sequence in half-duplex mode?
input:
Source: PPh consists of four periods of an 8-symbol sequence and is used in half-duplex mode for control channel receiver initialization and resynchronization.
Standard: V.34
output: The PPh sequence is used in half-duplex mode for control channel receiver initialization and resynchronization. It consists of four periods of an 8-symbol sequence, defined by a specific mathematical formula for each symbol in the sequence.

instruction: What is the initial silence period required for an answer modem upon connection to line before transmitting signal ANSam?
input:
Source: Upon connection to line, the modem shall initially remain silent for a minimum of 200 ms and then transmit signal ANSam according to the procedure in Recommendation V.8.
Standard: V.34
output: The answer modem must remain silent for a minimum of 200 ms upon connection to the line before transmitting signal ANSam.

instruction: What is the duration of the silent period ending Phase 1 in a call modem's operation?
input:
Source: During the 75 ± 5 ms silent period ending Phase 1, the call modem shall condition its receiver to receive INFO0a and detect Tone A.
Standard: V.34
output: The silent period ending Phase 1 in a call modem's operation lasts for 75 ± 5 ms. During this period, the call modem conditions its receiver to receive INFO0a and detect Tone A.

instruction: What is the duration of signal L1 that the call modem shall receive during the start-up procedure?
input:
Source: The call modem shall receive signal L1 for its 160 ms duration.
Standard: V.34
output: The call modem shall receive signal L1 for its 160 ms duration during the start-up procedure.

instruction: What actions should a call modem take if it receives INFO 0a with bit 28 set to 1?
input:
Source: If the call modem receives INFO 0a with bit 28 set to 1, it shall condition its receiver to detect Tone A and the subsequent Tone A phase reversal, complete sending the current INFO 0c sequence, and then transmit Tone B. Alternatively, if the call modem detects Tone A and has received INFO 0a, it shall condition its receiver to detect a Tone A phase reversal, complete sending the current INFO 0c sequence, and transmit Tone B. In both cases, the call modem shall then proceed according to 11.2.1.1.3.
Standard: V.34
output: The call modem should condition its receiver to detect Tone A and the subsequent Tone A phase reversal, complete sending the current INFO 0c sequence, and then transmit Tone B. It should then proceed according to the established protocol sequence.

instruction: What is the duration of signal MD if indicated as zero in INFO 1a during modem initialization?
input:
Source: If the duration of signal MD indicated by INFO 1a is zero, the modem shall proceed according to 11.3.1.1.2. Otherwise, after detecting the S-to- S transition, the modem shall wait for the duration of signal MD as indicated by INFO 1a and then shall condition its receiver to receive signal S and the S-to- S transition.
Standard: V.34
output: If the duration of signal MD is indicated as zero in INFO 1a, the modem proceeds directly to the next step without waiting for any MD signal duration. Specifically, it conditions its receiver to detect signal S and the subsequent S-to-S transition immediately after detecting the initial S signal.

instruction: What is the duration of signal TRN in a modem's transmission sequence?
input:
Source: Signal TRN consists of four constellation points and shall be transmitted for at least 512T.
Standard: V.34
output: Signal TRN consists of four constellation points and shall be transmitted for at least 512T.

instruction: What is the minimum duration the modem should transmit the TRN signal before conditioning its receiver to receive sequence MP?
input:
Source: After transmitting signal TRN for a minimum of 512T, the modem shall condition its receiver to receive sequence MP and may continue sending TRN for up to 2000 ms.
Standard: V.34
output: The modem should transmit the TRN signal for a minimum of 512T before conditioning its receiver to receive sequence MP. It may continue sending TRN for up to 2000 ms if necessary.

instruction: What actions does a modem take after receiving a 20-bit E sequence during Phase 4 of communication?
input:
Source: After receiving a 20-bit E sequence, the modem shall condition its receiver to receive B1. After receiving B1, the modem shall unclamp Circuit 104, turn on Circuit 109, and begin demodulating data.
Standard: V.34
output: After receiving a 20-bit E sequence, the modem conditions its receiver to receive B1. Upon receiving B1, it unclamps Circuit 104, turns on Circuit 109, and begins demodulating data.

instruction: What actions should an answer modem take if Tone B is detected during Phase 4?
input:
Source: If Tone B is detected during Phase 4, the answer modem shall respond to a retrain according to 11.5.2.2. The answer modem may initiate a retrain during Phase 4 according to 11.5.2.1.
Standard: V.34
output: If Tone B is detected during Phase 4, the answer modem shall respond to a retrain by turning OFF Circuit 106, clamping Circuit 104 to binary one, and transmitting silence for 70 ± 5 ms. It shall then transmit Tone A and proceed in accordance with the specified procedure for responding to retrain.

instruction: What is the sequence of operations a modem follows when initiating a retrain in duplex mode?
input:
Source: 11.6.1.1.2 After detecting signal S, the modem shall clamp Circuit 104 to binary one and be conditioned to detect the S-to-S transition. After detecting the S-to- S transition, the modem shall condition its receiver to receive sequence MP. When the modem has received at least one MP sequence, and the modem is sending MP sequences, the modem shall complete sending the current MP sequence and then send MP ′ sequences. 11.6.1.1.3 The initiating modem shall continue sending MP ′ sequences until it has sent an MP ′ sequence and received MP′ or E from the responding modem. The modem shall then complete the current MP ′ sequence and send a single 20-bit E sequence. The initiating modem shall determine the data signalling rates as described in 11.4.1.1.3, if it is the callmodem or in 11.4.1.2.3, if it is the answer modem. 11.6.1.1.4 After sending the E sequence, the initiating modem shall send B1 at the negotiated data signalling rate using the data mode modulation parameters. The modem shall then enable Circuit 106 to respond to the condition ofCircuit 105, start a new superframe, and begin data transmission using the modulation procedures of clauses 5 to 9.
Standard: V.34
output: When initiating a retrain in duplex mode, the modem first detects signal S, clamps Circuit 104 to binary one, and prepares to detect the S-to-S transition. Upon detecting this transition, it conditions its receiver to receive sequence MP. After receiving at least one MP sequence and while sending MP sequences, it completes the current MP sequence and switches to sending MP' sequences. The modem continues sending MP' sequences until it has sent an MP' sequence and received MP' or E from the responding modem. It then completes the current MP' sequence and sends a single 20-bit E sequence. Following this, the modem sends B1 at the negotiated data signalling rate using data mode modulation parameters, enables Circuit 106 to respond to Circuit 105, starts a new superframe, and begins data transmission using the specified modulation procedures.

instruction: What actions should a responding modem take after sending an E sequence during rate renegotiation?
input:
Source: After sending an E sequence, the responding modem shall send B1 at the negotiated data signalling rate using the data mode modulation parameters, enable Circuit 106 to respond to the condition of Circuit 105, start a new superframe, and begin data transmission using the modulation procedures of clauses 5 to 9.
Standard: V.34
output: After sending an E sequence, the responding modem should send B1 at the negotiated data signalling rate using the data mode modulation parameters. It should then enable Circuit 106 to respond to the condition of Circuit 105, start a new superframe, and begin data transmission using the modulation procedures specified in clauses 5 to 9.

instruction: What are the timeout periods for a modem to initiate the retrain procedure after transmitting the S-to-S transition without receiving sequence E?
input:
Source: If after transmitting the S-to- S transition, the modem has not received sequence E for the following timeout period, it shall initiate the retrain procedure. If bit 24 in INFO 0 is set to 1 (the CME bit in Table 14), the timeout period shall be 30 seconds. If bit 24 in INFO 0 is set to 0, the timeout period shall be 2500 ms plus three round trip delays.
Standard: V.34
output: The timeout period depends on the setting of bit 24 in INFO 0. If bit 24 is set to 1, the timeout period is 30 seconds. If bit 24 is set to 0, the timeout period is 2500 ms plus three round trip delays.

instruction: What is the sequence of operations for error-free half-duplex communication when the call modem is the source modem?
input:
Source: 12.2.1.1 Call modem error-free operation
