12.2.1.1.1 During the 75 ± 5 ms silent period ending Phase 1, the call modem shall condition its receiver to receive INFO 0a and detect Tone A. After the 75 ± 5 ms silent period, the call modem shall send INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 0, followed by Tone B.
12.2.1.1.2 After receiving INFO 0a, the modem shall condition its receiver to detect Tone A and the subsequent Tone A phase reversal.
12.2.1.1.3 After detecting the Tone A phase reversal, the call modem shall wait 40 ± 10 ms and transmit a Tone B phase reversal. Tone B shall be transmitted for another 10 ms after the phase reversal, and then the modem shall transmit signal L1 for 160 ms. The modem shall then transmit signal L2 and condition its receiver to detect Tone A.
12.2.1.1.4 After detecting Tone A, the call modem shall transmit Tone B and condition its receiver to receive INFO h.
After receiving INFO h, the modem shall proceed according to 12.3.1.
Standard: V.34
output: The sequence begins with the call modem conditioning its receiver during a 75 ± 5 ms silent period to receive INFO 0a and detect Tone A. After this period, it sends INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 0, followed by Tone B. Upon receiving INFO 0a, the modem prepares to detect Tone A and its subsequent phase reversal. After detecting the Tone A phase reversal, the call modem waits 40 ± 10 ms, transmits a Tone B phase reversal, continues Tone B for another 10 ms, then transmits signal L1 for 160 ms, followed by signal L2, while conditioning its receiver to detect Tone A. After detecting Tone A, it transmits Tone B and prepares to receive INFO h, proceeding to the next phase after reception.

instruction: What are the recovery mechanisms for a call modem when Tone A is detected before correctly receiving INFO 0a?
input:
Source: 12.2.1.3.1 If, in 12.2.1.1.2 or 12.2.1.1.3, Tone A is detected before correctly receiving INFO 0a, or repeated INFO 0a is received, the modem will repeatedly send INFO 0c. If the call modem receives INFO 0a with bit 28 set to 1, it will condition itself to detect Tone A followed by a phase reversal in Tone A, complete sending the current INFO 0c sequence, and then transmit Tone B. Alternatively, if the call modem detects Tone A having correctly received INFO 0a, it will condition itself to detect a phase reversal in Tone A, complete sending the current INFO 0c sequence, and transmit Tone B. In either case, the call modem then proceeds according to 12.2.1.1.3.
Standard: V.34
output: When Tone A is detected before correctly receiving INFO 0a, the call modem will repeatedly send INFO 0c. If INFO 0a is received with bit 28 set to 1, the modem conditions itself to detect Tone A followed by a phase reversal in Tone A, completes sending the current INFO 0c sequence, and then transmits Tone B. Alternatively, if the call modem detects Tone A after correctly receiving INFO 0a, it conditions itself to detect a phase reversal in Tone A, completes the current INFO 0c sequence, and transmits Tone B. In both cases, the modem then proceeds to the next phase of operation.

instruction: What actions does an answer modem take upon receiving INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 1?
input:
Source: If the answer modem receives INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 1, it will condition itself to detect Tone B, complete sending the current INFO 0a sequence, and transmit Tone A. Alternatively, if the answer modem detects Tone B having correctly received INFO 0c, it will complete sending the current INFO 0a sequence, and transmit Tone A. In either case, the answer modem then proceeds according to 12.2.1.2.3.
Standard: V.34
output: Upon receiving INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 1, the answer modem conditions itself to detect Tone B, completes sending the current INFO 0a sequence, and transmits Tone A. It then proceeds according to the specified protocol sequence.

instruction: What are the timing parameters for the phases 2 and 3 in a modem communication?
input:
Source: Figure 24/V.34 – Phases 2 and 3 – Answer modem is source modem10 ms160 ms 288T≤ 670 ms 75 ± 5 ms75 ± 5 ms10 ms50 ms 70 ± 5 ms ≤ 2000 msB CJCM L1L2 A SPPTRN JM16T 40 ± 10 ms25 msINFOh INFO0aB AINFO0c B A S 16T 16T ≤ 2000 ms128T 288TSP P T R N SP P TRN S S 128T 288T
Standard: V.34
output: In V.34 modem communication phases 2 and 3, the answer modem acts as the source modem with specific timing parameters: the initial phase has a duration of 10 ms, followed by a period of 160 ms, and then 288T where T is the symbol period. The total time for these phases should not exceed 670 ms. Additional timing parameters include intervals of 75 ± 5 ms, 10 ms, 50 ms, and 70 ± 5 ms, with certain phases requiring completion within ≤ 2000 ms.

instruction: What actions does an answer modem take upon receiving INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 1?
input:
Source: If the answer modem receives INFO 0c with bit 28 set to 1, it will condition itself to detect Tone B followed by a phase reversal in Tone B, and transmit Tone A. Alternatively, if the answer modem detects Tone B having correctly received INFO 0c, it shall be conditioned to detect a phase reversal in Tone B, and transmit Tone A. In either case, the answer modem shall then proceed in accordance with 12.2.2.2.3.
Standard: V.34
output: The answer modem conditions itself to detect Tone B followed by a phase reversal in Tone B, and transmits Tone A. Alternatively, if it detects Tone B after correctly receiving INFO 0c, it conditions itself to detect a phase reversal in Tone B and transmits Tone A. In both scenarios, the modem then proceeds according to the established protocol for further communication.

instruction: What is the sequence of signals exchanged between source and recipient modems during control channel initial training and restart?
input:
Source: Source modem Recipient modemPrimary channel dataControl channel data Control channel data109 104106106 104 109109106104≥ 16T < 120T32TPPh ALT MPh MPh EPPh ALT MPh MPh E≥ 16T 32T < 120T70 ± 5 ms FIGURE 25/V.34...[D25] = 10.5 cm 12.4.1 Source modem 12.4.1.1 The source modem shall condition its receiver to detect signal PPh. After a silent interval of 70 ± 5 ms, it sends signal PPh followed by signal ALT for a minimum of 16T. Upon detection of signal PPh, the source modem shalltrain its control channel equalizer using signal PPh, and condition its receiver to receive MPh from the recipient modem. 12.4.1.2 After receiving signal PPh, the source modem shall send sequence MPh within 120T. 12.4.1.3 When the source modem has received at least one MPh sequence and the modem is sending MPh sequences, the modem shall complete the current MPh and send a single 20-bit E sequence. At this time the modem shalldetermine the data signalling rate for the primary channel as follows: The source modem’s transmit rate shall be the maximum rate enabled that is less than or equal to the data signalling rates specified in both modems’ MPh sequences. 12.4.1.4 After sending sequence E, the source modem shall enable Circuit 106 to respond to Circuit 105 and transmit user control channel data using the data signalling rate indicated in the MPh sequence transmitted by therecipient modem. After receiving sequence E, the modem shall unclamp Circuit 104, turn on Circuit 109, and receivecontrol channel user data at the data signalling rate indicated in the MPh sequence sent by the source modem. 12.4.2 Recipient modem 12.4.2.1 The recipient modem conditions its receiver to detect signal PPh. After detecting signal PPh, it shall transmit signal PPh, train its control channel equalizer using signal PPh, and condition its receiver to receive MPh fromthe source modem. 12.4.2.2 After the recipient modem transmits signal PPh, it shall transmit signal ALT. 12.4.2.3 After transmitting signal ALT for at least 16T and no more than 120T, the recipient modem sends sequence MPh.
Standard: V.34
output: The sequence begins with the source modem detecting signal PPh after a silent interval of 70 ± 5 ms. It then sends signal PPh followed by signal ALT for a minimum of 16T. Upon detecting PPh, the source modem trains its control channel equalizer and prepares to receive MPh from the recipient modem. The recipient modem, after detecting PPh, transmits PPh, trains its equalizer, and prepares to receive MPh. It then transmits ALT for at least 16T but no more than 120T, followed by sequence MPh. The source modem, after receiving at least one MPh sequence and while sending MPh sequences, completes the current MPh and sends a single 20-bit E sequence. This determines the data signalling rate for the primary channel based on the maximum rate enabled that is less than or equal to the rates specified in both modems' MPh sequences. After sending E, the source modem enables Circuit 106 to respond to Circuit 105 and transmits user control channel data at the rate indicated in the recipient modem's MPh sequence. The recipient modem, after receiving E, unclamps Circuit 104, turns on Circuit 109, and receives control channel user data at the rate indicated in the source modem's MPh sequence.

instruction: What is the process for determining the data signalling rate for the primary channel when a recipient modem has received at least one MPh sequence and is sending MPh sequences?
input:
Source: When the recipient modem has received at least one MPh sequence and the modem is sending MPh sequences, the modem shall complete the current MPh and send a single 20-bit E sequence. At this point, the modem shall determine the data signalling rate for the primary channel as follows: The recipient modem’s receive rate shall be the maximum rate enabled that is less than or equal to the data signalling rates specified in both modems’ MPh sequences.
Standard: V.34
output: The recipient modem completes the current MPh sequence and sends a single 20-bit E sequence. The data signalling rate for the primary channel is then determined as the maximum rate enabled that is less than or equal to the data signalling rates specified in both modems’ MPh sequences.

instruction: What actions should a source modem take if it detects Tone A instead of signal PPh during the control channel start-up sequence?
input:
Source: 12.4.3.1 If, in 12.4.1.1, the source modem is the call modem, upon detection of Tone A instead of signal PPh, it shall transmit Tone B. Upon reception of INFO h, it shall proceed according to 12.3.1. If the source modem is the answer modem, upon detection of Tone B instead of signal PPh, it shall transmit Tone A. Upon detection of INFO h, it shall proceed according to 12.3.1.
Standard: V.34
output: If the source modem is the call modem and detects Tone A instead of signal PPh, it should transmit Tone B. Upon reception of INFO h, it should proceed with the standard start-up sequence. If the source modem is the answer modem and detects Tone B instead of signal PPh, it should transmit Tone A. Upon detection of INFO h, it should proceed with the standard start-up sequence. This procedure is specifically applied to the control channel start-up sequence after primary channel equalizer training.

instruction: What is the procedure for control channel resynchronization between page transmissions when no change in modulation parameters is desired?
input:
Source: 12.6.1.1 If a change in modulation parameters is desired, the source modem proceeds according to 12.4.1.1. Otherwise, the source modem shall transmit silence for 70 ± 5 ms, then transmit signal Sh for 24T followed by Sh for 8T. 12.6.1.2 The source modem shall then condition its receiver to detect signal PPh or signal Sh followed by Sh, and then send sequence ALT. 12.6.1.3 If signal PPh is detected, the modem shall transmit signal PPh followed by sequence ALT for a minimum of 16T, condition its receiver to receive MPh, and then proceed in accordance with 12.4.1.2. 12.6.1.4 If signal Sh followed by Sh is detected, the modem shall condition its receiver to detect sequence E, and then send sequence ALT for a minimum of 16T but no more than 120T, followed by sequence E. The modem shall then enable Circuit 106 to respond to the condition of Circuit 105 and transmit user control channel data using the control channel data signalling rate from the previous transmission. After receiving sequence E, the modem shall unclamp Circuit 104, turn on Circuit 109, and receive user control channel data.
Standard: V.34
output: The source modem transmits silence for 70 ± 5 ms, then transmits signal Sh for 24T followed by Sh for 8T. It then conditions its receiver to detect signal PPh or signal Sh followed by Sh, and sends sequence ALT. If signal PPh is detected, it transmits signal PPh followed by sequence ALT for a minimum of 16T, conditions its receiver to receive MPh, and proceeds accordingly. If signal Sh followed by Sh is detected, it conditions its receiver to detect sequence E, sends sequence ALT for a minimum of 16T but no more than 120T, followed by sequence E. It then enables Circuit 106 to respond to Circuit 105 and transmits user control channel data using the previous transmission's control channel data signalling rate. After receiving sequence E, it unclamps Circuit 104, turns on Circuit 109, and receives user control channel data.

instruction: What actions does a modem take when the received signal level falls below the turn-off threshold?
input:
Source: If the received signal level falls below the turn-off threshold as defined in 6.6.2, then the modem shall turn OFF Circuit 109 and clamp Circuit 104. If the received signal level returns above the turn-on threshold defined in 6.6.2, the modem shall turn ON Circuit 109 and unclamp Circuit 104.
Standard: V.34
output: When the received signal level falls below the turn-off threshold, the modem turns OFF Circuit 109 and clamps Circuit 104. If the signal level subsequently returns above the turn-on threshold, the modem turns ON Circuit 109 and unclamps Circuit 104.

instruction: What is the maximum time allowed for a responding modem to send MPh after receiving signal PPh in a modem communication?
input:
Source: If the responding modem is the recipient modem, after receiving signal PPh, it shall send MPh within 120T (ofALT) and then proceed in accordance with 12.4.2.4.
Standard: V.34
output: The responding modem must send MPh within 120T (of ALT) after receiving signal PPh in a V.34 modem communication.

instruction: What is the purpose of the precoder filter in a communication system?
input:
Source: q(n) Precoder filter output
Standard: V.34
output: The precoder filter in a communication system is used to process the input signal before modulation to mitigate the effects of intersymbol interference (ISI) and other channel impairments. It typically operates by shaping the signal spectrum or applying specific coding techniques to improve signal integrity and reduce errors during transmission. The output of the precoder filter, denoted as q(n), is a processed version of the input signal u, which is then used for further modulation and transmission.

instruction: What are the functions of bits 52 to 54 in the MP sequence Type 0 for modems?
input:
Source: 52 Modem Control Channel Enable: 0: disabled, 1: enabled. 53 Seamless Signalling Rate Change Enabled: 0: disabled, 1: enabled. 54 Modem Control Channel mode select. Reserved for future use and should be set to 0 by the transmitting modem and not be interpreted by the receiving modem.
Standard: V.34
output: Bits 52 to 54 in the MP sequence Type 0 for V.34 modems have specific functions: Bit 52 controls the Modem Control Channel Enable (0: disabled, 1: enabled). Bit 53 controls the Seamless Signalling Rate Change Enabled (0: disabled, 1: enabled). Bit 54 is for Modem Control Channel mode select, which is reserved for future use and should be set to 0 by the transmitting modem and not interpreted by the receiving modem.

instruction: What are the three categories of auxiliary channel superframes in modem control protocols?
input:
Source: There are three categories of auxiliary channel superframe: •clear secondary channel superframes; •framed secondary channel superframes; and •modem control superframes. The clear secondary channel superframes are used to transport 56 bits of secondary channel data for a total of 200 bits per second. The framed secondary channel superframes are used to transport 42 bits of secondary channel data for a total of150 bits per second. When the modem needs to transport modem control data, it will flow control the secondary channelas indicated in 6.2.2 and allocate all 56 bits of the superframe for modem control.
Standard: V.34
output: The three categories of auxiliary channel superframes are clear secondary channel superframes, framed secondary channel superframes, and modem control superframes. Clear secondary channel superframes transport 56 bits of secondary channel data at 200 bits per second. Framed secondary channel superframes transport 42 bits of secondary channel data at 150 bits per second. Modem control superframes allocate all 56 bits of the superframe for modem control when needed.

instruction: How are modem control superframes structured in modems?
input:
Source: These superframes are constructed as follows (see Table A.3): Table A.3/V.34 – Modem control superframes Bit 0 is the first bit transmitted. The definition of these bits is described in the subclauses below on each modem control type. The secondary channel in both the transmitter and receiver are flow controlled. The 4-bit modem control type willbe repeated in each of the four 14-bit groups. The 8-bit modem control data may be repeated in each of the four 14-bitgroups, or it may contain different data in each of the four 14-bit groups, depending on the modem control type. Thedefinitions of each modem control type are given below. NOTE 1 – Specific coding of these frames is for further study. There are four categories of modem control superframes: •Request; •Update; •Precode coefficient; and •Precode CRC. Either modem can initiate a request at any time. A modem can only initiate an update in response to a request, although it will only initiate an update for those requests that it chooses to grant. In addition, the parameters of the request may bemodified by the modem initiating an update before returning these parameters in the update. More details will be given inthe description of each modem control type in the following subclauses. If a modem sends a request and does not receivean update, it shall not repeat the request for at least ten seconds. NOTE 2 – The duration and conditions of error recovery procedures are for further study. Redundant bits are sent to ensure valid reception of requests and updates. The receiver shall establish detection criteria,which minimizes the probability of false detection of requests for a given error rate, and maximizes the probability ofcorrect detection of updates. See Table A.4. Table A.4/V.34 – Modem control superframe categoriesBit position Meaning 0-1; 14-15; 28-29; 42-43 All ones 2-5; 16-19; 30-33; 44-47 Modem control type 6-13; 20-27; 34-41; 48-55 Modem control data Modem control superframe categoryDescriptionControl type bit mapping RATER Rate update request 0000 RATEU Rate update 0011 PRECODER Precode coefficient update request 0101 PRECODEU Precode coefficient update 1010 PRECODECOEF Precode coefficient 0101 PRECODECRC Precode CRC 0101
Standard: V.34
output: Modem control superframes in V.34 modems are structured with Bit 0 as the first bit transmitted. Each superframe consists of four 14-bit groups. The first 4 bits in each group represent the modem control type, which is repeated across all four groups. The following 8 bits contain modem control data, which may be repeated or vary across groups depending on the control type. The superframes are categorized into four types: Request, Update, Precode coefficient, and Precode CRC. Requests can be initiated by either modem at any time, while updates are only sent in response to requests. Redundant bits are included to ensure valid reception, with specific bit positions allocated for all ones, modem control type, and modem control data.

instruction: What are the possible responses of modem B upon receiving a rate request from modem A?
input:
Source: If modem B receives a rate request from modem A, then modem B can deny the request by not responding, or it can do one or both of the following: initiate a rate update or initiate a rate request. If modem A is requesting a change in modem B’s transmit data rate, modem B can respond with a rate update which indicates a transmit data rate which is less than or equal to that requested by modem A. If modem A is requesting a change in modem B’s receive data rate, modem B can respond with a rate request which indicates modem B’s maximum reliable receive data rate.
Standard: V.34
output: Upon receiving a rate request from modem A, modem B can deny the request by not responding, or it can initiate a rate update, a rate request, or both. If the request is for a change in modem B's transmit data rate, modem B can respond with a rate update indicating a transmit data rate that is less than or equal to the requested rate. If the request is for a change in modem B's receive data rate, modem B can respond with a rate request indicating its maximum reliable receive data rate.

instruction: What happens when bit 155 of a Type 1 or bit 53 of a Type 0 MP sequence is set to 1 in a modem's transmission?
input:
Source: If bit 155 of a Type 1 or bit 53 of a Type 0 MP sequence is 1, the transmit modem will transmit the TRN sequence and flow control the primary channel as indicated in 11.6 during the last data frame of the superframe prior to updating the data rate. This will allow the transmit modem to update its data mode parameters by overwriting them. If bit 155 of a Type 1 or bit 53 of a Type 0 MP sequence is 1, the receive modem will flow control the primary channel as indicated in 11.6 during the last data frame of the superframe prior to updating the data rate. This will allow the receive modem to update its data mode parameters by overwriting them.
Standard: V.34
output: When bit 155 of a Type 1 or bit 53 of a Type 0 MP sequence is set to 1, the transmit modem will transmit the TRN sequence and flow control the primary channel during the last data frame of the superframe prior to updating the data rate. This action allows the transmit modem to update its data mode parameters by overwriting them. Similarly, the receive modem will flow control the primary channel during the last data frame of the superframe prior to updating the data rate, enabling it to update its data mode parameters by overwriting them.

instruction: What is the structure of the precode coefficient superframe bits in a modem?
input:
Source: Table A.9/V.34 – Precode coefficient superframe bitsBit position Meaning
0-1 11
2-5 1010
6-13 Reserved
14-27 Same as 0-13
28-41 Same as 0-13
42-55 Same as 0-13
Bit position Meaning
0-1 11
2-5 0101
6-13 Real Coefficient (Least significant 8, bit 6 is LSB)
14-15 11
16-19 0101
20-27 Real Coefficient (Most significant 8, bit 27 is MSB)
28-29 11
30-33 0101
34-41 Imaginary Coefficient (Least significant 8, bit 34 is LSB)
42-43 11
44-47 0101
48-55 Imaginary Coefficient (Most significant 8, bit 55 is MSB)
Standard: V.34
output: The precode coefficient superframe bits in a V.34 modem are structured as follows: Bit positions 0-1 are set to '11', positions 2-5 to '1010', and positions 6-13 are reserved. The pattern repeats for positions 14-27, 28-41, and 42-55, mirroring the 0-13 bit pattern. For the real and imaginary coefficients, bit positions 0-1 are '11', positions 2-5 alternate between '0101' for different segments, with positions 6-13 and 20-27 representing the least and most significant 8 bits of the real coefficient, respectively, and positions 34-41 and 48-55 representing the least and most significant 8 bits of the imaginary coefficient.

instruction: What is the purpose of in-band DCE control in data communication?
input:
Source: In-band DCE control and synchronous data modes for asynchronous DTE
Standard: V.80
output: In-band DCE control is used to manage and control the data communication equipment (DCE) through signals transmitted within the same frequency band as the data. This allows for simultaneous transmission of control signals and data without requiring separate channels or bands, facilitating efficient communication between asynchronous data terminal equipment (DTE) and synchronous networks.

instruction: What are the data signalling rates and corresponding hex codes for synchronous access mode commands in cellular systems?
input:
Source: Table 10/V.80  Synchronous Access Mode Command/lndication Bit Rate Values (values for parameters <tx>, <rx>, <maxp>, <prate>) Symbol Hex code Duplex or primary channel data signalling rate <p12> 20h 1 200 bit/s <p24> 21h 2 400 bit/s <p48> 22h 4 800 bit/s <p72> 23h 7 200 bit/s <p96> 24h 9 600 bit/s <p120> 25h 12 000 bit/s <p144> 26h 14 400 bit/s <p168> 27h 16 800 bit/s <p192> 28h 19 200 bit/s <p216> 29h 21 600 bit/s <p240> 2Ah 24 000 bit/s <p264> 2Bh 26 400 bit/s <p288> 2Ch 28 800 bit/s <p312> 2Dh 31 200 bit/s <p336> 2Eh 33 600 bit/s <p320> 2Fh 32 000 bit/s <p560> 30h 56 000 bit/s <p640> 31h 64 000 bit/s
Standard: V.80
output: The data signalling rates and corresponding hex codes for synchronous access mode commands in cellular systems are as follows: 1,200 bit/s (20h), 2,400 bit/s (21h), 4,800 bit/s (22h), 7,200 bit/s (23h), 9,600 bit/s (24h), 12,000 bit/s (25h), 14,400 bit/s (26h), 16,800 bit/s (27h), 19,200 bit/s (28h), 21,600 bit/s (29h), 24,000 bit/s (2Ah), 26,400 bit/s (2Bh), 28,800 bit/s (2Ch), 31,200 bit/s (2Dh), 33,600 bit/s (2Eh), 32,000 bit/s (2Fh), 56,000 bit/s (30h), and 64,000 bit/s (31h).

instruction: What are the test parameters recommended for comparative tests of modems over telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: 1 List of test parameters (see Table 1/V.56) TABLE 1/V.56 Test parameters Ref. No. Parameter Four-wireTwo-wire switched network point-to-point Serial modemsParallel modems 123456789 10111213Total attenuation or receiving signal level Attenuation distortionEnvelope or group delay distorsionFrequency shift (or offset)Sudden changes of attenuationInterruptionsPhase hitsPhase jitterHarmonic distortionListener echo"White" noiseImplusive noiseSingle tone interferenceX XXXXXXXXX XX XXXXXXXXXXXXX
Standard: V.56
output: The recommended test parameters for comparative tests of modems over telephone-type circuits include total attenuation or receiving signal level, attenuation distortion, envelope or group delay distortion, frequency shift (or offset), sudden changes of attenuation, interruptions, phase hits, phase jitter, harmonic distortion, listener echo, 'white' noise, impulsive noise, and single tone interference. These parameters are applicable to both four-wire and two-wire switched networks, as well as point-to-point connections, and are relevant for both serial and parallel modems.

instruction: What are the typical attenuation distortion values for Mode 1 at 300 Hz, 500 Hz, and 800 Hz frequencies?
input:
Source: Frequency (Hz) Attenuation distortion (dB) Mode 1 (see Note 1) Mode 2 (see Note 2) Mode 3 (see Note 5) 300 500 800 ≈ 1600 2500 2800 3000 6 3 1 Unspecified 3 6 12 8 2 0 8 Unspecified 12 K1 b) 0.35 K1 0 0 0.2 K1 0.3 K1 0.4 K1
Standard: V.56
output: The typical attenuation distortion values for Mode 1 are approximately 6 dB at 300 Hz, 3 dB at 500 Hz, and 1 dB at 800 Hz. These values are subject to tolerances of ±5%.

instruction: What are the group-delay distortion values for Mode 1 at frequencies 500 Hz, 600 Hz, and 1000 Hz?
input:
Source: FrequencyGroup-delay distortion (ms) (Hz)Mode 1 500 600 1000140018002200260028002.0 1.3 0 (see Note 3) 0.5 (see Note 4) 0 (see Note 3) 0.5 (see Note 4)0.3 (see Note 3) 2.0
Standard: V.56
output: For Mode 1, the group-delay distortion values are 2.0 ms at 500 Hz, 1.3 ms at 600 Hz, and 0 ms at 1000 Hz (with Note 3 indicating these are ripple valley values).

instruction: What are the typical frequency shifts that can be applied by channel converters?
input:
Source: Frequency shifts e.g. ± 5 Hz, ± 6 Hz or ± 10 Hz by means of channel converters.
Standard: V.56
output: Typical frequency shifts that can be applied by channel converters include ±5 Hz, ±6 Hz, or ±10 Hz.

instruction: What is the recommended duration of the start element in start-stop systems using the seven-unit alphabet?
input:
Source: that the duration of this start element should be a one-unit interval for the modulation rate under consideration, at transmitter output;
Standard: V.4
output: The recommended duration of the start element in start-stop systems using the seven-unit alphabet is a one-unit interval for the modulation rate under consideration at the transmitter output. This start element should correspond to condition A (space).

instruction: How may the detection of a character out-of-parity be represented in data transmission systems?
input:
Source: that the detection of a character out-of-parity may be represented by: a) reverse question mark graphic character or a representation of the capital letters SB (see ISO 2047) provided that these letters occupy a single character position on the screen or printer, and could have been entered by a single key stroke, recognizing it may be difficult to achieve a legible 'SB' character from some matrix printers or displays where the characters are printed; or b) a recording of the 1/10 (SUB) character on the tape or other storage medium, where provided and that, where a SUB character occurs in a received transmission, or is presented to a DTE via a storage medium, e.g. paper tape, then the reaction should be as in a) and b) above.
Standard: V.4
output: The detection of a character out-of-parity can be represented by either a reverse question mark graphic character or a representation of the capital letters SB, provided these occupy a single character position and could have been entered by a single key stroke. Alternatively, it may be represented by a recording of the 1/10 (SUB) character on the tape or other storage medium, where provided. In cases where a SUB character occurs in received transmission or is presented via a storage medium, the reaction should mirror the aforementioned representations.

instruction: What is the data transmission rate specified for a duplex modem using frequency division technique on telephone networks?
input:
Source: 2400 BITS PER SECOND DUPLEX MODEM USING THE FREQUENCY DIVISION TECHNIQUE STANDARDIZED FOR USE ON THE GENERAL SWITCHED TELEPHONE NETWORK AND ON POINT-TO-POINT 2-WIRE LEASED TELEPHONE-TYPE CIRCUITS
Standard: V.22
output: The data transmission rate specified is 2400 bits per second for a duplex modem utilizing the frequency division technique on general switched telephone networks and point-to-point 2-wire leased telephone-type circuits.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of modems designed for 2400 bit/s duplex data transmission over the General Switched Telephone Network and point-to-point 2-wire leased telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of these modems are as follows: a) duplex mode of operation on the GSTN and point-to-point leased circuits,b) channel separation by frequency division,c) quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 600 baud (nominal),d) inclusion of a scrambler,e) inclusion of an adaptive equalizer and a compromise equalizer,f)inclusion of test facilities, g) data signalling rates of: 2400 bit/s synchronous,2400 bit/s start-stop,1200 bit/s synchronous,1200 bit/s start-stop, h) it is compatible with a V.22 modem operating in Modes i) or ii) at the 1200 bit/s signalling rate and includes automatic bit rate recognition.
Standard: V.22
output: The principal characteristics include: a) duplex mode of operation on both the General Switched Telephone Network and point-to-point leased circuits; b) channel separation by frequency division; c) quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 600 baud (nominal); d) inclusion of a scrambler; e) inclusion of an adaptive equalizer and a compromise equalizer; f) inclusion of test facilities; g) support for data signalling rates of 2400 bit/s synchronous, 2400 bit/s start-stop, 1200 bit/s synchronous, and 1200 bit/s start-stop; h) compatibility with V.22 modems operating at 1200 bit/s signalling rate, including automatic bit rate recognition.

instruction: What are the carrier frequencies for the low and high channels in a modem?
input:
Source: The carrier frequencies shall be 1200 ± 0.5 Hz for the low channel and 2400 ± 1 Hz for the high channel.
Standard: V.22
output: The carrier frequency for the low channel is 1200 ± 0.5 Hz, and for the high channel, it is 2400 ± 1 Hz.

instruction: What are the threshold levels for circuit 109 to transition between ON and OFF states?
input:
Source: High channel threshold: - greater than -43 dBmcircuit 109 ON- less than -48 dBmcircuit 109 OFFLow channel threshold:- greater than -43 dBmcircuit 109 ON- less than -48 dBmcircuit 109 OFFThe condition of circuit 109 between the ON and OFF levels is not specified except that the signal detector shall exhibit a hysteresis action, such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs shall be at least 2 dB greater thanthat for the ON to OFF transition.
Standard: V.22
output: The high and low channel thresholds for circuit 109 are greater than -43 dBm for the ON state and less than -48 dBm for the OFF state. The signal detector must exhibit hysteresis, with the OFF to ON transition level at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition level.

instruction: What are the modes of operation for a bis modem?
input:
Source: Mode 1 2400 bit/s ± 0.01% synchronousMode 2 2400 bit/s start-stop 8, 9, 10 or 11 bits per characterMode 3 1200 bit/s ± 0.01% synchronousMode 4 1200 bit/s start-stop 8, 9, 10 or 11 bits per character.
Standard: V.22
output: The V.22 bis modem can be configured for four modes of operation: Mode 1 operates at 2400 bit/s ± 0.01% synchronous, Mode 2 operates at 2400 bit/s start-stop with 8, 9, 10, or 11 bits per character, Mode 3 operates at 1200 bit/s ± 0.01% synchronous, and Mode 4 operates at 1200 bit/s start-stop with 8, 9, 10, or 11 bits per character.

instruction: What is the generating polynomial used in the self-synchronizing scrambler for a modem transmitter?
input:
Source: A self synchronizing scrambler having the generating polynomial 1 ⊕ x-14 ⊕ x-17 shall be included in the modem transmitter.
Standard: V.22
output: The generating polynomial used in the self-synchronizing scrambler is 1 ⊕ x^-14 ⊕ x^-17. This polynomial is applied to the message data sequence, effectively dividing it, with the coefficients of the quotients forming the output data sequence.

instruction: What is the polynomial used in the self-synchronizing descrambler for a modem receiver?
input:
Source: A self synchronizing descrambler having the polynomial 1 ⊕ x-14 ⊕ x-17 Shall be provided in the modem receiver. The message data sequence produced after demodulation shall be effectively multiplied by the generating polynomial 1 ⊕ x-14 ⊕ x-17 to form the descrambled message.
Standard: V.22
output: The self-synchronizing descrambler in a modem receiver uses the polynomial 1 ⊕ x^-14 ⊕ x^-17. This polynomial is applied to the message data sequence after demodulation to form the descrambled message.

instruction: What are the key steps in the handshake sequence for a calling modem operating at 2400 bit/s?
input:
Source: a) On connection to line the calling modem shall be conditioned to receive signals in the high channel at 1200 bit/s and transmit signals in the low channel at 1200 bit/s in accordance with § 2.5.2.2. It shall apply an ON condition to circuit 107 in accordance with Recommendation V.25. The modem shall initially remain silent. b) After 155 ± 10 ms of unscrambled binary 1 has been detected, the modem shall remain silent for a further 456 ± 10 ms then transmit an unscrambled repetitive double dibit pattern of 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s for 100 ± 3 ms. Following this signal the modem shall transmit scrambled binary 1 at 1200 bit/s. c) If the modem detects scrambled binary 1 in the high channel at 1200 bit/s for 270 ± 40 ms, the handshake shall continue in accordance with §§ 6.3.1.2.1 c) and d). However, if unscrambled repetitive double dibit 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s is detected in the high channel, then at the end of receipt of this signal the modem shall apply an ON condition to circuit 112. d) 600 ± 10 ms after circuit 112 has been turned ON the modem shall begin transmitting scrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s, and 450 ± 10 ms after circuit 112 has been turned ON the receiver may begin making 16-way decisions. e) Following transmission of scrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s for 200 ± 10 ms, circuit 106 shall be conditioned to respond to circuit 105 and the modem shall be ready to transmit data at 2400 bit/s. f) When 32 consecutive bits of scrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s have been detected in the high channel the modem shall be ready to receive data at 2400 bit/s and shall apply an ON condition to circuit 109.
Standard: V.22
output: The key steps for a calling modem operating at 2400 bit/s include: 1) Conditioning to receive signals in the high channel and transmit in the low channel at 1200 bit/s, applying an ON condition to circuit 107, and remaining initially silent. 2) After detecting 155 ± 10 ms of unscrambled binary 1, remaining silent for 456 ± 10 ms, then transmitting an unscrambled repetitive double dibit pattern of 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s for 100 ± 3 ms, followed by scrambled binary 1 at 1200 bit/s. 3) If scrambled binary 1 is detected in the high channel at 1200 bit/s for 270 ± 40 ms, continuing the handshake. If unscrambled repetitive double dibit 00 and 11 is detected, applying an ON condition to circuit 112. 4) 600 ± 10 ms after circuit 112 is turned ON, beginning to transmit scrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s, and 450 ± 10 ms after, the receiver may start making 16-way decisions. 5) After transmitting scrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s for 200 ± 10 ms, conditioning circuit 106 to respond to circuit 105, readying the modem to transmit data at 2400 bit/s. 6) Upon detecting 32 consecutive bits of scrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s in the high channel, readying the modem to receive data at 2400 bit/s and applying an ON condition to circuit 109.

instruction: What are the transmission and reception bit rates for an answering modem upon connection to the line?
input:
Source: On connection to line the answering modem shall be conditioned to transmit signals in the high channel at 1200 bit/s in accordance with § 2.5.2.2 and receive signals in the low channel at 1200 bit/s.
Standard: V.22
output: Upon connection to the line, the answering modem transmits signals in the high channel at 1200 bit/s and receives signals in the low channel at 1200 bit/s.

instruction: What actions does a modem take upon detecting loss of received line signal?
input:
Source: When the modem detects loss of received line signal (as specified in §§ 3.2 and 3.3) it shall turn OFF circuit 109 and shall clamp circuit 104 to binary 1. If received line signal is then detected (as specified in §§ 3.2 and 3.3) the modem shall turn ON circuit 109 but shall leave circuit 104 clamped to binary 1. If during the next 100 ms the modem detects a retrain sequence it shall proceed according to § 6.4 above. If the modem has not detected a retrain sequence by the end of the same 100 ms it shall remove the clamp from circuit 104. If at any time after turning ON circuit 109 following a dropout the modem detects loss of equalization, it shall proceed according to § 6.4 above.
Standard: V.22
output: Upon detecting loss of received line signal, the modem turns OFF circuit 109 and clamps circuit 104 to binary 1. If the received line signal is subsequently detected, the modem turns ON circuit 109 but keeps circuit 104 clamped to binary 1. If a retrain sequence is detected within the next 100 ms, the modem proceeds according to the retrain procedure. If no retrain sequence is detected within this period, the clamp on circuit 104 is removed. Additionally, if loss of equalization is detected after turning ON circuit 109 following a dropout, the modem follows the retrain procedure.

instruction: What is the sequence of actions a modem performs when initiating a rate change?
input:
Source: Upon initiation of a rate change, manually or by a change in the condition of circuit 111, the modem shall apply an OFF condition to circuit 106, clamp circuit 104 to binary ones and shall transmit unscrambledrepetitive double dibit 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s for 100 ± 3 ms. During this procedure, circuits 109 and 107shall remain on. b) Following this, the modem shall transmit scrambled R1 as defined in Table 3/V.22 bis at a rate of 1200 bit/s. c) 450 ± 10 ms after detection of unscrambled repetitive double dibit 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s from the distant modem, the receiver shall examine the descrambled repetitive dibits R2 from the distant modem todetermine the operating rate for subsequent transmission as defined in Table 3/V.22 bis; at this time, the receiver may begin making decisions at the rate indicated by R2 which may differ from R1. d) 600 ± 10 ms after detection of unscrambled repetitive double dibit 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s from the distant modem, the transmission shall begin transmission of scrambled binary ones at a rate indicated by the dibitR2 from the distant modem. Following transmission of 200 ± 10 ms of scrambled binary ones, the modemshall condition circuit 106 to respond to circuit 105 and the modem shall be ready to transmit data. e) When 32 consecutive bits of scrambled binary one at the rate indicated by dibit R2 from the distant modem have been detected, the modem shall set circuit 112 to indicate the operating rate and unclamp circuit 104.
Standard: V.22
output: When initiating a rate change, the modem first applies an OFF condition to circuit 106, clamps circuit 104 to binary ones, and transmits unscrambled repetitive double dibit 00 and 11 at 1200 bit/s for 100 ± 3 ms, keeping circuits 109 and 107 on. It then transmits scrambled R1 at 1200 bit/s. After detecting unscrambled repetitive double dibit 00 and 11 from the distant modem, the receiver examines descrambled repetitive dibits R2 to determine the operating rate. Transmission of scrambled binary ones at the rate indicated by R2 begins 600 ± 10 ms after detection, followed by conditioning circuit 106 to respond to circuit 105 after 200 ± 10 ms of scrambled binary ones. The modem sets circuit 112 to indicate the operating rate and unclamps circuit 104 upon detecting 32 consecutive bits of scrambled binary one at the R2 rate.

instruction: What are the operating rates for dibits R1 and R2 in a bis modem?
input:
Source: Operating rate Dibit R1 and R2 2400 120011 01 or 10
Standard: V.22
output: The operating rates for dibits R1 and R2 in a V.22 bis modem are 2400 bits per second for R1 and 1200 bits per second for R2. The dibit values can be 01 or 10.

instruction: What is the initiation signal for instigating remote loop 2 in Modem A?
input:
Source: When Modem A is instructed to instigate a remote loop 2, the modem shall transmit an initiation signal of unscrambled binary 1 at 2400 bit/s (or 1200 bit/s).
Standard: V.22
output: The initiation signal for instigating remote loop 2 in Modem A is an unscrambled binary 1 transmitted at 2400 bit/s (or 1200 bit/s).

instruction: What are the key electrical characteristics considered in generator testing?
output: Generator testing focuses on several key electrical characteristics including open circuit voltage, output signal waveform under load, short-circuit current capability, and performance with test terminations. These tests ensure the generator meets specified operational parameters under various conditions.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics specified for a balanced digital interchange circuit?
input:
Source: This Recommendation specifies the electrical characteristics of a balanced digital interchange circuit, that may be employed when specified for the interchange of serial binary signals between Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) and Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE) or in any point-to-point interconnection of serial binary signals between data equipments. The balanced digital interchange circuit will normally be utilized on data and timing, or control circuits where the data signalling rate is up to a maximum limit of 52 Mbit/s.
Standard: V.12
output: The electrical characteristics specified for a balanced digital interchange circuit include its use for the interchange of serial binary signals between Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) and Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE), or in any point-to-point interconnection of serial binary signals between data equipments. It is typically utilized on data and timing, or control circuits with a data signalling rate up to a maximum limit of 52 Mbit/s.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics specified for a balanced digital interchange circuit?
input:
Source: This Recommendation specifies the electrical characteristics of a balanced digital interchange circuit, normally implemented in integrated circuit technology, that may be employed when specified for the interchange of serial binary signals between Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) and Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE) or in any point-to-point interconnection of serial binary signals between data equipments. The interchange circuit includes a generator connected by a balanced interconnecting cable to a load consisting of a receiver and a termination. The electrical characteristics of the circuit are specified in terms of required voltage, and current values obtained from direct measurements of the generator and receiver components at the interchange points. The logic function of the generator and the receiver is not defined by this Recommendation, as it is application dependent. Minimum electrical requirements for the interconnecting cable are furnished.
Standard: V.12
output: The electrical characteristics of a balanced digital interchange circuit include required voltage and current values obtained from direct measurements of the generator and receiver components at the interchange points. The circuit is typically implemented in integrated circuit technology and is used for the interchange of serial binary signals between Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) and Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE), or in any point-to-point interconnection of serial binary signals between data equipments. The logic function of the generator and receiver is application-dependent and not defined by these characteristics. Minimum electrical requirements for the interconnecting cable are also specified.

instruction: What are the key components of a balanced digital interchange circuit?
input:
Source: The balanced digital interchange circuit is shown in Figure 2. The circuit consists of three parts: the generator (G), the balanced interconnecting cable, and the load. The load is composed of a receiver (R) and a cable termination/fail-safe network. The electrical characteristics of the generator and the receiver are specified in terms of direct electrical measurements while the interconnecting cable is described in terms of its electrical characteristics.
Standard: V.12
output: A balanced digital interchange circuit consists of three main components: the generator (G), which produces the signal; the balanced interconnecting cable, which carries the signal; and the load, which includes a receiver (R) and a cable termination/fail-safe network. The generator and receiver have specific electrical characteristics, and the interconnecting cable is defined by its electrical properties. Resistors in the circuit, such as the generator pull-down resistor (Rgp) and termination resistor (Rt), have specified values with a tolerance of ±2%.

instruction: What are the voltage characteristics for a generator's binary 0 and binary 1 states in a balanced source system?
input:
Source: The generator circuit meeting these requirements results in a low impedance-balanced source that will produce a differential voltage applied to the interconnecting cable in the range of 590 mV to1500 mV. The signalling sense of the voltages appearing across the interconnecting cable are defined as follows: a) The A terminal of the generator shall be negative with respect to the B terminal for a binary 0 (SPACE or OFF) state. b) The A terminal of the generator shall be positive with respect to the B terminal for a binary 1 (MARK or ON) state. For either binary state, the magnitude of the differential voltage (Voc or Voc*) measured between the two generator output terminals shall not exceed 1.5 V.
Standard: V.12
output: In a balanced source system, for a binary 0 (SPACE or OFF) state, the A terminal of the generator is negative with respect to the B terminal. For a binary 1 (MARK or ON) state, the A terminal is positive with respect to the B terminal. The differential voltage applied to the interconnecting cable ranges from 590 mV to 1500 mV. The open circuit differential voltage (Voc or Voc*) between the two generator output terminals should not exceed 1.5 V for either binary state.

instruction: What are the voltage requirements for the steady state logic input in a differential voltage measurement setup?
input:
Source: Vt   > 590 mV,   Vt*   > 590 mV
    Vt   –   Vt*    < 100 mV
0 V > Vos > –       V, 0 V > Vos* > –        
  Vos – Vos*   < 100 mV 1.6 1.6 V4EST/G0TERMINATION/G0MEASUREMENTS
Standard: V.12
output: The steady state logic input requires that Vt and Vt* must each be greater than 590 mV, with the difference between Vt and Vt* being less than 100 mV. Additionally, Vos and Vos* must each be between 0 V and -1.6 V, with the difference between Vos and Vos* being less than 100 mV.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics required for a differential receiver's input impedance and input threshold?
input:
Source: The electrical characteristics of a receiver without termination or fail-safe provision are specified in terms of measurements illustrated in Figures 7 to 9 and described in 4.2.1 and 4.2.2. A circuit meeting these requirements results in a differential receiver having a high input impedance, and a small input threshold between ± 150 mV.
Standard: V.12
output: A differential receiver must have a high input impedance and a small input threshold between ±150 mV. The input current should be no greater than 350 µA when one leg's voltage ranges from −0.5 V to −2.0 V while the other leg is held at −1.32 V, under both power-on and power-off conditions.

instruction: What are the minimum and maximum operating voltages for a receiver as illustrated in the voltage sensitivity table?
input:
Source: Figure 9 illustrates the minimum and maximum operating voltages of the receiver... Applied voltages Resulting input voltage Resulting common mode voltage Via Vib Vid Vcm –0.50 V –0.65 V +0.150 V –0.575 V –0.65 V –0.50 V –0.150 V –0.575 V –0.50 V –2.00 V +1.50 V –1.25 V –2.00 V –0.50 V –1.50 V –1.25 V –1.85 V –2.00 V +0.150 V –1.925 V –2.00 V –1.85 V –0.150 V –1.925 V
Standard: V.12
output: The minimum operating voltage is -2.00 V and the maximum operating voltage is -0.50 V, as shown in the table where Via and Vib range between these values for different conditions.

instruction: What are the electrical characteristics required for an interconnecting cable in balanced digital interchange circuits?
input:
Source: The cable shall consist of twisted pair conductors and have an overall shield. The two wires of each pair shall be connected to the same signal, one to the A/A ′ and the other to the B/B ′ signal poles. Maximum single conductor DC Resistance (DCR) at 20 °C 3.5 Ω Differential Impedance at 50 MHz 110 Ω ± 11 Ω Maximum Signal Attenuation at 50 MHz 4.5 dB Mutual Capacitance within pair at 1 kHz 47.6 ± 6.5 pF/m Propagation Delay maximum: 79 ns Skew (pair-to-pair) 2.0 ns
Standard: V.12
output: The interconnecting cable must consist of twisted pair conductors with an overall shield, where each pair's wires are connected to the same signal poles (A/A' and B/B'). Key electrical characteristics include: maximum single conductor DC resistance of 3.5 Ω at 20°C, differential impedance of 110 Ω ± 11 Ω at 50 MHz, maximum signal attenuation of 4.5 dB at 50 MHz, mutual capacitance within the pair of 47.6 ± 6.5 pF/m at 1 kHz, maximum propagation delay of 79 ns, and pair-to-pair skew of 2.0 ns.

instruction: What are the physical characteristics of a cable with a nominal diameter of 0.38 mm?
input:
Source: Conductor: 0.08 mm 2, 7 strands of 0.13 mm, tinned annealed copper, nominal diameter 0.38 mm.
Insulation: Polyethylene or polypropylene; 0.24 mm nominal wall thickness; 0.86 mm ± 0.025 mm outside
diameter.
Foil Shield: 0.051 mm nominal aluminium/polyester laminated tape spiral wrapped around the cable core.Braid Shield: Braided 0.13 mm, tinned plated copper in accordance with 80% minimum coverage, in
electrical contact with the aluminium of the foil shield.
Outside Diameter: ≤ 10.6 mm.
Standard: V.12
output: The cable features a conductor made of 0.08 mm², 7 strands of 0.13 mm, tinned annealed copper. It has insulation of polyethylene or polypropylene with a 0.24 mm nominal wall thickness and an outside diameter of 0.86 mm ± 0.025 mm. The cable includes a foil shield of 0.051 mm nominal aluminium/polyester laminated tape spiral wrapped around the cable core and a braid shield of braided 0.13 mm, tinned plated copper with 80% minimum coverage, in electrical contact with the aluminium of the foil shield. The overall outside diameter is ≤ 10.6 mm.

instruction: What are the two modes of operation specified for the T.38-to-interworking function?
input:
Source: Two modes of operation are specified for the T.38-to-V.152 interworking function: native versus emulated interworking.
Standard: V.153
output: The two modes of operation specified for the T.38-to-V.152 interworking function are native and emulated interworking.

instruction: What are the principal modes of operation defined for VBDoIP and FoIP interworking?
output: The principal modes of operation defined for VBDoIP and FoIP interworking are emulation mode and native mode. Emulation mode involves the interworking function emulating the behavior of a traditional circuit-switched network to maintain compatibility with existing equipment. Native mode allows for direct packet-based communication without emulation, leveraging the capabilities of IP networks. Methods for discrimination between these modes are also specified to ensure proper operation.

instruction: What are the three major application areas of voiceband data in telecommunications?
input:
Source: Teleservices may be categorized into three major applications areas: facsimile, text-based communication and general data services. The three VBD application areas may be summarized as (by using notation 'application/transport'): – Facsimile/modem : Gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, see, e.g., [ITU-T V.152] for pass-through mode and [ITU-T T.38] for packet relay mode. – Text/modem : Gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, see, e.g., [ITU-T V.152] for pass-through mode and [b-ITU-T V.151] for packet relay mode. – Data/modem : Gateway technologies for PSTN-to-IP interworking, see, e.g., [ITU-T V.152] for pass-through mode and [b-ITU-T V.150.1] for packet relay mode.
Standard: V.153
output: The three major application areas of voiceband data in telecommunications are facsimile, text-based communication, and general data services. These are categorized using the notation 'application/transport' as follows: Facsimile/modem for gateway technologies in PSTN-to-IP interworking, Text/modem for similar gateway technologies, and Data/modem for general data services gateway technologies.

instruction: What is the definition of voiceband data in the context of packet networks?
input:
Source: 3.1.1 voiceband data [b-ITU-T V.150.0]:  The transport of modem signals over a voice channel of a packet network with the encoding appropriate for modem signals.
Standard: V.153
output: Voiceband data refers to the transport of modem signals over a voice channel of a packet network, utilizing encoding that is appropriate for modem signals.

instruction: What is the native VBDoIP-to-FoIP mode in a media gateway?
input:
Source: 3.2.4 native VBDoIP-to-FoIP mode : This is an internal mode of operation of the VBDoIP-to-FoIP gateway with a direct interworking between both (gateway local) IP connection endpoints where no circuit-switched bearer technology is used internally in the gateway.
Standard: V.153
output: The native VBDoIP-to-FoIP mode is an internal mode of operation in a VBDoIP-to-FoIP gateway where there is direct interworking between both IP connection endpoints locally within the gateway, without using any circuit-switched bearer technology internally.

instruction: What are the two interworking models considered for real-time facsimile services in IP peering scenarios?
input:
Source: This Recommendation considers real-time facsim ile services in case of IP peering. The understanding of IP peering is he re simplified to the p eer model of an ITU-T T.38 domain ("FoIP" for fax-over-IP) with an ITU-T V.152 domain ("VBDoIP" for voiceband data-over-IP).
Standard: V.153
output: The two interworking models are the T.38 model for FoIP (fax-over-IP) and the V.152 model for VBDoIP (voiceband data-over-IP). Both models facilitate interworking between an IP network and a circuit-switched network (CSN), with gateways featuring an IP interface and either an analogue line interface or a digital 1 x 64 kbit/s synchronous TDM (STDM) interface.

instruction: What are the two principal modes of operation for -to-T.38 interworking in IP-to-IP networks?
input:
Source: 7 Definition of the principal modes of operation V.152-to-T.38 interworking in the context of IP-to-IP means cascading of the two interworking functions for [ITU-T V.152] and [ITU-T T.38]. There are basically two possibilities of interworking. 7.1 Emulation mode Emulation mode is the indirect V.152-to-T.38 interworking when a TDM domain is internal to the IWF, as shown in Figure 3.
Standard: V.153
output: The two principal modes of operation for V.152-to-T.38 interworking in IP-to-IP networks are emulation mode and direct interworking mode. Emulation mode involves indirect V.152-to-T.38 interworking with a TDM domain internal to the Interworking Function (IWF). Direct interworking mode, on the other hand, does not involve a TDM domain and directly converts between V.152 and T.38 protocols within the IP network.

instruction: What are the two modes of operation for -to-T.38 interworking?
input:
Source: Native mode is the direct V.152-to-T.38 interworking where there is no TDM domain internal to the IWF, as shown in Figure 4. This interworking model requires the involvement of a 'synchronous TDM' (STDM) domain due to the definition of both ITU-T Recommendations. Such an STDM domain would be located in an internal node.
Standard: V.153
output: The two modes of operation for V.152-to-T.38 interworking are native mode and emulation mode. Native mode involves direct V.152-to-T.38 interworking without a TDM domain internal to the IWF. Emulation mode requires the involvement of a synchronous TDM (STDM) domain located in an internal node.

instruction: How is the ITU-T T.30 protocol handled in relation to the T.38 endpoint?
input:
Source: Handling of the ITU-T T.30 protocol shall be relate d to the 'T.38 endpoint', and then according to [ITU-T T.38], since the ITU- T T.30 protocol is transpar ent for the ITU-T V.152 mode.
Standard: V.153
output: The ITU-T T.30 protocol is handled in relation to the 'T.38 endpoint' according to ITU-T T.38 specifications, as the T.30 protocol is transparent for the ITU-T V.152 mode. This means the processing of T.30-over-T.38 information and T.30-over-V.152 information is entirely decoupled in the basic model of interworking.

instruction: What protocols are used for capability negotiation in gateway communications?
input:
Source: The mechanisms for negotiation vary depending on the endpoint's capabilities exchange protocols used, which can be the session description protocol (defined in [IETF RFC 4566]) or [ITU-T H.245]; the call control protocol, as defined in [ITU-T H.323], and the session initiation protocol (SIP), defined in [IETF RFC 3261]; and/or the media gateway control protocols as defined in ITU-T H.248 and ITU-T J.171.
Standard: V.153
output: Capability negotiation in gateway communications can utilize several protocols depending on the endpoint's capabilities exchange. These include the session description protocol (SDP) as defined in IETF RFC 4566, used by SIP terminals, SIP gateways, and H.248 gateways; ITU-T H.245, which complies with ITU-T H.323; and media gateway control protocols as defined in ITU-T H.248 and ITU-T J.171. Additionally, call control protocols defined in ITU-T H.323 and the session initiation protocol (SIP) defined in IETF RFC 3261 are also used for negotiation.

instruction: What are the two methods for stimuli transport in ITU-T VBDoIP mode?
input:
Source: Stimuli transport in ITU-T V.152 VBDoIP mode may be either via a network telephone event (NTE) encoding according to [IETF RFC 4733], or in-band using the ITU-T V.152 VBD codec. The two possibilities lead to different RTP packet types with dedicated RTP payload type values.
Standard: V.153
output: In ITU-T V.152 VBDoIP mode, stimuli transport can be achieved either via a network telephone event (NTE) encoding according to IETF RFC 4733, or in-band using the ITU-T V.152 VBD codec. These methods result in different RTP packet types with dedicated RTP payload type values.

instruction: What are the operational modes in voiceband data over IP and facsimile over IP gateways?
input:
Source: There are two operational modes in [ITU-T V.152] : audio (VoIP) and voiceband data (VBDoIP). On its turn, [ITU-T T.38] also has two operational modes that can be classified as audio (VoIP) and facsimile packet relay (FoIP).
Standard: V.153
output: Voiceband data over IP (VBDoIP) gateways have two operational modes: audio (VoIP) and voiceband data (VBDoIP). Facsimile over IP (FoIP) gateways also have two operational modes: audio (VoIP) and facsimile packet relay (FoIP). State transitioning between these modes is triggered by specific stimuli, such as VBD stimuli for VBDoIP.

instruction: What are the primary grade of service metrics affected by a VBDoIP-to-FoIP gateway in an IP network?
input:
Source: From a user's point of view, the quality of the facsimile transmission service is dependent on a number of factors. The VBDoIP-to-FoIP gateway itself is contributing to the end-to-end QoS primarily on grade of service metrics: IP transfer delay (IPTD), IP packet loss ratio (IPLR) and IP packet delay variation (IPDV), due to the location of this gateway entirely within the IP network portion.
Standard: V.153
output: The primary grade of service metrics affected by a VBDoIP-to-FoIP gateway in an IP network are IP transfer delay (IPTD), IP packet loss ratio (IPLR), and IP packet delay variation (IPDV). These metrics are influenced due to the gateway's location entirely within the IP network portion.

instruction: What is the impact of dejitter buffers on one-way transfer delay in communication systems?
input:
Source: Use of dejitter buffers impact fundamentally the one-way transfer delay of information.
Standard: V.153
output: Dejitter buffers fundamentally impact the one-way transfer delay of information in communication systems by temporarily storing incoming packets to smooth out variations in packet arrival times, which can introduce additional delay to the transmission.

instruction: What are the two methods for state transitioning of audio/T.38 endpoints in PSTN-to-IP media gateways?
input:
Source: Appendix III of [ITU-T T.38] defines two methods for state transitioning of audio/T.38 endpoints implemented in PSTN-to-IP ITU-T H.248 media gateways. This Recommendation only considers the MGC-controlled ITU-T T.38 transitioning behaviour (see clause II.4.2.1).
Standard: V.153
output: The two methods for state transitioning of audio/T.38 endpoints in PSTN-to-IP media gateways are the MGC-strict controlled method and the MG autonomous transitioning method. The MGC-strict controlled method involves the Media Gateway Controller (MGC) strictly controlling the state transitions, while the MG autonomous transitioning method allows the Media Gateway (MG) to autonomously manage its state transitions.

instruction: What is the SDP offer/answer model used for in IP communication?
input:
Source: SDP offer/answer (O/A) model (as per [b-IETF  RFC 3264]); see also Figure II.2. The O/A capability negotiation is tied to call/session control signalling.
Standard: V.153
output: The SDP offer/answer model is used for capability negotiation in IP communication, specifically for negotiating media capabilities between endpoints. This model involves one endpoint making an offer of media capabilities, and the other endpoint responding with an answer, either accepting or modifying the offered capabilities. It is commonly tied to call/session control signaling in protocols like SIP.

instruction: What is the purpose of the MGC function in a local gateway during media format negotiation?
input:
Source: The MGC function in the local gateway may then create an ITU-T H.248 context (see Figure II.3) with the selected audio codec(s) a nd the V.152-to-T.38 in terworking function.
Standard: V.153
output: The MGC function in the local gateway creates an ITU-T H.248 context with the selected audio codec(s) and the V.152-to-T.38 interworking function to facilitate media format negotiation and ensure compatibility between different codecs and protocols.

instruction: What are the key steps involved in the MGC controlled transitioning method for an alternate speech/fax service?
input:
Source: Five steps highlight the major ITU-T H.248 signalli ng information. The first st ep is related to the entire creation of the ITU-T H .248 context, the establishment of the ITU-T H.248 stream and the bearer preparation for audio. The tw o subsequent steps are mid-call acti vities related to the start of fax transmission, and the last two steps describe th e transition back to audio, after a successful fax transmission.
Standard: V.153
output: The MGC controlled transitioning method for an alternate speech/fax service involves five key steps. Step 1 involves the creation of an H.248 context, establishment of an H.248 stream, and bearer preparation for audio. The next two steps are mid-call activities related to the start of fax transmission. The final two steps describe the transition back to audio after a successful fax transmission. This method requires the local media gateway to support H.248.2 protocol capabilities for reporting detected stimuli in the IP bearer-path.

instruction: What are the key components of an ITU-T H.248 command for creating a -to-T.38 context?
input:
Source: Add = ip/2/$/$ { ; IP "V.152" Termination
  Media {
   Stream = 1 { ; there is just one Stream per Term.
    LocalControl {
     ipdc/realm  = "providerX.com"
         ; IP network indication (here "V.152 domain")
     Mode=SendReceive,
     ReservedGroup = OFF ,
     ReservedValue = OFF  ; because just single
                          ; audio codec
    },
    Local{
     v=0
     c=IN IP4 $
     m=audio $ RTP/AVP 8 101 111
     a=maxmptime:20 - 30
     a=rtpmap:101 telephone-event/8000 ; RFC 4733/4      a=rtpmap:111 PCMA/8000            ; ITU-T V.152
     a=gpmd:111 vbd=yes
    },
    Remote{  ; Remote descriptor might also be sent in
             ; a later Modify request
     v=0      c=IN IP4 19.70.3.2
     m=audio 54530 RTP/AVP 8 101 111
     a=maxmptime:20 - 30
     a=rtpmap:101 telephone-event/8000 ; RFC 4733/4      a=rtpmap:111 PCMA/8000            ; ITU-T V.152
     a=gpmd:111 vbd=yes
    }
   }   },
  Events = 1234 {ctyp/dtone} ; MGC requests H.248.2
                             ; ctyp/dtone event
                             ; notification
},
Add = ip/8/$/$ { ; IP "T.38" Termination
  Media {
   Stream = 1 { ; there is just one Stream per Term.
    LocalControl {
     ipdc/realm  = "providerY.com"
         ; IP network indication (here "T.38 domain")
     Mode=SendReceive,
     ReservedGroup = OFF ,; one media group
     ReservedValue = OFF  ; just one audio codec, might
                         ; also be ON in case two or
                         ; audio codecs are requested                          ; in 'audio' media descr.     },
    Local{
     v=0  ; Single Media Group  "audio flow"
     c=IN IP4 $
     …
     m=audio $ RTP/AVP 8 127
     a=rtpmap:127 telephone-event/8000
     a=ptime:20
    },
    Remote{
     v=0  ; Single Media Group  "audio flow"
     c=IN IP4 12.9.19.65
     …
     m=audio 100 RTP/AVP 8 127
     a=rtpmap:127 telephone-event/8000
     a=ptime:20
    }    }   }
}
Standard: V.153
output: The key components include the Add command for both V.152 and T.38 terminations, Media sections specifying Stream configurations, LocalControl settings with mode and realm, Local and Remote descriptors for SDP parameters, and an Events descriptor for notifications. Specifically, the V.152 termination is configured with PCMA audio codec, telephone-events, and a PCMA VBD codec, while the T.38 termination is set up for later transitioning with reserved properties for audio codec.

instruction: What are the key components of a MEGACO/2 reply message for creating a -to-T.38 context?
input:
Source: MEGACO/2 [11.9.19.70] 
… 
Add = ip/2/2/1 { ; IP "V.152" Termination  
  Media { 
   Stream = 1 { ; there is just one Stream per Term. 
    Local{ 
     v=0 
     c=IN IP4 19.70.27.4 
     m=audio 40008 RTP/AVP 8 101 111 
     a=maxmptime:20 - 30 
     a=rtpmap:101 telephone-event/8000 ; RFC 4733/4      a=rtpmap:111 PCMA/8000            ; ITU-T V.152 
     a=gpmd:111 vbd=yes 
    }, 
    Remote{  ; Remote descriptor might also be sent in 
             ; a later Modify request 
     v=0 
     c=IN IP4 19.70.3.2 
     m=audio 54530 RTP/AVP 8 101 111 
     a=maxmptime:20 - 30 
     a=rtpmap:101 telephone-event/8000 ; RFC 4733/4      a=rtpmap:111 PCMA/8000            ; ITU-T V.152 
     a=gpmd:111 vbd=yes 
    } 
}}}, 
Add = ip/8/3/2 { ; IP "T.38" Termination  
  Media { 
   Stream = 1 { ; there is just one Stream per Term. 
    Local{ 
     v=0  ; Single Media Group  "audio flow" 
     c=IN IP4 12.9.4.6 
     … 
     m=audio 40120 RTP/AVP 8 127 
     a=rtpmap:127 telephone-event/8000 
     a=ptime:20  
    }, 
    Remote{ 
     v=0  ; Single Media Group  "audio flow" 
     c=IN IP4 12.9.19.65 
     … 
     m=audio 100 RTP/AVP 8 127 
     a=rtpmap:127 telephone-event/8000 
     a=ptime:20  
    } }}}
Standard: V.153
output: The MEGACO/2 reply message for creating a V.152-to-T.38 context includes two ADD commands for IP terminations. Each ADD command specifies Media with Stream configurations, including Local and Remote descriptors. The Local descriptor contains session information such as version (v=0), connection information (c=IN IP4), media (m=audio), and attributes (a=) like maxptime, rtpmap for payload types, and gpmd for V.152 voice band data indication. The Remote descriptor similarly includes session, connection, media, and attribute information, potentially sent in a later Modify request. The configurations acknowledge the requested media capabilities and stream setups.

instruction: What are the three transport flows carried by an ITU-T H.248 stream in a -to-T.38 context?
input:
Source: Actually, there are three transport flows carried by that stream: PCMA/RTP media flow, RTCP control flow and ITU-T T.38 UDPTL flow. The three flow components are discriminated by three separate IP transport addresses.
Standard: V.153
output: The three transport flows carried by an ITU-T H.248 stream in a V.152-to-T.38 context are PCMA/RTP media flow, RTCP control flow, and ITU-T T.38 UDPTL flow. These flows are discriminated by three separate IP transport addresses.

instruction: What are the key attributes specified in a T.38 fax over IP stream descriptor?
input:
Source: a=T38FaxVersion:1 a=T38FaxRateManagement:transferredTCF a=T38FaxUdpEC:t38UDPFEC a=T38FaxMaxBufferSize:2000 a=T38MaxDatagram:512 a=T38MaxBitRate:14400 (… additional T.38 attributes may be included)
Standard: V.153
output: The key attributes in a T.38 fax over IP stream descriptor include T38FaxVersion, which specifies the version of T.38 protocol used; T38FaxRateManagement, indicating the method for managing fax transmission rates, such as 'transferredTCF'; T38FaxUdpEC, specifying the use of UDP error correction methods like 't38UDPFEC'; T38FaxMaxBufferSize, defining the maximum buffer size in bytes, typically 2000; T38MaxDatagram, setting the maximum datagram size, usually 512 bytes; and T38MaxBitRate, indicating the maximum bit rate for fax transmission, commonly 14400 bps. Additional attributes may also be included as needed.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Notification Request and Notification Reply in the context of ITU-T T.38 fax over IP transitions?
input:
Source: Notification Request (MG to MGC): MEGACO/2 [11.9.19.70] … Notify = ip/8/3/2 { ObservedEvents = 1235 { ipfax/faxconnchange{faxconnchng=EOF} } } "T.38" IP termination reports detection of end-of-fax event. 8) Notification Reply (MGC to MG): MEGACO/2 [11.9.19.65] … Notify = ip/8/3/2
Standard: V.153
output: The Notification Request is sent from the Media Gateway (MG) to the Media Gateway Controller (MGC) to report the detection of an end-of-fax event (EOF) on the T.38 IP termination. The Notification Reply is the acknowledgment from the MGC to the MG confirming receipt of the notification. This exchange is part of the process to transition between fax and audio modes in a T.38 fax over IP session.

instruction: What are the key components of an ITU-T H.248 stream descriptor for a -to-T.38 context transition?
input:
Source: Modify = ip/2/2/1, Modify = ip/8/3/2 { ; IP "T.38" Termination Media { Stream = 1 { ; there is just one Stream per Term. Local{ v=0 ; Single Media Group "audio flow" c=IN IP4 12.9.4.6 … m=audio 40120 RTP/AVP 8 127 a=rtpmap:127 telephone-event/8000 a=ptime:20 }, Remote{ v=0 ; Single Media Group "audio flow" c=IN IP4 12.9.19.65 … m=audio 100 RTP/AVP 8 127 a=rtpmap:127 telephone-event/8000 a=ptime:20 } }}}
Standard: V.153
output: The key components of an ITU-T H.248 stream descriptor for a V.152-to-T.38 context transition include the Modify command for IP terminations, Media stream configuration with Local and Remote descriptors, and specific RTP/AVP payload types. The Local descriptor specifies the media type ('audio flow'), connection information (IP address), and media format (RTP/AVP with payload types 8 and 127 for audio and telephone-event respectively, at 8000 Hz sampling rate, with a packet time of 20 ms). The Remote descriptor mirrors these settings to ensure no audio transcoding is needed when in audio state.

instruction: What are the key components of the Media Gateway Control Function (MGCF) to IM Media Gateway (IM-MGW) interface?
input:
Source: 3GPP TS 29.332 (2009), Media Gateway Control Function (MGCF) – IM Media Gateway (IM-MGW); Mn interface .
Standard: V.153
output: The key components of the Media Gateway Control Function (MGCF) to IM Media Gateway (IM-MGW) interface include the Mn interface, which is defined for controlling the media gateway functions. This interface facilitates the exchange of control messages between the MGCF and IM-MGW, enabling the setup, modification, and release of media streams in the network.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Modem-on-hold feature in modems?
input:
Source: Figure 20/V.92 − Modem-on-hold request acknowledged
Standard: V.92
output: The Modem-on-hold feature in V.92 modems allows the modem to temporarily suspend the data connection without disconnecting, enabling the user to receive or make a voice call while the internet connection is on hold. This feature is particularly useful for users who share a single telephone line for both voice and data communications.

instruction: What is the required duration of silence a digital modem should transmit after detecting Tone A for more than 50 ms during a retrain response?
input:
Source: After detecting Tone A for more than 50 ms, the digital modem shall turn OFF circuit 106, clamp circuit 104 to binary one and transmit silence for 70 ± 5 ms. The digital modem shall then transmit Tone B, condition its receiver to detect a Tone A phase reversal, and proceed in accordance with the full Phase 2 start-up procedure.
Standard: V.92
output: The digital modem should transmit silence for 70 ± 5 ms after detecting Tone A for more than 50 ms and before transmitting Tone B.

instruction: What is the purpose of the synchronizing signal in data transmission?
input:
Source: For the whole duration of the interval between the OFF to ON transitions of circuits 105 and 106, the line signal shall be that corresponding to the continuous transmission of dibit 11. This shall be known as the synchronizing signal.
Standard: V.26
output: The synchronizing signal ensures the stability of timing recovery at the receiver by providing a continuous transmission of dibit 11 between the OFF to ON transitions of circuits 105 and 106. This helps mitigate data-pattern sensitivity issues in timing recovery.

instruction: What are the threshold levels and response times for circuit 109 to turn ON and OFF?
input:
Source: A fall in level of the incoming line signal to -31 dBm or lower for more than 10 ± 5 ms will cause circuit 109 to be turned OFF. An increase in level to -26 dBm or higher will, within 10 ± 5 ms, turn this circuit ON. The condition of circuit 109 for levels between -26 dBm and -31 dBm is not specified except that the signal level detector shall exhibit a hysteresis action such that the level at which the OFF to ON transition occurs is at least 2 dB greater than that for the ON to OFF transition.
Standard: V.26
output: Circuit 109 turns OFF when the incoming line signal level falls to -31 dBm or lower for more than 10 ± 5 ms. It turns ON when the signal level increases to -26 dBm or higher within 10 ± 5 ms. The condition of circuit 109 for levels between -26 dBm and -31 dBm is not specified, except that the signal level detector must exhibit hysteresis, ensuring the OFF to ON transition occurs at a level at least 2 dB greater than the ON to OFF transition.

instruction: What are the response time specifications for circuits 106, 121, and 122 in data communication equipment?
input:
Source: 6.3 Response times of circuits 106, 121 and 122
Circuit 106
OFF to ON 65-100 ms (see Note 1)
(Provisional)25-45 ms (see Note 2)
(Provisional)
ON to OFF ≤ 2 ms
Circuit 121
OFF to ON 80 ms to 160 ms
ON to OFF ≤ 2 ms
Circuit 122
OFF to ON < 80 ms
ON to OFF 15 to 80 ms
Standard: V.26
output: For circuit 106, the OFF to ON response time is 65-100 ms for infrequent operation of circuit 105 and 25-45 ms for frequent operation. The ON to OFF response time is ≤ 2 ms. Circuit 121 has an OFF to ON response time of 80 ms to 160 ms and an ON to OFF response time of ≤ 2 ms. Circuit 122 has an OFF to ON response time of < 80 ms and an ON to OFF response time of 15 to 80 ms.

instruction: What timing signals should be provided by a modem to the data terminal equipment?
input:
