instruction: What are the signal transmission requirements for instigating a remote loop 2 between two modems?
input:
Source: When modem A is instructed to instigate a remote loop 2, the modem shall transmit an initiation signal of unscrambled binary 1. Modem B shall detect 154-231 ms of the initiation signal, and then transmit to modem A scrambled alternate binary ones and zeros (reversals) at 1200 bit/s (or 600 bit/s). Modem A shall detect 231-308 ms of scrambled reversals, cease transmission of the initiation signal, and then transmit scrambled binary 1 at 1200 bit/s (or 600 bit/s). Modem B shall detect the loss of initiation signal and activate loop 2 within modem B.Modem A, upon receiving 231-308 ms of scrambled binary 1 shall indicate to the DTE that it may begin sending test messages.
Standard: V.22
output: To instigate a remote loop 2, modem A must transmit an initiation signal of unscrambled binary 1 after synchronization and handshake completion. Modem B must detect this signal for 154-231 ms and then respond with scrambled alternate binary ones and zeros (reversals) at 1200 bit/s (or 600 bit/s). Modem A then detects these scrambled reversals for 231-308 ms, stops the initiation signal, and transmits scrambled binary 1 at the same bit rate. Modem B detects the loss of the initiation signal, activates loop 2, and upon receiving 231-308 ms of scrambled binary 1, indicates to the DTE that test messages may begin.

instruction: What is the purpose of the RTP payload format defined in Annex E of the procedures for connecting analogue PSTN text telephones over an IP network?
input:
Source: Amendment 1 introduces Annex E, which defines the RTP payload format for the transport of text as T.140 character data over IP networks, removing the need to make a reference to an historic RFC published by the IETF.
Standard: V.151
output: The RTP payload format defined in Annex E is designed for the transport of text as T.140 character data over IP networks. It facilitates the end-to-end connection of analogue PSTN text telephone terminals over an IP network utilizing text relay, eliminating the need to reference an historic RFC published by the IETF for this purpose.

instruction: What are the main transport methods for Text over IP (ToIP)?
output: The main transport methods for Text over IP (ToIP) include Audio mode, VBD (Voice Band Data) mode, and Text relay mode. Audio mode is used for transmitting text as audio signals, VBD mode is utilized for transmitting text as voice band data signals, and Text relay mode is specifically designed for transmitting text in a relay format. Additionally, there is capability for switching between these transport modes depending on the requirements of the communication.

instruction: What are the key components of call discrimination procedures in telecommunication systems?
output: The key components of call discrimination procedures include V.8 bis processing, V.8 CI/XCI processing, a call discrimination overview, call discrimination SDL diagrams, and visual flow control. These components work together to ensure proper call setup and discrimination in telecommunication systems.

instruction: What is the purpose of interoperation between two PSTN to IP Network gateways in analogue text telephone terminals communication?
input:
Source: This Recommendation defines the interoperation of two PSTN to IP Network gateways that facilitate the end-to-end connection of analogue text telephone terminals over an IP network.
Standard: V.151
output: The interoperation between two PSTN to IP Network gateways facilitates the end-to-end connection of analogue text telephone terminals over an IP network, enabling communication between these terminals across different network types.

instruction: What is text telephony?
input:
Source: 3.13 text telephony : A telecommunications capability that supports real-time text conversation on communication networks.
Standard: V.151
output: Text telephony is a telecommunications capability that supports real-time text conversation on communication networks.

instruction: What are the three basic models considered for supporting Text Telephony over IP (ToIP)?
input:
Source: There are three basic models that can be considered for support of this application. These models are dependent upon the transmission characteristics and Quality of Service of the IP network in which the text telephone conversation is being established. The models can be summarized as: a) Support of text telephony over VoIP connections (i.e., utilizing audio mode transport). This model is outside the scope of this Recommendation. b) Support of text telephony utilizing Voice Band Data (VBD) transport as defined in [ITU-T V.152]. c) Support of text telephony utilizing Text Relay transport with VBD fallback according to this Recommendation.
Standard: V.151
output: The three basic models for supporting Text Telephony over IP (ToIP) are: a) Support of text telephony over VoIP connections utilizing audio mode transport, b) Support of text telephony utilizing Voice Band Data (VBD) transport, and c) Support of text telephony utilizing Text Relay transport with VBD fallback. The first model is outside the scope of certain recommendations, while the latter two involve specific transport methods for text telephone signals over IP networks.

instruction: What are the possible connection combinations for Text over IP (ToIP) applications?
input:
Source: The possible connection combinations are: a) PSTN Text Telephone to PSTN Text Telephone; b) PSTN Text Telephone to IP Text Telephone.
Standard: V.151
output: The possible connection combinations for Text over IP (ToIP) applications are: PSTN Text Telephone to PSTN Text Telephone, and PSTN Text Telephone to IP Text Telephone.

instruction: What are the main components shown in the ToIP gateway reference model?
input:
Source: Figure 6-1 provides a conceptual reference model for a ToIP gate way. The model shows two stacks conjoined by the ToIP application. The left-hand stack is that of a typical text telephone which has a signal converter (modulation). The right-hand stack represents the IP networking functions of a ToIP Gateway.
Standard: V.151
output: The ToIP gateway reference model consists of two main stacks conjoined by the ToIP application. The left-hand stack represents a typical text telephone with a signal converter for modulation. The right-hand stack represents the IP networking functions of the ToIP gateway.

instruction: What are the different types of interconnects described for PTP devices in telecommunications?
input:
Source: Interconnect #1 is an acoustic coupling betw een a PTP device to an analogue PSTN phone. Interconnect #2 is the connecti on between the PSTN phone that is acoustically coupled to the PTP device. The IP gateway connect ed at the interconnect #2 point shall support the tr ansmission of text signals from the end PTP device using this Recommendation. Interconnect #3 is an acoustic coupling of a PTP device to an IP endpoint (e.g., an IP phone). The support of the transport of the PTP signals over IP in this interconnect is described in Annex D. Interconnect #4 is the direct inte rconnection of a PTP device to a gateway via the PSTN or other time division multiplexing (TDM) network (e.g., an enterprise TDM network). The IP gateway connect at the interconnect #4 poi nt shall support the transmission of text signals from the end PTP device using this Recommendation.
Standard: V.151
output: The different types of interconnects for PTP devices include: 1) Interconnect #1, which is an acoustic coupling between a PTP device and an analogue PSTN phone; 2) Interconnect #2, the connection between the PSTN phone acoustically coupled to the PTP device, where the IP gateway supports text signal transmission; 3) Interconnect #3, an acoustic coupling of a PTP device to an IP endpoint like an IP phone, with PTP signal transport over IP; and 4) Interconnect #4, the direct interconnection of a PTP device to a gateway via the PSTN or other TDM network, where the IP gateway supports text signal transmission.

instruction: What are the two transport modes supported by ToIP gateways for text telephony?
input:
Source: Gateways that are compliant to this Recommendation shall support ToIP utilizing either text relay or VBD mode.
Standard: V.151
output: ToIP gateways support text telephony through two transport modes: text relay mode and Voice Band Data (VBD) mode. VBD mode is suitable for transporting text telephony signals and can also handle non-text signals like speech, allowing gateways to remain in VBD mode throughout the call, including periods of speech interspersed with text telephony signals.

instruction: What are the conditions under which a -compliant gateway may use VBD mode for the transport of PTP signals?
input:
Source: A V.151-compliant gateway may use VBD mode for th e transport of PTP signals for the following conditions: 1) The PTP signal modulation detected is one that is not supported fo r text relay by both gateways. 2) Probing sequence timeouts as specified in clause 20.
Standard: V.151
output: A V.151-compliant gateway may use VBD mode for the transport of PTP signals under two conditions: 1) The PTP signal modulation detected is one that is not supported for text relay by both gateways, and 2) Probing sequence timeouts as specified.

instruction: What is the priority between text and voice transmission in a gateway system?
input:
Source: For alternating text and voice, text shall be given priority. The gate way shall use text mode as long as there is text to be transmitted and played out. When the gateway is in connection with an HD X text telephone, voice can be conveyed between bursts of text without further consideration.
Standard: V.151
output: In a gateway system, text transmission is given priority over voice. The gateway uses text mode as long as there is text to be transmitted and played out. Voice can be conveyed between bursts of text when connected to an HDX text telephone without further consideration.

instruction: What is the requirement for the first character received on the PSTN interface of a gateway when transmitted to the IP network?
input:
Source: The first character received on the PSTN interface of the gateway shall be transmitted only once to the IP network, i.e., it shall not be lost nor erroneously repeated by the gateway.
Standard: V.151
output: The first character received on the PSTN interface of the gateway must be transmitted only once to the IP network, ensuring it is neither lost nor erroneously repeated by the gateway.

instruction: What are the two stages involved in the establishment of the text telephone physical layer connection?
input:
Source: The establishment of the text telephone physical layer consists of two stages. The first stage involves call discrimination including the detection and discrimination of the text telephony signals on the PSTN interface of the gateway. The second stage involves the establishment of the physical layer connection between the gateway and the text telephony terminal.
Standard: V.151
output: The establishment of the text telephone physical layer connection involves two stages. The first stage is call discrimination, which includes the detection and discrimination of text telephony signals on the PSTN interface of the gateway. The second stage involves the establishment of the physical layer connection between the gateway and the text telephony terminal.

instruction: What mechanisms can be implemented by gateways to improve ToIP session performance under poor network conditions?
input:
Source: [IETF RFC 2198] (RTP redundancy) shall be implemented by gateways compliant to this Recommendation. [IETF RFC 2733 ] (RTP FEC) and SPRT may also be implemented by the gateway. Use of one or more of these mechanisms during a ToIP session is required if network conditions are such that acceptable performance cannot be achieved without them.
Standard: V.151
output: Gateways can implement RTP redundancy as per IETF RFC 2198, RTP Forward Error Correction (FEC) as per IETF RFC 2733, and SPRT mechanisms to improve ToIP session performance under poor network conditions. The use of one or more of these mechanisms is required when network conditions degrade to a point where acceptable performance cannot be achieved without them.

instruction: What are the supported modulations in text relay mode for gateways?
input:
Source: A list of the modulations supported in text relay mode by the gateway is shown in Table 15-1. Gateways compliant to this Recommendation shall advertise the support for at least one of these modulations. Table 15-1 – PTP modulations Modulation Description V18 V.18 'native mode' V.21 modulation BELL103 Bell 103 based PTP modems (Annex D of [ITU-T V.18]) V23 Videotext terminals ('Minitel'; see Annex E of [ITU-T V.18]) V21 V.21 encoded per [ITU-T T.50] (Annex F of [ITU-T V.18]) EDT European Deaf Telephone utilizing V.21 frequencies at 110 bit/s (Annex C of [ITU-T V.18]) TIA825 Baudot terminals at 45.45 bit/s or at 50 bit/s (Annex A of [ITU-T V.18])
Standard: V.151
output: The supported modulations in text relay mode for gateways include V18 (V.18 'native mode' V.21 modulation), BELL103 (Bell 103 based PTP modems as per Annex D of ITU-T V.18), V23 (Videotext terminals like 'Minitel' as per Annex E of ITU-T V.18), V21 (V.21 encoded per ITU-T T.50 as per Annex F of ITU-T V.18), EDT (European Deaf Telephone utilizing V.21 frequencies at 110 bit/s as per Annex C of ITU-T V.18), and TIA825 (Baudot terminals at 45.45 bit/s or at 50 bit/s as per Annex A of ITU-T V.18).

instruction: What are the required SSE event encodings for using the SSE protocol instead of the default payload type switching protocol for mode control?
input:
Source: Table 15-3 – Required SSE event encodings Event encoding (Decimal) Indicated media state 1 Initial Audio 2 Voice Band Data (VBD) 5 Text Relay 6 Text Relay Probing
Standard: V.151
output: The required SSE event encodings for using the SSE protocol are: 1 for Initial Audio, 2 for Voice Band Data (VBD), 5 for Text Relay, and 6 for Text Relay Probing. Both gateways must signal support for all of these encodings to use the SSE protocol instead of the default payload type switching protocol for mode control.

instruction: What encoding is used for modem data in text relay mode between gateways?
input:
Source: In the case that the connection results in text relay, the modem data will be encoded utilizing T.140 encoding. Data integrity between the end modems will be ensured as long as the data modems are using 8-bit character sizes (including parity). For other character sizes, the data will be corrupted due to the assumption that the data is encoded using T.140.
Standard: V.151
output: In text relay mode between gateways, modem data is encoded utilizing T.140 encoding. Data integrity is ensured when the data modems use 8-bit character sizes, including parity. For other character sizes, the data may be corrupted due to the T.140 encoding assumption.

instruction: What is the impact of CI/XCI signal loss in protocol on ANSam tone generation?
input:
Source: V.8 allows for the loss or non-transmission of CI/XCI in the protocol definition, so carriage of these signals using voice mode is acceptable. If CI/XCI is not detected properly by the remote PTP device, there can be up to an additional 3 seconds of delay for the ANSam tone generation relative to the case where CI/XCI is detected.
Standard: V.151
output: If CI/XCI signals are not detected properly by the remote PTP device in the V.8 protocol, it can result in an additional delay of up to 3 seconds for the ANSam tone generation compared to when CI/XCI is properly detected.

instruction: What are the signal detection criteria for transitioning to VBD or text relay mode in a gateway?
input:
Source: Table 20-1 – Signal detection criteria Signal detected Detected TTY mode SSE RIC 390-Hz tone for 1 second V.23 Annex E of [I TU-T V.18] call mode V.23 Low channel 1300-Hz tone for 1 second V.23 Annex E of [I TU-T V.18] answer mode V.23 High channel 980-Hz tone for 1 second V.21 Annex F of [ITU-T V.18] call mode V.21 Ch1 1650-Hz tone for 1 second V.21 Annex F of [ITU-T V.18] answer mode V.21 Ch2 V.21 low-band modulated character, 110 bit/s EDT Annex C of [ITU-T V.18] V.21 Ch1 1270-Hz tone for 1 second Bell 103 Annex D of [ITU-T V.18] call mode Bell 103 modem 1400-Hz mark, 1800-Hz space FSK signals Baudot Annex A of [ITU-T V.18] TIA-825A (50 bit/s) TIA-825A (45.45 bit/s)
Standard: V.151
output: The signal detection criteria include specific tones and their durations that trigger transitions to VBD or text relay mode. These are: a 390-Hz tone for 1 second for V.23 Annex E call mode (Low channel), a 1300-Hz tone for 1 second for V.23 Annex E answer mode (High channel), a 980-Hz tone for 1 second for V.21 Annex F call mode (Ch1), a 1650-Hz tone for 1 second for V.21 Annex F answer mode (Ch2), V.21 low-band modulated character at 110 bit/s for EDT, a 1270-Hz tone for 1 second for Bell 103 call mode, and 1400-Hz mark with 1800-Hz space FSK signals for Baudot at 50 bit/s or 45.45 bit/s.

instruction: What is the significance of the 'tty_mode' parameter in payload type switching?
input:
Source: tty_mode=unknown
PT=audio
audio 
Figure 20-2 – SDL for payload type switching (sheet 1 of 6) 

Figure 20-2 – SDL for payload type switching (sheet 2 of 6)
Standard: V.151
output: The 'tty_mode' parameter in payload type switching indicates the mode of operation for the teletype (TTY) device. It can have values such as 'unknown', 'X', 'FDX', or 'V.18', each representing different operational states or configurations of the TTY device during the communication process. For example, 'FDX' stands for full-duplex mode, allowing simultaneous two-way communication, while 'V.18' refers to a specific ITU-T recommendation for text telephony over IP networks.

instruction: What is the procedure when a gateway receives a TR payload type while in audio mode?
input:
Source: This procedure box is entered when a TR payload type is received while the connection is in audio mode. This is the case when an HDX modulation has been detected by the remote gateway and both gateways support this HDX modulation. The gateway entering this procedure box shall attempt to connect with its local PTP device using an HDX modulation.
Standard: V.151
output: When a gateway receives a TR payload type while in audio mode, it indicates that an HDX modulation has been detected by the remote gateway and both gateways support this HDX modulation. The gateway entering this procedure shall attempt to connect with its local PTP device using an HDX modulation.

instruction: What is the purpose of the SDL diagrams in the SSE protocol for call discrimination processing?
input:
Source: The following SDL diagrams define the procedures at the gateway for call discrimination processing when using SSE protocol switching. These SDL diagrams are derived from the call discrimination call flows given in Appendix II. The symbols used in the SDL diagrams are defined in Figure 20-1.
Standard: V.151
output: The SDL diagrams define the procedures at the gateway for call discrimination processing when using SSE protocol switching. They detail the sequence of operations and decision points, including handling of V.18 text relay support, auto-mode/probing initiation, and modulation type checks. The diagrams use specific symbols to represent different states and transitions in the protocol.

instruction: What is the purpose of the auto-mode/probing process in gateway communication?
input:
Source: The purpose of the auto-mode/probing process is to determine what modulation its local PTP device supports. This procedure starts when the gateway receives an SSE(TP) from the remote gateway. If the RIC in the SSE(TP) indicates CI/XCI was detected, the gateway shall perform the 'automoding originating' procedure as defined in clause 5.1 of [ITU-T V.18] with the modification of only looking for modulations that it supports for text relay. If the RIC in the SSE(TP) indicates a signal detected other than CI/XCI, the gateway shall perform automode probing as defined in Figure 2b of [ITU-T V.18] and its corresponding text. The gateway shall not generate the ANSam signal at the beginning of these procedures, i.e., it shall skip over the generate ANSam block in Figure 2b of [ITU-T V.18] and go straight to the probing flows. The gateway shall only probe for modulations that it supports for text relay.
Standard: V.151
output: The auto-mode/probing process in gateway communication is designed to determine what modulation the local Plain Old Telephone Service (POTS) Terminal Product (PTP) device supports. This process is initiated when the gateway receives a Signal State Event (SSE) from the remote gateway. Depending on the Remote Indication Code (RIC) in the SSE, the gateway will either perform the 'automoding originating' procedure or automode probing to identify supported modulations for text relay, skipping the ANSam signal generation and focusing only on supported modulations.

instruction: What modulation does a gateway use to connect with a local PTP device when its tty_mode state variable is ?
input:
Source: If the gateway's tty_mode  state variable is V.18, the gateway shall use the modulation indicated by the RIC of the received SSE(TR) to connect with  the PTP if that modulation is supported by the gateway. If the gateway does not support the modul ation indicated by the RIC in the received SSE(TR), the gateway shall use a supported modulation that is closest to the signalling rate of the modulation indicated in the RIC.
Standard: V.151
output: When the gateway's tty_mode state variable is V.18, it uses the modulation indicated by the RIC of the received SSE(TR) to connect with the PTP, provided that modulation is supported by the gateway. If the modulation indicated by the RIC is not supported, the gateway uses a supported modulation closest to the signalling rate of the modulation indicated in the RIC.

instruction: What is the default format for transporting T.140 encoded data when SPRT is used?
input:
Source: SPRT defines several formats for carrying data. If  SPRT is used then the default format for transporting T.140 encoded data  shall be I_OCTET_INFO as described in clause 15.4.11.1 of [ITU-T V.150.1].
Standard: V.151
output: The default format for transporting T.140 encoded data when SPRT is used is I_OCTET_INFO, as described in the specifications for SPRT protocol.

instruction: What are the default values for maxPayloadSizeChannel0, maxPayloadSizeChannel1, and maxPayloadSizeChannel2 in SPRT capability?
input:
Source: maxPayloadSizeChannel0 INTEGER(140..256) OPTIONAL, -- Default 140
maxPayloadSizeChannel1 INTEGER(132..256) OPTIONAL,  -- Default 132
maxPayloadSizeChannel2 INTEGER(132..256) OPTIONAL,  -- Default 132
Standard: V.151
output: The default values for maxPayloadSizeChannel0 is 140, for maxPayloadSizeChannel1 is 132, and for maxPayloadSizeChannel2 is 132 in SPRT capability.

instruction: What is the purpose of the T140Audio capability in H.245-based systems?
input:
Source: Gateways compliant to this Recommendation must be able to support the transmission of text interleaved with audio. The respective capability definition for H.245-based systems is in Table B.1, as taken from Annex G of [ITU-T H.323]. Table B.1 – H.245 capability definition for text transport (T140Audio) Capability name: T140Audio Capability class: Audio Capability Capability identifier type: Standard. Capability identifier value: itu-t (0) recommendation (0) h (8) 323 annex(1) g (7) audio(0) maxBitRate The maxBitRate field shall be included and indicate the maximum bits per second. When using the Flow Control Command or other signals in relation to this capability, any maxBitRate field shall be interpreted to be in units of bits/s, as opposed to the typical 100 bits/s used in H.245. This is due to the low bit rate nature of real-time text communication, including the low bit rates used by many PSTN textphone protocols.
Standard: V.151
output: The T140Audio capability in H.245-based systems is designed to support the transmission of text interleaved with audio over packet-based networks. It specifically facilitates the transport of analogue PSTN text telephony signals, including real-time text communication, by defining the necessary capabilities for H.245-based systems. This capability includes parameters such as maxBitRate, which indicates the maximum bits per second for the transmission, and is tailored to accommodate the low bit rate nature of text communication, differing from the typical 100 bits/s used in H.245 by interpreting maxBitRate in units of bits/s.

instruction: What does the cps parameter indicate in a communication session?
input:
Source: Parameter name: cps 
Parameter description: This is a collapsing capability. 
Indicates the maximum number of characters per second that may be 
received on a session. When carried in side an Open Logical Channel 
(OLC), it indicates the maximum transmission rate that the other endpoint 
may use if it opens a corresponding text session.
Standard: V.151
output: The cps parameter indicates the maximum number of characters per second that may be received on a session. When included in an Open Logical Channel (OLC), it specifies the maximum transmission rate the other endpoint may use if it opens a corresponding text session.

instruction: What does the RemainInVBDNotPreferred parameter indicate in a gateway's operation?
input:
Source: Parameter name: Rema inInVBDNotPreferred 
Parameter description: This is a collapsing capability. 
Indicates that the gateway would prefer to switch out of VBD mode 
between text spurts. Both gateways must indicate this preference for the 
gateway to switch out of VBD mode af ter a text spurt, else the gateway 
shall remain in VBD mode for the duration of the call. 
Parameter identifier value: standard: 101 
Parameter status: Optional 
Parameter type: Logical 
Supersedes: –
Standard: V.151
output: The RemainInVBDNotPreferred parameter indicates a collapsing capability where the gateway prefers to switch out of Voice Band Data (VBD) mode between text spurts. For the gateway to actually switch out of VBD mode after a text spurt, both gateways involved in the communication must indicate this preference. If not, the gateway will remain in VBD mode for the entire duration of the call. This parameter is optional and of logical type, with a standard parameter identifier value of 101.

instruction: What are the payload types specified for audio telephony events in the given configuration?
input:
Source: payloadType 101     -- The PT for the RFC 2198 packet     },     element {      dataType : audioData : audioTelephonyEvent {        audioTelephoneEvent : "0-15"      },      payloadType 102     }    }   },
Standard: V.151
output: The payload types specified for audio telephony events are 101 for RFC 2198 packets and 102 for audio data with audio telephony events ranging from 0 to 15.

instruction: What MIME type is used in SDP for representing text relay capability in the transmission of analogue PSTN Text Telephony signals over packet-based networks?
input:
Source: The text relay capability and associated procedures are represented in SDP using the MIME type 'audio/t140c'.
Standard: V.151
output: The MIME type 'audio/t140c' is used in SDP to represent text relay capability for the transmission of analogue PSTN Text Telephony signals over packet-based networks.

instruction: What does the 'remain-in-vbd' parameter indicate in a gateway's preference for mode switching?
input:
Source: A 'remain-in-vbd=yes' indicates preference to stay in VBD mode, while 'remain-in-vbd=no' indicates preference to switch between VBD and AUDIO modes between text spurts. This attribute is optional. If it is not sent, the gateway is indicating that its preference is to not switch out of VBD mode after text spurt.
Standard: V.151
output: The 'remain-in-vbd' parameter indicates a gateway's preference for staying in Voice Band Data (VBD) mode or switching between VBD and AUDIO modes. A value of 'yes' means the gateway prefers to stay in VBD mode, while 'no' means it prefers to switch between VBD and AUDIO modes between text spurts. If this parameter is not sent, it indicates a preference to not switch out of VBD mode after a text spurt.

instruction: What are the key differences in media stream establishment between IP text devices and gateways?
input:
Source: When establishing a call, an ITD shall advertise support for ToIP in accordance with Annex B or Annex C, with one notable important exception: the ITD shall not include a list of supported modulations. Absence of the list of modulations shall be used as an indicator to the V.151 gateway that the remote side is an ITD. Further, ITD devices shall not utilize SSEs in order to control state transition to ToIP. Rather, once a media flow is established to transport T.140 characters, either the gateway or the ITD may transmit text immediately and without further negotiation. Payload type switching is used to transition between audio and text relay modes. In general, ITDs transmit text characters when communicating with other ITDs using [b-IETF RFC 4103], which specifies the establishment of a separate RTP stream specifically for transmitting text characters. However, since PSTN gateway devices interleave audio and text data, ITDs need to support both [b-IETF RFC 4103] to interwork with other ITDs and V.151 for communicating with PSTN gateways. As such, ITDs shall indicate support for both transport methods when exchanging capability information.
Standard: V.151
output: IP text devices (ITDs) and V.151 gateways differ in media stream establishment primarily in their handling of modulations and support for different transport methods. ITDs do not include a list of supported modulations when advertising support for ToIP, which signals to the V.151 gateway that the remote side is an ITD. Unlike V.151 gateways, ITDs do not use SSEs for state transition to ToIP; instead, text transmission can begin immediately once a media flow is established. ITDs must support both [b-IETF RFC 4103] for communication with other ITDs and V.151 for communicating with PSTN gateways, indicating support for both during capability exchange. In H.323-based systems, ITDs offer separate proposals for [b-IETF RFC 4103] and V.151 within the fastStart SEQUENCE, allowing the called device to choose the appropriate streams based on its capabilities.

instruction: What is the purpose of text relay in telecommunications?
input:
Source: Figure D.1 – Example text relay call flow for ITD/gateway text relay interoperability
Standard: V.151
output: Text relay in telecommunications is designed to assist individuals with hearing or speech impairments by converting spoken language into text and vice versa. This service enables real-time communication between users through text intermediaries or automated systems, ensuring accessibility and inclusivity in telecommunication services.

instruction: What is the purpose of the M-bit in the payload format for real-time text transported within an audio stream?
input:
Source: This M-bit shall be set to '1' for the initial packet transmitted for any given SSRC value presented on the wire and shall be set to '1' following a period of 'silence' where no RTP packets are transmitted. In all other cases where packets are tran smitted successively, this bit shall be set to '0'. A period of 'silence' is defined to be more than 300 ms without transmitting a packet.
Standard: V.151
output: The M-bit is set to '1' for the initial packet transmitted for any given SSRC value presented on the wire and following a period of 'silence' where no RTP packets are transmitted for more than 300 ms. In all other cases where packets are transmitted successively, this bit is set to '0'.

instruction: What is the purpose of the T.140 block counter in RTP packets?
input:
Source: The T.140 block counter is similar in purpose to the sequence number and is necessary since text packets and audio packets may share the same sequence number space. Without this counter, it would not otherwise be possible to detect lost text packets. The T.140 block counter shall be initialized to zero for the first text packet transmitted and, once passing the value 0xFFFF, shall be reset to zero. Devices that receive a text packet containing a T.140 block counter that has incremented higher than expected shall assume that the difference between the recently received counter value and the expected counter value indicates the number of lost text packets. Note, however, that there may multiple characters within a text packet, so this does not serve to indicate the number of lost characters.
Standard: V.151
output: The T.140 block counter in RTP packets serves to detect lost text packets, especially when text and audio packets share the same sequence number space. It is initialized to zero for the first text packet and increments with each subsequent packet, resetting to zero after reaching 0xFFFF. A discrepancy between the received and expected counter values indicates the number of lost text packets, though it does not specify the number of lost characters.

instruction: What are the seven openly specified signaling methods used in PSTN text telephony?
input:
Source: With the PSTN, there are seven different, openly specified signalling methods used in text telephony. These signalling methods are country-specific. The signalling methods are TIA-825A (Baudot), DTMF, EDT, V.21, Bell103, Minitel and V.18. Each uses a different modulation and character encoding in the transmission of text. The methods are described in the annexes of [ITU-T V.18].
Standard: V.151
output: The seven openly specified signaling methods used in PSTN text telephony are TIA-825A (Baudot), DTMF, EDT, V.21, Bell103, Minitel, and V.18. Each method uses a different modulation and character encoding for text transmission.

instruction: What are the key components illustrated in ToIP call flow diagrams?
input:
Source: the white vertical rectangles  under the ToIP endpoints (G1 a nd G2) give the state of the respective endpoint; the shaded vertical rectangles under the te xt telephony terminals (T1 and T2) and the ToIP endpoints (G1 and G2) give the signals th at are being transmitted by the respective Terminal or endpoint; while in audio and VBD mode, the ToIP  endpoints are continually transmitting and receiving audio CODEC packets as defined el sewhere in this Recommendation. For clarity, these packets are only exp licitly shown when special circumstances surround them.
Standard: V.151
output: In ToIP call flow diagrams, key components include white vertical rectangles under ToIP endpoints (G1 and G2) indicating the state of the respective endpoint, and shaded vertical rectangles under text telephony terminals (T1 and T2) and ToIP endpoints (G1 and G2) showing the signals being transmitted by the respective terminal or endpoint. Additionally, while in audio and VBD mode, ToIP endpoints continuously transmit and receive audio CODEC packets, which are explicitly shown only under special circumstances.

instruction: What are the possible connection modes when a full-duplex (FDX) text phone calls another full-duplex (FDX) text phone with both supporting the other's text phone type?
input:
Source: FDX FDX Y Y TR 
VBD if G1 does not support T2 and T1 = T2. 
No connect if T1 != T2
Standard: V.151
output: The possible connection modes are Text Relay (TR) if both text phones support each other's type, or Voice Band Data (VBD) if the calling text phone's gateway does not support the called text phone's type but both text phones are of the same type. If the text phones are of different types, there will be no connection.

instruction: What is the function of the CI/XCI sequence in a -compliant gateway?
input:
Source: Since T1 is the V.18 calling PTP, it will generate a CI/XCI sequence. Since G1 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, it will detect CI/XCI indicating to G1 that it is connected to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detection of CI/XCI, G1 may continue to transmit the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to G2, or it may optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. The diagram does not show the optional VBD SSE negotiation at this point. After CI/XCI sequence is completely transmitted to G2 (either through audio or VBD encoding), G1 shall send an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and terminate regeneration of signals to T1. G1 shall stay in the mode of silence generation to T1 until it exits the TP state via an SSE from G2.
Standard: V.151
output: The CI/XCI sequence in a V.151-compliant gateway serves to indicate that the gateway is connected to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detection of this sequence, the gateway can either continue transmitting the sequence using audio mode or optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI). After completely transmitting the CI/XCI sequence, the gateway sends an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) and terminates regeneration of signals to the calling terminal, entering a mode of silence generation until it exits the TP state via an SSE from the remote gateway.

instruction: What happens when CI/XCI is not detected by G1 during a call flow involving ANSam tone generation?
input:
Source: This call flow takes into consideration the case were CI/XCI is not detected by G1, possibly because the ANSam tone was generated first due to the manner in which the call was established. G2, upon detecting the ANSam, will initiate a transition to VBD mode. While in VBD mode, both gateways will monitor the V.8 signals at their PCM interfaces, G1 seeing the CM signal indicating a PTP device and G2 seeing the JM signal indicating a PTP device. At the end of CJ reception, G1 will initiate a transition to text relay mode through the generation of an SSE(TR) to G2. The transition from VBD to text relay mode needs to be handled so that the V.21 carrier generated by the gateways meets the 75 ± 5 ms as required by [ITU-T V.8].
Standard: V.151
output: When CI/XCI is not detected by G1, possibly due to the ANSam tone being generated first, G2 upon detecting the ANSam will initiate a transition to VBD mode. Both gateways will then monitor the V.8 signals at their PCM interfaces, with G1 detecting the CM signal indicating a PTP device and G2 detecting the JM signal also indicating a PTP device. Following CJ reception, G1 will transition to text relay mode by generating an SSE(TR) to G2, ensuring the V.21 carrier meets the 75 ± 5 ms requirement.

instruction: What is the frequency of the carrier signal used in the CI/XCI sequence detection?
input:
Source: 1300 Hz carrier
Standard: V.151
output: The carrier signal used in the CI/XCI sequence detection operates at 1300 Hz.

instruction: What happens when a calling PTP terminal generates a CI/XCI sequence in a -compliant gateway scenario?
input:
Source: Since T1 is the V.18 calling PTP, it will generate a CI/XCI sequence. Since G1 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, it will detect CI/XCI indicating to G1 that it is connected to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detection of CI/XCI, G1 may continue to transmit the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to G2, or it may optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. The diagram does not show the optional VBD SSE negotiation at this point. After CI/XCI sequence is completely transmitted to G2 (either through audio or VBD encoding), G1 shall send an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and terminate regeneration of signals to T1. G1 shall stay in the mode of silence generation to T1 until it receives an SSE indicating a new mode from G2.
Standard: V.151
output: When a V.18 calling PTP terminal generates a CI/XCI sequence, a V.151-compliant gateway (G1) supporting SSE protocol detects this sequence, indicating a connection to a V.18 PTP terminal. G1 may then continue transmitting the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to another gateway (G2) or optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. After completely transmitting the CI/XCI sequence to G2, G1 sends an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and terminates signal regeneration to the calling terminal (T1), entering a silence generation mode until receiving a new mode indication from G2.

instruction: What happens when a -compliant gateway detects a CI/XCI sequence from a PTP terminal?
input:
Source: Upon detection of CI/XCI, G1 may continue to transmit the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to G2, or it may optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. The diagram does not show the optional VBD SSE negotiation at this point. After CI/XCI sequence is completely transmitted to G2 (either through audio or VBD encoding), G1 shall send an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and terminate regeneration of signals to T1. G1 shall stay in the mode of silence generation to T1 until it receives an SSE response from G2 indicating a new mode (either VBD or text relay).
Standard: V.151
output: Upon detecting a CI/XCI sequence from a V.18 PTP terminal, a V.151-compliant gateway can either continue transmitting the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to the remote gateway or optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to the remote gateway. After completely transmitting the CI/XCI sequence, the gateway sends an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to the remote gateway and terminates regeneration of signals to the local PTP. It then remains in a mode of silence generation to the local PTP until receiving an SSE response indicating a new mode (either VBD or text relay).

instruction: What happens when G2 detects an ANSam signal from T2 in a text relay scenario?
input:
Source: Upon detection of the ANSam signal from T2 by G2, G2 will send an SSE (TR:V.18) indicating that it has detected ANSam signal from T2 and that T2 is a V.18 modem and that G1 should start its text relay auto-mode probing sequence. Since G2 does not support native V.18 mode, it will not respond to the ANSam generated by T2, but will wait until it detects a PTP modulation that it supports (Baudot in this example). After detecting the Baudot probing signal from T2, G2 will immediately respond with Baudot, triggering T2 to go into Baudot mode. The Baudot probing character that was detected by G2 is sent to G1 using text relay mode.
Standard: V.151
output: When G2 detects an ANSam signal from T2, it sends an SSE (TR:V.18) indicating the detection of the ANSam signal and that T2 is a V.18 modem. This prompts G1 to start its text relay auto-mode probing sequence. Since G2 does not support native V.18 mode, it does not respond to the ANSam but waits to detect a PTP modulation it supports, such as Baudot. Upon detecting the Baudot probing signal from T2, G2 immediately responds with Baudot, causing T2 to switch to Baudot mode. The detected Baudot probing character is then sent to G1 using text relay mode.

instruction: What happens when a answering PTP generates ANSam after 3 seconds without receiving CI/XCI?
input:
Source: Since T2 is a V.18 answering PTP, it will generate ANSam after 3 seconds (because CI/XCI was not received). Since G2 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, it will detect ANSam and initiate a switch to VBD mode. T2 is allowed to probe T1 using VBD mode. G2 does not respond to any of the T2 probing sequences, even those that represent modulations that G2 supports since it has not been established that an end-to-end text relay connection can be successfully made between all gateways and PTP devices.
Standard: V.151
output: When a V.18 answering PTP generates ANSam after 3 seconds without receiving CI/XCI, a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol will detect ANSam and initiate a switch to VBD mode. The PTP is then allowed to probe using VBD mode. However, the gateway does not respond to any probing sequences, even those it supports, unless it is established that an end-to-end text relay connection can be successfully made between all gateways and PTP devices.

instruction: What happens when a answering PTP does not receive CI/XCI and how does a -compliant gateway respond?
input:
Source: Since T2 is a V.18 answering PTP, it will generate ANSam after 3 seconds (because CI/XCI was not received). Since G2 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, it will detect ANSam and initiate a switch to VBD mode. T2 is allowed to probe T1 using VBD mode. G2 does not respond to any of the T2 probing sequences, even those that represent modulations that G2 supports since it has not been established that an end-to-end text relay connection can be successfully made between all gateways and PTP devices.
Standard: V.151
output: When a V.18 answering PTP (T2) does not receive CI/XCI, it generates ANSam after 3 seconds. A V.151-compliant gateway (G2) that supports SSE protocol detects this ANSam and initiates a switch to VBD mode, allowing T2 to probe T1 using VBD mode. However, G2 does not respond to any of T2's probing sequences, even to those representing modulations it supports, unless an end-to-end text relay connection is confirmed between all gateways and PTP devices.

instruction: What happens when a calling PTP terminal generates a CI/XCI sequence in a -compliant gateway scenario?
input:
Source: Since T1 is the V.18 calling PTP, it will generate a CI/XCI sequence. Since G1 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, it will detect CI/XCI indicating to G1 that it is connected to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detection of CI/XCI, G1 may continue to transmit the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to G2, or it may optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. The diagram does not show the optional VBD SSE negotiation at this point. After CI/XCI sequence is completely transmitted to G2 (either through audio or VBD encoding), G1 shall send an SSE(TP: CI/XCI) to G2 and terminate regeneration of signals to T1. G1 shall stay in the mode of silence generation to T1 until it receives an SSE response from G2 indicating a new mode (either VBD or text relay).
Standard: V.151
output: When a V.18 calling PTP terminal generates a CI/XCI sequence, a V.151-compliant gateway (G1) that supports SSE protocol detects this sequence, indicating a connection to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detection, G1 can either continue transmitting the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to another gateway (G2) or optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. After completely transmitting the CI/XCI sequence to G2, G1 sends an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and stops regenerating signals to the calling terminal (T1), entering a mode of silence generation until receiving an SSE response from G2 indicating a new mode (either VBD or text relay).

instruction: What happens when a calling PTP generates a CI/XCI sequence in a -compliant gateway scenario?
input:
Source: Since T1 is the V.18 calling PTP, it will ge nerate a CI/XCI sequence. Since G1 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, it will detect CI/XCI indi cating to G1 that it is connected to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detecti on of CI/XCI, G1 may continue to transmit the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to G2, or it ma y optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. The di agram does not show the optional VBD SSE negotiation at this point. After CI/XCI seque nce is completely transmitted to G2 (either through audio or VBD encoding), G1 shall se nd an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and terminate regeneration of signals to T1. G1 shall stay in the mode of silence generation to T1 until it receives an SSE response from G2 indicating a ne w mode (either VBD or text relay).
Standard: V.151
output: When a V.18 calling PTP generates a CI/XCI sequence, a V.151-compliant gateway (G1) that supports SSE protocol detects the CI/XCI sequence, indicating it is connected to a V.18 PTP terminal. Upon detection, G1 may continue transmitting the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to another gateway (G2) or optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2. After completely transmitting the CI/XCI sequence to G2, G1 sends an SSE(TP:CI/XCI) to G2 and stops regenerating signals to the V.18 PTP, entering a mode of silence generation until it receives an SSE response from G2 indicating a new mode (either VBD or text relay).

instruction: What happens when G2 detects an ANS tone in a -compliant gateway scenario?
input:
Source: Since G2 is a V .151-compliant gateway that  supports SSE protocol, upon detection of the ANS tone, G2 will initiate a switch to VBD mode.
Standard: V.151
output: Upon detection of the ANS tone, G2, being a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, will initiate a switch to VBD mode.

instruction: What is the significance of the 2225-Hz answer tone in Bell 103 modem communication?
input:
Source: Bell 103 is a special case of the FDX to FDX scenario since, unlike other FDX modems such as V.21, the originating modem is first to generate carrier upon detection of the 2225-Hz answer tone. T2 being the answering Bell 103 PTP device will initiate the generation of 2225-Hz answer tone. Since G2 is a V.151-compliant gateway that supports SSE protocol, upon detection of the 2225-Hz tone, G2 will initiate a switch to VBD mode.
Standard: V.151
output: In Bell 103 modem communication, the 2225-Hz answer tone is significant because it triggers the originating modem to generate carrier. This is a unique characteristic of Bell 103 modems, distinguishing them from other full-duplex (FDX) modems like V.21. Upon detection of this tone, a V.151-compliant gateway supporting SSE protocol will switch to Voice Band Data (VBD) mode, initiating the process for establishing a text relay mode connection if the modulation is supported by both gateways.

instruction: What is required for establishing a PTP connection in scenarios where T1 and T2 modulations are involved?
input:
Source: In this scenario, T1 and T2 modulations must be the same for the PTP connection to be established. There is no support for protocol conversion in this scenario. Ensuring that T1 and T2 modulations are the same allows non-PTP data modems that use the same physical layer modulation to also be supported using relay.
Standard: V.151
output: For a PTP connection to be established in scenarios involving T1 and T2 modulations, both modulations must be identical. There is no support for protocol conversion in such scenarios. This requirement ensures that non-PTP data modems using the same physical layer modulation can also be supported through relay.

instruction: What is the role of the SSE(VBD:ANSam) signal in a communication scenario?
input:
Source: T2 will generate a V.8 ANSam signal at the start of the call. Upon detection of the ANSam, G2 will initiate a transition to VBD mode through generation of a SSE(VBD:ANSam). The V.18 probing is allowed to be performed end-to-end through the VBD channel. G2 will not respond to any probing signals even in cases where it supports the modulation in the probing signals.
Standard: V.151
output: The SSE(VBD:ANSam) signal is generated by G2 upon detection of the ANSam signal from T2. It initiates a transition to Voice Band Data (VBD) mode, allowing V.18 probing to be performed end-to-end through the VBD channel. G2 does not respond to any probing signals, even if it supports the modulation in those signals.

instruction: What happens when a device detects an ANSam signal in a compliant system?
input:
Source: T2 will generate a V.8 ANSam signal at the start of the call. Upon detection of the ANSam, G2 will initiate a transition to VBD mode through generation of a SSE(VBD:ANSam). The V.18 probing is allowed to be performed end to end through the VBD channel. G2 will not respond to any probing signals even in cases where it supports the modulation in the probing signals.
Standard: V.151
output: Upon detection of the ANSam signal, the device initiates a transition to Voice Band Data (VBD) mode by generating a SSE(VBD:ANSam) signal. The system allows V.18 probing to be performed end-to-end through the VBD channel, but the device will not respond to any probing signals it supports during this probing phase.

instruction: What are the two modes that G1 can use to transmit the CI/XCI sequence to G2 in a -compliant gateway scenario?
input:
Source: Upon detection of CI/XCI, G1 may continue to transmit the CI/XCI sequence using audio mode to G2, or it may optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2.
Standard: V.151
output: G1 can transmit the CI/XCI sequence to G2 using either audio mode or VBD (Voice Band Data) mode. In audio mode, the sequence is transmitted as audio signals. Alternatively, G1 may optionally initiate a transition to VBD mode by sending an SSE(VBD:CI/XCI) to G2, encoding the sequence as voice band data.

instruction: What is the role of a -compliant gateway in detecting modulations?
input:
Source: Since G2 is a V .151-compliant gateway, it is required to detect all varieties of V .18 modulations for the purposes of initiating transition to VBD mode.
Standard: V.151
output: A V.151-compliant gateway is required to detect all varieties of V.18 modulations for the purpose of initiating a transition to VBD (Voice Band Data) mode. This detection is crucial for determining the connection to a V.18 PTP (Point-to-Point) terminal and facilitating the appropriate mode transition for the session.

instruction: What happens when a called PTP terminal initiates the first text transmission in a scenario where the gateway supports its HDX modulation?
input:
Source: T2, being the called PTP terminal, will, according to PTP etiquette, initiate the first text transmission. Since G2 supports the HDX modulation used by T2, it will detect the modulation per V.151 requirements and send an SSE(TP:Baudot) to G1 indicating a request to transition to text relay mode. G2 shall buffer all received characters until a transition to text relay mode is complete. G2 shall not respond to T1 until transition to text relay mode is complete and it receives characters from G1.
Standard: V.151
output: The gateway supporting the called terminal's HDX modulation will detect the modulation and send an SSE(TP:Baudot) to the other gateway, requesting a transition to text relay mode. It will buffer all received characters until the transition is complete and will not respond to the calling terminal until the transition is finished and characters are received from the other gateway.

instruction: What happens when two -compliant gateways detect a PTP signal that is not supported via text relay?
input:
Source: Since the gateways are V.151-compliant, they will detect a PT P signal that is not suppor ted via text relay and will initiate a transi tion to VBD mode. The gateway receiving the SSE(VBD) will respond with SSE(VBD) and the transition to VBD will be comple ted. The gateways will st ay in VBD mode for the duration of the call.
Standard: V.151
output: When V.151-compliant gateways detect a PTP signal that is not supported via text relay, they initiate a transition to VBD mode. The gateway receiving the SSE(VBD) responds with SSE(VBD), completing the transition to VBD mode. The gateways remain in VBD mode for the duration of the call.

instruction: What happens when two gateways do not support the modulation of their local PTP devices, with one being FDX based and the other HDX based?
input:
Source: In these scenarios, either or both of the gateways does not support the modulation of its local PTP device. Both PTP devices are not V.18 PTP devices, and one is FDX based while the other is HDX based. No successful connection will be achieved, although the channel may be transitioned to VBD mode since the gateway should detect either of the PTP signals.
Standard: V.151
output: When two gateways do not support the modulation of their local PTP devices, with one being full-duplex (FDX) based and the other half-duplex (HDX) based, no successful connection will be achieved. However, the channel may transition to voice band data (VBD) mode if either of the PTP signals is detected by the gateway.

instruction: What is the process for transitioning to text relay mode after sequence completion between PTP devices?
input:
Source: After completion of V.8 sequence between the two PTP devices using VB D mode, the gateways shall (within the 75-ms requirement) transition to text relay mode, locally generating the appropriate V.21 carrier and transmitting received character s via text relay encoding.
Standard: V.151
output: After completing the V.8 sequence between two PTP devices using VBD mode, the gateways must transition to text relay mode within 75 ms. This involves locally generating the appropriate V.21 carrier and transmitting received characters via text relay encoding.

instruction: What are the key differences between Scenario #7 and Scenario #5 in terms of device support?
input:
Source: This scenario plays out identical to scenario #5. The only difference between these scenarios is that G2 does not support native V.18 mode , but the call flow is identical.
Standard: V.151
output: The key difference between Scenario #7 and Scenario #5 is that in Scenario #7, G2 does not support native V.18 mode, whereas in Scenario #5, G2 supports native V.18 mode. Both scenarios otherwise play out identically with T1 using FDX modulation PTP (Bell 103 in this example) and T2 using V.18 PTP, with G1 supporting FDX modulation (Bell 103 in this example).

instruction: What triggers the switch to VBD mode in a communication system when T1 is the calling PTP?
input:
Source: Since T1 is the V.18 calling PTP, it will generate a CI/XCI sequence. G1 may optionally detect CI/XCI and transmit it in VBD mode. Upon detection of ANS by G2, if G1 has not already switched to VBD encoding based on CI/XCI detection, G2 will start VBD encoding.
Standard: V.151
output: The switch to VBD mode is triggered either by the detection of CI/XCI sequences by G1 or upon the detection of ANS by G2. If G1 has not already switched to VBD encoding based on CI/XCI detection, G2 will initiate VBD encoding upon detecting ANS.

instruction: What happens when G2 detects the ANS tone in a -compliant gateway scenario?
input:
Source: Since G2 is a V.151-compliant gateway, upon detection of the ANS tone, G2 will initiate a switch to VBD mode. When G2 detects the carrier for a FDX modulation that it supports for text, it shall initiate a transition to text relay mode through the generation of a packet containing the NULL character encoded using TR payload type if G1 has also indicated support for this modulation. If G1 does not support the modulation used by T2, the connection will remain in VBD for the duration of the call.
Standard: V.151
output: Upon detection of the ANS tone, G2 initiates a switch to VBD mode. If G2 subsequently detects the carrier for a full-duplex (FDX) modulation that it supports for text, it will transition to text relay mode by generating a packet containing the NULL character encoded using TR payload type, provided G1 also supports this modulation. If G1 does not support the modulation used by T2, the connection remains in VBD mode for the call duration.

instruction: What happens when a -compliant gateway detects a 2225-Hz answer tone from a Bell 103 PTP device?
input:
Source: T2 being the answering Bell 103 PTP device will initiate the generation of 2225-Hz answer tone. Since G2 is a V.151-compliant gateway, upon detection of the 2225-Hz tone, G2 will initiate a switch to VBD mode.
Standard: V.151
output: Upon detection of the 2225-Hz answer tone from a Bell 103 PTP device, a V.151-compliant gateway will initiate a switch to Voice Band Data (VBD) mode. This transition is part of the process to establish a connection in scenarios involving Bell 103 modems.

instruction: What conditions must be met for G2 to start text relay encoding when detecting a signal from T2?
input:
Source: When the signal from T2 is detected by G2, G2 will start text relay encoding only if G1 also supports this modulation.
Standard: V.151
output: G2 will start text relay encoding only if G1 also supports the modulation being used by T2.

instruction: What happens when G1 detects CI/XCI signals in a communication scenario involving VBD encoding?
input:
Source: In this scenario, G1 may switch to VBD encoding on the detection of CI/XCI. If G1 did not switch to VBD on CI/XCI, G2 will initiate a switch to VBD encoding upon detection of a PTP signal that it does not support in text relay mode. The session will stay in VBD mode. Note G1 will not initiate a transition to text relay mode upon detection of the PTP signal from T1 since it knows that G2 does not support this modulation.
Standard: V.151
output: When G1 detects CI/XCI signals, it may switch to VBD encoding. If G1 does not switch to VBD encoding upon detecting CI/XCI, G2 will initiate a switch to VBD encoding upon detecting a PTP signal that it does not support in text relay mode. The session will remain in VBD mode. G1 will not transition to text relay mode upon detecting the PTP signal from T1 because it recognizes that G2 does not support this modulation.

instruction: What determines whether text relay or VBD signals are used in a communication scenario between FDX PTP and HDX PTP devices?
input:
Source: Text relayed signals VBD signals NOTE Text relay is only used if T2 is included in the modulations supported by G1. Use VBD if T2 is not included in G1's modulations.
Standard: V.151
output: The use of text relay or VBD signals is determined by whether the gateway (G1) supporting the FDX PTP device's modulation (T1) also supports the HDX PTP device's modulation (T2). If G1 supports T2's modulation, text relay is used. If G1 does not support T2's modulation, VBD signals are initiated.

instruction: What happens when two gateways do not support the modulation of their local PTP devices and one is FDX based while the other is HDX based?
input:
Source: In these scenarios, either or both of the gateways does not support the modulation of its local PTP device. Both PTP devices are not V.18 PTP devices, and one is FDX based while the other is HDX based. No successful connection will be achieved, although the channel may be transitioned to VBD mode since the gateway should detect either of the PTP signals.
Standard: V.151
output: No successful connection will be achieved between the two gateways if they do not support the modulation of their local PTP devices, with one being FDX based and the other HDX based. Although the channel may transition to VBD mode upon detection of either PTP signal, the incompatibility between the devices prevents a successful connection.

instruction: What is the recommended buffer size for a gateway handling text transmission between different speed endpoints?
input:
Source: A general rule is that a user will not create continuous output for more than one minute before expecting a response or making a pause. However, if input is by means of voice-to-text technologies at the maximum character rate of 30 characters per second, that means there is an input of 1800 characters. If the output is to the slowest possible text telephone, the US Baudot method, performing 6 characters per second, the buffer will build up 1800 – 360 = 1440 characters. This calculation leads to a general indication that a gateway buffer of 2 kbytes should be sufficient.
Standard: V.151
output: A gateway buffer of 2 kbytes is recommended to handle text transmission between endpoints with different speeds. This size accounts for scenarios where input might be at a maximum character rate of 30 characters per second (e.g., voice-to-text technologies) and output to the slowest text telephone method (e.g., US Baudot at 6 characters per second), potentially building up a difference of 1440 characters.

instruction: What is the purpose of a Frequency Shift Keyed Modem in telecommunications?
input:
Source: ANSI/TIA-825-A-2003, A Frequency Shift Keyed Modem for Use on the Public Switched Telephone Network
Standard: V.151
output: A Frequency Shift Keyed (FSK) Modem is used to transmit digital data over the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) by shifting the carrier frequency between two distinct frequencies to represent binary data. This modulation technique is commonly employed for low-speed data communications, such as text telephony and basic data transfer applications.

instruction: What are the frequency specifications for binary 1 and binary 0 in 5-bit mode text telephone operation?
input:
Source: The modulation is frequency shift-keyed modulation (i.e. no carrier is present when a character is not being transmitted) using 1400 Hz ( ±5%) for a binary 1 and 1800 Hz ( ±5%) for a binary 0.
Standard: V.18
output: In 5-bit mode text telephone operation, binary 1 is represented by 1400 Hz (±5%) and binary 0 is represented by 1800 Hz (±5%).

instruction: What is the carrier frequency specified for modems?
input:
Source: 2.1 Carrier frequency
Standard: V.32
output: The carrier frequency for V.32 modems is typically 1800 Hz, which is used for modulation and demodulation processes in these devices.

instruction: What are the principal characteristics of modems operating at data signalling rates of up to 9600 bit/s on general switched telephone networks and leased telephone-type circuits?
input:
Source: The principal characteristics of the modems are as follows: a) Duplex mode of operation on GSTN and 2-wire point-to-point leased circuits (see Note 2).b) Channel separation by echo cancellation techniques.c) Quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 2400 bauds.d) Any combination of the following data signalling rates may be implemented in the modems: 9600 bit/s synchronous (optional),4800 bit/s synchronous (mandatory),2400 bit/s synchronous (for further study). e) At 9600 bit/s, two alternative modulation schemes, one using 16 carrier states and one using trellis coding with 32 carrier states, are provided for in this Recommendation. However, modems providing the9600 bit/s data signalling rate shall be capable of interworking using the 16-state alternative. f) Exchange of rate sequences during start-up to establish the data rate, coding and any other special facilities. g) Optional provision of an asynchronous mode of operation in accordance with Recommendations V.14 or V.42.
Standard: V.32
output: The principal characteristics include: a) Duplex mode of operation on general switched telephone networks (GSTNs) and 2-wire point-to-point leased circuits, with channel separation by echo cancellation techniques. b) Use of quadrature amplitude modulation for each channel with synchronous line transmission at 2400 bauds. c) Support for data signalling rates of 9600 bit/s synchronous (optional), 4800 bit/s synchronous (mandatory), and 2400 bit/s synchronous (for further study). d) At 9600 bit/s, two alternative modulation schemes are provided: one using 16 carrier states and another using trellis coding with 32 carrier states, with mandatory interworking capability using the 16-state alternative. e) Exchange of rate sequences during start-up to establish the data rate, coding, and any special facilities. f) Optional provision of an asynchronous mode of operation.

instruction: What are the attenuation requirements for transmitted energy density at 600 Hz and 3000 Hz in a communication system?
input:
Source: The transmitted power level must conform to Recommendation V.2. With continuous binary ones applied to the input of the scrambler, the transmitted energy density at 600 Hz and 3000 Hz should be attenuated 4.5 ± 2.5 dB with respect to the maximum energy density between 600 Hz and 3000 Hz.
Standard: V.32
output: The transmitted energy density at 600 Hz and 3000 Hz should be attenuated 4.5 ± 2.5 dB with respect to the maximum energy density between these frequencies.

instruction: What is the process for encoding a 4-bit data group in trellis coding for transmission?
input:
Source: The scrambled data stream to be transmitted is divided into groups of 4 consecutive data bits. As shown in Figure 2, the first two bits in time Q1 n and Q2 n in each group, where the subscript n designates the sequence number of the group, are first differentially encoded into Y1 n and Y2 n according to Table 2. The two differentially encoded bits Y1 n and Y2 n are used as input to a systematic convolutional encoder which generates a redundant bit Y0 n. This redundant bit and the 4 information-carrying bits Y1 n, Y2n, Q3n and Q4 n are then mapped into the coordinates of the signal element to be transmitted according to the signal space diagram shown in Figure 3 and as listed in Table 3.
Standard: V.32
output: In trellis coding, a 4-bit data group is processed by first differentially encoding the first two bits (Q1n and Q2n) into Y1n and Y2n using a specific encoding table. These encoded bits are then input into a systematic convolutional encoder to generate a redundant bit Y0n. The redundant bit along with the original 4 bits (Y1n, Y2n, Q3n, and Q4n) are mapped into the coordinates of the signal element to be transmitted, according to a predefined signal space diagram and mapping table.

instruction: What is the function of circuit 115 in modem operations?
input:
Source: The modems shall pass synchronous data to the DTE on circuit 104 under the control of circuit 115. Clocks shall be included in the modems to provide the DTE with transmitter signal element timing on circuit 114 and receiver signal element timing on circuit 115.
Standard: V.32
output: Circuit 115 controls the synchronous data transfer from the modem to the DTE (Data Terminal Equipment) and provides receiver signal element timing to the DTE.

instruction: What is the maximum allowable time delay for circuit 106 to follow the state of circuit 105 after start-up and retrain sequences?
input:
Source: After the start-up and retrain sequences, circuit 106 must follow the state of circuit 105 within 2 ms.
Standard: V.32
output: The maximum allowable time delay for circuit 106 to follow the state of circuit 105 after start-up and retrain sequences is 2 milliseconds.

instruction: What are the generating polynomials for the scrambler in call mode and answer mode modems?
input:
Source: Call mode modem generating polynomial: (GPC) = 1 + x^-18 + x^-23; or Answer mode modem generating polynomial: (GPA) = 1 + x^-5 + x^-23
Standard: V.32
output: The generating polynomial for the scrambler in call mode modems is 1 + x^-18 + x^-23. For answer mode modems, the generating polynomial is 1 + x^-5 + x^-23.

instruction: What are the signal-state mappings for 9600 bit/s nonredundant coding and trellis coding?
output: For 9600 bit/s nonredundant coding, the signal-state mappings include combinations of Y0, Y1, Y2, Q3, and Q4 with corresponding Re and Im values. For example, input 00000 maps to Re=-1, Im=-1, and input 0001 maps to Re=-3, Im=-1. For trellis coding, the mappings are similar but include additional combinations such as input 10000 mapping to Re=-3, Im=-2, and input 0001 mapping to Re=-1, Im=-2. The exact mappings are detailed in a table format with specific Re and Im values for each coded input.

instruction: What are the scrambler and descrambler polynomial allocations for modems in call mode and answer mode on the general switched telephone network?
input:
Source: On the general switched telephone network, the modem at the calling data station (call mode) shall use the scrambler with the GPC generating polynomial and the descrambler with the GPA generating polynomial. The modem at the answering data station (answer mode) shall use the scrambler with the GPA generating polynomial and the descrambler with the GPC generating polynomial.
Standard: V.32
output: On the general switched telephone network, the modem in call mode uses the scrambler with the GPC generating polynomial and the descrambler with the GPA generating polynomial. Conversely, the modem in answer mode uses the scrambler with the GPA generating polynomial and the descrambler with the GPC generating polynomial.

instruction: What are the components of the receiver conditioning signal used in start-up and retrain procedures?
input:
Source: The receiver conditioning signal shall be used in the start-up and retrain procedures defined in 5.4 and 5.5. The signal consists of three segments: 5.2.1 Segment 1, denoted by S in Figures 4 and 5, consists of alternations between states A and B as shown in Figure 1, for a duration of 256 symbol intervals. 5.2.2 Segment 2, denoted by S in Figures 4 and 5, consists of alternations between states C and D as shown in Figure 1, for a duration of 16 symbol intervals. The transition from segment 1 to segment 2 provides a well-defined event in the signal that may be used for generating a time reference in the receiver. 5.2.3 Segment 3, denoted by TRN in Figures 4 and 5, is a sequence derived by scrambling binary ones at a data rate of 4800 bit/s with the scrambler defined in 4. During the transmission of this segment, the differential quadrant encoding shall be disabled. The initial state of the scrambler shall be all zeros, and a binary one applied to the input for the duration of segment 3. Successive dibits are encoded onto transmitted signal states. The first 256 transmitted signal states are determined from the state of the first bit occurring (in time) in each dibit. When this bit is ZERO, signal state A is transmitted; when this bit is ONE, signal state C is transmitted. Immediately after 256 such symbols, successive scrambled dibits are encoded onto transmitted signal states in accordance with Table 5 directly without differential encoding for the remainder of segment 3. The duration of segment 3 shall be at least 1280 and not exceed 8192 symbol intervals. Segment 3 is intended for training the adaptive equalizer in the receiving modem and the echo canceller in the transmitting modem.
Standard: V.32
output: The receiver conditioning signal consists of three segments. Segment 1 (denoted by S) involves alternations between states A and B for 256 symbol intervals. Segment 2 (also denoted by S) involves alternations between states C and D for 16 symbol intervals, providing a well-defined event for generating a time reference in the receiver. Segment 3 (denoted by TRN) is a sequence derived by scrambling binary ones at 4800 bit/s with a scrambler, with the initial state of the scrambler being all zeros. During Segment 3, the differential quadrant encoding is disabled, and the first 256 transmitted signal states are determined by the state of the first bit in each dibit. The duration of Segment 3 is at least 1280 and does not exceed 8192 symbol intervals, intended for training the adaptive equalizer and echo canceller.

instruction: What is the structure of the rate signal in a modem?
input:
Source: The rate signal consists of a whole number of repeated 16-bit binary sequences, as defined in Table 6, scrambled and transmitted at 4800 bit/s with dibits differentially encoded as in Table 1. The differential encoder shall be initialized using the final symbol of the transmitted TRN segment. The first two bits and each successive dibit of the rate sequence shall be encoded to form the transmitted signal states.
Standard: V.32
output: The rate signal in a V.32 modem consists of a whole number of repeated 16-bit binary sequences. These sequences are scrambled and transmitted at 4800 bit/s, with dibits differentially encoded. The differential encoder is initialized using the final symbol of the transmitted TRN segment. The first two bits and each successive dibit of the rate sequence are encoded to form the transmitted signal states.

instruction: What are the signal states used in modems for an even number of symbol intervals?
input:
Source: Signal states ACAC..AC for an even number of symbol intervals T; similarly with CA, AA and CC.
Standard: V.32
output: The signal states used in V.32 modems for an even number of symbol intervals are ACAC..AC, CACA..CA, AAAA..AA, and CCCC..CC. These states are alternated or repeated for the duration of the symbol intervals to facilitate communication between modems.

instruction: What do bits B4, B5, and B6 indicate in a 16-bit rate sequence?
input:
Source: B4 1 denotes ability to receive data at 2400 bit/s (see Note 1)
B5 1 denotes ability to receive data at 4800 bit/s
B6 1 denotes ability to receive data at 9600 bit/s
B4-6 0 0 0 calls for a GSTN cleardown
Standard: V.32
output: In a 16-bit rate sequence, bit B4 set to 1 indicates the ability to receive data at 2400 bit/s, bit B5 set to 1 denotes the ability to receive data at 4800 bit/s, and bit B6 set to 1 signifies the ability to receive data at 9600 bit/s. A combination of B4, B5, and B6 all set to 0 calls for a GSTN cleardown.

instruction: What are the key steps in the start-up procedure for achieving synchronism between calling and answering modems on international GSTN connections?
input:
Source: The procedure for achieving synchronism between the calling modem and the answering modem on international GSTN connections is shown in Figure 4. The procedure includes the estimating of round-trip delay from each modem, thetraining of echo cancellers and receivers initially with half-duplex transmissions, and the exchanging of rate signals forautomatic bit-rate and mode selection.
Standard: V.32
output: The start-up procedure involves several key steps: estimating round-trip delay from each modem, training echo cancellers and receivers initially with half-duplex transmissions, and exchanging rate signals for automatic bit-rate and mode selection. The modem repetitively transmits carrier state A, detects incoming tones at frequencies 600 ± 7 Hz and 3000 ± 7 Hz, and then detects phase reversals in these tones. Upon detecting phase reversals, the modem changes its transmission state, starts a counter/timer, and eventually stops transmitting upon detecting a second phase reversal. It then proceeds to train its receiver, detects rate sequences, and transmits sequences and signals to finalize the connection setup, including adjusting for echo cancellation and indicating available data rates and operational modes.

instruction: What actions should a modem take upon detecting an incoming 16-bit E sequence?
input:
Source: On detecting an incoming 16-bit E sequence as defined in 5.3.2, the modem shall condition itself to receive data at the rate and with the coding indicated by the incoming E sequence. After a delay of 128 symbol intervals, it shall apply anON condition to circuit 109, and unclamp circuit 104. The modem shall then enable circuit 106 to respond to the condition of circuit 105 and be ready to transmit data.
Standard: V.32
output: Upon detecting an incoming 16-bit E sequence, the modem should condition itself to receive data at the rate and with the coding indicated by the E sequence. After a delay of 128 symbol intervals, it should apply an ON condition to circuit 109, unclamp circuit 104, enable circuit 106 to respond to the condition of circuit 105, and be ready to transmit data.

instruction: What are the frequency tolerances for detecting incoming tones in a modem start-up sequence?
input:
Source: Once an incoming tone is detected at 600 ± 7 Hz or 3000 ± 7 Hz, the calling modem should proceed with the start-up sequence even if no 2100 Hz tone has been detected.
Standard: V.32
